First, something topical, just to clear the proverbial phlegm from our
collective throats -- http://www.tcp.com/%7Eprime8/Orbit/mission.html

http://www.thespot.com/ or as I like to call it "my bush in the life of ghosts."

------- Forwarded Message (recycle, maaan!)

So I was surfing through http://www.tcp.com/%7Eprime8/Orbit/index.html
(cool 'zine) and found a pointer to http://www.thespot.com/ (Melrose-Place
meets Baywatch meets Real World meets Geeks/Internet) which was listed
under orbit's "disturbing web sites (URLs to make you hurl)" link...

So who are the people behind this? Hollywood? TV? Ad Agency? And why?  Is
there money to be made in creating these interactive sites?? How much?

Geoff White -- do you know what the deal is -- looks like they're hooked
through Silicon Reef, which in turn is hooked up via Internex. ... Got any
inside info? Anyone?

                               DISTURBING WWW SITES




                                                  The Spot
                                      http://www.thespot.com 

                     From prime8 
                     Date: Sun, 25 Jun 1995 14:33:39 -0700
                     From: Patrick Farley (prime8)
                     To: MichalcM@xxxxx.edu
                     Subject: The Spot

                     Hi again Mike,

Here's something else to disturb you and waste your time: a new site on the
WWW called The Spot. It's a cross between a geek house and MTV's "The Real
World", or perhaps more ap propriately The Resort filtered through "Melrose
Place". The supposed premise of this site is that a quintet of gorgeous
Malibu brats conned somebody into buying them a huge seaside house, a
domain name and a 500-trillion-gigabyte server, as well as hiring an army
of professional HTML geeks, graphic designers, photographers and UNIX
support team to project their collective ego into cyberspace. My hacker
friends here have been tracing the source of this website and have
discovered that it is a huge advertising venture. While I have nothing
against commercialism on the Web (that's how I'm feeding myself, after all)
this site is creepily Phildickian in its blurring of the authentic and the
contrived.

What really disturbs me about "the Spot" is this: even though I consciously
realize that the women presented are (probably) just actresses playing
parts, and that their journal entries are (probably) written by teams of
non-union Hollywood screenwriters, and their photographs are (probably)
completely posed, and this entire project is (almost certainly) an enormous
marketing weapon aimed directly at me and my demographic, I can still get
off on the voyeuristic thrill of looking into these women's "private
lives". It functions much like pornography; the fact that you know it's all
contrived and calculated does not diminish its potency to the erotic
imagination.

This in itself wouldn't be so disturbing if the residents/characters of
"the Spot" didn't spend so much time trying to convince the audience that
they are in fact real people.

It also feels a little bit like a hostile colonization of cyberspace. Those
of u s who've homesteaded the web with our crappy, quirky little sites are
now having the ground bought out from under us by Big Money, and the sound
of bulldozers is not far off. Maybe I'm wrong about this. I sure hope so.

     yours, 
     patrick 

Read some of my friend's responses here.


                                 The Spot's Carrie: brainy bohemian
                                 dream girl or cynical media puppet?
                                                         


My friends and I had this conversation on ICB on 6/22/95 7:15 p.m., pasted
here verbatim:


<Davinator> "thespot" is a sham perpetrated by an ad agency which will
<Davinator> soon be selling product placements
<Goddess> I called the ad agency
<Goddess> fattal and collins
<caliban> ew
<prime8> oh really?
<caliban> why?
<maniac> excellent.  now we know.
<Davinator> what did they say heather?
<prime8> that's even more loathesome than I previously thought
<Goddess> I called to make sure it was really an ad agency
<Goddess> and then sean called
<caliban> Net revenues$115,042$97,197$337,027$289,699
<Goddess> and said he was from the sentinel and got even more info
<maniac> we should get the gay and lesbian groups to yell at the ad
<maniac> agency for that idiocy where one of the characters called the
<maniac> other lesbian.
<prime8> fuck yeah
<tapeworm> wow what is this ad?
<prime8> thespot.com on www
<Goddess> it's not an ad yet
<tapeworm> ok sure thespot.com on www but what IS it?
<maniac> it's a cross between a geek house and mtv's "The Real World"
<maniac> in appearance.
<Goddess> they are going to phase in promotional spots
<Goddess> it's a "serial" about life in a melrose place geek house
<tapeworm> oh my
<Goddess> it's REALLY lame
<Goddess> nice graphics.
<Goddess> obviously professional
<tapeworm> where does it take place?
<Goddess> down south
<caliban> geek house
<caliban> no geeks look like that.
<Goddess> nope
<caliban> no geeks have asses like that or washboard stomachs like that
<Goddess> nor do geeks with such nice bandwidth have such lame jobs and
<Goddess> no education :)
<prime8> hey, is it okay if i cut and paste this conversation directly onto their message
 board?
<maniac> go look when you get a chance.  it's amusing in a disgusting
<maniac> way.
<caliban> patrick: yes
<caliban> please do

So I pasted the above conversation onto The Spot's Message Board. It was
there for a few days before somebody there was smart enough to remove it.

                                                        
                                 In this movie, The Spot's Tara gives
                                indisputable proof that she is, in fact,
                                             real. 


I spoke with Tara, Carrie and Michelle live on IRC channel #spot on July 6,
1995. I asked all the pointed questions: who is paying for the Spot, why do
you pretend to be real people, are you going to take mushrooms and if so
are you going to write that in your journals, etc. Tara's response to these
questions were such sophistries as "How do we know anything's real?" and
"What's the point of anything?" The other people logged on the channel were
telling me to lighten up. "Of course it's not real -- it's an interactive
fantasy, so just enjoy it." etc. I began to feel they were right.  After
all, I did on many occasions frequent Bianca's Smut Shack, an elaborate
interactive fantasy featuring a fictitious figurehead known as Bianca. So
what the hell? Why not flow with the Spot?

Later that day I received the following letter from Tara: 



Date: Thu, 6 Jul 1995 21:47:14 -0700
X-Sender: thespot@mailhost.primenet.com (Unverified)
To: prime8@resort.com
From: tara@thespot.com (Tara Hartwick)
Subject: The Spot     http://www.thespot.com

        Patrick-

Thanks for your mail.  FYI- I am all woman and the opinions expressed are
my own.  

{Insert -- This in response to my question, "Are you real 
or are you a character created by a team of writers?"}

However, I do realize I was jumping the gun by calling my
professor a pussy.  I believe in equality for all people- I was just
venting during a particularly stressful moment before.  Lets be kind to
each other.
        
                Tara

*sigh* 



Why be angry?

Another post that was wiped off the Spot's message board was this brilliant
rant by bc@wetware.com.  God bless him!



Sat, 17 Jun 1995 22:53:50 GMT 
Why am I angry at The Spot? 

Because I find it so poorly written as to be insulting to my
intelligence.

Because I find the fact that it is a marketing "warning shot" aimed 
square across my bow to be insulting.

And because, like many of the people on the Internet, I was the 
unpopular kid all my life. Now the place where I *am* popular is 
being invaded by the Prom Queens and Junior Marlon Brandos, saying
"Oh by the way, WE'RE the cool people again. We would snub you
in real life, but we're gonna be nice, JUST THIS ONCE, and let you
peer over our shoulders at how WE, the COOL people, live in real life."

Details:

What the Spot claims it is and what it actually is are so 
discordant as to be nauseating. 

It never comes out and says it's real people who write their own 
material, but the creators try as hard as possible to make it sound 
that way. Hey, I don't *mind* fiction, but drop the pretense. 
You're not fooling anyone.

Second, the Spot tries really hard to be realistic, but that's 
so badly done as to be laughable:

1) If these people are all waitresses and aspiring actors, 
why is this site so riddled with slickness? Every single page 
has a different "cool" background gif pattern. All the photos 
are beautifully scanned. Every "member" of the collective has 
their own *logo.*

Here's a solution: Show the "creators" and say, "Hey, we got these
people to live in this house and check out this freaky cyberspace
thing. We've got a trained staff to turn their mewling into web 
pages because, well, we wanted them to look really cool." No shame 
that!

2) They're all poor, yet not one of them has ever been fat in their
lives. Nevermind ethnic mix or any of that stuff! Guess being 
unemployed gives you more time to do your nails or burn up those abs.
Oh yeah, in LA they SHOOT ugly people. I forgot.

3) They are all stereotypes. The stereotypes presented are mean. 
They hurt people. Bimbo characters delude people into thinking that 
the world is full of bimbos. It's not. The world is full of fat
people who are sad a lot of the time, who eat fried chicken 
in their underwear, and work because they have to. You guys claim
realism, yet your world has no room for fat people, smart people,
or uncool people. Most of the romance novels I've read were LESS
stereotyped, and much better written, than your stuff.

5) The characters are totally inconsistent. Here's a woman showing 
a picture of herself in a babydoll nightie and saying, *right next 
to it*, "There's no space for rent between my legs." Right. Does
this woman have an IQ below the freezing point of ice?

6) The characters come off totally wooden. It's patently obvious the
writers have never ever been to Short Stories 101. Clue: the first thing
they write on the board is "Show, don't tell." Translation: if the
character wants to communicate deepness, they do it with deep actions,
not by saying "I'm so deep, man."

Why am I angry? Because I know what "real life" is. This "Spot" 
project tries to tell me that it is real life, or at least realistic, 
and not only fails to do so, but insults me as well.

It asks me to believe in these terribly written, patently fake 
characters. It even asks me to write to them. 

That insults my intelligence.

It says, "hey, LA is full of beautiful white young people who don't
know anything about "cyberspace" but create logo-rife web pages of
their real lives." Nobody I know has a $50,000 plastic-injected chest.
Giant breasts don't come with wasp-waists in my world. I know people
who are in fantastic shape. But since they work for a living, they 
don't have corded abdominal muscles like your actors.

That insults my lifestyle. 

Someone told me this Spot was being done by an ad agency. Well, it
sure isn't hitting ME, the apparent target market. (And I am a single
white male, 32, making in excess of $60,000 per year.)

It doesn't make me envious. It doesn't make me wanna buy perfume or
a car. I make my own perfume, and keep my 1963 Corvair convertible
in racing tune.

This is the Internet. People are smart here. They don't sell
like the rest of the populace. You have to have good content to
sell them. You have to have believable characters. You have to
avoid stereotypes, because people here, if they see a stereotype,
they get angry.

And most of all, you can't go around with a "we're cooler than you"
attitude. People on the net have a chip on their collective shoulder
about that. It's roughly the size of the Moon.

Wanna see a good "real people living in a beach house" web page?
Go load The Armory
                                              
- --------------------
Most telling clue that the Spot is probably fake:

One of the journal entries is written by a dog.

Silicon Reef is a "WebDesign" firm, they have apparently co-located a server
over at InterNex.  When I was last over there, the sales guys at InterNex were
churtling over this site, needless to say I was not impressed. (Makes me glad
I don't work there anymore :)

The angle is to get a bunch of hits and them mostlikely sell advertising, but
think about it for a minute...

 A reminder for tomorrow's "SFRaves South Bay Lunch".

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Wednesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

On Mon, 31 Jul 1995, Andrew wrote:

> 
> The book is quite short, but a deep provacative read. This puts words to
> thoughts and feelings sensed in altered states as well as gives a vivid
> description of a mescaline trip for the unexperienced. If you have the
> patience, Huxley's brilliant command of the language, though with near
> excessive sentences, may give you some clear images for the illumination
> that fades too fast.

  Very true. Huxley comes as close as possible to putting words to the 
ineffable. However, his mescalin experiences were those of a solitary 
intellectual. He sees and reflects -- but his interaction with people, as 
described in the *Doors*, is near zero.
  It would be a service to the rave community if someone could write a 
"Doors of Perception* with an eye to how feelings of belonging or harmony 
with a group are heightened (if they are) by enhanced consciousness.

On Tue, 1 Aug 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> I think it's brilliant, actually.

>Quoth Bongo25@aol.com
>Greetings to all,
>  I've been trying to download some of the lovely Stuff provided for all of
>us from Hyperreal (trippy visuals), Unfortunately all of the ones I've tried
>are compressed with 'Compact Pro' and I have 'Stuffit Lite'. Are any of the
>downloads provided commpressed with 'Stuffit', or am I being an idiot &
>overlooking something?

I'm using the freeware version of Stuffit Expander and it has no problem
unstuffing Compact Pro archives. I just tried unstuffing an old Compact Pro
file to make sure. I just dragged it over and dropped it on the stuffit
icon. (MacOS 7.5.1 not sure how Windoze users do it.) Perhaps you just need
to download a different verson of stuffit. I don't remeber where I got my
copy. It was either AOL (I only used the 10 free hours, I swear) or BMUG.
Good luck there's lots of wicked cool suff on Hyperreal. If you get stuck
and are running MacOS let me know and I'll put a copy on a floppy and bring
it to Sunset.

Precedence: bulk

Before the rumor mill goes out of control on this, let me say that I talked
with both Dub Tribe and Donovan (separately, so it adds even more credence
to the story) about what happened in Santa Cruz.  Basically, the promoter
was a scam artist.  He led Dub Tribe on for weeks about getting a site,
then when they arrived Saturday evening it turned out to be on the beach
at Davenport.  Ex Why Zee already demonstrated in no uncertain terms why
it is stupid to put on a $20 event on a public beach, but apparently you
can get away with a lot of stupidity if you're a promoter in Santa Cruz.

Of course, as soon as they arrived, so did the cops, who chased them away.
Tiring of all this, Dub Tribe suggested that everyone get their money back
from the promoter.  The promoter apparently said something to the effect
that people should get their money from Dub Tribe (who did not get paid).
As reported here previously, some people finally did get their money back
but only after an extended wait.  

I've also heard the record store that was selling tickets continued to
do so past 1 am even though they knew no final location had been found.

I thought we had left this kind of promoter idiocy behind on the west
coast, but it seems that was my mistake . . .

phred

I thought I would forward this to ya'll..

**Send all comments to: RecordTime@aol.com**


The Techno Report
Compiled by
Mike Huckaby (RECORD TIME)

        First of all, I'd like to thank everyone for the enormous response to my
charts and columns.  The response has been sogreat that I have decided to do
charts and columns every week instead of biweekly.

        Here are a few bits and pieces in the world of techno for this
week.  We are currently completely sold out of Muzik, the new underground
magazine from the UK, I mentioned last time.  You don't want to miss the
next issue for
anything!  The next issue promises to have an R&S Records cassette tape of
unreleased material attached to it!  Tracks from Carl Craig, Ken Ishill,
Kenny Larkin, and Juan Atkins will be included.  And previously released
stuff from DJ Hell and Joey Beltram, just to name a few.  And of course it
will be available at Record Time.

Hot News Flash - Just In!

        Dave Clarke, the man himself has just phoned be up to let me know
that a few
white labels of Red 3 have been pressed up, and that a copy it is on its way
to me.  I'm anxious to hear it again myself.  I only heard it onece in March
when we spun together at a party in England.  I'll do a full review of it whe
I recieve this copy.

        Other News in the making:  The Goodmen will no longer be recording
for Fresh Fruit out of Holland.  Another Holland based label is said to be
responsible for the Goodmen now.  Also look out for a new Jack Prongo 12
inch from Holland as well.

        Zach Roberts of Indx Records from Detroit releases a new single called
Halogen Forthcoming releases from Touch'e Records

        I've managed to track down a bit more information about the releases on
Touch'e Records this summer.  It seems that the very next release on Touch'e
will be a track called "PaRelax" by Amfibian, followed by a Felix Da House
Cat releas.  Tracks on Felix's release include "The Chaos Engine and "Citzen
Bishop".  The third and final release I have info on will be a 12 inch by
Loophole.  The titles will be named "LoopHole", "Antoinette", and "Time
Clock".

Miscellaneous Release Notes

        Air Liquide is releasing a ton of material right now.  They have a
current 12 inch out called "Live in New York", and will have a double 12
inch out soon called "Stoboplastics".  The DJungle Fever crew releases on
acid
tweeking 7 inch by Bizz OD.  The track is called "Little Funky Jazz Piano".
 Ian Poole releases remixs of his "Celtic Cross" 12 inch.  The of the tracks
is a remix by DJ Sneak.

          Christian Vogel releases a Double 12 inch on Tresor through Mosquito
Records called Absoute Time.  There are mabye two tracks on it worth checking
out.  Reload Records out of Belgium releases another Techno pounder entitled
Subjective Duality.  And Finally, look out for Techno Nations Volume 4,
available on CD & LP from Cheap Records.  Good Techno stuff is included.
 Material is provided by Luke Slater, Tim Taylor, Bandulu, Damon Wild, &
Patrick Pulsinger.

Thats all for Now
See Ya!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug  1 13:03:48 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA22587; Tue, 1 Aug 1995 13:03:48 -0700
Received: from rocky.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA22582; Tue, 1 Aug 1995 13:03:45 -0700
Received: by rocky.ucdavis.edu (8.6.12/UCD3.4)
	id NAA25080; Tue, 1 Aug 1995 13:03:36 -0700
Date: Tue, 1 Aug 1995 13:03:34 -0700 (PDT)
From: Marc Pfister <mjpfister@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez045207@rocky
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Santa Cruz & Wack Promoters
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950801123918.19661A-100000@rocky>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Man, what's going on with all the promoters and Santa Cruz lately? First 
Ex Why Zee loses their location at the Civic Auditorium and tries to 
throw their party at Bonny Dune, using Bass the whole time. Dumb.
Then the whole Dubtribe debacle. I don't know any more than was just 
mentioned here. Again, some shysters tried to charge money to throw a 
party on a 100% bust-likely beach. Sheer Idiocy.
And remember Catastrophic Planet? Well, I mean do you remeber the flyers, 
since the party never happened? Our friends at Ex Why Zee once again lost 
their location and the Civic Auditorium. This time they only left a 
message on one of their voicemails about someone being seriously ill 
forcing the cancellation of the party. Yeah right. A certain LA dj who 
was slated to play didn't find out that the party was cancelled until 5 
pm Fri night, I'm not sure if he had already driven up to Santa Cruz. He 
later did a little snooping and found out that the Civic Auditorium had 
ceased negotiating with Ex Why Zee a month ago! He also found out that 
Bass had stopped selling a week ago too. Both are extremely ironic 
considering that Thousands of beautiful 5x7 Catastrophic flyers were 
being passed out at last week's Funky Techno Tribe. Now perhaps it was a 
mistake and those flyers weren't supposed to be passed out, but things 
certainly are suspicious....
So all I can say is caveat emptor, buyer beware! Read the fine print at 
the bottom of those flyers. If you see the last three letters of the 
alphabet, you might want to think twice. If someone is throwing a party 
that sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Right now everybody and 
thier cousin bob is trying to be a promoter. Those who start small and 
humble will go far. Those who try to start by throwing all-star mega-rave 
spectacula-ramas will find themselves in the position of Prometheus. So 
if you choose to fly with them, you might get burned...

marc

Sunday night.

Dubtribe at Minna St was nice.  I like the little gallery
there.  It was free.  Fairly well ventilated.  A little mental 
with some housey propoganda.  Shirtless bald guys on PCP were
funny while I was there.  I heard violence in paradise sent
acid trippers running into the alley with their faces
contorted in horror.  The sound system was loud.

I think alot of folks got pretty high - there's maybe some
good drugs in town.  More than a few were commenting "this e ain't
all pahty pahty pahty ..."  Which I interpret as one too many
"a little much" style moments.

Dubtribe was kinda Rock n Roll.  They were ok.  
Headbanging is sooo ... violent looking.

I really wanted to hear Doc Martin.  But I left 
before he came on.

Dave




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Aug  1 14:54:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA29041; Tue, 1 Aug 1995 14:54:51 -0700

Date: 1 Aug 1995 13:16:00 -0800
From: "Mark Camp" <mark_camp@qmmac.emu.com>
Subject: Re: DubTribe in Santa Cruz?
To: "Larry Ching" <larryc@netcom.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP/QM 3.0.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   RE>DubTribe in Santa Cruz?

Dubtribe didnt happen.  I live just around the corner from Urban Oulet, the
store that was selling tickets.  The number said "$15 or $20 for two, so bring
a friend and it will only be 10 bucks each".  So my roomate and I walked down
to the store at around 9pm.  The lady selling the tickets said that the 20 for
2 deal was only till 8.  The message on the number said nothing about a time
limit for tickets.  So we talked her into giving us tickets for $25.   After
buying the tickets we asked for directions and no one would give them to us. 
Everyone working at the store told us to ask someone else for directions. 
After 10 minutes or so we gave up and walked back home to meet up with some
friends.   

At around 11pm we found out the party had been busted.  The original spot was
accross from the cement factory in Davenport just past Bonny Doon.  They
decided to move it to a place called the Eucaliptis Grove.   Its about 27
miles north on Santa Cruz and it is VERY private propery.  My roommate threw a
party there last summer that got broken up in less than an hour.   But, we
decided to go anyway.  About half way there we saw the rider truck and a line
of 20 or so cars going the oposit direction.  So we figured it got
busted.....again......so we turned around and headed back to town.  

On our way back we spotted a line of cars going up a road on the mountain side
of hiway 1.  So we started following them.  We went up this road about a mile
or so and the caravan stopped.  Seems they were lost, couldnt find the
Eucaliptis Grove.   We knew exactly where it was so we told everyone to follow
us.  

It was quite wierd to be showing the people throwing the party where their
party was...........  

The entrance to the Grove is this little drive way with a big fence and a
lock.  Someone managed to .......find the combination to the lock and the gate
was opened and all the cars drove in and found a place to park (by now there
were about 30-40 cars. 

Apparently, as soon as the driver of the Rider truck found out it was private
property they decided they did not want to set up there.  We were the first
ones to leave so I'm not too sure what happend after that but from what I'm
told, Dubtribe went home.  

Meanwhile, back at the Urban Oulet.......

They are refusing to refund any money.  Last I heard we are to hold on to our
tickets as a raincheck for their next party.   Others were told to take
something from the store that is worth $15.   Another friend of mine was
grabbed around the neck and thrown out the door as he asked for his money
back.

-M


--------------------------------------

they really beat some guy up (one womans boss -- was he "in"?).

Frequency 8 would like to thank all of the people who have helped to
make our first 7 events possible - especially those who have helped us
carry the equipment to and from our outside locations, and to those who
have given us a hand driving people from our map points to our trailheads.

This Friday night from 11:30 to 6:00 we ask you to join us in celebrating
our 8th cybertrancendental experience on a beach 45 minutes north of San
Francisco.  DJs will be MARS, MystrE and Cyr.  Map point will be open from
11:30 to 1:30 only.  We are asking for a $4.00 donation - so far this has
been stictly a break/even affair with any extra money going towards the
purchase of a new sound system which we will be using this Friday.

You will definately need a FLASHLIGHT and wearing a pair of sensible shoes
for going down the trail will be a wise move.  Feel free to bring water and
perhaps a stick or two for the bonfire - you may also want a towel to take 
advantage of the nearby hot springs or the ocean.

Please people, remember that this is a renegade party - our last party got
broken up because ONE person drove erratically through the town of Stinson
Beach and when they got pulled over told the Sherriff that he was looking 
for the party on the beach (the sherriff notified the park police (who were
very nice) and that was the only hassle we've had all summer).

We sure could use 5-6 people to help us lug all the heavy equipment - if you
can help, please e-mail me privately.

We do this party because we love the music - and you will not hear an
evening of music like Frequency 8 anywhere else - check us out - smiles
ARE mandatory!!!!
Jim Cyr (surfpunk@well.com)

(edena picks up the phone, ringing pats in)

Edena: oh, hello pats, dahling!
Patsy: hullo dahling...

(patsy stumbles down the stairs bottle in hand, cigarette in other)

Patsy: Edena, dahling... have you heard of this hip new rave thing
       called Fertility Ate? Supposed to be *all* the rage...
Edena: Virility what?
Patsy: Eddie dahling! Listen! You simply cannot go on rotting at home
       with that bitch daughter of yours... you *must* go out more
Edena: dahling! there simply aren't *any* good parties these days....
         I mean the times of renegade raves, you know, *dancing* 'til
         sunrise, Xtasy *pouring* through the veins, feeling twenty
         and fabulous again.... I mean *these* times, dahling, are over....
         arrideverchi, gone! dahling.... Now it's lucky if we're awake
         for a bollocky Sunset.... No, dahling! There are *no* good
         parties anymore... rave is as dead as disco! Joey Beltram shares
         a grave with Donna Summers, dahling! Don't you see?
Patsy: Eddie! Eddie! You *must* get a hold of yourself!
       Dahling! Look. It is stated here... the latest issue of
       !Hola! magazine, dahling: "Rave is Reborn: Fertility Ate is the
       midwife!". This is *it* dahling! The NEW hip event to be seen at!
Edena: I simply *cannot* believe that a party costing little more than
       a bottle of aspirin could be worth driving *hours* to get to...
Patsy: Visuals, dahling! Visuals! look. it says: "great visuals"
       dahling! this is the plan: we'll drop a couple of hits each,
       dance-trance all night friday, we'll miss out saturday,
       but come out *smiling* sunday afternoon.... it's perfect, Eddie:
       just in time for Sunset.
Edena: Oh.... I just don't know.... It all seems so... tiring.
       I mean... must we go on like this, dahling? Dance, dance, dance!
       Wiggle, wiggle , wiggle! I mean, dahling: if I dance anymore, my
       hips will fall off... Is that what you want dahling? An old, 
       toothless, hipless friend?
Saffy: (walking down the stairs) well, Mommy, maybe then you will finally
       fit into you old clothes again.....
Patsy: oh. IT's the BITCH daughter again...
(Edena looks shocked)
Patsy: ignore her, dahling! look! By friday we could be surrounded by
       *mobs* of beautiful underage youths.
Edena: oh.... I just don't know....
Saffy: mommy! don't go!
Patsy: EddiE!!!!!!!!!
       look! it says here: "hot springs nearby"....
Edena: hot springs, dahling?
Patsy: hot springs, dahling! absolutely _fabulous_ *hot springs*!
Edena: oh!... we must go!
Saffy: mommy! you promised! no more parties!
Edena: saffy! dahling! It will be ok.... I'll just wear my new Lacroix
       bathing suit! dahling! It will be fabulous!

Hello.  This is dutch from CDC Soundsystem.  I would like to thank everyone
who believed in us enough to come to our event.  We honestly hope you
enjoyed yourselves and maybe learned something in the process.  We didn't
aim to commercialize ourselves by putting on a huge party.  We attempted to
use a little class and honor in generating the numbers that we did.
Besides an extra ordinary budget (all of which went into killer visuals and
sound, great personnel and djs, and a big UFO),  we did not resort to sex,
violence, or other popular promotional tactics.  We just put cool pictures
and our imagination on our flyer.  As Carlos and I have been highly active
in the SF scene, we really appreciate the people who stood up for our
organization and our honor.  Thank You!

We would also like to thank some others who helped to make this event possible:

 The XogeniX crew, the freaks at Ameba (we love you), Tribal funk,  Econ
graffix, D.J. Long of M.U.F.O.N., Hollywood Dog (maybe you'll get that
lazer show right next time), EAR Sound, Synergy, Opticalux, Tim the
carpenter, the guy who discovered helium, the Balloon Lady, Scooter (even
though you were late), and about 30 more of our friends who will remain
faceless so you don't get bored.

The dj line-up was:

in the main room:

        Tracy of the Ameba gang (10-11:50)

        Tony (11:50-1:40)

        John Williams (1:40-3:30)

        Dutch ,GOD I HAD FUN (3:30-5:15)

        Carlos, with an end I shall never forget (5:15-7:00)

in the XogeniX room (foyer area)

        Sausee

        Timmy Hendrix

        Das                       <SAME TIMES AS ABOVE>

        Simon

        Norplant (Orlando, FL)

in the Ameba-Tribal Funk warp zone

        Andrew, Alan, and Mark in no specific order as usual


The books that were donated were forwarded to the city of Richmond to help
out some very needy youths in the area.  Thank you for the support.

There was about 500 people who took advantage of the $15 discount price for
dressing up as an alien.  THIS IS NOT NORMAL.  The last show only 20 did.
People really went all out.  Excellent costumes I might add.  One poor soul
completely covered himself with a felt tip marker!  I am looking forward to
the next show to see if there will be a full room of aliens.

As far as actual numbers are concerned, there was nearly 3000 people at
Area 51.  Almost 2700 paid between $15 and $25.  Yes, we made a little
bundle of money.  We are not going to lie.  This sum of cash should be just
enough to purchase a new killer sound system to add to the growing list of
renegades in the bay area.  Look for us on the next frontier.  We may take
it on a test drive at Burning Man.  Who knows?

Anyway, we hope that in the future some of you will join us and actually
help us, teach the masses about our beloved way of life.

There are many friends on the road of life.  Its all just a matter of
slowing down a little to pick them up.


Contact has been made...........
CDC Soundsystem

Something Crunch forwarded to me. Is nothing sacred?

>X-Sender: alastair@mail.magna.com.au
>Mime-Version: 1.0
>Date: Sun, 30 Jul 1995 12:08:35 +1000
>To: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
>From: alastair@magna.com.au (Alastair Rankine)
>Subject: And you thought SurfWatch was bad...
>Sender: owner-ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
>Precedence: bulk
>X-UIDL: 807073215.001
>
>Not rave related, but here goes.
>
>>From the latest MacWEEK:
>
>---
>
>Internet rating systems
>
>Taking another approach, Microsoft Corp., Netscape Communications Corp. and
>Progressive Networks Inc. last month formed an alliance called the
>Information Highway Parental Empowerment Group (IHPEG) that plans to
>publish a strategy by year-end that will allow software companies and
>concerned citizens to work together on a technological solution.
>
>"Our goal is to build filtering capabilities into the industry-standard
>Internet access software products ... and to open up a third-party network
>so the industry can create and implement its own ruling systems and methods
>for implementation," said Rob Glaser, president of Seattle-based
>Progressive Networks and chairman of IHPEG.
>
>Glaser said an HTML tagging system may be one aspect of the solution, but
>another may be the creation of multiple rating systems allowing parents to
>choose one that best fits that family's values.
>
>"For example, the [rating] system I want to use for my 5-year-old son may
>be very different than the one someone else chooses for their 15-year-old,"
>Glaser said. He added that he envisions a day when various recognized
>organizations, from the Christian Coalition to the American Civil Liberties
>Union would offer rating systems.
>
>---
>
>Nice to know that the makers of RealAudio, Netscape and EDLIN have our best
>interests at heart. I did a bit more sniffing around and found the press
>release here:
>
><http://www.realaudio.com/contentp/rabest/IHPEG.html>
>
>It seems to me that it's not a big step from _allowing_ some sort of
>ratings system to operate on the web to _requiring_ one. Firstly we get the
>technical "enhancement" to the HTML spec to allow web publishers to
>classify their content according to the usual impossible to understand
>standards. "This web page contains frequest course sex and occasional
>language." The next step is to have browers (Netscape, MSN browser) to
>understand these new tags and restrict viewing of unsuitable material
>(configured and "locked" on a per-browser basis I guess).
>
>Fortunately this whole plan seems to be relatively easy to subvert. In fact
>it would be kinda fun to put an "unsuitable for children" tag on a link to
>some institutionalised religion of some sort.
>
>In a bit of rather shoddy journalism, an article in Canada's Globe & Mail
>newspaper referenced the IHPEG saying that it was a "World Wide Web
>Consortium, which includes technogiants AT&T, Digital Equipment, IBM,
>Microsoft and Sun Microsystems". God knows how these other corporate
>entities got into the act.
>
><http://www.globeandmail.ca/Cyber-14.html>
>
>As Torquemada would say: "Be pure, be vigilant, behave!"
>
>--
>|||| Alastair Rankine | alastair@magna.com.au | Mac C++ Guy | VFR750 ||||
>
>
>

Here is one person's comments on "the spot".  Jack currently works at
InterNex so direct all flames to him (not to me).

As far as I.m concerned I don't believe that the spot should not exist,
I fully believe that it should and people should go to it if that's their
thing.   It's OK if that isn't their thing.  Personally I find the concept
rather neat but the content is sorely lacking appealing mostly to the
"free, white and 21" set (and their wannabes :).  So to this end I 
went ahead and registered TheScene.Com, I don't have the time to build
up this Web Site in any major way but I will provide WebSpace for any
of you entreprenurial ravers out there whould whould like a go, ala
"the real deal".  Any takers can e-mail me a webmaster@v-site.net

I know if I used just half of the "tru stories" that I know, (with the names
changed to protect the guilty :) It could put the shallow lives portrayed
on the spot to shame :)  well if anyone is interested in a project like
this, let me know :)



				G
 


---------- Text of forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 2 Aug 1995 11:45:05 -0700
From: Jack Wang <Jack.Wang@InterNex.Net>
To: Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
Subject: Re: cool web sites // scary view into the TV-ization of the web

The criticisms mounted against thespot.com are as a fine example of cultural
fascism as I have seen lately.  I will not purport myself to be a ardent fan
of "the spot" nor would I consider myself to be a critic; however, to
dismiss its web page as trash and kitsch is to blindly condemn it as
culturally irrelevanct.

One thing that may appear revolutionary to some may similarly appear as
passe' to others.  For instance, some may consider pro-wrestling as a
steroid-ridden, ultra-violent bastardization of sport.  And yet, for others,
pro-wrestling is an entertaining role-play of good vs. evil.  Nevertheless,
pro-wrestling is still a culturally valid arena of sport and entertainment
in our society, and to dismiss it would be committing an act of cultural
censorship.

In the 1930s, Hitler destroyed numerous works of art by European
expressionists, works by Gustav Klimt, Edvard Munch, Egon Schiele, and many
others, all because he thought that this entire genre of artwork was
culturally degnerate.  He exhibited all these artists in one exhibition, and
spray-painted graffiti all over their paintings, decrying it as "perverse,
satanically inspired, etc."...
And, to many art purists at the time, these works by Schiele and Klimt and
others were "perverse", in their depiction of young nude men and women, so
Hitler was only tapping into a certain sensitivity of the artgoing public,
and exploiting that cultural xenophobia.

All you computer hackers and cyber-purists may find that "the spot" has
bastardized your poor beloved Web.  Well, unfortunately, as with any other
communication medium, whether it be a canvas, a photograph, a telephone, or
a television, even the Web will be used in controversial ways, or ways
originally unintended by its creators.

This aside, I personally find "the spot" to be an innovative use of the Web,
a highly original, well-produced concept, essentially a new and fun (albeit
rather silly) interactive way to view the soap opera via cyberspace.  If the
spot's detractors find its content to be trash, well, then perhaps they
could create an interactive dialogue Web page for Platonic philosophy or
something of the sort.  To deny "the spot" a place in today's cyberspace
culture is tantamount to knee-jerk, elitist and short-sighted censorship.

Jack Wang

Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
> As far as I.m concerned I don't believe that the spot should not exist,
> I fully believe that it should and people should go to it if that's their

who is talking about the spot not existing? I just wanted to point it
out as an interesting car-wreck (or billboard, depending on yer point
of vu) for us to rubberneck at as we drive down the info-superhighway.

Jack Wang <Jack.Wang@InterNex.Net>:
> The criticisms mounted against thespot.com are as a fine example of cultural
> fascism as I have seen lately.
> ...
> In the 1930s, Hitler destroyed numerous works of art by European
> expressionists, works by Gustav Klimt, Edvard Munch, Egon Schiele, and many
> others, all because he thought that this entire genre of artwork was
> culturally degnerate.  He exhibited all these artists in one exhibition, and

This whole thing is a ridiculous statement. Like going completely
overboard. Nobody, not me, not the people whose messages I forwarded
have said anything about cernsorship. It's really nothing more than
people collectively going "eeeeewwww -- crass commercialism -- that's
grosss!"

WHat's the big deal about people's opinions? Let them have opinions all
they want as long as they don't run around telling people what to do. 

Basically, people are complaining about TVish commercialism (and  the
cultural control it exerts in telling people what is or isn't cool)
coming to the net. THese same people probably feel the same kind of
disdain for "Baywatch" or "Beverly Hills 90210"... but hey, the
opinions are there, and the shows are still on TV. Chill.

> spray-painted graffiti all over their paintings, decrying it as "perverse,
> satanically inspired, etc."...

I think you need to re-think Nazi censorship. They rarely complained
about "satan" -- Nazi spirituality was actually a strange brew of
germanic pagan "knight" culture/folklore/mysticism, paganism, nature
worship, and satanism. Today we'd call this "new age" (which is one of
the reasons we must keep a watchful eye on both the new agers and the
christians too). Is the Celestine Prophesy the next Mein Kampf? Who
knows -- is Forrest Gump the next "Triumph of the Will" ?? :-)

The nazis did have some very narrow views on what was "degenerate", and
this had to do more with art that didn't reflect the "family values"
they wanted to promote (strangely similar to the family values of the
christian right wing nowadays). A predominant value was
"anti-intellectualism" which meant that any of that
fancy-schmancy-art-skool-schtick (e.g. impressionism) had to go.
Hyper-Realism is about all the average simpleton can be fed as "art"
without getting any weird pretentions ideas... next thing you'll know
they'll be hangin around with jews and communists and wearing art-fag
boots.... ANd you can't goose step in art-fag boots, now can you!

Finally, as a failed artist, Hitler certainly needed to lash out
against all his peers that were getting attention, (and getting laid)
while he was off painting idyllic country scenes and spankin his
monkey.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Aug  2 14:23:49 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA23076; Wed, 2 Aug 1995 14:23:49 -0700
Received: from jeeves.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA23071; Wed, 2 Aug 1995 14:23:46 -0700
Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.32.19]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id OAA22949; Wed, 2 Aug 1995 14:19:40 -0700
Date: Wed, 2 Aug 1995 14:19:40 -0700
Message-Id: <199508022119.OAA22949@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: False claims of "cultural fascism" on the Web
Cc: Jack Wang <Jack.Wang@InterNex.Net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Normally I just let stuff like this pass me by, but I just _had_ to jump in
on this one...

>The criticisms mounted against thespot.com are as a fine example of cultural
>fascism as I have seen lately.  I will not purport myself to be a ardent fan
>of "the spot" nor would I consider myself to be a critic; however, to
>dismiss its web page as trash and kitsch is to blindly condemn it as
>culturally irrelevanct.

Okay.  First of all, I think this is going _way_ overboard to accuse people
of cultural fascism.  I'd like you to refer me to a *single* post that
actually proposes banning "the spot" from the web.  You will, however, see
many people talking about how silly it is.  Remember, saying something
shouldn't exist and outlining plans to get rid of it are two different
things.  And, frankly, I think describing culture as relevant or irrelevant
in the first place is a false concept.  Culture simply describes the social
situation of a society at a given period of time.  People aren't condemning
it as culturally irrelevant; they are condemning it for its lack of
substance.  Unfortunately, "kitsch" and "trash" are a part of this culture.
We're simply saying it's a part of the culture we really don't care for and
that we'd be better off without.

>
>One thing that may appear revolutionary to some may similarly appear as
>passe' to others.  For instance, some may consider pro-wrestling as a
>steroid-ridden, ultra-violent bastardization of sport.  And yet, for others,
>pro-wrestling is an entertaining role-play of good vs. evil.  Nevertheless,
>pro-wrestling is still a culturally valid arena of sport and entertainment
>in our society, and to dismiss it would be committing an act of cultural
>censorship.

I hate to say it, but this example _exactly_ illustrates the point a lot of
people are trying to make.  By your reasoning, expressing your opinion
negatively against something at any time is "cultural censorship."  No, it
is making your opinion on the subject known.  Cultural censorship is "hey,
we don't like pro-wrestling, so let's get a committee together in congress
to make it illegal."  Please keep your terminology straight.
        Also on this note: So what if something like, say, arena gladiators
came back into style.  People killing each other for money on tv, perhaps.
Does this mean that we should accept it and say "well, hey, it's just
another part of our culture" just because it exists?  I don't think so.  The
example is exaggerated, but the message is the same.  Just because something
exists doesn't make it good, even subjectively.

>In the 1930s, Hitler destroyed numerous works of art by European
>expressionists, works by Gustav Klimt, Edvard Munch, Egon Schiele, and many
>others, all because he thought that this entire genre of artwork was
>culturally degnerate.  He exhibited all these artists in one exhibition, and
>spray-painted graffiti all over their paintings, decrying it as "perverse,
>satanically inspired, etc."...
>And, to many art purists at the time, these works by Schiele and Klimt and
>others were "perverse", in their depiction of young nude men and women, so
>Hitler was only tapping into a certain sensitivity of the artgoing public,
>and exploiting that cultural xenophobia.

As stated above, nobody is supporting the idea of legally banning "the spot"
from the Web.  Therefore, this analogy is totally invalid.

>All you computer hackers and cyber-purists may find that "the spot" has
>bastardized your poor beloved Web.  Well, unfortunately, as with any other
>communication medium, whether it be a canvas, a photograph, a telephone, or
>a television, even the Web will be used in controversial ways, or ways
>originally unintended by its creators.

So we should just say "gee, that's too bad" and let it go at that?  There is
such a thing as standing up for your beliefs, although a lot of corporate
rep types wouldn't necessarily understand that.  Pragmatists like you have
gotten the world into quite a bit of trouble in the last several decades.
Maybe it's about time that changed.

>
>This aside, I personally find "the spot" to be an innovative use of the Web,
>a highly original, well-produced concept, essentially a new and fun (albeit
>rather silly) interactive way to view the soap opera via cyberspace.  If the
>spot's detractors find its content to be trash, well, then perhaps they
>could create an interactive dialogue Web page for Platonic philosophy or
>something of the sort.  To deny "the spot" a place in today's cyberspace
>culture is tantamount to knee-jerk, elitist and short-sighted censorship.
>
>Jack Wang

And yet once again, nobody wants to _legally_ deny "the spot" a place on the
Web.  Have you ever heard of economic sovereignty?  Well, how about cultural
sovereignty then?  If people aren't interested in some part of the reigning
culture, it will disappear.  Saying "the spot" shouldn't exist and not using
it to get your point across is totally different than saying "the spot"
shouldn't exist and lobbying congress to get rid of it.  People are going to
make their opinions known, and accusing them of "cultural censorship"
because of that is not only reactionary and poorly thought-out, it is also
trying to bring about the 1984 mentality that you claim we are spouting.
        Free speech is for everyone, Jack, even those you disagree with.

        Just my $.02 1/2.



Jake Reichert			|  Your talk is so terribly tired/

	Also, to add a little rave-relatedness (of a sort), it is now coming out

involving a bad acid trip -- very naively depicted if you ask me, but very

PS with a little stretch I can believe that this actually was the idea of an 
MTV-house wannabe with a brother into Webdesign...  In fact a "whois 
thespot.com" mentions "Tara's brother"'s name...  Its still too glossy though, 
and the address, a suite near USC-ISI in Marina Del Ray, doesn't sound like a 
beach house. Does anyone else know about Fattal and Collins (the ad agency 
mentioned in the original post)?  BTW "the spot" did appear as a Glenn Davis 
Cool Site in early June; maybe he knows the story.  Or call Tyler (Tara's 
brother) at (310) 305-1838...

integrating a plethora of genres. In forthcoming issues, we intend on
including features from the following concentrations: art, music, fashion,
prose, fiction, cuisine, club/rave scene, gossip, drag queens, sex,
editorials, and FREE CLASSIFIEDS. Each issue will have a distinct focus,
threading the material together.

content-the wilder the better-from around the globe. Our upcoming issue

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Aug  2 23:16:54 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA23535; Wed, 2 Aug 1995 23:16:54 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA23525; Wed, 2 Aug 1995 23:16:51 -0700
Date: Wed, 2 Aug 1995 23:16:51 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
To: Jonas Judd <jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu>
cc: SFRaves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: PG-13 access anyone? (not directly rave related)
In-Reply-To: <9508021641.AA05447@taurus.>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950802230521.8776V-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This is a big issue, not directly related to raving.  The summary - building
the technology and infrastructure for third-party ratings of WWW objects will
enable filtering applications, one of which could be used for parental 
control, in a *voluntary* way, without requiring that content authors 
rate them  For those with even a passing interest in how 
collaborative filtering/rating will work, check out something I've written at

  http://www.organic.com/Staff/brian/community-filters.html

and an implementation of such a system proposed at

  http://wex.www.media.mit.edu/people/wex/rate-proposal.html

using technology related to

  http://rg.media.mit.edu/projects/homr/

with an architecture incorporating

  http://www-diglib.stanford.edu/rmr/TR/TR.html

and

  http://www.acl.lanl.gov/URI/URCspec/

We hope it'll be at least similar what IHPEG commits to, because it does 
a WHOLE lot more than just parental control.

	Brian

On Wed, 2 Aug 1995, Jonas Judd wrote:
> Something Crunch forwarded to me. Is nothing sacred?
> 
> >X-Sender: alastair@mail.magna.com.au
> >Mime-Version: 1.0
> >Date: Sun, 30 Jul 1995 12:08:35 +1000
> >To: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
> >From: alastair@magna.com.au (Alastair Rankine)
> >Subject: And you thought SurfWatch was bad...
> >Sender: owner-ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
> >Precedence: bulk
> >X-UIDL: 807073215.001
> >
> >Not rave related, but here goes.
> >
> >>From the latest MacWEEK:
> >
> >---
> >
> >Internet rating systems
> >
> >Taking another approach, Microsoft Corp., Netscape Communications Corp. and
> >Progressive Networks Inc. last month formed an alliance called the
> >Information Highway Parental Empowerment Group (IHPEG) that plans to
> >publish a strategy by year-end that will allow software companies and
> >concerned citizens to work together on a technological solution.
> >
> >"Our goal is to build filtering capabilities into the industry-standard
> >Internet access software products ... and to open up a third-party network
> >so the industry can create and implement its own ruling systems and methods
> >for implementation," said Rob Glaser, president of Seattle-based
> >Progressive Networks and chairman of IHPEG.
> >
> >Glaser said an HTML tagging system may be one aspect of the solution, but
> >another may be the creation of multiple rating systems allowing parents to
> >choose one that best fits that family's values.
> >
> >"For example, the [rating] system I want to use for my 5-year-old son may
> >be very different than the one someone else chooses for their 15-year-old,"
> >Glaser said. He added that he envisions a day when various recognized
> >organizations, from the Christian Coalition to the American Civil Liberties
> >Union would offer rating systems.
> >
> >---
> >
> >Nice to know that the makers of RealAudio, Netscape and EDLIN have our best
> >interests at heart. I did a bit more sniffing around and found the press
> >release here:
> >
> ><http://www.realaudio.com/contentp/rabest/IHPEG.html>
> >
> >It seems to me that it's not a big step from _allowing_ some sort of
> >ratings system to operate on the web to _requiring_ one. Firstly we get the
> >technical "enhancement" to the HTML spec to allow web publishers to
> >classify their content according to the usual impossible to understand
> >standards. "This web page contains frequest course sex and occasional
> >language." The next step is to have browers (Netscape, MSN browser) to
> >understand these new tags and restrict viewing of unsuitable material
> >(configured and "locked" on a per-browser basis I guess).
> >
> >Fortunately this whole plan seems to be relatively easy to subvert. In fact
> >it would be kinda fun to put an "unsuitable for children" tag on a link to
> >some institutionalised religion of some sort.
> >
> >In a bit of rather shoddy journalism, an article in Canada's Globe & Mail
> >newspaper referenced the IHPEG saying that it was a "World Wide Web
> >Consortium, which includes technogiants AT&T, Digital Equipment, IBM,
> >Microsoft and Sun Microsystems". God knows how these other corporate
> >entities got into the act.
> >
> ><http://www.globeandmail.ca/Cyber-14.html>
> >
> >As Torquemada would say: "Be pure, be vigilant, behave!"
> >
> >--
> >|||| Alastair Rankine | alastair@magna.com.au | Mac C++ Guy | VFR750 ||||
> >

>can get away with a lot of stupidity if you're a promoter in Santa 
Cruz.

I'm sorry Fred, but I can't help but say that Santa Cruz promoters 
aren't stupid!! I speak only for myself in saying this, but I see Cloud 
Factory, the SC family, and ourselves (Harmony) pull off parties all 
the time in Santa Cruz! So obiously, some of us down here are doing 
something right! I think it was just a matter of bad coincidence for 
XYZ. And they tried to make something out of nothing, (maybe the wrong 
way,) but they tried. Now, about the Dub Tribe party, I don't even know 
who the promoters were. But please, don't knock a whole city, because 
two promoters fucked up. There are some of us who bust our asses 
getting legal spaces for parties down here. Have you ever been to one 
of our parties? Maybe you should come down and check it out! 

Peace, love and harmony to all,

Greg

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  3 07:40:55 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id HAA20303; Thu, 3 Aug 1995 07:40:55 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id HAA20297; Thu, 3 Aug 1995 07:40:52 -0700
From: Sho Kuwamoto <sho@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199508031440.HAA20297@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Rave in the Media (_Kids_) 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 3 Aug 1995 07:40:51 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 855       
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ellen Steuer <ellen@anonymous.com> writes:
> [Overview of movie _Kids_ deleted]
> yeah, but if these kids were raving they wouldn't be getting in so much
> trouble:)

Here, I disagree.  I love the scene, but I've also seen it
drag people down.  How many kids do you know who go to
parties every weekend, drop out of school, hold crappy jobs,
and sell drugs on the side to make ends meet?  In the
midwest, at least, the answer is "too many."  There are kids
out there who don't have a place to live and float from
couch to couch and party to party.  Is this right?

I guess I feel that we are all partly to blame.  I know we
all want to have fun and I know we all want to escape having
to be "responsible", even for the space of an evening, but
the fact of the matter is that there are a lot of kids out
there who are in trouble.  

What do we do?

-Sho

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  3 09:07:05 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA26625; Thu, 3 Aug 1995 09:07:05 -0700
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA26618; Thu, 3 Aug 1995 09:07:02 -0700
Received: from [198.93.4.120] (sf-tty21-ppp.well.com [198.93.4.120]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id JAA17807; Thu, 3 Aug 1995 09:06:51 -0700
Message-Id: <199508031606.JAA17807@well.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 3 Aug 1995 09:09:09 +1000
To: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Re: Burning Man
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>>I was wondering where one stays when you go up there?  Do you camp out?
>>and what about food and water?  does everyone bring there own supplies?
>>
>>Any info you can provide would be helpful.  I want to go with a friend of
>>mine but this would be our first time.
>>
>>p.s.
>>
>>I heard SRL is bringing some of there machines to it this year.
>>
>>thanks,
>>
>>mitch
>
>
>Most everyone camps out.  You must bring everything.  There is nothing there
>and nothing provided except for porta potties.  Check out www.burningman.com
>
>e mail me if you have anymore questions.
>

I should mention...  It's desert,  VERY DRY,  therefore bring at least
2 gals of water per day per person.   It is,  however a 25 minute ride
into Gerlach,   but because of the dryness,   you will be drinking LOTS
of water....   You'll also need it for washing,  there is NO running water,
but there are hot springs nearby...  I know of two of them...  Most people
usually hang out there during the heat of the afternoon.

You will also need a compass.   Unless you are in the center of camp,
where they have lantern beakons for the 4 points of the compass,   if
you situate your camp in the outskirts of Burning man village,   it
can save you lots of time,  trying to locate your camp at night,  or
even in the day.   Learn how to use it...   It might not be a bad idea
to put a light "beacon" on your tent at night...

Another thing,   don't rely on large busses, vans,  and other moveable
vehicles as landmarks,  they move around a lot.

If you have an airplane,   just fly right on in...   VFR rules apply,
of course...   :-)

See Ya all there,   hopefully with a good internet connection... I've
voluneered to help set up a link.   I have one of San Jose's chief radio
engineers and myself working on the problem.   See me if you really think
you can help.   Right now,  we need some good high gain UHF antennas,  and
Microwave equipment.   Right now,  we are analysing topo maps,  determining
which repeater sites can get a "hit" into the Playa.

I'll report later on the feasability.   My friend has some very powerful
digital radio repeaters,  mostly in S. Calif,   but some of these are on
mountains so high that they can reach well into N. Calif and Nevada.

If the S. Calif repeater can hit a repeater that can hit the Playa,  then
we'll have a 24 hr/ day 64kb connection.   We're keeping our fingers crossed.

My friend and I might fly out there sometime next week to check out the
area in person.

If we get this internet connection,  be looking out for some killer
"On the scene" reports.

Crunchman

>>>I was wondering where one stays when you go up there?  Do you camp out?
>>>and what about food and water?  does everyone bring there own supplies?
>>>

>>
>>
>>Most everyone camps out.  You must bring everything.  There is nothing there
>>and nothing provided except for porta potties.  Check out www.burningman.com
>>
>>e mail me if you have anymore questions.
>>
>
>I should mention...  It's desert,  VERY DRY,  therefore bring at least
>2 gals of water per day per person.   It is,  however a 25 minute ride
>into Gerlach,   but because of the dryness,   you will be drinking LOTS
>of water....   You'll also need it for washing,  there is NO running water,
>but there are hot springs nearby...  I know of two of them...  Most people
>usually hang out there during the heat of the afternoon.
>
>You will also need a compass.   Unless you are in the center of camp,
>where they have lantern beakons for the 4 points of the compass,   if
>you situate your camp in the outskirts of Burning man village,   it
>can save you lots of time,  trying to locate your camp at night,  or
>even in the day.   Learn how to use it...   It might not be a bad idea
>to put a light "beacon" on your tent at night...
>
>Another thing,   don't rely on large busses, vans,  and other moveable
>vehicles as landmarks,  they move around a lot.
>
>If you have an airplane,   just fly right on in...   VFR rules apply,
>of course...   :-)
>
>See Ya all there,   hopefully with a good internet connection... I've
>voluneered to help set up a link.   I have one of San Jose's chief radio
>engineers and myself working on the problem.   See me if you really think
>you can help.   Right now,  we need some good high gain UHF antennas,  and
>Microwave equipment.   Right now,  we are analysing topo maps,  determining
>which repeater sites can get a "hit" into the Playa.
>
>I'll report later on the feasability.   My friend has some very powerful
>digital radio repeaters,  mostly in S. Calif,   but some of these are on
>mountains so high that they can reach well into N. Calif and Nevada.
>
>If the S. Calif repeater can hit a repeater that can hit the Playa,  then
>we'll have a 24 hr/ day 64kb connection.   We're keeping our fingers crossed.
>
>My friend and I might fly out there sometime next week to check out the
>area in person.
>
>If we get this internet connection,  be looking out for some killer
>"On the scene" reports.
>
>Crunchman
>
>
>
>

On Thu, 3 Aug 1995, Sho Kuwamoto wrote:

> I guess I feel that we are all partly to blame.  I know we
> all want to have fun and I know we all want to escape having
> to be "responsible", even for the space of an evening, but
> the fact of the matter is that there are a lot of kids out
> there who are in trouble.  
> 
> What do we do?

The only thing I can think of to do is to set an example for these kids.  
Show them that we still have *alot* of fun and can escape responsibility 
for an evening, but at the same time hold down good jobs and support 
ourselves.  The ones who are in trouble won't get help until they ask for 
it and some don't even realize that what they are doing is self 
destructive. They have to burn out first and when they realize they have 
nothing to show for all those years, then they may ask for help. It's up 
to us to be there for them when that time comes.  C'est mon avis.......

love,
Amy

HELLO!  (Big *SMILE*) =)

It wasn't me with all the good vibes early this morning when Mike felt it,
but it's hit me and I'm working on giving out a bit of my own that's since
emerged.

I've been reading the list silently for a while now, but today I figured
I'd break my silence and try to release this wave of happiness that's been
building inside.

Just an hour ago I finished up one stage of a project I've been working a
year on and sent it off to my advisor in Scotland.  It's out of my hands
(temporarily) and I am so relieved.  Whew, these past few weeks of 12 hour
days in a lab are over.  YiIPPEEEEEEEEE YAAAHHOOOOOOOOOOO!

So I suggest everyone try to capture and feel whatever positive energy may
be floating about.  Take a pause, think about the last really great
positive experience you had.  How did you feel?  Close your eyes, try to
rekindle that feeling.  Now scrunch up tight all the muscles in your body
and hold it, now release in a big stretch and a smile.

Thanks to Mike for "wake up" (maybe it was _you_ all along).  

Now TAG, you're it.

Keep the energy flowing.

annie

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Aug  3 13:19:51 1995

From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)
Message-Id: <199508032017.NAA19954@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Media and Responsibility
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Sho brings up an excellent point, and one which has been
disturbing me a lot too.. But, unfortunately, it is not for us to tell
other people how to live, only to set a good example..

Also, it's important to remember that a little bit of 
"dropping out" may actually be good for society.. Those of us working
in areas that impact electronic commerce can see that in a few years, as
the impact of some of these new technologies really sinks in, there will
probably be a huge shrinkage in the number of people who need to work
in order to keep the present level of economic activity going.
It will be possible then to build a society where people will only
have to work, say, three days a week. People who are dropping out voluntarily
may actually contribute to stabiliy, because there will almost certainly
not be "enough" jobs to go around. Voluntary simplicity or involuntary, it's
our choice.. (because we will be the ones running the show at that point.)

-Chris

Dear All;

	I was looking through CD's I haven't listened to in a while, and
came across 101. Listening to their studio stuff, you would never know
they have such raw, primal energy in their live performences, but having
seen them in Philadelphia, many years ago, they are just fantastic. They
were the 1st to go all electronic, and are some of the fathers of the
electronic groove. So I'll ask my immortal ?, what ever happened to them? 
I'm told Depeche Mode is French for Fast Fasion, and they fit me just
fine!!!! 

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian Darkness, LMT/EE/CET

Well to throw my response into the pool, I have been extatically 
(sp?) happy for about 2 weeks now, constantly ever since I went 
visiting my friends in Santa Barbara. I had THE best time playing 
with them and spinning awe-inspiring music. I have had the constant 
e-smiles ever since. But today it climaxed for this morning I 
received email that they are coming here tomorrow so we can go run 
around the city all weekend and have some really intense happiness. 
Maybe I beamed a little too much and sent some of my happiness over 
the net via my SLIP!? Oh who knows and who cares as long as happiness 
prevails! I wish eternal happiness to anyone who just takes a minute 
to stop and close their eyes and feel the rush of pure energy that we 
can emminate if we all try! Who knows maybe I might see some of you 
this weekend and be able to share some of my happiness, a happiness 
that I have not known for 2 years when I chose to leave the scene. 
Well I don't want to take up too much bandwidth with my incessant 
ramblings so if you do feel the energy, just take a minute and 
breathe it in!!! You won't be sorry!!!

Luv ya all! ;-}
-----------------------------------------------------------
Christopher Silveira
a.k.a. eric longfellow (the lost dj)

Hmmm...well I didn't wake up with a bunch of energy, because I never 
really went to sleep.  I just had WAY TOO much positive energy!!!  It was 
really great (especially since I had a final today).  I danced the night 
away at a great club down here and when it came time for beddie bye, 
sleep didn't seem very important (of course I was coming down from X too 
so).  I don't think it was me (though I am sure I released tons of energy 
last night and took it in from all my fellow ravers), so a big thanks to 
whoever it was.  I think I am gonna swim a couple laps...have fun y'all.

Brian Behlendorf said:
> 
> I think it's brilliant, actually.  
> 
> A co-worker met "Carrie" I think it is, at a salon party in SF recently.  
> Based on his experience, I think the only conclusion one can draw is 
> there's no such thing as 100% "real" or 100% "fake" :)
> 
> 	Brian
> 

I agree with Brian.  The content is only so-so, but the concept is amazing.
It is a totally trashy piece of upper middle class white kids
pretending to be poor while living in a house on the Beach in Santa Monica?
(Okay, one is "hispanic" or something that i dont really see in persona or 
physique) 

Standard hollywood script writing. 

Point is.  The idea of an interactive story where you can suggest
plot lines, get response from characters, talk to them live on IRC, etc etc,
is damn well incredible.

"Tara" the person who seems to be in charge of the project went up to 
SF to do a little demonstration of it at the "Anon Salon" at a 
benefit for the Climate Theater (??? this is second hand)
And she did a demo of The Spot for the people there... 
(whatever that means)

I dunno, i think the point here is, is that people shoudl take this idea
and run with it.  THIS IS ON THE WEB.  Not a TV/CABLE STATION.  A lot 
of people have access to broadcast similar things.  It's like being
able to print a Zine, cuz you've got $10 and access to Kinko's
except this is more high scale.

(Notably, people who havent been brought up in schools where they
are taught to use computers, or who don't have access to computers
because of monetary access are therefore not able to distribute information,
and i, personally, like to keep that in mind:  The audience and the publishers
of any thing are going to be biased because of that.)

(oh great... my first post in like six months, and i coudlnt
figure out how to squeeze some rave bs in here.. :)

 ,
dana

"If I weren't real, could I do this?"

smiley face to beam out across the net.  We are coming to the city this 
weekend, I decided last night, we are running away from Santa Barbara.  I have 
the most insane bass pumpin', I've been spinning, in many ways, and I am 
absolutly estatic.  Went to bed last night in kind of a funk, and woke up this 
morning funky.  Thank you all for everything.  What an incredible community 
this is.  I can't even express in words how incredible I feel today, everyone 
must be beaming out to everyone else at the speed of light.

THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU

be the ones with the e-eating grinns on (much better than the other kind).

So much for the bandwidth, and words are simply failing to express how 
incredible I am feeling at this moment.  So I just beam out to all of you!

   This may be the fullest weekend I've had in the calendar - a total of
   11 events Friday and Saturday, plus the weeklies, plus Renewal on
   Sunday and Jack's House on Wednesday. On Friday, Stompy features the
   killer Chicago combo of Derrick Carter and Mark Farina, Frequency 8
   returns with another outdoor party, Komotion stars SFR's Ethan and Joe
   Rice, and the other parties also have hot lineups. Spend Saturday
   afternoon in the light at Light! then catch DJ Pierre at Wicked (last
   year's visit caused quite a stir) or mu-Ziq at All Together Now, then
   spend another afternoon at Renewal on Sunday.
   
   I'll be off at Siggraph next week, but I think I'll be able to log in
   and send the calendar from there.

   
                              THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, August 4th - Stompy Stomp 
   Stompy Frisco Players: Derrick Carter, Mark Farina, John Howard.
   Stompy Frisco Lightshow: Pure, Synergy Mixed Media w/Mr Donovan. 174
   King St @ 3rd. 21+, $12.
   
   Friday, August 4th - Sway
   DJs Jeff Miller, Josh, Richie. 415.267.5901
   
   Friday, August 4th - Frequency 8 
   DJs MARS, MystrE & Cyr. 11:30pm-6am; map point open from
   11:30p-1:30am. $4 donation requested. Bring flashlight, water, and
   sensible shoes. 415.541.5019
   
   Friday, August 4th - Parthenon
   DJs Karizma, Swing Kid, Donald Glaude, Spun, Jan Cooley & DJ Dan.
   Ambient room featuring Rig-A-Tony's Ambient Crew. in Sacramento.
   415.436.0582 916.658.2844

   Gen-X. 415.AMP-EX69 510.273.2427 408.236.3479

   415.536.9453

Radio/TV Shows 

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   

    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Well, Come-unity was as loud, thumpin' and crowded as expected, but for some
reason (beyond my understanding) it didn't have that "feel". 
 I don't know, maybe its the vacation I've had or an overdose of outdoorsy
mellow intimate parties like Freq. 8 and New Moon.  It seems to me that
Comeunity has gotten too big for its britches (at least space-wise).  Hard to
dance, and it gets way hot only after a few mins. on the floor.   


(the 25$ parking citation I found snugly placed on my windshield didn't help
either =p )

Smiley meter:

             Vibe:       8Smiles (still had the hittin' tunes)
Dancin space:       5Smiles (after 2Am, it was a mosh pit)
 Hugz'n'grins:       6Smiles (this too depreciated the night progressed)
    Eye candi:        7Smiles(the dance floor had disco visuals but
downsrairs had some OK trancy effects)

Overall:  6.5Smiles =) =D => =D =) =D =&  O.K.

paz y amor
Adam

BSP...BSP...BSP...BSP...BSP...BSP...BSP...BSP...

Hi all,

Starting tonight , and continuing Sat, and next Fri and Sat. will be the
Pre-Burning Man show/performance/cool stuff at the SOMAR gallery. What a
great way to get primed for a night out. It starts at 8 PM til around
midnight. This is gonna be one hellova show. All kinds of great artists and
performers. Some highlights will be Collapsing Silence (dance) and the
Hoverdrum (expanded with 2 drumers)!! This is a fundraiser to help pay for
the Burning Man and is $10 to get in :(  Yeah I know, it will be worth it!

Hope to see ya there,
Be sure and smile and say Hi.

(I'll be the one blasting folks with 1,000,000 + volts of High Frequency
electricity. It feels GGGOOOOOoooooDDDD)

luv ya

V.

The Happy Rasta Raver

and do whatever it takes to my the party that you are at right now the one to
go off.  But unfortunately I didn't have any friends to snap me out of it

Virtual Sites instead.

Well I can only say that I had a great time, the music was great, I went with
about 15 of my friends.  Took a friend who turned 40 that day out for his first
party, and he had a great time.  We've been doing C/U for a couple years and

party is only what you make it.  To really truthful I am really tired of
everyone

getting
me down as of late.

Oh, what a cheap scolding you give, Ron Nikel.  In one sentence you say,
"Quit your whining and complaining," and almost immediately thereafter
YOU say, "I am really tired of everyone complaining about every little
thing."  The postings you were referring to weren't whining in any sense
that I see, but your rejoinder sure is.  

Or would you rather have it that nobody should say anything here not
totally positive.  Whining is one thing, telling it like you really
saw it is quite another.  I'll tell you this much, after going to
Come/Unity off and on for three years, I'm disappointed but not
surprised to hear Geoff's comments.  You couldn't ask for anyone more
positive about the scene and especially about Come/Unity than Geoff,
and yet, what do we hear in response to his honest reaction to the
party this week but "quit your whining."

As for what YOU are getting tired of, I have only one piece of advice:
practice what you preach.

Flame off, indeed.

peace out
phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug  4 21:17:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA13965; Fri, 4 Aug 1995 21:17:00 -0700
