To: Otis <steav@frodi.cs.uop.edu>, Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Subject: Re: Come,er,shaw
Cc: Ron Nikel <ren@nin.engr.sgi.com>, SFRaves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I probably shouldn't have teed off on Ron as much as I did.  Especially
as someone who's put in a fair share of concern about where things are
headed with this scene-such-as-it-is.  But Come/Unity was really really
special, in fact, it was rather important in the early history of this
list and the people here.  On the one hand, it's hard to see things
sliding downhill when they really were so great, on the other things
never can or should stay the same.  Overall the energies of the underground
scene that briefly surfaced in the clubs in SF in 1991-93 have dissipated
and there is kind of a plowing under and reseeding going on right now.
The music is still there, but the scene is not.  

There *are* a ton of us out there who learned from the first wave and
are riding along on the second.  The small parties and gatherings and
planning being done around the Bay Area have sustained the vibe and sent
it in a new direction.  It's less glamorous than the big blo-up of the
early '90s but that's probably better for us anyway.  If you want to see
where glamor goes, just read DJ magazine.  

But even in the UK, there's still a strong underground, as indicated in
an interesting article in the new Mixmag (the one with Goldie on the
cover).  It's trance-oriented music, it's underground and semi-legal
parties, it's people doing it because they want to, not because they
are making pots of money off it, in short, it's very much like what
we're doing too.  And I'm sure this is true the world over when you
dig under the flavor-of-the-season superficial aspects of the scene
and find out what people are doing outside of the massive parties.

I loved Come/Unity in 1993 but you know, it didn't happen every night
or even every week, even if in a moment of nostalgia it seems like it
did.  I searched through dozens of hit-and-miss events before finding
Come/Unity and the other good events of that time, the only difference
now is I have a bit more of a success rate based on that experience.
We've got Sunset, F&F, MESS, Frequency 8, New Moon and a bunch of other
regular or occasional gatherings to choose from, and they're all good
in their own different ways, and sometimes they achieve that greatness
we're always looking for.  Kinda hard to imagine a better situation,
really.  

I don't think for the most part that people on this list whine or
grandstand.  We have storms of debate and noise from time to time, but
sfraves has always aspired to something better and nearly always
succeeded.  If you don't like the way things are going, say what you
think but please keep in mind the history and the mutual support and
the *people* you are talking to.

Enough mutterings from the soapbox here . . .

phred

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: interesing URLs on things that ravers are interested in :-)
Date: Fri, 04 Aug 1995 21:49:00 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <npm@eit.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Browsed around http://www.gold.net/users/bt22/ (Nicholas Saunders' site)
and found some interesing comments. Note that I still don't advocate taking
X nowadays just because it's like playing russian roulette (e.g. see
http://www.gold.net/users/bt22/pillstilJuly.html) in more ways than one...

I guess it's clear that as with anything else, there are strong positives
and strong negatives. (note pre-emptive flame extinguisher).

For example:

http://www.gold.net/users/bt22/psychological.html:

| Interview with a psychiatrist about psychiatric
| dangers of Ecstasy
| 
| I have always warned that the greatest danger of taking Ecstasy is
| psychological. For my new book, I have interviewed Dr. Karl Jansen of The
| Maudsley Hospital, one of the very few researchers in this field and a
| psychiatrist who specialises in drug related psychiatric problems. Here is
| an abbreviated version of my interview with him:
|
| [[...]]
|
| What about depression?
| 
| Depression and mania definitely can be triggered by Ecstasy if you are
| predisposed. MDMA lowers serotonin, and low serotonin levels have been
| linked with depression and suicide in some studies (not of MDMA users). The
| effect of many antidepressants (e.g. Prozac) is to increase the action of
| serotonin. In very simple terms, antidepressants have the opposite effect
| on serotonin action to MDMA. There are thus theoretical reasons to propose
| that MDMA use will show an association with depression and possibly
| suicidal thoughts, though this association has not been established as yet.
| 
| Are people with strong self image more likely to have problems?
| 
| No. The more strong minded people are, the fewer problems they will
| have. Its the neurotic, anxious people who have a lot of fantasy anyway;
| already have sleep disturbances; have a very high imagery level; an unhappy
| family background. . . these are the people who are likely to suffer
| adverse consequences.
| 
| How should people deal with such problems?
| 
| If a person has anxiety or depressive disorder related to MDMA use, they
| should seek treatment. The options are cognitive-behavioural therapy [where
| the goal is to alter behaviour through finding underlying causes],
| psychodynamic psychotherapy [an insight oriented Freudian-based therapy
| which aims to understand what is going on] and anti depressants such as
| impramine and fluoxetine [Prozac].
| 
| If they have delusions, their friends should take them to a GP who should
| be asked to refer them to a psychiatrist. They will probably be treated
| with an antipsychotic medicine such as haloperidol. This is a more pleasant
| route than going directly to a General Hospital where a less sympathetic
| attitude may be encountered.


==============================================================================
http://www.gold.net/users/bt22/religion.html

| [...]
|
| The rabbi had more positive views about youth drug use. "Traditional
| religions have lost the ability to provide followers with mystical
| experiences. Instead, young people are far more likely to have such
| experiences while on LSD and Ecstasy." Most religious leaders, he said,
| were against the use of drugs because of their own ignorance. "If priests
| really want to understand young people they should take drugs
| themselves. Then they would learn that MDMA can produce the same quality
| and potential value as other mystical experiences." But is taking a drug
| really as effective as years of devotion? "It can be seen as cheating, but
| it gets you to the same place."
| 
| My third interview was with Bertrand, a Rinzai Zen abbot in his early
| seventies. He started taking Ecstasy while he was a Zen student undertaking
| Koans, tasks such as understanding the sound of one hand clapping. "My
| master would give me such a task, and tell me not to come back until I
| understood it. Normally this took hours or even days of contemplation, and
| even then I would be told to go away and try again. But on Ecstasy the
| answers came swiftly and clearly. My master was most impressed though I
| never told him the secret of my success." Bertrand felt that Ecstasy had
| genuinely helped him on his rise to becoming an abbot, but admitted he once
| misused the drug. He was teaching a large group of students, neatly bowed
| before him in their black robes, while under the influence. "I feel no
| energy from you", he scolded, "You are like rows of corpses": an honest
| comment, but one that did not help the students, rather it made them feel
| put down.
| 
| Bertrand had never experienced dancing on Ecstasy, but he was curious and
| accepted my invitation to a party. He found the music unbearable at first,
| but eventually his face glowed and he announced "This is meditation  to
| be truly in the moment and not in your head!" He later explained that the
| object of meditation was to cease the internal dialogue and yet be fully
| aware of what was happening, and that is exactly what the dancers were
| doing.
| 
| Next morning Bertrand said he had had a revelation: his school of Zen
| concentrated too much on the contraction such as disciplined meditation,
| but what was really needed by most students was the opposite, to let go and
| expand in the way he had just witnessed at the party. Two weeks later he
| told me that he had just given the best meditation course of his life as a
| result: instead of strict discipline he encouraged the students to open up
| and have fun.
| 
| Lastly, I interviewed a Soto Zen monk, also a teacher of meditation, called
| Pari who said that his school of Zen was the only one that acknowledged the
| value of drugs: his master had used LSD and MDMA. "Ecstasy is a wonderful
| tool for teaching. For example, I had a very keen student who tried hard to
| meditate but never managed; Ecstasy allowed him to do so without the
| 'trying' blocking his efforts. That one experience helped him to make fast
| progress, and he had since been ordained a monk."
| 
| Asked about how Ecstasy helps achieve enlightenment, Pari made this
| analogy: "It is like a climber walking in the mountains who is lost in the
| fog and unable to see the peak he has set out to climb. All of a sudden the
| fog clears and he experiences the reality of the peak, and gains a sense of
| direction.  Even though the fog moves in again, and its still a long, hard
| climb, this glimpse is usually an enormous help and encouragement."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug  4 23:28:11 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id XAA20112; Fri, 4 Aug 1995 23:28:11 -0700
Received: from ix5.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA20107; Fri, 4 Aug 1995 23:28:06 -0700
Received: from  by ix5.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id XAA26494; Fri, 4 Aug 1995 23:25:37 -0700
Date: Fri, 4 Aug 1995 23:25:37 -0700
Message-Id: <199508050625.XAA26494@ix5.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Re: Us drug users
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, reading the thread to this point has inspired me to put my two 
cents in finally!  I do have a good suggestion (for those of you who 
have not tried it) as far as trying drugs is concerned.  I've found 
that a real good place to find out "just exactly what the facts is" 
about what you're doing is to look up your specific drug in the 
Physician's Desk Reference.  They spend a lot of time going into what 
the drug is for, the various ways it can affect you, and a lot of case 
studies where different results are all documented there.  No rumors 
floating around in this book, all hard-core facts!  I consider to be 
quite reliable when you're looking to see just how screwed up a 
particular drug can make you in its after-effects.  

Basically all I can say about drugs (I joyously take them myself and 
don't regret a single hit, trip, or experience I've ever done or had) 
is that I've found I have to take a very practical point of view when 
it comes to them.  I do it purely for entertainment, just as I would go 
to a movie, go on a camping trip, etc.  And just like a camping trip, a 
certain amount of practical planning has to go into it to make it a 
really great experience.  I always make sure there's nothing I have to 
worry about (i.e. wearing jewelry I might lose while tripping, making 
sure all my important shit is in one place and easily accessible and 
difficult to lose, and surrounding myself with people I love while 
experimenting with unknowns).  I really do believe I owe it to 
practicality that I've never had a bad trip (knock on wood!) so far.  A 
lot of people I've know don't seem to feel that these things deserve 
any concern, and some bad shit has gone down because of it.  (god this 
is starting to sound preachy!)  I guess it's not drugs I have any 
problems with, it's the people who have no idea how to handle them that 
I have a problem with, like how you don't blame the car but rather the 
drunk driver behind it.  And I totally agree with all the things that 
were said by the guy who first started this drug thread!  

I hope this post doesn't sound too stupid, but it's a point of view I 
wish more people had, they'd enjoy themselves a lot more and would 
probably have a lot less of a moral problem with drugs I think if they 
did.  So all you happy drug-users, bone up on your Physician's Desk 
Reference (no need to buy, just sneak into your local book store and 
sit and read about the drug of your choice, and put it back!), take 
care of your shit, and have fun!

> Well I can only say that I had a great time, the music was great, I went with
> about 15 of my friends.  Took a friend who turned 40 that day out for his first
> party, and he had a great time.  We've been doing C/U for a couple years and
> this
> was as usual a really good vibe.  Quit your whining and your complaining.  A
> party is only what you make it.


Hmm, I thought I just said  that.


  
> To really truthful I am really tired of
> everyone
> complaining about every little thing that doesn't feel like it used to, who
> is better, and hearing shut up your stupid.  This list has really started
> getting
> me down as of late.
> 
> FLAME OFF
> 
> Ron.

Well first of all, it doesn't feel like it use to, but then I don't expect
it to. I'm almost 39 now and I've been doing this for the last 4 years, this is
not boasting, just a fact.  The Scene does change, some for the better some
for the worse, it definitely doesn't have that innocent LUV PHASER force
that it did 2 or 3 years ago but all good things come to and end.  I think a
lot of the people who were really part of the scene then are trying to take the 
lessons and connections and friendships that were created during that time
and build something lasting... (in cyberspace ? :)  

Come/Unity always was and always will be special in my mind, whether it
becomes the beacon of light that it has been or even if it closes it's doors.

Perhapse a little history is in order here,  You guys out there who know the
real deal please correct any miss information.

Come/Unity was a party originally started by Martin, Simon,Garth, Jeno and
Malachy.  I'm not really sure about the exact players or times but I do
remember at least the involvement of Mal in the parties I went to.  Mal
was a very special person, I'm not going to go into the details here, they
are all on the hyperreal Website if your really interested, but suffice it
to say that Mal was a true "Evolutionary Agent", and the parties that were
held when he was involved were simply mind blowing when it came to the
"LUV Phaser Vibe".  He eventually decided to end the party thinking that it`had gotten too big and he wanted to do "smaller more intimate" gatherings.
The "Final Come/Unity" Was the first Tuesday in March of '93, Mal's
accident was the Full Moon of that same month.  A large party was thrown
in the Richmond Civic center planned by many of the various rave posse'
and promoter groups to be a benefit for Mal and to try and focus all of the
healing energy of the SF FAmily as a whole,  it was most likely the largest
Come/Unity ever held and indeed it was an amazing party and gesture.

The current Come/Unity is a re-incarnation of the previous one,  I'm not
exactly sure who is involved with this one but the DJ's are still Jeno,
Simon, and Garth.  The music is often kickin but it is really crowded
now and it is hard to find a place where you can really d/trance, which is what
It's all about for many of us.

At the earlier Come/Unity's I've seen people's live's altered on the
dance floor I'm sure it still happens for some, that is the amazing
thing about the Scene. No matter how gnarly it get's for you and your
experience, there is almost always someone who has a life transforming
experience at the same party, for some of us who go out, part of
getting the job done is to beam out the energy, even at a shitty party,
for those receptive beings who may be in the right synchronistic
co-ordinate in their life that they can receive it and and "feel the
vibe" so to speak. It is very hard to do this year after year, party
after party, and it eventually wears the best of us down.  I think the
Scene here is in a gestation period.  Outdoor parties like Sunset, Light
and the FMR are tools that people who want to do this can use to
recharge their batteries.

So far this summer has been amazing, I'm not looking back from the point
of view that "boy, it ain't what it used to be", it's true, it ain't, but
we all have to look to the future and make tomorrow the world that many of us
got a glimpse of in '92.

I didn't go to C/U in 91-93. I didn't know Malachy.  I went to C/U 3
days ago.  I had loads of fun.  I thought it was an excellent party.
I even enjoyed the fact that there were lots of people and that
dancing consisted simply of jumping up and down.  So maybe in 1999
I'll be thinking that C/U was more fun in 1995.  But I intend to enjoy
it for what it is now.  And that's what C/U will mean to ME.  Again,
that's just me...you are quiet welcome to romanticize the past.

But now seriously, there IS a good vibe out there.  I can't compare it
to the vibe you guys felt 3 years ago (because, again, I didn't go to
C/U in 92).  But you can't tell me that what YOU felt 3 years ago is
better than what I am feeling now.  It might be the case that my
perception of the current vibe is similar to what you had experienced
3 years ago.

So things get boring after a while.  What else is new?  Maybe it's
time to do something else?  :) ?  Let me recommend restoring MGs.  Or
inline skating?  Jazz?  Maybe polo?  It's a great rush!  (If you are
interested I can point you to appropriate mailing lists ;)

Peace and love

  v

>I guess I feel that we are all partly to blame.  I know we
>all want to have fun and I know we all want to escape having
>to be "responsible", even for the space of an evening, but
>the fact of the matter is that there are a lot of kids out
>there who are in trouble.  
>
>What do we do?
>
>-Sho

Sho,

we are not all partly to be blamed for someone's misdirection.  If you 
send positive energy at a party than the only thing others will recieve 
is positive energy.  If someone is going to waste themselves don't 
think its because of raving.  They could find it through alcohol or 
speed just as well.  I've met tons of people wasting away who never 
went to raves.

Raving does not have to be an escape of responsibility.  Tribal dance, 
family, music, and the release of your soul are absolutely necessary to 
live a balanced life.  In many ways raves help people become more 
responsible.  I really think those irresponsible people you spoke of 
would be that way even if they did not rave.

love chris

In-Reply-To: <199508010243.TAA00368@ix2.ix.netcom.com>

DRUGS AND CULTURE; CULTURE AND DRUGS
The two are interchangable.  Because the kind of culture you are 
sociaslized in will have a great effect on how drugs effect you and what 
your drugs of choice will be.  For example, is any coincidence that me, a 
middle class male from London, is a complete pot head; why, for example, 
have I never taken heroine or pharmacuticals or speed or coke and yet 
been tripping and e-ing since 18?
And this is also a big factor that one should consider when taking a new 
drug: do I like the poeple in this culture, do I respect and like their 
values, do they make me laugh?  All these factors should be intially 
considerd when the individual is straight.  And think about it hard 
because if you like the drug you will know what stage you will be at it 
in six months time.  Just food for thought for 2 cense.
TRISTAN.

On Mon, 31 Jul 1995, Gary 
Burns wrote:

> 
> 	Thought I'd jump in on the subject, one thats been a fairly
> 	big part of my life the last several years.
> 
> 	Much has been covered already; drugs can be a medium for 
> 	visting places that are much harder to get to through other 
> 	means; drugs are not for all; drugs are dangerous; drugs 
> 	can be pretty expensive (in a lot of ways); drugs are for 
> 	mugs; drugs make you thin, sext, cool...
> 
> 	Drugs, for me, were a revelation - after being brought up
> 	on a Scottish working class diet of alcohol abuse, violence
> 	and the hard-man image, my first experiences with drugs 
> 	were eye-opening to say the least. Dabbling in E in
> 	particular, and just about everything else in general, has
> 	brought with it a wealth of experience and learning that I
> 	doubt I would have been blessed with should I have chosen
> 	not to jump down that path.
> 
> 	Of course learning isn't always pleasant, and drugs can have
> 	a way of putting things over in a particularly nasty
> 	way. The axiom, 'there is no bad trips, only bad trippers',
> 	may be true but disreagarding its advice too many times, I've
> 	learned that chemicals can play around with your mind in the
> 	most unpleasant of ways.
> 
> 	Drug use has brought me in touch with a lot of truly wonderful
> 	people (real and immaginary ;') and has also placed me in
> 	situations I'd rather not have been - the 'Drug culture' is 
> 	a mix of nirvana and the foul - the money involved brings 
> 	violence, there's addiction, greed and self-distruction. 
> 
> 	Some of these things can be seen as personal failings (it could
> 	never happen to me), maybe they are, but some things have a way 
> 	of wearing you down.
> 
> 	To end with something that has been said before, there's no 
> 	absolutes here - If you want to partake, do so, if you wish 
> 	to abstain, well...But before condoning or condemming, learn
> 	about the issues invovled, misinformation on drugs is very
> 	prevelant in this society - altough people on the list seem 
> 	much more informed than the GP - and when, if, you do choose
>         to sample, or are simply continuing to do so, enjoy - and good 
> 	luck,
> 
> 	Still learning,
> 	Gary			
> 
>

there albums in the house I lived next door to in London.  I went in

power to do thing's you have only ever dreamed about.  And it was being 
operaterd by people who really knew what they were doing; th results of a 
lifetimes dedication.  Also, one of them bought my house which turned out 
to be a nice little earner.  Definatly one of my favourite bands (notice 
that there're British?).

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: ch-ch-ch-changes!
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Ah the discussion of how things used to be and how they are now. People 
in general tend to latch on to things, people, scenes and cultures and 
set themselves up for disappointment when it changes.  If you don't grow 
and change then you stagnate and rot in unhappiness - fighting a losing 
battle of "how it was".  Look at all these politicians trying to tell us 
that the 1950's were the ideal time for "family values".  There was sure 
alot wrong with the 50's as well such as very little civil rights for 
non-whites and women. Look at how we've changed since then! 

On a rave note, I entered the scene after it began "changing".  I 
arrived on New Year's Eve 92/93.  So I'm not "old school" enough to 
remember the costumes and Toon Town days, but I have been here long 
enough to feel like a significant part of this culture.  I can't look 
back at how it used to be, for I wasn't a part of it, but I'd like to 
think that I help contribute tremedous positivity and love to each party 
I go to and each person I meet.  Raving may not be the same, but it is 
still good!  I have met some incredibly wonderful people and been to 
countless mind blowing parties since I came into the scene in 93. If it 
weren't great, I would have gotten bored and dropped out.  Being the 
*same as it used to be* is not necessarily synonymous with *good*.  Just 
go with the flow and as I always say: Change is the only constant. 
Be happy and you WILL be free.

love,
Amy

Upon reading a previous post concerning the possibility that this Jake
Slazenger guy was a hoax and not really the one we know and love as Mu-ziq,
I was deeply disturbed and had to come down to the truth.  I went to the one
place I knew I could trust... the hyperreal.com web page.  I found the info
on Mu-ziq and here it is...

Q: Who is Mu-ziq?
A: Mu-ziq is a 22 year old from South London named Michael Paradinas.

...

Q:  What other names does Michael Paradinas use?
A:  Mu-ziq, Tusken Raiders, Jake Slazenger, Gary Moschles

Weehee, our dilemma was solved.  These are all one and the same and the world
is whole again...

So see ya at that little shindig...

Dallas and Kat

hello all,

I came into the scene in Feb. 1994 so I'm not old school either.  I 
don't know if the scene was better in 1991 but I do know that it is 
exploding this summer!  I can't believe how many free outdoor parties 
are going on.  Pacific, Gateway, Newmoon, Fullmoon, Mother Earth, 
Frequency 8, parties in Marin, ect.  It is amazing!  It is impossible 
to go to all of them but they all continue to produce that beautiful 
family vibe that its all about.

Yesterday Crunchman told me that there was 12 parties going on this 
weekend!  I don't know if that included Sacramento but it is going 
through some growth as well.  I feel so lucky because for the first 
time I have my weekends free and certain beautiful people are striving 
to bring us together.  I just keep growing and growing and growing as 
we keep growing and growing and growing.

love chris

From: Vince <vince@vmar.com>
Subject: Re: Robot wars info (save your $$).
Cc: Ville Aikas <aikasevj@u.washington.edu>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 I just thought you may be interested in this bit of info from SRL,
regarding the Robot Wars from last year. I have a copy of the entire
article available at www.vmar.com/SRL_scam.html

A much better value (IMHO) $$ will be the SEEMEN show this Friday night at
the Trocadero. These are good sized machines in the SRL style, done by some
local (SF) artists, who I would much rather support.

forwarded text........

REWARD OFFERED for information leading to the whereabouts of Joseph
Matheny. Mr. Matheny was the producer for our last major performance,
A CALCULATED FORECAST OF ULTIMATE DOOM. He was also the
producer for the =84ROBOT WARS=BE event staged at Ft. Mason in SF in
August. He hired Mark Pauline, Liisa Pine, and Terry McGovern, from
SRL to build the protective railing around the machine presentation
area. He also arranged for the rental of one of SRL's forklifts for
5 days to set up and break down the event. Somehow the date for
payment kept slipping further and further away.


Originally, Mark Pauline was assured by Methiny that SRL would be paid
when the money was received from Robot Wars. When payment from Methiny
seemed in doubt back in September, Mark Pauline called the Robot Wars
owners, Mark Thorpe and Gary Pini, to advise them of the problems
encountered in securing payment from Methiny, and to see if a direct
payment to SRL from Robot Wars for services rendered could be
arranged.

Pini and Thorpe agreed that SRL was owed the $1550.00 but refused to
pay SRL directly, instead paying Methiny for work done by SRL. Methiny
then split town. Robot Wars intends to continue their commercial
presentations of =84popcorn machines=BE to the public on a yearly
basis. Admission was $30.00 a head for the August event with 1200
paying customers. In view of the insensitive way that an event as
flush with cash as Robot Wars dealt with SRL's relatively small
payment, Mark Pauline recommends that robot builders stay away from
future Robot Wars events.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I came to the scene in late 1991, early 1992 when I was 18. The Summer of 92 will 
always be remembered for its truly awe-inspiring vibe. I would go 
from Friday to Sunday night with no sleep, every single weekend for 
the year. It was incredible, it change my life in many ways that 
cannot be explained. I made so many friends, people that I could 
actually talk to openly without fear of repercussions. 
It became so much a part of my life that I actually somewhat 
abandoned the rest of it. I ended getting myself in a lot of trouble 
at home, work, and school. I couldn't fight reality anymore, in fact 
it seemed a lot of people felt the same way. All the people I knew 
slowly started to filter out of the scene. I held on as long as I 
could, but finally I left also. I started to put my life back 
together, cleaned myself up, found a job, got back into school. It 
took me up until a couple of months ago to actually get up the nerve 
to go to a party again. And I owe it all to my best friends in Santa 
Barbara, whom I love more than anyone, for dragging me out with them 
the July 4th weekend when they were in the city. I love you both big 
bunches!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! =)
Now I feel like I have a balance once again. Anyway, my point is 
that from the few parties I have been to lately after my near 2 year 
sabbatical, the scene has changed a great deal. It will never be like 
it was back in 92. I went through a 3 month depression after leaving 
the scene in 93 cuz of the emptiness I felt without it. But the thing 
we have to understand is that everything evolves. Evolution can be in 
a good direction or a bad direction. A good evolution leads to higher 
forms of the original, bad evolution can lead to extinction in which 
case the chain starts over with something else. The important thing 
about parties is that they are only as good as the energy people are 
willing to put into them. Our scene is more than killer music, 
mind-opening drugs, and trancie visuals. It is a feeling! A feeling 
that we all share together such that when we see each other at a 
party and smile, there is twinkle in each other's eyes that says that 
our love, caring, and individual energy went into this to make this 
work! We love each other and the things we can do together! WE make 
this possible!
I think that when I left in 93 I had just depleted my energy beyond 
my scope of understanding. In my break I developed a life in the real 
world where I was happy. That was my mistake b4, I wasn't happy b4 
the rave came around. I started going and that became my happiness. 
The balance between reality and rave(party) must be defined for each 
of us in order to maintain stability. When there is no stability, 
there is no central point to pull positive energy from, therefore 
making us erratic and the balance tips.
Anyway, what I am trying to saying is that our life is what we make 
of it. Parties may not seem to be the same or have the same vibe as 
they used to. That is true, but what we need to concentrate on is 
remembering the vibe and shaping our energy around that and letting 
other people experince it. Share your energy, you know the difference 
that can make! It is when negativity is introduced in a situation 
that things fall apart, dreams die, imaginations stop. Without the 
positive energy from all of us, we will never know how high we can 
travel or waht we can accomplish. We can never forget that.
I truly apologize for going off for so long, I get started and I just 
can't stop. But just do me a favor and think about what I said for a 
moment one day when you wake up in a funk. Trust me I did...

Luv to all who will listen! =P
-----------------------------------------------------------
Christopher Silveira
a.k.a. eric longfellow (the lost dj)
csil@hooked.net
http://www.hooked.net:80/users/csil/
Junior Dragon   -=(UDIC)=-
- "Beats so phat ya might gain weight!!!"

Subject: Sunday Living
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

[ To SFRaves mailist -  personal reviews of Sunset/Renewal , Nick
  Turner's "Hawkwind" concert , Karma at Big Heart City ]

 After a three week work-enforced absence from the "dance n' trance" 
scene , I was quite happy to don my black and yellowed checkered
shirt with the ecstatic face of Goofy (tm) on the front drive to
Berkeley to Sunset/Renewal. I got there a half-hour before
sunset - t'was so good to hear that house music and see/hear those
happy people again! ( Hello at Mike , Ameet , Philip , Rocky , and the
others ! ). Loren was spinning as the sun dropped below the distant 
ridge. [ Insert the usual warm fuzzy stuff about Sunset here ].
By the way - why Sunset & Renewal? I don't remember what history
is behind Renewal - is it new?

 I couldn't stay too long , as I was going to see Nick Turner at the 
Great America Music Hall in SF. After driving over the Bay Bridge to SF,
I managed to find some well-lit street parking a block from the club, 
and I bought a ticket from someone who had an extra. 

 It was a great concert! Loud , riff-repetious/hypnotic space metal 
music with Mr. Turner on saxaphone and flute. He played with other 
Hawkwind alumni Del Dettmar on synths ,Simon House on violin , and
Alan Powell on drums. The other folks in the band were from a group 
called Pressurehead, and a fellow named Len Del Rio on keyboards. 

 I suspect Mr. Turner is in his late forties , if that young. It seems
the older he gets , the more shamanistic he looks - Genesis P. Orridge
might find that encouraging! Anyway , I'm listening to the new CD with
same band member lineup as tonight's concert ( I bought it at the club
tonight ) , it's called "The Eternal Sky" by Anubian Lights , on the
Hypnotic/Cleopatra label. Very "world-music" rhythmic space trippy ambient 
so far - not as grungy as the concert , athough they were playing 
a lot of old Hawkwind stuff tonight. I recommend both the live concerts
by Nick Turner and the latest CD to those who like to dance n' trance
( and who don't have any prejudices against electric guitars ).

 After Mr. Turner & company , I drove to Big Heart City to check out
Karma , the new Sunday night weekly that specializes in "psychedelic
trance". I liked it! Nice clean sound ( even though it seemed that 
the music was slamming past the red leds at the mixer - I guess they 
turned down the input gain at the power amps ), nice clean club ,
nice clean restrooms. Music was very techno fast trance - DJ's were
Adam and Craig . Someone told me there had been a live performance 
earlier by "Ted" , and the little synths with chiclet keypads were
still interconnected on three tables when I got there at 1AM. 
Attendence was about 30 people .

 Bad aspect of this weekly is that the section of Mission Street that
Big Heart City is located at has street cleaning at 2AM in the morning.
Since Karma is supposted to be a 10PM to 4AM event , some care needs
to be taken in parking. 

 For some reason , Karma shut down at 2AM tonight , not 4AM as shown on
the flyer. I don't know if that'll be happening every Sunday night for
Karma or not. Still - if you like that trancy techno , be sure to check
this out! Usually , I'm not a hard techno/high bpm kind of guy , but 
tonight it felt right! 

 At one point I tried "dancing" with one of the i-beam pillars they 
have at Big Heart City - I tapped and slid the tips of my fingers over
the bumpy textured paint of the pillars , and the sensation from my
fingers seemed almost as "loud" as the music! Very mysterio ....

 See you folks later! ( Maybe Harmony ... ))

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Subject: sunset/renewal
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Pacific was able to give their ailing sound system a reprieve by teaming up
with Renewal for this weekend's party for a very wonderful time.  It
seemed to be a funkier crowd with a greater vpp (vibe per person) ratio than
the last few sunsets.  I liked the smaller size, about 200 while we were
there.  Hopefully, Pacific's recent decision to take things a little further
underground will have a lasting effect through the rest of the season.

I won't bore everyone with the usual cliche's about the beautiful music,
weather, bay view, naked person, etc.  One incident worth noting occured
when someone who was dancing suddenly collapsed and went into seizure or
convulsions.  The music was turned off and an ambulance was called.  He was
up and walking b4 medical aid arrived, but it was pretty scary for a while.

It made me wonder abou what the proper thing to do would have been if the
guy was taken out on a stretcher.  Do you crank up the music after he's
gone and just continue with the happy vibe like nothing happened?  Do you
end the party out of respect for the serious nature of the incident?  Or
do you play something solemn and ask people to conjur up some healing energy?

We left just after that at around 7:30 as the party restarted and continued
with the celebration of life.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

This happened at a party in Kentucky.  It was a free outdoor camping
weekend with a big dj line-up (Interstellar Outback).  A woman that
many of us knew (she was a net-raver) od'd on heroin, and was taken
out in an ambulance.  She was flatlined a couple times, and none of us
knew what was going to happen.  After this, there was a big debate over
starting the music again or not.  No good answers were found.

Stopped by Azul@Casanova on Thursay.  Alfie and James were spinning the down
tempo soulful funky house. No one really dancing but its a nice place to hook
up, drink a beer, not too loud so you can converse, and its free.

Stompy was a classic King St. super sweaty jam.  Caught the end of John's set
-- I like him more and more.   Mark Farina's  steadily become my fave DJ and
its no wonder.  Derrick Carter didn't show so Mark spun most the night --
Chicago showman to the end that boy was on fire.  I actually tried to leave
around 6 but couldn't seem to stop dancing though I could barely wobble
around that last hour.  Good vibe though the energy seemed to be up and down
probably due to the heat and extra tourists this time of year.

Sunset was great as always and it seemed to have a little more of that old
vibe I remember.  The new sound system was sweet!  Got to make up for missing
John Howard's set at Stompy -- he spun some jammin triphoppy stuff that I dug
in a  fun, crazy set.  Great music, great people, and that beautiful bay we
live by -- ya gotta love it.   

phuture (Bret)

From: "JMRTNKO! please stand by..." <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: All Together... & your ears
To: ezzevvravess <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: brycer@ultima.org, nrg@ultima.org
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9508071247.A25954-0100000@netcom4>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


First, let me say that regardless of the technical difficulties, Bog's 
party Sat night was quite amazing. I chuckled at the swimming pool idea 
only to regret not bringing a suit a couple hours later. Jonah nearly put 
me in the hospital by refusing to play a bad track and let me leave the 
dance floor (Hearing "Colin's Tamborim" and "testone" again was worth my 
money alone).

So while I still enjoyed the party, I have to say that the sound was some 
of the most damaging I've ever experienced. My ears are still ringing two 
days later. I didn't help that Mu-Ziq used high-pitched noise for 
transitions between tracks. I noticed at least a dozen people around me 
(including myself) covering their ears. I knew I should have brought 
earplugs. It'll be the last time I forget.

But the sound never should have been that bad in the first place. We've 
all seen (heard) how good and loud Bryce and Ethan's systems can sound 
without causing irreperable ear damage. Unfortunately, other promoters 
haven't been so enlightened and continue to light every red diode on 
every meter in the place.

we've talked about this many times before, and some folks have 
contributed some great information, but I'd like to get it off the list 
and in the hands of those responsible for the problem... and those who 
are unknowingly exposed to it.

If someone can write or compile any info on proper sound equalization, 
tinnitus, &c., I'd like to design a small informational pamphlet to print 
and pass out to people (and promoters). I don't want this thing to be a 
killjoy, but we know that great sound doesn't necessarily have to be 
damaging sound. 

jmar.

Hello everybody,

Wow, the Renewal/sunset party was great.  The soundsystem was not 
Pacific's, is that so?  I noticed a group standing around behind the dj 
that had also thrown a party up in the Marin headlands maybe a month 
ago. 

So is Pacific passing the Sunset torch to a new crew?  Personally, I have 
mixed feelings about this possibility, but I think that Javier and 
friends are great.  They seem very  positive, hopeful, together, 
ambitious and clean-cut, which is how Galen and friends always seem, 
too.  The clean-cut part is important because of having to get permits 
and deal with the authorities, as Galen's suave handling of security 
personnel has demonstrated many times.  

Welcome to the new kids, if you're listening.  New people coming in, 
throwing parties, keeping the music alive is what everybody with any 
sense wants to see.  


love,

ann

jmar ("JMRTNKO! please stand by..." <martinko@netcom.com>) writes:

>So while I still enjoyed the party, I have to say that the sound was some 
>of the most damaging I've ever experienced. My ears are still ringing two 
>days later. I didn't help that Mu-Ziq used high-pitched noise for 
>transitions between tracks. I noticed at least a dozen people around me 
>(including myself) covering their ears. I knew I should have brought 
>earplugs. It'll be the last time I forget.


Yeah, I hear you on this one (pun initially unintended).

But here's a great trick I learned at a live too much joy concert in Ithaca,
NY from one of my roomies...

(1) go into the bathroom
(2) pick a stall
(3) get some t.p.
(4) go back to the floor and stick some in your ears to taste.

now, you may look a bit funny, but if you're like me, you _always_ forget
those stupid plugs at home.  My ears won't ring using this.  Just be careful
cleaning it out later!

Peace,
 Q

I haven't been to a Wicked in awhile, but it seems to me that Wicked has
got this new look.  I think they set up King St. really nice also.  I
can't believe that venue can be arranged into so many different
possibilities. More fans, more speakers, more everything, even somehow 
more space.  Even a handy bubble in the middle of the dancefloor for that 
extra bounce.  I had an L.A. techno-rave flashback during a few songs, it 
was quite nostalgic.

this is actually not criticism, but an answer to it..kind of!

first of all, the new moon crew says many, many, many thanks to the 
following:

ethan miller	for speakers, cables, incredibly positive energy
		beaming out for miles around

joe rice	for playing, for the loan of amp, tables, cables, decks
		and also, for radiating positive energy and for
		bringing a friend with the same good vibe

gaby sankovich	for being absolutely amazing in every way.  this party
		could not have happened without you, honey.  this lady
		knows her stuff and can deal with crazy raver moon
		madness in all its forms. we learned so much from you
		last week!  

gregg helt	for keeping it all together, with duct tape

ronan		for being there, for playing, for comprehending the
		new moon vibe

hymns and anthems	a warm-hearted raver tribe that provided 
			brawn, brains, good spirits, encouragement
			and your very own dj-shaman

heather jones	for helping get us organized, for positive female energy

bio-jeff, ronan, cyril, joe rice, jim huckin, billie, kelly for playing

philip		for taping the party

billy sankovich	for transportation, for a level head, for good advice and 
		many thoughtful conversations

greg sankovich	for bringing his amp and cellular phone.  and also for
		having a good sense of humor

philip and gregg again...	for design and implementation of soon-to-be
				patented wind-proof plastic cup/tea-light 
				candles

since this is a party all of us did for the joy of it, i wanted to make 
sure that people got some credit for their contributions.  if i've left 
anyone out..due to ignorance or forgetfulness...i apologize.  please 
post yourself, if you like, to correct any oversights!


finally, i want to say that the new moon is a party we do for the fun of 
it.  to satisfy ourselves, our friends as well as  people we barely 
know.  we are 
NOT really a "crew" like Pacific or whatever...we are mostly a very loose 
group of people that like this party and come together once a month or so 
to listen to music and experience together a profoundly spiritual 
event...the completion and renewal of the lunar cycle.  we are not a 
church or cult or anything and people that come to the party can have a 
wonderful time without thinking about such spiritual matters at all.
HOWEVER, enough magical things have happened around this party to make 
even a dedicated hardboiled scientist such as myself respect the ongoing 
and evolving mystical nature of this gathering.

basically, what i'm saying is that if circumstances or poor planning 
foiled your attempt to make it to the New Moon in July, be 
grateful...because it's entirely possible that you should not have been 
there.  we did everything in our power to guide you.  some people made it 
to the beach that night against amazing odds...some people turned back at 
the parking lot, not realizing that we were only 3/4 mile down the beach 
and that those lights in the distance were our attempt to light the way.  
these difficulties do not reflect badly on anyone, by the way.

again, thank you everybody for making it so good,

ann

ps also a special thankyou to mona love in mississippi, who emptied the 
voice mail and allowed jennifer to find us at last

> It made me wonder abou what the proper thing to do would have been if the
> guy was taken out on a stretcher.  Do you crank up the music after he's
> gone and just continue with the happy vibe like nothing happened?  Do you
> end the party out of respect for the serious nature of the incident?  Or
> do you play something solemn and ask people to conjur up some healing energy?

Well, Lee, I can't remember exactly what time you left, but after the guy 
was able to get up, the music began again very softly and it was really 
mellow ambient stuff. The dj (I think it was Solar) kept it soft and 
mellow for awhile I think until after the ambulance left. I went for a 
walk at that time to keep warm and when I got back Loren was on and the 
sun was nearly set. By then the music had incredible energy and so did 
the crowd.  I think the incident brought us all together in a way: like 
reminding us that we are all in this together. I felt such *great* vibes 
- there were about 20 of us in a huge group hug, then we all formed a 
huge circle holding hands.  We were all really together that night.  I 
got to get a little closer to a couple of sfravers that day as well and 
that was very pleasant.  I won't see you all again til Friends & Family.
I'm going to Mount Shasta this weekend for some much needed camping.
As for the proper thing to have been done with the seizure incident - I 
think it was handled perfectly and respectfully.

love,
Amy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug  7 21:34:47 1995

Cc: amit@tang.bdti.com
Subject: Music for Martians
Reply-to: buvac@cs.Stanford.EDU
From: buvac-lists@cs.Stanford.EDU
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Correy, Mike and I went to MUSIC FOR MARTIANS on Saturday.  This was a
free party on a beach 17 miles north of Santa Cruz.  It was very
small: peaked at around 60 people @2am, and there were maybe 20 people
when we left @8am.  The music was excellent; the dj names I remember are
James, Tom, Wool, and Jason, all from Santa Cruz.  I especially
enjoyed James' and Tom's sets.  The vibe was incredible.  Most of us
were trancing all night.  There was some kind of magic in the air.
I fell in love with the Santa Cruz family.

I don't know who the organizers were, but they were really on top of
things.  They had a permit for the party and everything ran smoothly.
The only complaint one could have was that the generator died 2 or 3
times throughout the night.  However, they always got it started up
within 10 minutes.  I actually enjoyed the moments of silence: got a
break from dancing and it was nice just listening to the waves.

Now I'm too burned out to go to FMR :(   But I think it was worth it. 

Peace and love

SASA

  A reminder for tomorrow's "SFRaves South Bay Lunch".
 
  For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
 me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
 the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
 nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
 we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).
 
  It's every Wednesday , depending on my own work schedule , the
 weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!
 
 				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
 
 ------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...
 
 When: Wednesday  
 Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
 Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto
 
 Directions:
 
 * From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 
 
 * Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
   (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)
 
 * Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
   
 * You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
   driveway on your right.
 
 * We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
   Next to the restrooms and ball courts.
 
 Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

[ to SFRaves mailist ]

 I was wondering if anyone here , especially the South Bay folks , have
any nostalgic thoughts about radio station 97.7 ( "Hot 97.7" ). It just
changed owners and formats lately , from "urban contemporary" to yet
one more KFOG style rock music dispenser. This change was made despite
protests from long-time listeners. 

 It seemed that every car with a monster stereo system was tuned to this
station. I never listened to it on a regular basis , but I knew a lot
of folks who did.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Recently, Lee Fogel said :
> 
> Not directly rave related, ... I know that
> some here would be interested to know that Jerry Garcia has
> passed away.  I was never a fan, but a feel a sense of loss  for
> one of our culture's psychedelic musical shamans.
> 
> Lee
> 
 And let's not forget those great times in the Oakland Colesium
parking lot - Atomic Rooster , etc. . 
 
 I'm also a raver who's a Grateful Dead fan , and I have mixed feelings
about Jerry Garcia's passing. In one sense , the travelling circus
culture that sprang up in association with the group , without the
group's encouragement, was in my opinion a life style dead-end. On the
other hand , I've had my share of spiritually positive moments
at Dead shows that rival many raves' "vibe". 
 
 So - I forsee ... massive Grateful Dead memorial shows where
DeadHead DJs mix vinyl and CD Grateful Dead music ( especially those
tasty bootlegs! ) . They never had a fancy stage show anyway , so
pre-recorded music would be just as well ... I'd go, if only in
memory of a man who gave my some great times in my life.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Message-Id: <01HTV93LYSNM005JF8@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com",EDEN1::IN%"socal-raves@ucsd.edu"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

whether you were a fan of the grateful dead or not (as i am), there's
  one VERY important thing they brought to society: a place where anybody
    at all could go and be completely free with their lifestyle, and 
      co-exist with thousands of people from other walks of life, with
        everyone having a good time.
there have been VERY few events in history where this sort of thing 
  was allowed to happen; social and racial strata always blocked the way.

raving certainly holds promise as a successor to this tradition; it's
  time for a change of guard, maybe...

it's quite possible that raving is one of the LAST REMAINING bastions of
  total freedom in music and celebration, if the dead are indeed gone
    (of course, i'm NOT gonna bury that band prematurely, they've had
      several disasters and recovered just fine)
...but just in case, the baton mite have been passed at 4am today...

Dave Scruton
http://hyperreal.com/~scruton

        Reply to:   Narnia

I was the one who was thinking about arranging a bus to Narnia.  We've dedided not to do the bus because at this point we're not sure whether or not we have to go down a day early to set up.  Also the bus was going to be pretty expensive, and although quite a few people responded, there weren't enough to make sure we could definitely cover all the expenses.  If anyone is going to Narnia, we're going to be setting up a super chill pavillion so keep an eye out for us.  I'll post all the info as it gets worked out.
Also if anyone needs a ride, I know a couple of people driving down so let me know.  Also, if you're going and you have extra room, let me know or post it to sfraves - it's going to be a pretty incredible event and it would be cool to get as many of the sf crew down there as possible.
The Narnia posters just came out last week and they look pretty incredible.  I have a whole stack so if any of you sfravers want one, just let me know.

Partial lineup for Narnia (according to the poster):
Mark E. Quark
Dmitry
Robbie Hardkiss
Jeno
Garth
Jason Bentley
Jon Bishop
DJ Dan
Mark Farina

sfnarnia info: 415.437.4067

See you there!
Bart

Here it is a day early since I'm in LA and I don't think I'll have
email access tomorrow.  Harmony and United look good for this weekend,
maybe Plastik too if it isn't too big.  This connection at Siggraph is
slow so I'll stop there.  See you back in the Bay Area next week!

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Wednesday, August 9th - Jack's House 
   LA's Taylor, Sandra Collins & Alison. UK DJ & Planet 4 artist Guy
   Oldhams. Resident DJ Talizman. 510.464.4942
   
   Friday, August 11th - Harmony Two-Year Anniversary
   DJs James, Trent, Graeme LaPaix, DJ Dan, Ethan, Brandon (Solid
   Grooves) & Galen, EBE (Solid Grooves recording artist). Visuals by
   Michael Clay. $10. outdoors in a ranch. 408.486.9591 408.450.3044
   
   Friday, August 11th - Common Ground 
   djs dan, tony, doran, donald glaude, ted, karizma 916.558.0850
   415.437.4421 (probably in sacramento area)
   
   Saturday, August 12th - United presents SLAM'n' Beats
   DJs Galen, Tony, Jeno, Markie, Eddie Richards. Ambient by Nick
   Phillip, Professor Smith and Joe Rice. 10pm-7am. 415.764.0228
   
   Saturday, August 12th - Plastik: come enter the realms of
   understanding
   DJS Garth, Simply Jeff, Rage, Tony, Ghost, Simon, Carlos, Rick
   Preston, Liquid. 415.536.9441 510.869.3660
   
   Saturday, August 12th - Metro Jazz 
   DJs George, Kevin, Felix, Suiki. Cafe Bastille, 22 Belden Alley. (nr
   Bush & Kearny). $6, 21+, 10:30 til Terminus.
   
   Friday, August 18th - ENIT - Lollapalooza After-Party
   Freaky Chakra vs Single Cell Orchestra, Banco de Gaia, Sven Vath,
   Keoki, Moby, Traci Lords + a film by Future Sound of London. 9pm-4am
   at the Warfield, SF. Seems to be free with Lollapalooza ticket stub.
   or $20 + ripoff @ BASS.
   
   Saturday, August 19th - Tribal Funk invites you to join us for a night
   of Nothin' but Love
   DJ Dan, Donald Glaude, DJ Utopia, DJ Surf, Tony, Derrick Carter,
   Galen. 415.905.4476 408.291.3243
   
   Friday, August 25th - Ambient Jungle Midnight Cruise
   top deck: Ismael & Co., reggae ambient dub. mid deck - special guests
   TBA. lower deck: Jason Walker, Moonpup, Nick Philip, Sean Murray.
   departs Pier 40 at midnight. advance tix $18 at Housewares and BPM.
   $25 at boat. 415.241.1560
   
   Friday, August 25th - Green
   Pumping Hypnotic Sound: Garth, Shon, Josh & Jeff Miller. Lasers &
   Visuals by Acropolis. 10pm-6am. 408.551.2813 510.464.5974 415.267.6998

   Friday, August 26th - Friction (The Trance Zone)
   DJs Trance, Barry Weaver, Tony, Ghost, & Minor Ivo Carol. 415.286.7570
   
   Thursday, August 31st - Monday, September 4th - Burning Man Festival
   will include a Wicked party. http://www.well.com/www/tcircus/Burnman
   http://www.lh.com/burn 415.985.7471
   
   Saturday, September 9th - Schwa is Happening
   Matthew Godfathar, Dan, Jon Bishop, Simon, Tony & introducing Rawl-E.
   415.436.0990 510.274.4100
   
   Saturday, September 30th - Cool World presents Cyberfest II

Radio/TV Shows 

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello everyone,

    Well I have to say, everything is coming along great for Friday 
night. Contrary to a little rumor, we DO still have our original 
beautiful outdoor location. We have a couple of changes that need to be 
addressed.
    
    First as some of you know, Dj Dan is booked for two parties for 
Friday night, (Harmony + Common Ground in Sac.) His intentions were to 
spin at Common Ground, then drive to Harmony and spin, then drive to 
the airport to catch a plane. (All in the same night!!!) While that all 
might be possible with his time frames, we don't think it is a good 
idea. We think it would put too much stress on us, Common Ground's 
promoters, and especially Dan! So it is on a sad note that we say, Dan 
will not be performing at Harmony on Friday. :( He will still be 
performing in Sac. at Common Ground. :) 

    On a happier note, we are pleased to say that we have booked a 
replacement. Filling in for Dj Dan will be Markie, (Thank you Markie!) 
All other Djs, performers, etc. are still booked and comfirmed. That 
includes the following:

----------------------------------------------------------------------

    Djs: Brandon (solid grooves)
         Trent
         Markie
         Graeme
         Ethan
         Galen
         James
              + Live   E.B.E. Audio (solid grooves recording artist)

    Visuals: Michael Clay   and   E.B.E. Video

    Lasers: Hollywood Dog

    Chill area: The Crew

    Free H2O
                (And yes, still) $10 (with a smile)
***********************************************************************
*    Also, we are working together with Greenpeace, to provide a free * 
*info booth at the party. There has been a lot of concerning stuff    * 
*brought to our attention, (via talking with them,) that we want to   * 
*pass on to you. So please take home some info that we have put our   * 
*own time and money into providing for you. It is really important    * 
*that we all get involved with saving our home, our planet.           *
***********************************************************************

Directions will be posted on the voice mail #'s on Friday (7-8pm)

        (408)486-9591           (408)450-3044

    The location is about five minutes off one of the major bay area 
freeways. (So it's easy to get to!) 
----------------------------------------------------------------------

    We have many surprises in store for you! Feel free to bring tents 
(if you want,) toys, and anything else you want! Be sure to stock up on 
energy, cause you're gonna need it! Also, bring your best smiles, and 
lots of hugging juice!!! 
    
    Until then keep smiling and keep the vibe alive!!!!

Peace, love, and harmony to all beautiful people!,

Greg

Ps. If you have any ?'s write to me or call the info lines!

sound system that we purchased and showcased last night at our Wednesday
weekly.  Which we put on for free last week.  Don't call us a rip off!  You
will probably be listening to it soon enough at one of our free parties,
and I still owe partial rent for August. We didn't just show up yesterday
to take the SF scene for all its worth.  I really shouldn't have to defend
Carlos and myself from this kind of onslaught.

When we first dicided to throw a big party we wanted it to be different.
We took 6 months to plan each one.  We put our heart and soul into it.
Were talking 100%.  There was nothing left to chance.  That's probably to
reason we don't get tagged.  people are too busy having fun.

So,  the next time you, Otis <steav@frodi.cs.uop.edu>, decide to talk shit,
make sure you were at the party you were thrashing.  If you were there I
might have been able to get some constuctive criticism.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: dutchcdc@slip.net (Dutch Starbuck)
Subject: Ear Drumin'
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The recent Cosmicbog party had an excellent sound system.  The reason for
the ringing in your ears is due to the reverberation of the sound off the
walls and ceiling.  You did notice that the main room was a basketball
court.  Do you remember the echo you used to hear in gym?  That is reverb.
Without something to kill the sound at the impact point, like foam, it will
always be there.

The only suggestion I might have is to find another space.

If anyone needs any special info, I might be able to help.  I also know a
lot of qualified people to ask.  eMail me at dutch@slip.net

dutch
CDC

From: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Matthew D. P. K. Lanier)
Subject: drumming
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all.  I'm really looking foreward to Harmony, tomorrow, (i'll go to
anything outside).  i've been bringing my drum ( a tabla ) to the last
couple raves and have spent much of the time drumming along to the whatever
grove happens to be going.  a couple of times, i've met other people there
who had percussion like shakers, bongos, or other drums, and we've had some
of the most intense drumming circles.  it seems to tap into the tribal
elements of rave music, and bring me into the community really fast and
really intensely.  Rather than focusing on the melody, which seems far to
linear for my tastes, drumming catches me into the groove and doesn't let go.
i'm asking any of you, who might be going to harmony tomorrow who have drums
or percussion to bring them.  i'll be walking around with a multiculored
tabla on a string.  please join me, and help make the rave experience better.

hope to see you all there

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier
vox 415-666-5659
pager 1-800-862-8577

peace behind us, around us, let all around us be peace."

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug 11 14:22:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA19373; Fri, 11 Aug 1995 14:22:38 -0700
Received: from MPLVAX.SRI.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA19362; Fri, 11 Aug 1995 14:22:34 -0700
Date:    Fri, 11 Aug 1995 14:21:10 PDT
From: HARTLEY@MPLVAX.SRI.COM
Message-Id: <950811142110.1f5f@MPLVAX.SRI.COM>
Subject: a fond farewell  
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Vmsmail-To: SMTP%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

about three months ago i came to san francisco.  i didn't know anyone,
didn't know what to expect, and didn't know where to go. 

since then i have been to the most absolutely amazing parties i have 
seen anywhere, met many of the people i know are the best in the world,
and generally had the greatest time of my life!
so i wanted to thank all of you who have made it so great.  from the 
tiny underground gatherings to the huge parties, the promoters, the
dj's, the people who do it because they love it, and mostly the people.
you are the nicest and brightest i have ever met.  and no other place, 
i mean anywhere, has a better vibe!  the only thing thicker is the fog!

i've been to parties on mountain sides, and parties on the beach.
i've danced in phat clubs, dusty parks, and sweaty lofts.
i've hugged, held hands and danced with people i'd never seen before
and probably never will again, and i've felt so high i thought my
feet would never reach the ground! 

this place is mystical.  magical!  and i hate that i have to leave, but
i have things to finish on the other coast.  so to all of you who have made
my stay so absolutely FANTASTIC thank you so much.  all of you.  those i
have really met and those i know only from cyberspace.  great big special
thanks to mike clay, diane tabellija, jake reichert, and sarvi for driving me
around wherever i _had_ to go every weekend.  you guys are the greatest!
thanks to jan, joe, brian, brian, tiff, patrick, alyssa, ... oh god, fukin 
everybody for being here and making it the place it is!  

but i could drag on forever, and i don't have much time left!  
my plane leaves on monday, and so i only have three more nights to enjoy!
catch y'all out there!   :)

Peace. Love. Unity. Respect.
Keep it alive!

seth

Precedence: bulk

I thought you folx down south might find this interesting!


>
>This is an article which was printed in the Vancouver Province today ...
>
>
>_____________________________________________________
>RAVE IS ABOUT TO CROAK, FEAR THE ORIGINALS
>It's (choke, sob, moan) gone mainstream
>
>
>The icons of the twentysomething crowd are doomed.
>
>Author Douglas Copeland has pronounced Generation X, the moniker he coined
>for the post-baby boom generation, dead.
>
>Grunge died last year, with the suicide of Nirvana's Kurt Cobain.
>
>Now another youthful phenomenon seems about to croak.  Purists say the
>all-night rave has - horrors! - gone mainstream.
>
>Those who witnessed the movement's birth in Canada are convinced the end is
>near for the raucous, clandestine, non-stop dance parties.
>
>"It was once 14 hours of pure energy.  Now, it's 14 hours of pure pain,"
>sighs Peter Scott, 23, a former rave promoter who revelled in Ontario's
>budding rave culture in the early 1990s.  "It's very upsetting to see it
>go."
>
>Scott says the rave scene blew its brinas out last month when 3,000 youths
>were at a racetrack outside Toronto for a three-day outdoor blowout billed
>as Destiny 10.
>
>Speakers the size of up-ended bungalows pounded out teeth-rattling dance
>tunes.  Billowing clouds of fake fog wafted through a dazzling "cyberbeam"
>light show as sweaty ravers milled around tents and a mobile "smart drink"
>bar.
>
>It was a great weekend bash but signs of decay were everywhere.
>
>The marathon rave featured, for example, a beer tent.  That's a sure sign
>of mainstream rot because raves have traditionally been alcohol-free.
>
>"Anything that's a subculture or part of the underground has to eventually
>become mainstream," says Scott.  "That's when the opportunists take it
>apart."
>
>Scott points the finger at Destiny promoter Ryan Kruger, a marketing
>student at York University.
>
>Rave isn't dying, just evolving, counters Kruger, 23.  "The people who have
>been throwing parties in the last year have really made a lot of effort
>towards providing a quality production.  It introduces a lot of new people
>to the scene.  It's still growing."
>
>Once a party gets rolling around 10 p.m., "old school" purists like Mathew
>Mulholland look with disdain at teen ravers who seem more concerned with
>fashion and drugs than music and dance.
>
>"It's a group of kids who haven't been exposed to anything besides rave
>culture," Mulholland says.  "They take it so damn seriously."
>
>Girls in pigtails, micro-miniskirts, bayby dolls and knee-high socks gyrate
>before guys in huge bowling shirts, bell-bottom jeans and retro Adidas
>sweat gear.
>
>Essentially, the girls are trying to look like eight-year-olds while the
>guys look like they belong on a whacked-out version of the Brady Bunch.
>Few are older than 18.
>
>Scott, pointing to a few wobbly waifs on the dance floor, says many are
>strung out on acid or the designer drug Ecstacy.
>
>The original ravers are sure the culture has been compromised and rave is
>headed for the grave.  Now they can only reminisce about the good old days.
>
>"The best days were spent in grungy warehouses where I was in the dark and
>it was cool," Scott says wistfully.  "There was this rampant loving that
>was going on.  Now, it just seems like people are cold.  They don't even
>look at you.  They're so screwed up that the communication is lost."
>
>
>
>
>

_______________________________________________________________________

        Ladies.  Gentlemen.  Shhh.  This is the way truth is.
          You've got to let those strange hands touch you.

_______________________________________________________________________

Subject: Newt supports Endangered Species Act ; opposes Republicans
Date: 11 Aug 1995 16:45:50 GMT
Message-Id: <2469199870.4871832@macshasta.com>
Organization: MacShasta Consulting
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

How Green is Gingrich?   copyright US News & World Report - 8/7/95

For the past several months, House Speaker Newt Gingrich has been meeting
informally with a star-studded group of scientists to discuss a wide range of
environmental issues, from ants to wetlands.  "The key is Gingrich is
interested in animals", says Harvard entomologist E.O. Wilson, a member of
the group, who points out that the speaker keeps a mold of Tyrannosaurus Rex
in his office.  Terry Maple, director of the Atlanta Zoo and a long-time
friend of Gingrich, helped organize the "zoo's who," which includes a
paleontologist Stephen J. Gould, entomologist Thomas Eisner and key members
of the Environmental Defense Fund.  They have already convinced Gingrich of
the ecological importance of smaller organisms, such as fungi and insects,
and may have influenced his decision to oppose Republican efforts to gut the
Endangered Species Act.  The group recently sent him a detailed brief on
disputes between environmentalists and private landowners.  On this issue,
Wilson says they want to serve as "honest brokers" in providing scientific
information and legislative options.  Adds Wilson: "I don't want to paint Mr.
Gingrich bright green, but I've been impressed by his quick, open mind."

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

On Thu, 10 Aug 1995, Dutch Starbuck wrote:

> The recent Cosmicbog party had an excellent sound system.  The reason for
> the ringing in your ears is due to the reverberation of the sound off the
> walls and ceiling.  You did notice that the main room was a basketball
> court.  Do you remember the echo you used to hear in gym?  That is reverb.
> Without something to kill the sound at the impact point, like foam, it will
> always be there.

There was no foam, but the plaster walls seemed to be 
absorbing quite a bit of the sound- which didn't affect how it sounded, 
but did lead to several rather large chunks of it plummeting to the 
floor, and that was before they even turned the lights off!  I was surprised 
the whole gym didn't just collapse with the rumbling bass provided by 
mu-siq :)

    Seth
<acid232dica>

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: drumming
To: "Matthew D. P. K. Lanier" <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199508110135.SAA09734@taz.hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9508121230.D22206-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> hello all.  I'm really looking foreward to Harmony, tomorrow, (i'll go to
> anything outside).  i've been bringing my drum ( a tabla ) to the last
> couple raves and have spent much of the time drumming along to the whatever
> grove happens to be going.  a couple of times, i've met other people there
> who had percussion like shakers, bongos, or other drums, and we've had some
> of the most intense drumming circles.  it seems to tap into the tribal
> elements of rave music, and bring me into the community really fast and
> really intensely.  Rather than focusing on the melody, which seems far to
> linear for my tastes, drumming catches me into the groove and doesn't let go.

The topic of drumming with electronic dance music has come up before, but 
I can't help but make another comment.  Drumming is wonderful, powerful, 
spiritual, tribal, and all that good stuff, but in combination with 
techno/house, it just makes the music sound like one continuous bad mix.  
It's great for the people drumming, but hell for the people 
trying to dance.  When the music already has tribal elements in it 
(bongos, etc), then it can work, but only with a REALLY good drummer.  Most 
drummers that I have been 
subjected to at raves have not quite been at that level.  Drummers are 
great in a chill out space, but not on the dance floor. Remember, techno 
is *supposed* to be linear and repetitive- this description was even used 
in England's Criminal Justice Bill to outlaw parties (i.e. gatherings 
around a "repetitive beat").  

But I digress...  Basically, it's very rare that any attempts by the 
audience to jam with the music does anything but annoy the people trying 
to dance.  I mean, is there anyone out there who actually enjoys whistles?!?
I didn't think so...

    Seth
<acid232dica>

BTW, the whistles at All Together Now were HORRRRRRENDOUS!!  Ugh.

law, although the excerpt is short enough that it might not be

that you reposted their copyrighted information here in any event.

Hello,

I'd have to say Harmony was one of the bestest, gosh darnest, funnest time i
had getin' down and dirty.  The people, the lights, the music, it all made
for a lovley evening in the moonlight.

It was a change of pace to have breakbeat and high tecno as opposed to the
trance and amiance one finds in the SF venues and it looked as if it brought
the firewalkers out on most of us..

I noticed a lot of newbies and first time ravers at this paticular event too
and it was nice to see that, as CYR put it, "they seem to be behaving
themselves".  A lot of the local ravers I saw too and a hearty "howdy" to
thoses that I didn't get to say hi to.


Smile O meter ratings:

         Vibes:    9 Smiles (the only drawback would be the speaker problems
@ round midnite)
Grins'n'hugs:   9 Smiles (The frendship ratings were once again on a high
note having met at least seven new people)
Dancing space: 9 Smiles (With a whole barn, who could go wrong...sorry for
kickin' up so much dust tho..)
Eye Candy:       10Smiles (for $10 the lazers, lights and neonish posters
werre more than enough for visual treats)
Thirst meter:  9.5 smiles (Free soda, you can't go wrong)

Overall   9.3Smiles  One of the strongest showings yet....

In ending, I must say I was really pleased to see people from other sound
systems show up to support this one and proving that the scene isn't about
 competition, but rater, us as a community supporting each other that will
keep us alive...

Adam

Recently, Adam ( Foustus@aol.com ) posted about Friday evening's Harmony -
> 
> I'd have to say Harmony was one of the bestest, gosh darnest, funnest time i
> had getin' down and dirty.  The people, the lights, the music, it all made
> for a lovley evening in the moonlight.

 For the time my wife Mary and I were there , we had a great time! I was
the guy wearing the Grateful Dead skull & roses/dancing skeleton t-shirt.

> 
> I noticed a lot of newbies and first time ravers at this paticular event too
> and it was nice to see that, as CYR put it, "they seem to be behaving
> themselves".  

 Lot's of folks went out of their way to greet & hug Mary , who I guess has
an earth motherly / mommy look to her. Folks I (literally) bumped into were
very nice and non-attitude.  

> 
> Smile O meter ratings:
> 
>          Vibes:    9 Smiles (the only drawback would be the speaker 
> problems  @ round midnite)

 I think some monitoring of mixer/amp levels would have helped at some
point - when we got there during Brandon's set at 9:30PM , the sound was
nice and crisp with punchy bass . I noticed that Brandon was keeping the
music peaks at the mixer down to a level where the red leds were just
being goosed . 

 My favorite aural memory was how the corrogated metal roof vibrated with
a hissing rattle on every bass beat - actually sounded good! ( I've been to
an event in an airplane hanger where the metal wall vibrations sounded
bad with the music ).

> Grins'n'hugs:   9 Smiles (The frendship ratings were once again on a high
> note having met at least seven new people)
> Dancing space: 9 Smiles (With a whole barn, who could go wrong...sorry for
> kickin' up so much dust tho..)

 Unfortunetly , I found out that I can't dance with horse poop dust swirling
about , it chokes up my throat! Harmony was the second time I've been exposed
to lots of dust in the presence of horses , and both times I've choked
up after about two hours. We left Harmony at about 12:30 AM - damn!

 Next time at that site - dust masks! 

> Eye Candy:       10Smiles (for $10 the lazers, lights and neonish posters
> werre more than enough for visual treats)
> Thirst meter:  9.5 smiles (Free soda, you can't go wrong)

 Are you talking about the warm soda in the tub ? Also - I didn't see any
obvious place for water, except two jugs on the left side of the stage,
no cups. If there was water at the site , it wasn't obvious - we brought
our own , so no problem for us two.
> 
> Overall   9.3Smiles  One of the strongest showings yet....
> 
 If my throat and lungs had held up , we would have stayed longer as well!

Larry & Mary / larryc@netcom.com
>
