From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler)
Subject: Harmony (2 Year)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,
    
    This is Greg from Harmony. Finally after getting some sleep last 
night I can muster up the energy to post! 

    I have to thank every single one of you that came out on Friday. 
You guys made that such a great party! I must admit, we didn't expect 
that many people. Every person there was so friendly and beautiful. I 
can never explain the feelings that we all got from this party. We were 
soooooo impressed with the way it turned out. It was like one of our 
past little parties, just magnified 3x. The vibe was still really 
strong, yet the party was kinda on the big side, (at least for us!) I 
was rather impressed with the "vibe per person ratio." (A little inside 
joke between the crew.) We could not have asked for a better 2 year 
party! So thanks again to everyone who came out!!!

    Now for those of you who called the voice mail after 12:15, we 
appologize. Like I said before, we didn't expect that many people, (or 
at least all at once!) So what happened was we ran out of parking, and 
had to shut down the voice mail. So sorry if you didn't get to make it. 

    Also, we would like to appologize for the hard core security. 
Everything was cool, until every single promoter in the bay area showed 
up and started harassing the owners of the ranch. After a while I guess 
the owners thought there was something bigger going on that night and 
started sketching. So they told security to tighten their grip on the 
party. (We told them to be leanient on everyone, and not to bust 
people. But the owners of the ranch had more pull with the security. :( 
) So that is why some of you might have gotten something taken away at 
the party. 

    On a happier note, for all those who are interested we didn't make 
any money, actually we came about a couple hundred dollars away from 
breaking even!! That's really good for that party. We put soooo much 
energy, time, and money into it. And it was worth every second, every 
dollar, and every bit of energy!!!! Thanks :) The total # of people for 
the night was around 1200. Which matched our budget of around $11,000. 
So including all of last weeks (last minute) equiptment purchases, and 
all other last minute expences, we broke even!! (Which was really 
suprising! Good too!!! :)

    There are a number of people I need to thank but it would take way 
too long. But you guys know who you are! So thank you! 

    In total, we will never forget that night. It was the best night of 
our lives! (Yes, I speak for everyone in the crew!) Thank you soooo 
much!!!! We love you!!!!

Peace, love, and harmony to all beautiful people!!!!,

Greg 

Ps. Yee Ha!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Precedence: bulk

hello all, especially seth, who took the time and energy to disagree with
me.  that's cool.
i've never become annoyed by a drummer at a rave b4, and have seen many
drums, from tablas to bongos, shakers to rattles.  for me, it all depends
how you want to interface with the music.  as a musician, i live with music,
and i love hearing a great piece of music and being with it, playing along
with it, having it contribute to me as i contribute to it.  if your way of
being with the music is by dancing,  cool.  if your way is with whistles,
cool.  if your way is by sitting and chilling, cool.  none of us have the
right or responsibility to discourage others from their own way of raving.
we're all raving with each other, not just individually raving with the dj
and the music.


thanks for expressing ya'self, man

be

matt


on saturday( i think) seth wrote -
 
>The topic of drumming with electronic dance music has come up before, but 
>I can't help but make another comment.  Drumming is wonderful, powerful, 
>spiritual, tribal, and all that good stuff, but in combination with 
>techno/house, it just makes the music sound like one continuous bad mix.  
>It's great for the people drumming, but hell for the people 
>trying to dance.  When the music already has tribal elements in it 
>(bongos, etc), then it can work, but only with a REALLY good drummer.  Most 
>drummers that I have been 
>subjected to at raves have not quite been at that level.  Drummers are 
>great in a chill out space, but not on the dance floor. Remember, techno 
>is *supposed* to be linear and repetitive- this description was even used 
>in England's Criminal Justice Bill to outlaw parties (i.e. gatherings 
>around a "repetitive beat").  
>
>But I digress...  Basically, it's very rare that any attempts by the 
>audience to jam with the music does anything but annoy the people trying 
>to dance.  I mean, is there anyone out there who actually enjoys whistles?!?
>I didn't think so...
>
>    Seth
><acid232dica>
>
>BTW, the whistles at All Together Now were HORRRRRRENDOUS!!  Ugh.
>
>


matthew d. p. k. lanier

Well I haven't been to a sunset party in about a month.  
This was as usual (for sunset) a GREAT party!  It seemed like the vibe just 
got thicker as the party went on. 
Nice sized crowd.  Didn't take long for the new # to get around.  I think 
the new # helped the party be a bit more underground helping give the 
party a bit more of a "ravier" vibe.  
Just as I was getting my things together the police showed up with from 
what i saw about 7 cars with their sirens flashing.  This brought a loud 
roar from the crowd obviously enjoying their light show.  This was a bit 
past 9:30, over the parks closing time.  I didn't wait around long to see 
the interaction as the cops got out of there cars.  I guess everyone left 
smoothly with no hassle given the beautiful vibe when I left.  
I just hope staying past the park closing time didn't hurt using that 
space again.  
Much thanks to the pacific crew,
and everyone else for helping make the party what it was.
 
:)
peter

Hi folks -

 Since Stanford radio station KZSU is playing such nice stuff 
on Tuesdays , I've decided to move the South Bay Lunch day
to Tuesday , ( from Wednesday ). Same time and location,
as described below. 

 Bring your brown bag or lunch pail - hope to see you there!

     Larry

--------------------------------------------------------------

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Tuesday, depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Tuesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 14 12:29:46 1995

        id AA13253 for ; Mon, 14 Aug 95 15:01:32 -0400
From: barnoc@presage.com (Brian Salter)
Reply-To: barnoc@presage.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: drumming
Date: 14 Aug 1995 11:48:38 GMT
Message-Id: <61406.10109015@presage.com>
Organization: Presage Software Development Co.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On saturday the 12th seth wrote:

>Drumming is wonderful, powerful, 
>spiritual, tribal, and all that good stuff, but in combination with 
>techno/house, it just makes the music sound like one continuous bad mix.  
>It's great for the people drumming, but hell for the people 
>trying to dance.

On sunday the 13th Matthew wrote:

>i've never become annoyed by a drummer at a rave b4, and have seen many
>drums, from tablas to bongos, shakers to rattles.  for me, it all depends
>how you want to interface with the music.

As a musician, I like to hear live playing and would always like to see
more of it at raves.  However, like Seth, I very often been annoyed 
by drummers while I dance.  This is not because I find them unwelcome or
inappropriate in the setting, but mainly because the live drumming was 
just not grooving very well with the records.  To be specific, it tends 
to be rhythmically inaccurate and lagging behind the beat.  I hope I'm 
not raining on anyone's parade, but I think it takes a lot of experience
and really focused energy to play along with house or techno in a way 
that adds to the music.  (especially if there are finicky ears around :) )

If someone gets fulfillment and enjoyment from drumming, that's a 
wonderful thing.  But when playing in public, it's not enough just to 
satisfy yourself...you have to do it for everyone around you.  So, my 
advice to any / all drummers is: concentrate, be creative, observe the 
people dancing around you, and most of all STAY ON TOP OF THE BEAT!!! 
(that means, don't get lazy).  Even the best musicians need to remember
these things.  I worked on a studio project this summer with a Brazilian 
percussionist who started playing in samba bands when he was 6 years old, 
and has since played all over the world with all sorts of famous types, and 
even *he* needed occasional prodding when his playing got a little off.
So don't get discouraged, anyone.  Just remember that behind the spirit
and magic of music there is also a lot of brains and sweat.

end of sermon

thanks for listnin'

-Brian

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 31 Jul 1995 22:34:44 -0600 (MDT)
From: kevin john geiger <geigerk@ucsu.colorado.edu>

Hello all,

 Exxon Corporation has set up/paid for a 1-800 line to contact US
 Senators.  It is under the auspice of a group that wants to refine the
 environmental laws and the regulatory tendency of US environmental
 policy.  The thing to remember is that EXXon is paying.  Anyway, a small
 group in Boulder has been trying to get this number out to the other
 side, if Exxon is providing we shall take.  They pay the bill but the
 caller is simply connected to the office of a US Senator.


1)  Dail 1-800-444-1555
2)  They will give you a short recorded message.
3)  Follow instructions if you have a touch tone phone, public ones work
 best and they have other advantages.  :
4)  Enter a zip code...they ask for yours but it doesn't have to be...it can

 be any in the US.
5)  Make a choice of the elected politician's office you want to be
 connected to. 
6)  When the staff person answers you are set to discuss the proposed
 environmental reform regulations, OR ANY OTHER ISSUE YOU WANT!

Couple of tricks...we found they limit the number of calls to 3 from each
 number.  Solution:  public phones are everywhere...enjoy Exxon's
 corporate attempt to influence "grassroots democracy"

Kevin

     Recently I've been staying away from most circuit parties and digging 
     into smaller, more intimate gatherings.  This weekend provided much 
     opportunity to experience more of this.  Among the experiences, I had 
     the opportunity to meet Kevin and Tristan and check out the house of 
     Mirrors.  
     
     I don't know if any other sfravers were there on Saturday but I had a 
     great time.  To me, it was a place where pretense and judgement were 
     absent and we were open and accepting of who we were and why we were 
     there...as a group and as individuals.  I was grateful that the 
     growing clubbiness I've seen recently was nowhere in sight.  (Hmmm, 
     this last sentence reminds me of Karen's post about mainstream raves.)
     
     Pollywog and James(?) (from Oklahoma/Kansas or whatever wheatland 
     place he came from) were terrific dj's.  James (as I'll dub him for 
     now) has been here about a month and certainly knows how to bring 
     people out on the floor with his music.  I can see him developing into 
     quite a thing as he knows how to work a crowd through his 
     music...something I haven't seen enough of these days.  And it's nice 
     to see that both he and Pollywog have a diverse taste in spinning--not 
     just staying within a particular genre.  James' talent will be a great 
     addition to the scene and I look forward to seeing him play again.
     
     Pollywog's second set was the shit.  If I can give it a name, trip-hop 
     comes to mind as I wound myself into a heavy trance state only to want 
     to hold my head as my brain went on overload with her music.  
     Stringing us out with pregnant pauses, I didn't know what to expect.  
     A definite delight to the senses.  This was the first time I heard 
     either dj and I was impressed...perhaps it was the vibe or the size of 
     the party and/or my state of mind, but whatever happened "it was all 
     good".
     
     Mmmm, didn't make it to Sunset :{ in the past two weeks due to other 
     committments but I'm glad to hear of the changes->growth->evolution.
     
     Looking forward to meeting and seeing people at F&F soon!
     
     Sunshiny love,
     Diane
     
     P.S.  Kevin K. I've got something you left in my car.  Contact me so 
     we can connect.  Oh, and Tristan, please pass along my compliments to 
     the dj's and give me James' real name, please.?!

Hey all,
 
Over the weekend some friends had a bad experience on what they thought 
was E. Their E was actually herion. After reading a little bit about the 
affects, as well as talking with others who have experienced it before, I 
came to the  conclusion that what they took this weekend was herion.
	What I was wondering for them, and for others, is what are the 
effects while you are on it? How do you feel when you come down? How long 
do the effects last? I heard that it can stay in your body for a few days 
and that it takes a while to feel normal again. What emotional affects do 
you feel? What causes the addiction to the drug? What physical affects 
are there? I've checked the 
archives on hyperreal but they do not address my specific questions.  
	Awhile back there was thread on brown stuff in E, and many 
concluded that the brown stuff was not herion. Well, my friends claimed 
that what they took was in tablet form and was dirty brown.

	Can anybody shed some light on the subject? Suggested reading?

Concerned,

dhouse

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 14 16:04:00 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA04415; Mon, 14 Aug 1995 16:04:00 -0700

	id PAA09185; Mon, 14 Aug 1995 15:36:29 -0700

Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: drumming 
In-reply-to: Your message of "14 Aug 95 11:48:38 GMT."
             <61406.10109015@presage.com> 
Date: Mon, 14 Aug 95 15:36:23 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> tends to be rhythmically inaccurate and lagging behind the beat.

well a good drummer is a good drummer and a bad drummer is bad -- you
just hear it. You don't need to be a musician to decide if something's
got a groove. In fact, being "on the beat" may very well be the sign of
a BAD drummer. Cuz funk, swing, or jazz is definitely not played "on
the beat".

If I want "on the beat" I'll get a metronome or drum machine. THe
purpose of a drummer is to do things that a machine can't.

Now if what you mean is "arrythmia" (aka the inability to keep the
beat), now that's a different matter entirely.

Most of the conga players I've heard (e.g. at come/unity a while back)
were *great*, they played rhythmically, but infused it with enough
funk to make it interesting.

> To be specific, it tends 
> to be rhythmically inaccurate and lagging behind the beat.  I hope I'm 

Some  house music puts a hi-hat lagging behind the beat. Kinda gives it
that chugging feeling. It's done that way for a reason, because
otherwise you wouldn't be dancing to it. Similarly, the whole effect of
jazz is from swinging the bass line behind the beat. So I think you
need to be careful in dissing "lagging" because funk would never exist
without it.

So to me, a drummer can make boring, repetitive quantized-down-into-
16th-note-with-4-bar-repeating-pattern-techno funky and interesting.
(Not that all techno is boring, but there is a lot of not so intersting
beats that a drummer can help with...)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Electronic Musician mag this month has an excellent extended section on 
how to do various different drumming styles electronically.  Niels is right --
there is far more subtlety and complexity there than you might think.  The
most boring thing in the world is a precisely perfect beat.

phred

right now. seek peace in the things that are always there, even when the 
people around you are not.

	-the beautiful white sparkle that plays on the ocean water 
	-the feel of the sunshine on your skin on a good day 
	-the ability to dance just for the hell of it (when other people are 
not so lucky) 
	-some stranger smiling at you when you least expect it. 
	(like i'm doing right now- sending you a ray of blue light) 
 
=) 
lulu-bean

On monday the 14th Niels wrote:
>well a good drummer is a good drummer and a bad drummer is bad -- you
>just hear it. You don't need to be a musician to decide if something's
>got a groove. In fact, being "on the beat" may very well be the sign of
>a BAD drummer. Cuz funk, swing, or jazz is definitely not played "on
>the beat".

and phred wrote:
 >The most boring thing in the world is a precisely perfect beat.

Thanks for the feedback...I have to say that I am *very* well aware of
these things.  Having spent years playing non-electronic music (including 
jazz and swing--I'm a sax player, FYI) before I ever touched a synthesizer 
or drum machine, I find precisely perfect beats just as annoying as you guys 
do.  I've spent hours with sequences nudging notes this way and that out of
their computer-precise places to try to make electronic music that feels more
 human.   So, I think I was a little misunderstood...
I should have been clearer and simply said that I just don't want to have
to endure BAD drummers.  There is a big difference between drummers who
play around the beat because they know their shit and drummers who lag  
through lack of skill or focus.

>Most of the conga players I've heard (e.g. at come/unity a while back)
>were *great*, they played rhythmically, but infused it with enough
>funk to make it interesting.

I guess I've not had as good luck as you in hearing the better conga 
players around...
so, your words are encouraging...

>You don't need to be a musician to decide if something's
>got a groove.

I agree wholeheartedly with that.
  
--Brian

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 12 Aug 1995 08:07:28 -0400

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 12 Aug 1995 00:27:45 -5
From: Adam Mackler <mackler@panix.com>
To: nyc-raves@netcom.com
Subject: NYC OFFICIALS TARGET RAVES: EQUIPMENT TO BE CONFISCATED.

ALL-NIGHT TEEN `RAVES' ARE FIRETRAPS, NYC OFFICIALS SAY
Dayton Daily News (DA) - SUNDAY, August 6, 1995
By: Dave Saltonstall NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
Edition: CITY  Section: NEWS  Page: 4A
Word Count: 411

TEXT:
NEW  YORK  -  To  the  kids who attend, they are known as raves - all-night
dance  parties  that move mysteriously into the city's abandoned warehouses
or lofts  for one night, like tremendous floating clubs, and then move on.

But  to  New  York  City fire officials, these raves have come to look like
something  else  -  the  city's  latest  firetraps, filled with hundreds of
partying youngsters reveling in typically unsafe, uninspected buildings.

    ``They're  Happy  Lands  waiting  to  happen,'' said Chief Fire Marshal
Michael  Vecchi,  referring to the 1990 Bronx social club blaze that killed
87  people.  ``And right now these raves are happening every weekend in the
city.''
   Exactly  where,  though,  is another question, since many rave promoters
make  a point of keeping their parties a secret until the last minute - and
even  then  leading  followers  on  a treasure hunt-like search to find the
exact  location.

   The  end  of  the  line is often a little-used office, loft or warehouse
where  the  determined  find  an  amazing  array  of  lights,  speakers and
throbbing  techno  music  -  but  rarely a sprinkler system or any properly
lighted  exit signs, say fire officials, who began targeting the rave scene
last spring.

   Since  May,  the city has closed at least six major raves in a crackdown
by  the  Fire  Department's  Social Club Task Force, set up after the Happy
Land  disaster.  In  most  cases, the spaces were jammed with at least four
times as  many people as they were built to accommodate.

   ``We are just trying to send a message to the promoters by maintaining a
presence,'' said Ken Gorecki, the task force's supervising fire marshal.

   Alan  Sax,  one  of  the city's preeminent rave promoters and producers,
said  the  Fire  Department's crackdown serves only to drive the rave scene
further  underground.  As proof, he said, there had been at least two major
raves  in  Manhattan  with  more  than 2,000 people at each in the last two
months.

   ``And the Fire Department had no clue what was going on,'' said Sax, who
defends raves as healthy, multicultural gatherings.

   One  problem,  fire officials say, is that the only charge many of these
rave  producers  have  had  to  face  is  criminal  nuisance, a misdemeanor
carrying  a  small  fine.  But  officials  are exploring using civil law to
confiscate  expensive stereo and lighting equipment.

   ``If  the  disc  jockeys  find  out  that  they  stand to lose all their
equipment  if they don't comply, they might be a little more hesitant to be
complicitous  in this,'' said Vecchi.

                Copyright (c) 1995, Dayton Newspapers Inc.

DESCRIPTORS:  NEW YORK CITY; RAVES; FIRETRAPS
plicitous  in this,'' said Vecchi.

                Copyright (c) 1995, Dayton Newspapers Inc.

DESCRIPTORS:  NEW YORK CITY; RAVES; FIRETRAPS

At 03:53 PM 8/14/95 -0700, Dave Foust wrote:
>Hey all,
> 
>Over the weekend some friends had a bad experience on what they thought 
>was E. Their E was actually herion. After reading a little bit about the 
>affects, as well as talking with others who have experienced it before, I 
>came to the  conclusion that what they took this weekend was herion.

Oh God, here we go again...
E is not cut with heroin. First of all it would me no sense since heroin
goes for something like $150/g. Secondly heroin is not very active when
taken oraly in such small doses (as in a pill).

>	What I was wondering for them, and for others, is what are the 
>effects while you are on it? How do you feel when you come down? How long 
>do the effects last? I heard that it can stay in your body for a few days 
>and that it takes a while to feel normal again. What emotional affects do 
>you feel? What causes the addiction to the drug? What physical affects 
>are there? I've checked the 
>archives on hyperreal but they do not address my specific questions. 

E is supposed to get you FUCKED UP just like heroin (well, sort of). I have
had many different types of high while on E and im sure it has do with alot
of things (dosage, surroundings, combinations with other drugs, etc).
 
>	Awhile back there was thread on brown stuff in E, and many 
>concluded that the brown stuff was not herion. Well, my friends claimed 
>that what they took was in tablet form and was dirty brown.

The brown stuff is probably caused by imcomplete systhesis of the safrole
oil used to make MDMA (its brown). The best way to tell if your capsule of
powder is the real shit is if it smells like liquorice

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 14 21:44:52 1995

In-Reply-To: barnoc@presage.com (Brian Salter)
        "Re (2):drumming" (Aug 14,  6:10pm)
References: <961998814.11462510@presage.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: barnoc@presage.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Re (2):drumming
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wasn't referring directly to your posting, Brian.  Any good drummer
knows how to lead or lag the beat and still basically 'be on the One.'
I've heard a couple of live drummers at 1015 lately who really added
a lot to the sound in the main room.

The biggest problem is that the most experienced drummers (hand, trap
or whatever) don't know about the rave/house/techno/whatever scene
hardly at all.  There's just no cultural connecting point for a lot
of them, in part because the scene is so recording-oriented and live
musicians like to play, well, live.  I think there is definitely room
for more fluid and interactive combinations of DJs and live musicians.
I mean, like duhhhh, that's what hip hop has really been all about
all along.  

In general, this goes with my current theme, which is it's time to tear
down the walls again.  Derrick Carter reminisced in an interview I saw
about how when house first blew up in Chicago in the 1980s, people mixed
that up with Talking Heads and all other kinds of stuff.  Doc Martin told
me about the early days in SF circa 1987 when he was just getting started,
playing in little hole in the wall clubs mixing wailing diva house with
Led Zeppelin and everyone going off in a big way.  

We've all become too category-bound, in my view, me included.

c u
phred

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

At 3:53 PM 8/14/95, Dave Foust wrote:
>Hey all,
>
>Over the weekend some friends had a bad experience on what they thought
>was E. Their E was actually herion. After reading a little bit about the
>affects, as well as talking with others who have experienced it before, I
>came to the  conclusion that what they took this weekend was herion.
        Hmmm..the eternal question ;) well, from my reading, and my
observations of tests done on street drugs in London and Amsterdam, NONE
have come up with heroin in them.  That, naturally, doesn't necessarily
mean anything. BUT, from my reading (Saunders "e for ecsatasy" and parts of
shulgin's PIKHAL and other 'scientific' reports i've seen a similarity
between what ppl call 'smacky e' and things like MDA, MDEA and other
things. Consider: was the subject feeling 'clear headed'? Were they feeling
drained or confused or disoriented? This could be either from MDA, MDEA or
even a Ketamine/speed combination.
        The other part of this question is that, in my opinion at least,
the effects of anything that are ingested are not objectively measureable
all the time. They synergize with 'you' and that takes into it both
neurochemistry as well as your own subjective disposition in general as
well as your 'mind set.'
        As far as my readings as well i haven't found MDMA to be labelled
as 'physically addictive' but i also think that the body and the mind
aren't so distinct from each other so there may be some kind of addiction
that may be psychological which may, in turn, create a physical craving.
>        Awhile back there was thread on brown stuff in E, and many
>concluded that the brown stuff was not herion. Well, my friends claimed
>that what they took was in tablet form and was dirty brown.
        Also, from my readings, this brown stuff is only impurities that
arise when a part of the creation process is ended too soon. Dunno, i'll
have to look this up again.
        most of all, DON'T JUST LISTEN TO ME! i'm just an art school grad
that likes to hypothesize and read a lot! :) i'd suggest Saunder's "e for
ecstasy" and Shulgin's PIHKAL and, though i haven't been able to find it
here, Bruce Eisner's book. These are the big three to my knowledge. There
is also a book (again, that i haven't been able to find) called "pathway to
the heart" which i would be interested in hearing about (through private
email if necessary).
        overall, i just want to say that get a lot of opinions from a
variety of sources and especially don't just listen to dumb (but well
intentioned) artists with too much time on their hands ;)
        peace,
                brad

!   ---------   the past, or hostages to the future. -Hakim Bey  ----------  ?

It might be my imagination, but the DJing at Sunset seems to be
getting better and better.  I thought Kevin, Galen, Gavin and
Solar all were right on this time around.  Nice crowd.  No one "did 
the fish", but we got to see Niels and David Minuk do the bee dance
instead.  And this is was probably the 3rd Sunset in a row that
the Captain managed to crush Janie's foot on the dance floor - but
she's gotten quite used to that now, so it's OK.  :)

I suppose most have heard that United with its amazing DJ lineup
at the Trocadero got busted Sat. nite at 1:30am.  A major bummer.
There were supposedly noise complaints even after turning the
volume down, to no avail.  The troc, of course kept the full $5000,
and displayed (so I hear) their usual fucked up attitude toward the
promoters and partiers.  There were no refunds.  This is second hand
info, so my facts may be off.

On drumming: very occasionally I've heard a live percussionist who added
something worthwhile to the DJ's art.  Mainly, I prefer music that takes me 
*beyond* the limits imposed by our sloppy protoplasmic origins.  I don't
mind a human feel as long it's sampled, looped, and tweaked to an altered
state.  Sure, as a musician I enjoy playing.  But as a trance-dancer,
drum machines and looped samples work best for me.  I won't even mention
whistles.

Glad Harmony went off, looking forward to F&F. :)

Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

At 9:14 AM 8/15/95, Sean wrote:
>Thanks everybody for the positive energy! I'm really going through the
>hardest times of my life and your mail has made me feel alot better!
>
>Thanks again everybody!
>
>
>
>
>
>-Sean
> "House Music All Night Long"

        you know what? i think that, for me at least, this is the ESSENCE
of what raving is about.  Mutual security.  A net of support.  People to
empathize with your struggles, to offer you advice, support, a helping
hand, a sense that you are never 'alone' in an otherwise inimical world, a
bridge across the gulf of alienation that our society cuts into us.  The
amount of energy that i get from just reading posts on here that aren't
even directed at me is amazing, almost too amazing because you can end up
depending on it and forgetting the 'real world' which is the danger that
i'm facing right now, living too vicariously, turning here when all of my
friends are leaving the city.  Yes, we are all responsible for the
happiness in our own lives, we can't rely on other people ALL the time but
knowing that when things get rough for people like sean and matthew and i
and probably a lot of you right now, that you can reach out and ask for
help and there WILL be people there.  Pulling yourself up by your own
bootstraps is a difficult thing, so when you can get that little boost
(even if it's only ascii and not even necessarily a reflection of the
person's 'real' behaviour) you can get on with your life and struggle
through the darkness with a bit more confidence and wait for the dawn to
break.
        well..IMHO at least :)
        peace,
                brad

Precedence: bulk

	Real quick post.  As a professional chemist (of the legal variety),
my take on the brown E thing:  it's impure.  Almost all organic compounds 
-- which E is one of -- ARE WHITE SOLIDS.  If it's not powdery and white,
the stuff wasn't manufactured properly, and more likely is contaminated with
something (a byproduct of its manufacture, NOT smack) that may or may not
necessarily be bad for your health. Keep in mind, that depending on what
process the chemist was using, there could be any number of things in
there, including mecury.  All this comes from having inexperienced
chemists working with suboptimal equipment and materials.  Take at your own
risk.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------
= 		    Steve Boyer (sboyer@violet.berkeley.edu)		     =
------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hey, folks! I just finished making my plans for 
Burning Man! Yea!

I'll be in (via flying) to Las Vegas on Wednesday, the 30th, 
and staying the night there. I've rented a 4x4 with 
which I'll go to the Manaflame fest. I'm returning to Reno 
then SJ in the afternoon on Monday, the 4th. Should anyone 
like to meet up in Las Vegas, at the festival, or in Reno, 
please let me know. Also, if anyone in LV _OR_ in Reno (no great pain 
to swing by there) needs a ride to the fest, or from the fest to 
Reno, again please ask. 

I only request that you bring enough water for yourself if you want to 
take me up on my offer.

The car-rental reservationist thought I was going on a whirlwind 
casino tour; I thought it best not to tell her of the meta-gamble 
that is Burning Man!

giddily-

Jocelyn

p.s. for anyone who cannot go- I'd be happy to make any offering, 
recitation, incantation, bizarre act (within personal boundaries),
etc... in your stead and report back on how it was given/received 
upon my return.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: plan
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I offer my apologies in advance if this is inappropriate
(if it is, please let me know, though...)

Hey all! Me and some other folk were wondering about what to expect 
weather-wise, temperature-wise, condition-wise, etc... in 
an attempt to ascertain the must-haves and must-plan fors- with the aim 
of planning what to bring. would one of you Bman-experienced folk 
review my checklist please? 

I will undoubtedly be the mother hen of the group I'll be with-
especially in the planning arena.

Here's what I plan to expect: anything.
Here's what I'm going to bring with that expectation in mind:

a tent- I might bring my own, though it's this incredibly 
old 3 person thing. From what I've heard, it's most likely 
that I'll want to take the tent down (pull the main pole/or
X-bar structure) during the day, so that the wind won't 
wreak havoc on it. Then get it back up before nightfall. True?
I'll know for sure whether I'm bringing my own or renting 
when I get a final head count from some lagger friends of mine 
who I also happen to love

There are two decent ways to secure a tent in sand/sandy soil-
one- instead of staking the ties into the ground, secure them 
with rocks (big ones) two- place your heaviest gear around the 
perimeter of the tent on the inside- I'm not really sure how loose 
the soil is- so I've no way of knowing if I should pack rocks????
and leave the stakes at home???

sleeping bags: mine are -20; so, I'll also bring some top sheets 
in case it's too hot for my afternoon catnap ;)

sunscreen & a hat or two, a long sleeved, light colored, cotton
sun shirt and one pair of lightweight cotton pants or a very long
skirt for full sun cover.

flashlight(s)-  at least one per person, more 
if I've got them. 

one pair jeans/one heavy wool sweater, and some kind of in-between 
jacket or sweatshirt, a tee-shirt, shorts, and swimsuit (I hear there 
are some hot springs nearby- tho I'm sure clothing is optional at 
the entire festival, hot springs included)

one towel per person

my first aid kit to which I'll add- more aspirin, solarcaine, a 
big, thick needle and some dental floss (for stitches, which I'm 
probably too wimpy to actually use), superglue (also for stitches, my 
preferred method) and duct tape (for tent rips), latex gloves, ear plugs

a tarp and some fold-up poles with which to erect it- the tarps I have 
double as rain gear- rectangular rain ponchos with a hood.

a compass,  but I've no idea how to use 
one- so, lotta good that'll do me! But if you're in the know-
definitely bring it! maybe you can teach me?!

toys: hand held instruments, something from which recorded music
can be played on batteries (boom box), cards & probably backgammon,
my camera

my small pilot stove & some cookware

things I'll pick up in Vegas:

food, fuel for the stove (i don't think I want to bring fuel 
on board the airplane- I'm going to call the airline and ask about this), 
cooler(s), water (1-2 gallons per person per day), some candle devices,
a few bottles of some decent Cabarnet and other such acoutrement
maybe some wood if I can find some in Vegas...

The one thing i'm totally in the dark about- how to mark the campsite 
so that i can find it at night??? The only idea I've had so far is 
finding some glow in the dark paints and bringing a white sheet along-
using the daytime tarp poles to hold this up at night. That aside, 
paying a good deal of attention in the daytime when we first arrive/
choosing camp carefully next to a visible/recognizable structure. 
This is one of my primary worries for the whole trip. 
any ideas???

Un abrazo fuerte!

Jocelyn

p.s. are snakes a concern? if so, what kind? what about lechegilla?
other noxious plant life? thanks again :)

So I hear about this blurb somebody wrote about an event in Barcelona,
Spain, where Underground Resistance was on the bill.  The writer has
his head up his arse, and didn't check his facts or willingly lied.

Underground Resistance was not scheduled for a live show.  It was a DJ
assault only.  They were delayed due to weather in Detroit, and missed
the connecting flight out of New York.  They tried every optional
airline, no flights.  They called the promoter, who suggested that they
send just Suburban Knight on the Concord (at an outrageous rate).  SK
went, played a good set, and came home as normal.  The promoter was
happy, and they are planning additional events with UR.

In the article in Musik, the writer makes it out that UR was scheduled
to play live and that they demanded the Concord for their flights.
This is such bullshit for anyone who knows Mad Mike and the UR guys.
These are the guys who are going to be going to the middle of a forest
2+ hours outside of San Francisco, asking only that their plane tickets
are covered, and maybe some pork n beans and some pepsi.

I expected so much more from Ben Turner.  I hope he tightens up his
editorial control.

some people complained they couldn't get through to the web site for
burning man info. It's actually a problem with the WELL being overloaded
with requests, so keep on trying http://www.well.com/user/burnman/

In the meantime, here's a bunch of pages from the web site that I'm cutting
and pasting in here to give you some info. No cool pictures though.

==============================================================================
The
                         Burning Man
                         Festival
                         1995

                         Now in its tenth year, Burning Man is a
                         unique annual celebration held in the high
                         desert wilderness of Northern Nevada. Over
                         the course of a long weekend, a temporary
                         community is established on the largest flat
                         expanse of land in North America, a small
                         city complete with its own radio stations,
                         daily newspaper, community centers and
                         civic monuments. Three days of art, music,
                         dance, and performance climax in the ritual
                         destruction by fire of a four-story human
                         effigy known as the Burning Man. This
year's festival will take place over Labor Day weekend, August 31st -
September 4th, 1995, and is expected to draw 2,500 participants. 

Registration and Contact Information
     Check it out if you're interested in attending, if you have anything to
     contribute to this site, or if you maintain a site of your own that
     includes Burning Man-related material.
==============================================================================

What It Is

            The Burning Man Festival

         1995

We all suffer from
partial fires caught
somewhere within
us, literally trapped
in one's gut or one's
groin, one's heart,
or one's head. The
Burning is a fire
that flows fully
through us.


         Larry Harvey



     In the desert there are as many paths to heaven as there are stars
     in the sky.

                                    Danger Ranger


Here we present perspectives on the festival. If you have some work bearing
on the Burning Man that you would like to publish here, please let us know.

     Out There...
     by Darryl Van Rhey

              Dreaming Burning Man

                       The Burning Man FAQ

==============================================================================

Burning Man 1995

                     Burning Events

         "One big
         cascading
         mass of
fire, reckless luxury,
the risk that makes you
richer. Something huge
comes to life when that
Man is ignited. A
grand extravagant
gambler's god,
Barbarian King of the
Real American Desert.
We're burning up our
fortune, all together saying, 'We can afford to lose. Pull the handle. Take a
shot.'"
Al Cacophony

This area features notices of events related to the Burning Man Festival and
performances of artist-participants in the festival. This area also features
more information about the performances and performers in the desert. We
hope to bring you a live feed from the desert to this area during the festival
itself.

Up-coming Events: 
     A Benefit for the Bands: August 25th & 26th
     at Bottom of the Hill in San Francisco 

              Coming to a Playa Near You: 
                  Events and attractions: 
                  The preliminary rundown 

==============================================================================

Welcome to

            The Burning Man Gallery

         1995


There is no single
interpetation of this
event. It is a unique
product of our
postmodern age;
pluralistic and complex,
skeptical and yet
completely
open-minded. Only by
direct participation,
through one's own
unique involvement can any answer be found.




     Some see the event as performance art between audience and
     performers...For others the event has a spiritual significance: a
     revival of "primitive" rituals that contemplate the
     interdependence of death and life in the cycle of nature, a
     sacrificial tribute to the all-sustaining, all-consuming power of
     the sun. At any rate, the days leading up to the ritual burning are
     reminiscent of a mystery pagent: full of torchlight parades,
     sacred dances, masking and holy revelry.

                                    Richard Washburn


Here we present the graphical perspectives of the participants of the festival.
If you have some work bearing on the Burning Man that you would like to
show here, please let us know.

     Video Imagery
     by Bill Knowland

                       Photography 
                       by George Post, Stewart Harvey, and
                       Tyree-Lynch
==============================================================================

Burning Man 1995

              Media Resource Center

         Over the years, Burning Man has
         received quite a lot of media
         coverage. This area is designed as a
central archive for this information as well as
a resource for journalists who wish to research
the event's history and background.

Important note to journalists: The Burning
Man Project welcomes press coverage on the
condition that participating journalists and
their crews do nothing to interfere with
anyone's immediate experience on the Playa.
Media representatives are expected to register
as participants ("No Spectators") and strongly
encouraged to camp on the Playa and become
part of the community. For more information
about media terms and conditions, or to
request press credentials, contact Project
Director Larry Harvey or call the Burning Man Hotline.

Featured Article:
     Michael Sion, Reno Gazette-Journal
     Sept. 6, 1994

              Playing With Fire: 
                  An Interview with Larry Harvey

                           Fire on the Playa: 
                                Stuart Mangrum on Burning Man

==============================================================================

Burning Man 1995

                      PARTYcipate

                                        Burning Man Needs
                                        You!

The Burning Man Project does not
merely need volunteers. It is
volunteers. Beginning with two
people in 1986, it has survived and
grown because individuals have come
forward to contribute their time,
skills, and resources. Anyone may
become a member of the Project if
they are willing to do something.
Ours is a supremely activist
community. All positions are unpaid.



WHERE WE NEED HELP: 

The following is a list of areas in
which we need help. If you want to
assist us, please call our HOTLINE.
Specify the task you would like to
perform and we'll refer you directly
to the appropriate organizer. Many
tasks will require no more than 3 hours of your time. 

     GATE 

     Greet participants as they arrive on the playa. The gate is staffed 24
     hours in 3 hour shifts. We need a compliment of sixty people to staff
     the gate. (This can be a fun job. You and your partners will represent
     the only human presence in a void. People will be very glad to see you)

CAMP SET-UP AND CONSTRUCTION

Help construct Central Camp and install the infrastructure of roads, markers,
and spires which define our civilized space.

     Early Construction
     Fifteen to twenty people to help build stages, shade structures, spires,
     markers and to help define the perimeters. It will be necessary to arrive
     approximately one week before the event. 
     Regular Construction
     Build experimental, temporary structures, handle repairs, etc. during
     the festival itself

CENTRAL CAMP STAFF

At Camp Center we maintain a cafe (espresso and juice), gift shop (shirts and
videos), and information booth. These must be staffed at all times during the
day and early evening.

     Cafe Staff
     Eighteen people to work three hour shifts at the Central Camp Cafe.
     Also need an Ice Czar to manage the cafe's supply of frozen water.
     This undoubtedly will be a very cool job. 
     Gift Shop Staff
     Hawk T-shirts and Videos to the denizens of the playa and help
     support the festival. Shade provided.

BLACK ROCK SAFETY RANGERS

Twenty to twenty-five people needed for Saturday and Sunday night to
manage errant revelers. There will be one tactical meeting in the desert.

     SOUND & LIGHTING TECHS

     Ten to twelve individuals with stage sound and lighting experience to
     set up the speaker systems and stages.

PLAYA CLEAN-UP

Everyone is expected to participate in clean-up Monday morning. We need
special volunteers, however, to spearhead this effort and, if possible, to stay
behind at least one extra day and assist in our extremely thorough effort. We
leave nothing behind.

     LAMP LIGHTING

     Our campsite is delineated by more than two dozen spire-like
     lampposts. Kerosene lanterns must be cleaned, lit and affixed to
     poles, and taken down daily. Costumes for this public task are
     highly recommended.

BURNING PAGEANT

This year our Burning Pageant on Sunday night will be choreographed in
way which will feel immediate and spontaneous. We need help to guide
large numbers of people. Costumes of your own invention are required.

     MECHANIC

     Maintain Gas Engines and Generators

DATA ENTRY

Macintosh File Maker database

     VIDEOGRAPHER

     Recording and documenting the festival

TECHNICAL ILLUSTRATOR

To work on the Burning Man Handbook

     ELECTRICIAN

     To work on the power grid and lighting

BLACK ROCK GAZETTE

Largest Circulation Daily on the Playa since 1992 needs the following folks:

     Assistant Editor
     Mac Expert, Page Layout Experience 
     Roving Reporter
     Digital Camera a big plus 
     Production Coordinator
     Copying, Collation, Distribution

INTERNET

Our presence on the Internet mirrors our experience of the desert. WEB sites
are added to our network very much as fires form an archipelago of lights on
the playa. If you wish to integrate into this fast-growing world and add your
peculiar point of view to the community, please contact:
burnlink-info@well.com

                                                     
Our central organization is guided by more than 30 separate coordinators
who oversee the efforts of nearly 300 people. Among this core team the
following positions have yet to filled in 1995:

CARGO WRANGLER

The Cargo Wrangler is responsible for organizing the transport of all
materials to and from the Black Rock Desert. A Class "B" drivers license
would be helpful.

     PLAYA MEDIA COORDINATOR

     The Media Coordinator is responsible for orienting the media. This
     includes initial contact of all organizations that contact us before the
     event. Last year all television teams, in particular, were required to
     raise their hands and swear an oath: "we pledge not to interfere with
     anyone's immediate experience". In return for their cooperation we
     furnish journalists with a press kit and a list of press guidelines. In the
     desert the Media Coordinator is expected to plan and maintain a Press
     Tent. Operating from this headquarters he or she keeps a register of all
     journalists, arranges for interviews with artists and other organizers,
     and supplies the press with ongoing information. After the event, the
     Coordinator is responsible for securing copies of all press coverage and
     video and film footage shot at the event. This position requires people
     skills. Experience with the media is a plus.

CLEAN-UP MANAGER

Someone is needed to coordinate clean-up on the playa. In 1994 a
beleaguered crew took 3 full days to complete this task. The job will double
in scope this year. If properly organized, we feel it can go much more
smoothly.

     GATE COORDINATOR

     Manage a staff of sixty individuals working in shifts to man the gate.

                                                     
Finally, if your perceive a community task which we have not thought of and
which you would like to perform, please call us and let us know. 

                           Burning Man depends entirely on
                           your initiative.

==============================================================================

A Practical Survival Guide to the 

          Community of Burning Man

         We are
         escorting
Burning Man into an
astonishing and surreal
desert environment. A
primary concern is to
interact with the
environment in a
positive and
ecologically sound
manner. We will
establish a temporary
community in the center
of a thoroughly flat 400
square mile hardpan alkali expanse ringed by majestic mountains. This
environment is worlds away from that to which we are accustomed and is
governed by physical laws which cannot be ignored.

There are a number of safety and conservation concerns which you must
be aware of as a participant of this event.



Coming to the Desert: What Your Party Must Bring:

   1.A vehicle in sound mechanical condition. Make sure you have a
     working spare tire, jack, and highway flares. We also suggest you fill
     your gas tank in Reno. 
   2.IMPORTANT! One gallon of water per person per day. Keep a supply
     of water in your vehicle at all times. 
   3.Enough food/beverages and ice for your whole party. 
   4.Garbage bags. 
   5.Bedding and shelter of some type; the winds can reach 40 mph. A good
     camp tent is recommended along with warm sleeping bags. 

We Suggest You Bring:

   1.Sunscreen/sunblock lotion. 
   2.Umbrellas, parasols, hats, sheets; something to break the midday sun -
     You'll be glad you did! 
   3.A cooking stove if you expect to heat food or liquid. 
   4.Flashlights and spare batteries. 
   5.Compass. 
   6.Folding chairs or camp stools. 
   7.Bicycles (mountain bikes with balloon tires are best). 



Desert Navigation

There are no roads, signs or street lights in the Black Rock desert. Much like
deep space, travel is accomplished in vectors of direction and distance. All
objects - human beings, cars, even our encampment - drastically diminish in
the scale of the desert. A difference in heading of 4 or 5 degrees can send
ones destination sweeping past unheeded to the left or right. Use your
odometer, compass and posted landmarks to find your way. Upon first
entering and leaving camp, take time to accurately observe landmarks among
surrounding peaks. They are useful guides during the day. At night it is very
difficult to determine the direction or distance of anything. Lights array
themselves in random and confusing patterns. Any observed point may be 4,
40, or, should you happen to fix on a star, 400 billion miles distant. We will
locate a tower equipped with a flashing beacon at the center of camp. The
central circle of our camp is laid out as a giant compass. Wooden spires mark
the cardinal directions and are color coded. Lesser poles mark degrees of the
compass. Even finding your own tent within Central Camp may prove to be
an challenging task at night. After you have setup your campsite, go to the
center of camp counting the number of steps. Using the wooden spires and
your compass, locate the vector (bearing) of your campsite. Remember your
vector/distance from this central position.

Our Campsite

   1.Driving on the desert produces a dust plume. Please approach the camp
     downwind. 
   2.Drive slowly and carefully within the immediate confines of our camp.
     Any vehicle which presents a safety hazard to the community will
     be disabled. 
   3.Do not drive or camp within our Central Circle or block roads leading
     into it. 
   4.Secure objects at your campsite (paper products, clothing, tarps,
     everything) against the wind. Objects as large as sleeping bags, chairs,
     card tables and empty ice chests have been carried away by occasional
     high winds. Weight the interior corners of your tent. Tent stakes which
     are 12-inch or longer are recommended. 
   5.Extended ropes or cables used to secure tents should be flagged. They
     are hazardous to pedestrians at night. 
   6.Every camping party is responsible for its refuse. Part of the beauty of
     the Black Rock desert is it's astounding blankness. Except for tire
     tracks and foot prints, our policy is to leave the desert a profoundly
     barren and empty quarter of the world. A general cleanup party will be
     held on Monday morning. You must participate. Take your trash out
     with you. Do not deposit garbage bags in Gerlach. 
   7.Do not ignite fireworks within the boundaries of camp! Do not keep
     loaded firearms in camp or discharge firearms across the playa! All
     firearms must be secured at all times; there are children here. 
   8.Please don't camp or park near the Burning Man. 



Conservation and Safety Pointers

   1.Dig no holes in the alkali desert surface. (We will provide portable
     toilets.) Holes (even back-filled) present a danger to recreational
     motorists. 
   2.Be aware of the very real danger of dehydration and sunstroke. Drink
     lots of water. If you begin to shiver in the midday sun, immediately
     seek the shade. In case of emergency, go to our medical station at the
     center of camp. Medical aides are on call and evacuation is available. 
   3.Do not camp in sleeping bags away from your vehicle at night. If you
     are driving on the desert at night, be aware that there may be people
     away from the campsite and also land sailers running in the darkness
     without lights. Drive slowly and with caution. Never cruise at night
     with your headlights off. 
   4.Use caution when turning at higher speeds. Tires will not slide on the
     alkali and vehicles will roll over. 
   5.After first leaving the paved road and driving onto the desert it is
     critical to avoid the perimeter of the flat where it intersects with the
     surrounding mountains. There is a band of very soft, occasionally
     swamp-like ground along the edge of the playa. If you drive into this
     area, you WILL get stuck. We suggest that when driving off-road you
     stay at least 1/4 mile from the edge of the alkali flat. Also avoid any
     other areas where the ground is not hard-packed and flat. 
   6.There are many hot springs near the mountains along the edge of the
     Playa. Always test the water temperature before entering. Don't bring
     pets, some of the pools are boiling hot. 
   7.Before departing camp on an excursion tell others of your plan.
     Introduce yourself to your neighbors. Contact a Ranger if anyone is
     missing. 
   8.Night-time distress signal: red highway flare or flash your headlights. 

Sound Abatement

Resign yourself to certain facts: a) sounds at night reverberate on the playa
b) people will camp where they will c) we don't live here in brick houses d)
this is, after all, a party. Follow these simple rules: To the degree you enjoy
silence, camp at a corresponding distance from the center of camp (keeping
in mind that any tent which is situated beyond the metropolitan fringe of our
circle could become the target of a stray vehicle at night-- erect reflectors!)
Should your need for quiet be absolute, bring earplugs. Celebrants: turn your
amplified music down at night.

Black Rock Rangers

It is the mission of the Black Rock Rangers to patrol the playa. Led by
legendary Danger Ranger, these intrepid scouts are trained to conduct search
and rescue missions, assist all campers in emergencies, provide for our camp
safety and distribute information. Ranger headquarters will be located at
Central Camp.



Commerce & Concessions

The sale of mass-produced commercial products is strongly discouraged by
our community. This is not a consumer event. Our desert economy has no
convenience stores. Short on batteries? Need more water? Forget your sun
block? Confront your own survival. Ask to your neighbors for help or look
for these supplies in the nearby towns of Gerlach and Empire. However,
every town should have a marketplace and our camp is no exception. If you
have created items which you wish to sell at our market, please contact us in
advance. Anything offered should bear the distinctive stamp of your
individual skill, taste, and ingenuity. Whatever you make should represent a
uniquely personal act. The market will be staffed by volunteers and a 10%
contribution from proceeds goes to the community project. Look for our
market in Central Camp. 

Storms

The Black Rock Desert is sometimes subject to rainstorms. Storm cells, fed
by rising thermals that stream upward from the surrounding mountains, may
arise in the evening. Likewise, dust storms can prowl the playa in packs or
sweep, in a broadened front, across the plain. Suddenly besetting us, they may
produce instant "white-outs". Seek immediate shelter and stay there. If you
are caught outside of shelter during this condition, simply sit down, cover
your face with your shirt and wait. Severe conditions rarely last more than
half an hour. Think of the playa as a giant mattress, flat and forgiving. In the
event of rain, again remain where you. Do not try to drive off the playa!
Rainfall here is quite selective. Fleeing a storm, you may merely gain a
wetter patch of ground and become mired. Sudden rainfall drains quickly
here. A three-hour shower may muddy the ground, but terrain will soon
become passable. Your best shelter is society. Should a major storm overtake
us, the Black Rock Rangers will patrol in emergency vehicles to rescue
straggling pedestrians. Nature is volatile at Black Rock, conditions change
suddenly, but, if you relax and stay calm, your patience will insure your
safety.

Freedom & the Media

Our only dogma on the playa is a simple rule: do nothing that interferes
with anyone's immediate experience. Our festival is dedicated to free
expression and we commend a broad tolerance for other peoples tastes. This
is a very large space and there is room for everybody. Obviously, anti-social
behavior represents very real interference with others, and the Black Rock
Rangers, helpful and hovering near, are ready to respond to any real
infraction of the public peace. More specifically, camera people and
journalists are also subject to this rule. Do not jump in front of the action,
obscure public view, or interfere with anyone's participation. On the other
hand, people do want pictures. Be reasonable. Should you feel that anyone
toting a camera is making a nuisance, contact a Ranger.

The policy of the Burning Man Project is to welcome journalists. We're
non-exclusive and regard coverage as a means of communication. We work
cooperatively with the media-- after all, they are helping us to affect the
outside world. Many who come here have learned about us through the
media. In exchange, however, we require reporters to absorb and respect our
unique ethos. Professional video crews are pledged not to interfere with your
experience. They are merely here to record what happens.



Community

Burning Man is an experiment in temporary community. Because many
people only know a world shaped by institutions, social service workers and
commercial transactions, they may not even recognize the signs of a
community. Here are a few indications: 

Capacity. 
     Communities are built on the recognition of the unique abilities of
     every member. Commerce and the public service sector define us on
     the basis of deficiency and need. 
Collective Effort. 
     Community is cooperative; uniting us as varied members of one body.
     When, by contrast, we consume a service, we're made passive. 50
     million people may view a television program or consume a beverage
     in complete isolation from one another. 
Informality. 
     In the community, transactions of value take place without money,
     advertising, or hype. Care emerges in place of structured service. 
Stories. 
     In universities, people know through studies. In businesses and
     bureaucracies, people know by reports. In communities, people know
     by stories. 
Celebration. 
     Community activities incorporate celebration, parties, and other social
     events. The line between work and play is blurred and the human
     nature of everyday life becomes part of the way of work. You will
     know that you are in a community if you often hear laughter and
     singing. 

Clean Up

Take nothing from the desert. Leave nothing behind. Every camping party is
responsible for its refuse. Part of the beauty of Black Rock is its astounding
blankness. Except for tire tracks and footprints, our policy is to leave the
desert a profoundly barren and empty corner of the world. All participants
are expected to participate in cleanup on Monday morning. Leave no debris
behind, including firewood, ashes, rocks and cigarette butts. Pick up
everything.

Hi everyone,

Here's the article for those of you who missed it. I'm transcribing it 
verbatim; it appeared in this am's Chronicle, although it looks like it  
originally may have come from the New York Times or its syndicate. Without 
further ado, then...

[headline] "Rave Drug Could Damage Brain"

[subhead] "Researchers say Ecstasy affects vital nerve cells"

"In experiments on animals, the popular street drug Ecstasy caused the 
brain to form abnormal connections that could lead to problems such as 
chronic depression, scientists have reported.

"The changes, which affect nerve cells throughout the brain, have been 
shown to occur on monkeys given 'recreational' doses of the drug. The 
finding is likely to apply to humans as well, said Dr. George Ricaurte, 
an assistant professor of neurology at the Johns Hopkins University 
School of Medicine in Baltimore, who carried out the research.

"Dr. Lewis Seiden, a neuropharmacologist at the University of Chicago, 
said, 'This is an important basic research discovery with implications 
for people who take MDMA (Ecstasy).'

"The drug, a methamphetamine derivative, may have long-term harmful 
effects on appetite, sleep, mood, impulsiveness and other mental 
functions, he said. Similar problems may occur in people taking a 
chemically related diet pill, fenfluramine, which is popular in Europe.

"The extent of the damage probably varies with dosage, Ricaurte said. 
People who take Ecstasy three or four times a year might not notice any 
changes in their behavior or thinking. But those who take large amounts 
-- like seven or eight doses a night during the dance parties called 
raves -- could be inviting more serious problems.

"Ricaurte's study was published in the August issue of The Journal of 
Neuroscience and was supported by the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

"Ecstasy is popular on campuses in the United States, Ricaurte said. In 
Britain, where raves are popular, it is the second-most popular street 
drug, after marijuana.

"After taking Ecstasy, people report an extraordinary loss in inhibitions 
and feel love toward their fellow human beings, Ricaurte said. Ecstasy 
produces its effects for four to six hours, he said, yet no one knows how 
the drug works.

"It is known, however, that Ecstasy perturbs one of the brain's major 
chemical systems for transmitting information. The chemical serotonin is 
released from a bundle of nerve cells in the brain stem. These cells make 
dense, threadlike connections, called axons, to other nerve cells all 
over the brain and into the spinal cord.

"The new research took a closer look at this process in rats and monkeys. 
Animals were given recreational doses of Ecstasy -- the amounts taken by 
many young people -- and their brains were examined 12 to 18 months later. 
In rats, new axons grew and made normal-looking connections all over the 
brain, Ricaurte said. But in squirrel monkeys, he said the axon regrowth 
'was markedly abnormal.'"

A comment from me: is anyone out there really taking 7 or 8 doses a night 
at these "dance parties called raves"? I've never heard of it, and think 
this research could be seriously flawed if that was considered the 
typical or recreational dose.

Is it possible for anyone to get the original paper and post to the list?

Kathryn

On Tue, 15 Aug 1995, Kathryn Ankrum wrote:

> 
> [headline] "Rave Drug Could Damage Brain"
> 
> [subhead] "Researchers say Ecstasy affects vital nerve cells"
> 
> "In experiments on animals, the popular street drug Ecstasy caused the 
> brain to form abnormal connections that could lead to problems such as 
> chronic depression, scientists have reported.

abnormal connections?
This is a possibility... but it remains to be proven that these regrowth 
patterns *cause* depression etc...

> "It is known, however, that Ecstasy perturbs one of the brain's major 
> chemical systems for transmitting information. The chemical serotonin is 
> released from a bundle of nerve cells in the brain stem. These cells make 
> dense, threadlike connections, called axons, to other nerve cells all 
> over the brain and into the spinal cord.

"perturbs" is a very biased term... anything that dramatically affects your 
consciousness will signigicantly alter neurotransmitter 
output... whether this change is drug driven or not.

> "The new research took a closer look at this process in rats and monkeys. 
> Animals were given recreational doses of Ecstasy -- the amounts taken by 
> many young people -- and their brains were examined 12 to 18 months later. 
> In rats, new axons grew and made normal-looking connections all over the 
> brain, Ricaurte said. But in squirrel monkeys, he said the axon regrowth 
> 'was markedly abnormal.'"

This reminds me of the the study done on rats to test the carcinogenic 
effects of Asarone (one of chemicals in Calamus), in which MASSIVE doses 
of the chemical were given to rats and found to be possibly cancer forming.
These results were then ludicrously extrapolated to human cases, 
completely ignoring the fact that human beings would *never* ingest that 
much asarone per body weight. Similarly, giving a rat, or even a squirrel 
monkey, a human dose of ecstasy, and then drawing possible conclusions 
for the human nervous system, may prove to be fallacious.
It is also interesting to note that no mention was made of a control 
group... I assume that there was one... but it's possible that there wasn't.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Aug 16 00:14:33 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA05108; Wed, 16 Aug 1995 00:14:33 -0700

	id AAA02287; Wed, 16 Aug 1995 00:11:39 -0700

To: lineHook <nvg8r@c2.org>

Subject: Re: Rave Drug Could Damage Brain (long) 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Tue, 15 Aug 95 23:34:46 PDT."
             <Pine.SUN.3.91.950815222625.13579B-100000@infinity.c2.org> 
Date: Wed, 16 Aug 95 00:11:35 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

lineHook <nvg8r@c2.org>:
> This reminds me of the the study done on rats to test the carcinogenic 
> effects of Asarone (one of chemicals in Calamus), in which MASSIVE doses 
> of the chemical were given to rats and found to be possibly cancer forming.
> These results were then ludicrously extrapolated to human cases, 
> completely ignoring the fact that human beings would *never* ingest that 
> much asarone per body weight. Similarly, giving a rat, or even a squirrel 
> monkey, a human dose of ecstasy, and then drawing possible conclusions 
> for the human nervous system, may prove to be fallacious.

Nowhere does the article explicitly state that they were giving the
test animals *HUMAN* doses of X. I don't think it helps to confuse the
issue by attempting to link the methods in this study with old, widely
reported, and clearly flawed studies of carcinogenicity based on
massive doses of toxins.

Lets not jump to conclusions based on these kinds of specious arguments
until we see the full article, ok??

However, I will admit that the original article is unclear on the
actual amounts used in the study -- my feeling is that this is more a
problem with the general boneheadedness of Chronicle reporters than a
problem with the scientific study. Yes, the sentence "the amounts taken
by many young people" is quite ambiguous. In general, however, these
kinds of studies are based on equivalent ratios of drug-dose to body
weight of the test subject. 

Then again, I've independently determined (at least for myself) that
there is a strong correlation between taking X and depression, and this
also corresponds to statements and empirical observations made by other
people I've talked to as well. You may disagree, but lets get the facts
first before raising the spectre of yet another anti-drug conspiracy
under the guise of "science".

> Then again, I've independently determined (at least for myself) that
> there is a strong correlation between taking X and depression, and this
> also corresponds to statements and empirical observations made by other
> people I've talked to as well. You may disagree, but lets get the facts
> first before raising the spectre of yet another anti-drug conspiracy
> under the guise of "science".

I definitely agree that there is some possible correlation between X 
and depression. I always get this empty void feeling after the 
weekend is over if I have done E and had a really good time. It 
usually happens when I am alone after all the fun is over. I don't 
think that iit is what the article is trying to call a "serious 
problem" though. I just feel that there is a balance to keep, like if 
you really have a wonderful time of course you are going to feel a 
slight longing for it to keep going. And after it is over of course 
you miss the feelings that you had, that is completely natural. And I 
think that X just amplifies those feelings just like all the other 
feelings you may have when you are on it. I don't believe I am going 
to become a manic depressive from taking MDMA, I just have to keep my 
wonderful, positive attitude going after everything is over, which 
may be difficult at times just because of fatigue, and the come-down, 
but it is nothing I believe to be a permanent problem caused by X.
This is just about me personally. I'm not saying that this happens to 
everyone, or that it should. It is just what I have observed 
personally, from my own experiences and some of my friends. It just 
goes to show that you always have to keep the feeling going, and 
always look up!

- squishes to all!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Aug 16 02:29:50 1995

        "Rave Drug Could Damage Brain (long)" (Aug 15,  7:36pm)
References: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950815191221.17251A-100000@crl7.crl.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: Kathryn Ankrum <kathank@crl.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Rave Drug Could Damage Brain (long)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'd say over-reacting to this article is not in order.  While animal
analogue studies are often done to examine drug efficacy and side effects,
even researchers in the field will agree that the correlation with human
use is weak at best.  There is also a widespread misunderstanding that
all primates are basically the same as humans; this is true at some levels
but not others.

Nevertheless, caution is in order.  MDMA is powerful stuff, and "necking
an E" every time someone goes out is clearly not a good idea.

The mass media reports of these studies can almost always be discounted,
no matter what they say.  I'd be just as skeptical of a report that said,
"Ectasy proven new wonder drug, docs say take it three times a day."

The mass media reports medical research infrequently, badly and without
context.  Strike three.

phred

On Tue, 15 Aug 1995, lineHook wrote:

> This reminds me of the the study done on rats to test the carcinogenic 
> effects of Asarone (one of chemicals in Calamus), in which MASSIVE doses 
> of the chemical were given to rats and found to be possibly cancer forming.
> These results were then ludicrously extrapolated to human cases, 
> completely ignoring the fact that human beings would *never* ingest that 
> much asarone per body weight. Similarly, giving a rat, or even a squirrel 
> monkey, a human dose of ecstasy, and then drawing possible conclusions 
> for the human nervous system, may prove to be fallacious.
> It is also interesting to note that no mention was made of a control 
> group... I assume that there was one... but it's possible that there wasn't.
> 

  A doctor friend of of mine at the University of Utah once said to me, 
"*Everything* is a poison. It's all a matter of dosage."

On Wed, 16 Aug 1995, lineHook wrote:

> 
> 
> On Wed, 16 Aug 1995, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> 
> > 
> > Then again, I've independently determined (at least for myself) that
> > there is a strong correlation between taking X and depression, and this
> > also corresponds to statements and empirical observations made by other
> > people I've talked to as well. 

>From a homeopathic perspective, any medication that disrupts homeostasis 
will incur a reaction in the opposite direction to reestablish balance.
Homeopaths take this rule quite literally, and thus, a drug, such as X, 
which induces an ecstatic state, according to some, will encourage the 
body to produce the opposite reaction, namely a depressing one. Once the 
drug has been eliminated by the body, it is thus entirely possible that 
all that is left for a while is the counterreactive state.

I know that a similar, yet more scientific, approach is used to explain 
certain aspects of *physical* dependence to depressant drugs, namely the 
nervous/anxious state that occurs after the high induced by opiates,
as well as the crash associated with stimulants such as cocaine. I am
not aware of any neuroscience that could also explain the 
post-X depression in such a fashion, but it is nontheless interesting to 
note the existence of a theoretical model, that of homeopathy, within which 
such a reaction is entirely justifiable.
