The following appeared in yesterday's Science Times.
Aug. 15, 1995

Popular Drug May Damage Brain

By SANDRA BLAKESLEE


   In experiments on animals, a popular street drug called Ecstasy caused the
brain to form abnormal connections that could lead to problems like chronic
depression, scientists have reported.

   The changes, which affect nerve cells throughout the brain, have been
shown to occur in monkeys given recreational doses of the drug. Thus the
finding is likely to apply to humans as well, said Dr. George Ricaurte, an
assistant professor of neurology at the Johns Hopkins University School of
Medicine in Baltimore, who carried out the research.

   Dr. Lewis Seiden, a neuropharmacologist at the University of Chicago,
said, "This is an important basic research discovery with implications for
people who take MDMA," or Ecstasy. The drug, a methamphetamine derivative,
may have long-term, harmful effects on appetite, sleep, mood, impulsiveness
and other mental functions, he said. Similar problems may occur in people
taking a chemically related diet pill, fenfluramine, which is popular in
Europe.

   The extent of the damage probably varies with dosage, Ricaurte said.
People who take Ecstasy three or four times a year might not notice any
changes in their behavior or thinking. But those who take large amounts -
like seven or eight doses a night during the dance parties called raves -
could be inviting more serious problems.

   Ricaurte's study was published in the August issue of The Journal of
Neuroscience and was supported by the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

   Ecstasy is popular on campuses in the United States, Ricaurte said. In
Britain, where raves are popular, it is the second most popular street drug,
after marijuana.

   After taking Ecstasy, people report an extraordinary loss of inhibitions
and feel love toward their fellow human beings, Ricaurte said.

   Ecstasy produces its effects for four to six hours, he said, yet no one
knows how the drug works.

   It is known, however, that Ecstasy perturbs one of the brain's major
chemical systems for transmitting information. The chemical serotonin is
released from a bundle of nerve cells in the brain stem. These cells make
dense, threadlike connections, called axons, to other nerve cells all over
the brain and into the spinal cord. The axons, when electrically activated,
squirt serotonin onto cells in the cortex, amygdala, hypothalamus and
midbrain regions.

   Previous research showed that Ecstasy destroys serotonin-carrying axons,
Ricaurte said. The drug "literally prunes the axon projections," he said,
while leaving the cell bodies alone. Then, in ways that are not yet
understood, the axons tend to regenerate and make new connections in the
brain.

   The new research took a closer look at this process in rats and monkeys.
Animals were given recreational doses of Ecstasy - the amounts taken by many
young people - and their brains were examined 12 to 18 months later.

   In rats, new axons grew and made normal-looking connections all over the
brain, Ricaurte said. But in squirrel monkeys, he said, the axon regrowth
"was markedly abnormal." Connections to nearby targets like the amygdala and
hypothalamus - circuits that help control emotion and hormone balance - were
overabundant. And reconnections to the higher cortex were absent.

   It seems that the shorter axonal projections recover but the longer ones
do not, Ricaurte said.

   Serotonin helps regulate mood, appetite and cognition, Ricaurte said.
People taking high doses of Ecstasy could suffer permanent damage to their
serotonin systems, he said, which could lead to chronic mood, memory and
sleep problems.

   The appetite suppressant fenfluramine, sold under the trade name Pondimin,
produces the same neurotoxicity as Ecstasy in mice, rats and monkeys,
Ricaurte said. The worry is that people take diet pills for long periods. "It
may well be that the doses used in humans could be without neurotoxic
effects, but we should look," he said.

   A federal study last year found no evidence that fenfluramine caused
permanent brain damage.


Copyright 1995 The New York Times

At 10:55 AM 8/16/95, lineHook wrote:
>>From a homeopathic perspective, any medication that disrupts homeostasis
>will incur a reaction in the opposite direction to reestablish balance.
>Homeopaths take this rule quite literally, and thus, a drug, such as X,
>which induces an ecstatic state, according to some, will encourage the
>body to produce the opposite reaction, namely a depressing one. Once the
>drug has been eliminated by the body, it is thus entirely possible that
>all that is left for a while is the counterreactive state.

        along this line, here's something i just posted to ne-raves where
we're talking about the same article.
--------
        sorry, i've snipped this entire article as i'm sure y'all have read
it.  What i'd like to pick up on is that the dangers here, or apparent
dangers, arise from the belief that there is a causal relationship between
mood and neurochemistry/brain structure and that this relationship goes one
way: your neurochemistry/brain structure affects your mood.  Now, i'm not a
neuropsychologist, nor am i a chemist, nor am i even closely related to any
scientific field
        BUT...
                i have an inkling that the relationship between
neurochemistry and mood is not a one way thing.  I suppose that it goes
back to the notion that mind and body are separate and that the flow of
cause and effect runs from body _to_ mind. (you do e, you feel good). I
think, rather, that mood is an index of a _synergy_ between neurochemistry,
organic brain matter, 'mind' and numerous other factors.  Because you
change one factor in the equation doesn't necessarily mean that you will
always end up with the same results.  So, if you are creating new pathways
and connections in your brain, this may be only a small alteration in 'the
big picture.'
        My example would be that you can alter someone's neurochemistry
with prozac, which creates 'happy thoughts' but, after the drug wears off
what are you left with? The homeostatic nature of your body 'naturally'
will try to maintain a balance between your highs and your lows. So, you
feel a bit down afterwards.  Maybe the person returns to their normal
thought and behaviour patterns or, MAYBE, the ability to shift gears to a
new way of thinking is realized from the chemical which, after the chemical
has left the body 'causes' the brain to utilize the neurochemicals that
'produce' happy thoughts.  (MIND affects BODY).
        Think about this analogy: your mood is sort of like a thermostat
and say it's set at 20 degrees celsius (which, for you americans is room
temperature ;) haha).  When it gets cold in the house the heat comes on and
the temperature of the house rises up to 20 deg, then the heat turns off.
When it gets hot, the air conditioning comes on to cool the house back to
20 degrees celsius.  Imagine your mood as a thermostat and, IMHO,
everyone's is at different temperatures but some of us, like me, had their
thermostats set REALLY low.
        What i'm trying to say is that, from personal experience, you can
have a variety of factors that make you depressed.  Chemistry is one of
them, surroundings and environment are another, past experiences and
psychological history are another and your 'way of thinking/percieving
things' is another.  I'm sure that there are a LOT more things that affect
your mood, a lot of them that we can't percieve...yet.  Anyways, thinking
about this, i've realized that my 'mean mood' (and i mean mean as in
average, haha) was pretty low for a LONG time, but one factor entered my
uhhh biological system and that caused a shift in my way of thinking, which
caused a shift in my environment and perceptions and that caused a shift in
my behaviour which caused a shift in what kinds of chemicals were in my
body which caused a shift in....ad infinitum.  The result was that my 'mean
mood' was not so down anymore.  I moved from below room temperature to HOT!
;) haha...well maybe i exaggerate.  Now, for me, the 'result' of the shift
in factors that i've described has raised my level up a LOT.  To the point
where the chemical _additions_ to my system aren't as necessary, the whole
equation can balance itself out.
        This is true for me, but, of course, not true across the board. If
i said it was i'd be following along the same line of logic as Ricaurte and
i think when you are dealing with a system as non-linear as mood, making
objective statements about a+b=c doesn't work. Non-linearity is, by nature,
unpredictable.  I know ppl who are depressed wrecks now after doing e (and
not in any excessive manner) but i also know people who's lives have been
altered for the good (i am tempted to say permanently but i won't).  I
think that one factor that might affect which way one goes is an idea of
what i'm saying. Maybe. and that's why i posted this, maybe if you take
this to heart ;) it will affect your examination of MDMA's effects on you
and your life and if you think of things in this way you can cut depression
off at the pass, so to speak. Shit, wouldn't it be AMAZING if EVERYONE who
did e and went out to parties and all that learned how to create their own
natural E-vibe and didn't say things like "i feel crappy, i need some
drugs," but instead said "i'm feeling crappy, look at that person and how
happy and beautiful they are, how much fun they're having" and BZZZAP you
are feeling good because your thoughts have affected your mood and probably
your neurochemistry.  I don't know, it works for me.
        hmm..i don't know if i'm making ANY sense (must have been all those
drugs i did in my past ;) haha).
        think happy,
                brad

Someone asked me:

>What are tyrosine and phenylalanine, and more importantly, where do
>you get them?  I get bad e ``hangovers'' and nothing seems to ease
>them;  I have tried prozac for the day after, and melatonin before
>going to sleep but neither has a noticable effect.


The following is information on Tyrosine and Phenylalanine was derived from
Earl Mindell's Vitamin Bible (Warner Bro's Books):

TYROSINE although a nonessential amino acid, is a high ranking
neurotransmitter and is important in it's role of stimulating and modifying
brain activity.  For instance, in order for phenylalanine to be effective
as a mood elevator, it must first be converted into tyrosine. If this
conversion does not occur because of some enzyme deficiency or a great need
elsewhere in the body for phenylalanine, insufficient quantities of
norepinephrine will be produced by the brain and depression will occur...

....Tyrosine has been used to help cocaine addicts kick their habits by
helping to avert the depression, fatigue, and irritability that accompanies
withdrawal.
(works for nicotine addicts as well) a regimen of tyrosine hydroxylase (the
enzyme that lets the body use tyrosine), and vitamins B1, B2 and niacin
seems to work....

PHENYLALANINE is an essential amino acid that is a high ranking
neurotransmitter. a chemical hat transmits its signals between the nerve
cells and the brain.  In the body, it's turned into norepinephrine and
dopamine, excitatory transmitters, which promote alertness and vitality.
Phenylalanine reduces hunger, increases sexual interest, improves memory
and mental alertness, alleviates depression.  Phenylalanine is available in
250-500mg tablets.  For appetite control, tablets should be taken one hour
before meals with juice or water(no protein).  For general alertness and
vitality, tablets hould be taken between meals with water or juice (again,
no protein). Phenylalanine is non addictive.  CAUTION! Phenylalanine is
contraindicated during pregnancy and people with PKU (phenylketonuria) or
skin cancer.

Well, there ya go.  I would recommend getting the book to get more details.
The book also contains cross references to other vitamins and nutrients
that work well together as well as safety precautions and dosage tables.
As with anything I would recommend caution and education when using these
types of supplements.

Hope this helps!

Peace

Tigger

Here are some pointers to some source information on this thread. Also
check out the base site <http://www.maps.org/> for some good scientifically
solid information...

The first URL is for a short paper by one of the scientists quoted in the
original article.

http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n3/nih.html
http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n3/neurmdma.html
http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n4/ucla.html


You can find Dr. George Ricaurte's e-mail address in that first document. I
would say, though, that if anyone wishes to contact him, try to coordinate
it through one person so that he doesn't get a flood of mail (as he
probably already will from many other sources!). Find out the info, then
post it to the list for others. I'd do this myself, but I don't have the
time, and I don't really have much knowledge of biochem. Takers?

From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris Beaumont)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Tyrosine 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

  Tigger's posting was essentially right.
Tyrosine has been used extensively by clinics to help people quit
stimulants, since it is used to replenish norepinephrine and dopamine
after periods of high neuronal firing.. (this also applies to stress)
The most interesting studies have been done by the military.
One thing that he didn't mention is that tyrosine should be taken in the
early morning, and that repeated, smaller dosages are better than one
big one...

Tyrosine will not reduce MDMA neurotoxicity, though.. just alleviate
some of the catecholamine depletion...

-Chris.

Scientists, after years of intensive research, have concluded that
  the exotic drug <alcohol>, found in many common beverages consumed
    by yuppies, business and sports types, may actually affect the
      health of brain cells:

  "it's extraordinary, the damage it can cause", quoted one scientist

  "there's definitely a link between abuse of this drug and health",
    said another authoritative source.

the exact consumption of this drug by the general populace is unknown,
  due to lack of research and also due to the forgetfullness of almost
    all clinical testing participants.

  "it definitely affects my brain, man" said one participant

  "wow. i'm drunk". said another

the conclusion drawn by our elite band of researchers: moderate use of
  this drug, or even occasional use, KILLS brain cells.  the DEA is, of
    course, considering applying a schedule to this new, exotic drug,
      before it is discovered by the majority of the populace.

...end news bulletin...

Phenylalanine is excellent for post-amphetamine depression.  (You know, that
"down" feeling the next day ;)  And can be taken daily as a dietary
supplement.  Though subtle, it has been effective for me.  You can find it
at just about any health food store.  Phenylalanine is also found in
Nutrasweet and therefore in Extra gum, Swiss Miss Sugar Free Hot Chocolate,
and so on... but hardly in effective doses.

One more word about brown spots in your E or "brown spots in my frat boys"
(as the thread used to be :)

Word from a chemist I know (take it for what it is...):
The brown spotted tabs or chocolate chip or whatever you call that stuff is
"MPPP" which was explained to me to be a synthetic derivative of heroin
which, because it's been resynthesized, IS orally active.  Yet another
theory to throw in the loop...

BTW, I'm back after being off the list for several months!  I hate my first
post back being all chemistry-related, but I can't seem to keep my mouth
shut. :P  Anyway, it was great to come back on and have the first posts I
see be about people helping to support each other through difficult times. 
I had forgotten what a tightly knit family this is.  You guys are the
coolest.

vibrating at the speed of love

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)

Subject: crackerjackin' & boozin'...its all the same.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 16 Aug 1995 16:26:21 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]

C'mon guys.  Everything we consume has some toxicity associated with it.  
As for synthetics, who the hell knows for sure?  Not enough research has 
been done on X or any other "illicit" drug to really find out what the 
long term effects of its use are.

The dismissal by some of E's toxicity by illustrating a legal drug does 
nobody a service.  Fact is I trust booze alot more than I trust E.  Why?  
Controls used in manufacture.  Simple as that.  E is not commercially 
avaialble.  the shit is made at labs sprinkled all over the place, as 
well as some pharm labs that stay open really late (done by some who 
moonlight).  A simple question, do you trust your brain on some chemist 
who does not have the quality controls avaialble to large commercial 
pharm. plants?  I do, on RARE occasions.  But alot less now than in the 
past.  I really try to stay away from the stuff.

The E that is going around now ain't the same shit I was taking years back.
As for booze, its pretty much the same, if not higher quality than 
previous years.

Booze is no more evil than E.  I would venture to say that E, and the 
business thereof is pretty evil.  The love you're feelin' on the dance 
floor, is not the same vibe that took place when you bought it for 
$15-$20, is not the same vibe when he bought it for $5-$10 dollars, is not 
the same vibe as the person who sold it to him for $3-$5 per.  People 
have been killed, framed, spent time in prison, and turned in their 
friends due to this "feel good" drug.  Can't really say that about booze 
since the lifting of prohibition now can you?

Yes, btw, I am for legalization of ALL drugs.  That would help the 
quality and underground issues assocaited w/ the drug.

I just hate to see people slam my fav beverage (beer), in favor of some 
uncontrolled crackerjack powder with a specific gravity less than 1.

Many things can be good when done in moderation.  I think E should be 
done in extreme moderation until quality can be assured.  And that will 
only happen when its legalized, and unfortunately taxed.

this is of course IMHO.

Shake your ass and your brain might follow,
John

JSL Wrote:

 
>Booze is no more evil than E.  I would venture to say that E, and the 
>business thereof is pretty evil.  The love you're feelin' on the dance 
>floor, is not the same vibe that took place when you bought it for 
>$15-$20, is not the same vibe when he bought it for $5-$10 dollars, is not 
>the same vibe as the person who sold it to him for $3-$5 per.  People 
>have been killed, framed, spent time in prison, and turned in their 
>friends due to this "feel good" drug.  Can't really say that about booze 
>since the lifting of prohibition now can you?

	Don't really agree with this. The evils you cite, and attribute
	to E, are not really a product of the chemical itself. Blaming
	an expensive powder for what are, essentially, human failings
	doesn't seem to make sense. I don't blame alcohol for all but
	destroying the life of people close to me; hootch aint' evil,
	it just is, same as E. 

	You're right though, people should be aware of the crap that 	
	surrounds the pills they pop, much of it due to the legal status
	of the drug - they should also know that they're taking a risk 
	when they do this. If your not completely sure of the source
	of the drug, then there's always the chance its going to do you
	some serious harm.

	When I first became informed, through the usenet, of some of
	the truth behind the propaganda spread about drugs; I started
 	jumping conclusions about 'scientific' studies that I've
	seen echoed here in a few posts on the subject. Now, while
	remaining sceptical about mainstream drug research and media
	coverage, I don't pay that much heed to it. Many scientific 
	'facts' are ephemeral in nature, for better or for worse, some
	more concrete than others. Other dangers seem more obvious to me. 

	Anyway, most drugs are dangerous in some ways, a lot of them are 
	also a whole lot of fun. Pays yer money and take your chance,

	Peace, 
	Gary

On Wed, 16 Aug 1995 14:47:48 -0700  Brian Benitez wrote:
>Here are some pointers to some source information on this thread. Also
>check out the base site <http://www.maps.org/> for some good scientifically
>solid information...
>
>The first URL is for a short paper by one of the scientists quoted in the
>original article.
>
>http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n3/nih.html
>http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n3/neurmdma.html

I spoke with Rick Doblin today who just talked with Ricarte. The key point of the recent studys:
1. The experiments on the spider monkeys were done with subcutaneous injections of MDMA at doses 2.5 times the normal human dose which in humans would be equivalent to 5 times the human dose since we take the drug orally and don't shoot it up.
2. The doses were administered every 8 hours for two days.
3. The results showed that the dendrites on serotonin neurons grew back irregularly
4. There was no behavioral changes noticed in the monkeys
5. There have been no behavioral changes noticed in humans, even older humans. 
6. There is a lot of speculation in the article but no conclusive evidence of anything to worry about
7. A study done last year with fenfloramine, an appetite suppressant which has identical effects on brain cells as reported above with MDMA  The drug has been used on a daily basis by many people for years and continues to be, it was just written up as the most promising weight control method in a recent issue of <cough cough> Readers Digest.  
A study done with people who used fenfloramine was conducted last year and showed no evidence of brain damage in those who used fenfloramine for many years.  No behavioral abnormalities. Perhaps Dr. Ricartte wishes to dissect these people and examine their brains? 
Let's end the propaganda war against drugs. Ricarte gets his money from NIDA. Let's spend the money to research and legalize drugs, not spread fear among the portulaca!
Bruce Eisner
>http://www.maps.org/news-letters/v5n4/ucla.html
>
>
>You can find Dr. George Ricaurte's e-mail address in that first document. I
>would say, though, that if anyone wishes to contact him, try to coordinate
>it through one person so that he doesn't get a flood of mail (as he
>probably already will from many other sources!). Find out the info, then
>post it to the list for others. I'd do this myself, but I don't have the
>time, and I don't really have much knowledge of biochem. Takers?

In article <9508152355.AA26217@dre.hal.com>,
jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell) wrote:
> Hey all! Me and some other folk were wondering about what to expect 
> weather-wise, temperature-wise, condition-wise, etc... in 
> an attempt to ascertain the must-haves and must-plan fors- with the aim 
> of planning what to bring. would one of you Bman-experienced folk 
> review my checklist please? 

The wisdom of the man burns within me like the sun against the desert
floor.

:-)

> I will undoubtedly be the mother hen of the group I'll be with-
> especially in the planning arena.
> 
> Here's what I plan to expect: anything.

Good thought.  Um, bring an emergency pair of warm clothes in case it
rains and turns the playa into mud.  That happened one year.

> Here's what I'm going to bring with that expectation in mind:
> 
> a tent- I might bring my own, though it's this incredibly 

The soil isn't sandy, its like packed talcum powder.  It's actually quite an
effort to sink stakes in past the first 3 inches or so.  Last year I had a
large 6 man tent, and once we staked it down we had no trouble with the
wind.

> sleeping bags: mine are -20; so, I'll also bring some top sheets 
> in case it's too hot for my afternoon catnap ;)

Because its so dry its pretty easy to conk out in the heat.

> sunscreen & a hat or two, a long sleeved, light colored, cotton
> sun shirt and one pair of lightweight cotton pants or a very long
> skirt for full sun cover.

If you got an umbrella that can block the light, that's pretty cool too.

> The one thing i'm totally in the dark about- how to mark the campsite 
> so that i can find it at night???

If you stay in the denser areas around the man, you can use the man and the
navigational light poles (bright blue lights) to find your camp.  Just
familiarize yourself with the layout of the camp during the day.  The only
way to get really lost is to travel out of sight of the man or to take to
many drugs.

Note to trippers, make sure you have a sober guide with you before you go on
jaunts.  Things get really chaotic around the camp.

> p.s. are snakes a concern? if so, what kind? what about lechegilla?
> other noxious plant life? thanks again :)

There are no animals or plants on the dry lake bed.  It's hundreds of square
miles of featureless flatness.

At 17:39 8/16/95, Jonathan Tea wrote:

>Word from a chemist I know (take it for what it is...):
>The brown spotted tabs or chocolate chip or whatever you call that stuff is
>"MPPP" which was explained to me to be a synthetic derivative of heroin
>which, because it's been resynthesized, IS orally active.  Yet another
>theory to throw in the loop...
>

Extremely doubtful. This is a synthetic heroin derivitave that's not too
common and is active at ridiculously low doses with a low margin of safety.
(It's easy to OD if you do too much). Unless he can come up with some NMR
results I'd say he's been seriously misinformed.

There's a simple explanation for dark spots - safrole. A necessary
precursor which is brown. Ever seen "black licorice" e? It's got a lot of
unsynthsized safrole in it and it's very dark brown.

The heroin feeling some e gives you means it's likely to be MDA or MDEA.

Joe

>The topic of drumming with electronic dance music has come up before, but 
>I can't help but make another comment.  Drumming is wonderful, powerful, 
>spiritual, tribal, and all that good stuff, but in combination with 
>techno/house, it just makes the music sound like one continuous bad mix.  

I write techno/house music and use live drums (congas, bongos, djembe, etc.)
while writing.  The combination of old technology with new technology can be
quite profound.  

>It's great for the people drumming, but hell for the people 
>trying to dance.  When the music already has tribal elements in it 
>(bongos, etc), then it can work, but only with a REALLY good drummer.  

But your right, you gotta be a good drummer and be able to keep a repetitive
beat....well!  More than a couple of drummers at a time just ruins the music
in most cases, but I'm sure there are exceptions.

Rick

	id NAA10339; Thu, 17 Aug 1995 13:49:46 -0700
Message-Id: <199508172049.NAA10339@ucdavis.ucdavis.edu>
Date: Thu, 17 Aug 1995 14:21:23 -0600
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Are your co-workers space aliens?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The following is not rave-related, but I thought it might put a grin on
your faces...

(This article has been attributed to a number of different sources,
mostly tabloid magazines, but apparently the real author is concealing
his identity. Probably for fear of alien retaliation.)

Many Americans work side by side with space aliens who look human --
but you can spot these visitors by looking for certain tip-offs, say
experts. They listed 10 signs to watch for:

  1. Odd or mismatched clothes. "Often space aliens don't fully
     understand the different styles, so they wear combinations that
     are in bad taste, such as checked pants with a striped shirt or a
     tuxedo jacket with blue jeans or sneakers," noted Brad Steiger, a
     renowned UFO investigator and author.

  2. Strange diet or unusual eating habits. Space aliens might eat
     French fries with a spoon or gobble down large amounts of pills,
     the experts say.

  3. Bizarre sense of humor. Space aliens who don't understand earthly
     humor may laugh during a serious company training film or tell
     jokes that no one understands, said Steiger.

  4. Takes frequent sick days. A space alien might need extra time off
     to "rejuvenate its energy," said Dr. Thomas Easton, a theoretical
     biologist and futurist.

  5. Keeps a written or tape recorded diary. "Aliens are constantly
     gathering information," said Steiger.

  6. Misuses everday items. "A space alien may use correction fluid to
     paint its nails," said Steiger.

  7. Constant questioning about customs of co-workers. Space aliens
     who are trying to learn about earth culture might ask questions
     that seem stupid, Easton said. "For example, a co-worker may ask
     why so many Americans picnic on the Fourth of July," noted
     Steiger.

  8. Secretive about personal lifestyle and home. "An alien won't
     discuss domestic details or talk about what it does at night or
     on weekends," said Steiger.

  9. Frequently talks to himself. "An alien may not be used to
     speaking as we do, so it may practice speaking," Steiger noted.

 10. Displays a change of mood or physical reaction when near certain
     high-tech hardware. "An alien may experience a mood change when a
     microwave oven is turned on," said Steiger.

The experts point out that a co-worker would have to display most if
not all of these traits before you can positively identify him as a
space alien.

Greetings Friends!

Let me preface this by saying that it pains me greatly to have to sound
this heavy handed. However, I've got wind of a rumour that there will be
some tickets for F&F at the door...

THIS IS ABSOLUTELY UNTRUE.

No one without tickets, whether or not we know you, whether or not you flew
in from Germany, whether or not you're one person in a car with 4 ticket
holders, you will not get in. We are absolutely committed to this.

Additionally, loads of excess people (and thier) cars endeavoring to get in
will only endanger the party. So if you don't have tix and could make other
plans for the evening we would all really appreciate it.

Once again, we deeply regret not being able to accomodate everyone but feel
it is the only conscienable way to proceed.

thanks much
ethan

Subject: Fun With Synthetics
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After reading a LOT of messages about various problems encountered with
synthetic drugs (Particularly everyone's fav MDMA) over the years on this
list, I've come to the conclusion that SFRaves needs to create a
buyer's/synthesizer's club. Chemically knowledgable synthesis folks could
be supplied with a stable source of stress-free non-narc clientele. Happy
ravers could be assured that they're getting pharmaceutical grade MDMA (or
whatever synthetic bops their bippy). World peace breaks out; hunger and
disease are eradicated; everyone lives happily ever after. Love spreads.
Mass empathy takes hold of the planet. All of life's problems solved,
humanity evolves to the next level where we are creatures of pure light
without heat, pure thought...

Personally, I like this idea a lot. :) OK? Where do we start?


And hey, for those of the law-enforcement persuasion that may be reading
this: We're speaking entirely hypothetically here. No one on this list
WOULD NEVER EVEN THINK of having ANYTHING to do with the EVIL SCOURGE ON
HUMANITY that ILLEGAL DRUGS represent.

We're all too busy getting drop-dead drunk on everclear and getting behind
the wheel, headed for your local elementary school's sidewalks. Cigarette
in hand, another in mouth. Hopped up on legally prescribed pain-killers,
sleep aids, and anti-depressants. The medicine cabinet's empty, better head
for the local drugstore to fill up.

Really, it's just a joke. Right?

The ENIT festival features a bunch of big names and a big price tag.  
Frequency 8 or Out-A-Sight may prove to be the better value...
On Saturday, Tribal Funk has a great lineup as does Eternia, although
both may be large and pricey.  I removed the listing for the
other party on Saturday since there are no tickets left.  Don't try to
go if you don't already have a ticket.

Thanks to all who have been sending in info...


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, August 18th - The ENIT festival- Lollapalooza After-Party
   Freaky Chakra vs Single Cell Orchestra, Sven Vath, Keoki, Moby, Traci
   Lords + a film by Future Sound of London + DJ Spooky. 9pm-4am at the
   Warfield, SF. $20 + ripoff @ BASS. 415.281.1410
   
   Friday, August 18th - Frequency 8 : Cyber-Trance Revelation
   DJs Mars, Mystr-E, Cyr. $5, indoors. map point open from 11pm-2am.
   415.541.5019
   
   Friday, August 18th - Out-A-Sight
   Jeno, Simon, Donald Glaude, Emma. 415.437.4462
   
   Saturday, August 19th - free outdoor afternoon celebration w/DJs
   Stonie, Billy & James. 415.487.7681 for more info.
   
   Saturday, August 19th - Tribal Funk invites you to join us for a night
   of Nothin' but Love
   DJ Dan, Donald Glaude, DJ Utopia, DJ Surf, Tony, Derrick Carter,
   Galen. 415.905.4476 408.291.3243
   
   Saturday, August 19th - Divine
   An evening of house music delivered deep and dark, hard and soft,
   bassic and acidic. 510.247.2474
   
   Saturday, August 19th - Eternia
   Terry Mullin (Chicago), Jeno, Garth, King Britt & Dozia (Philly), Jon
   Bishop (SD), Mojo (LA), Hipp-E (Colorado), Liquid, Shaheen (LA), Zone
   & Matthew Gadfathr, Pete Avila, Thad Jones. Richmond Civic Auditorium.
   415.979.3052 510.247.2202 209.573.7900
   
   Sunday, August 20th - Robot Wars afterparty
   DJs Darkhorse, dB, Markie, Jon Williams. 177 Townsend?
   
   Friday, August 25th - Ambient Jungle Midnight Cruise
   top deck: Ismael & Co., reggae ambient dub. mid deck - Ernie Munson &
   Markie. lower deck: Jason Walker, Moonpup, Nick Philip, Sean Murray.
   departs Pier 40 at midnight, goes till 5am. All Ages. advance tix $18
   at Housewares and BPM. $25 at boat. 415.241.1560
   
   Friday, August 25th - Green
   Pumping Hypnotic Sound: Garth, Shon, Josh & Jeff Miller. Lasers &
   Visuals by Acropolis. 10pm-6am. 408.551.2813 510.464.5974 415.267.6998

   DJs Trance, Barry Weaver, Tony, Ghost, Dutch & Minor Minor, Ivo &
   Carol. $5 off at door w/canned food donation. 415.286.7570
   510.553.7910 408.397.7780
   
   Saturday, August 26th - It's A Small World presents Flowerchild
   Garth, Simon, Dutch, Spinner, Markie. Live performance by Darwin
   Chamber and Fidelity Bytes. 510.202.0125 415.270.7602
   
   Saturday, August 26th - Progress : clearing the past
   DJs Tiga (Montreal), Josh, Jon Williams, Sean Murray, Richie, Andre
   Lucero
   415.974.4391
   
   Thursday, August 31st - Monday, September 4th - Burning Man Festival
   will include Wicked , SPAZ, Rig-A-Tony, Gateway & Ultraviolet 13.
   http://www.burningman.com/ 415.985.7471
   
   Friday, September 1st - Kundalini

   415.337.4337 510.944.7743

   Tony, Josh, Jeno, Solar, Doran. 415.905.9629

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.

     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * the Global Party Network Buzzline - 415.568.1338
     * The Groove Line - (415) 321.1500
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

This jogged a memory of a service in SF several years ago where you could
send in small samples of whatever for analysis. Don't recall who it was or
how in the world they convinced people to give an address for results --
maybe a number system where you just called in to get the results or
something.  Sorry for such a vague post, maybe I can track down more info.

Brian's alter ego states:
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
I've come to the conclusion that SFRaves needs to create a 
buyer's/synthesizer's club. Chemically knowledgable synthesis folks could 
be supplied with a stable source of stress-free non-narc clientele. Happy 
ravers could be assured that they're getting pharmaceutical grade MDMA (or 
whatever synthetic bops their bippy)....
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

WOW! I like that idea! :) Too funny.. It'd be like a co-op, but we'd
replace the O's, an in "Oh No!" or "Oh me god!", with E's...

.. but then, it'd be a Ce-ep, which sounds like a French Espresso Machine 
or s'mthing. !?!

On a related note, about the time of the New Year's last year, I remember 
that there was a major 'drug' bust in the Bay Area, where 40,000 hits of E 
were confiscated. 40,000!!!! Therefore, a friend and I then hypothesised 
that the correct thing for the Feds to do would've been to hand it over to 
NATO so they could airdrop it all over Bosnia and the rest of what was 
Yugoslavia!

        "Ah Slobodan, did I tell you how much I love you?"


(: rave on.blinky off :)    -Sy

If you must go to a rave this saturday:

FYI:

     Ethernia is being thrown by XYZ promoters.  If you have enjoyed the

depression., not to mention the cost increase of the drug itself.

& E) the high is something to experience, & I find it very enjoyable.

familar with the effects of both of those drugs separately, and then 
being very conservative, and slowly increaseing the dose of each(together) 
over time, and incidence.

acid is called candy flipping or trolling, then what would E & narcotics

As someone who comes from a country where 60% of all crime is alchahol 
related the piece of news that alchahol causes damage of the brain cells 
comes as no surprise to me; anyway, I thought that had already been 
prooven previously.  Alchahol is, with out a doubt one of the most 
fucked-up and bad drugs on the market.  It causes personality changes, 
fucks you up more physically then anyother drug with maybe the exception 
of herione, and one is always forced to buy the shitty tampered with 
version.  Imagine if everytime you went to buy pot it was watered down to 
a tenth of it's original strength; well that's what you do everytime you 
buy alchahol at a store.  It is also one of the cheapest drugs to 
manifacture yet, proportionatly, it is the most expensive.  And apart from 
having the effect of making girls really horney it has got nothing else 
going for it what so ever.  Maybe that's why me, an individual who at one 
or another has taken every known recreational drug known to man, never 
even started to drink until I was twenty-two years of age after I had 
already tried out everything else.  Take it from me boys, alchahol has 
got nothing going for it and if ever a drug needed hardercore leglslation 
to restrict it's use it is this drug.
So I say fuck alchahol, stay in the pink with pot and LSD instead.
TRISTAN.

On Wed, 16 Aug 1995, John S. Lee wrote:

> C'mon guys.  Everything we consume has some toxicity associated with it.  
> As for synthetics, who the hell knows for sure?  Not enough research has 
> been done on X or any other "illicit" drug to really find out what the 
> long term effects of its use are.
> 
> The dismissal by some of E's toxicity by illustrating a legal drug does 
> nobody a service.  Fact is I trust booze alot more than I trust E.  Why?  
> Controls used in manufacture.  Simple as that.  E is not commercially 
> avaialble.  the shit is made at labs sprinkled all over the place, as 
> well as some pharm labs that stay open really late (done by some who 
> moonlight).  A simple question, do you trust your brain on some chemist 
> who does not have the quality controls avaialble to large commercial 
> pharm. plants?  I do, on RARE occasions.  But alot less now than in the 
> past.  I really try to stay away from the stuff.
> 
> The E that is going around now ain't the same shit I was taking years back.
> As for booze, its pretty much the same, if not higher quality than 
> previous years.
> 
> Booze is no more evil than E.  I would venture to say that E, and the 
> business thereof is pretty evil.  The love you're feelin' on the dance 
> floor, is not the same vibe that took place when you bought it for 
> $15-$20, is not the same vibe when he bought it for $5-$10 dollars, is not 
> the same vibe as the person who sold it to him for $3-$5 per.  People 
> have been killed, framed, spent time in prison, and turned in their 
> friends due to this "feel good" drug.  Can't really say that about booze 
> since the lifting of prohibition now can you?
> 
> Yes, btw, I am for legalization of ALL drugs.  That would help the 
> quality and underground issues assocaited w/ the drug.
> 
> I just hate to see people slam my fav beverage (beer), in favor of some 
> uncontrolled crackerjack powder with a specific gravity less than 1.
> 
> Many things can be good when done in moderation.  I think E should be 
> done in extreme moderation until quality can be assured.  And that will 
> only happen when its legalized, and unfortunately taxed.
> 
> this is of course IMHO.
> 
> Shake your ass and your brain might follow,

>Oh dear, I thought people were a bit more clued in then this.  Anybody
>who says that E is just as evil as alchahol has clearly nnever been to a

>TRISTAN.
>

As for clued in, I see you're still using someones elses account ;).
Its not that E or booze is inherently evil.  They are just what they are,
drugs. The problem lies in their status within a society, and who stands to
profit or lose from said status.  In the case of booze, large, and small
companies benefit.  The users of the substances benefit as well, when its
used properly.  Booze in excess, or given to those who cannot handle it,
can lead to the problems you cited above.  E when used in excess can do the
same thing.  The fact that E is illegal means that there is an underworld
current that is involved in its manufacture, distrbution, and sales.  There
certainly might be some who do the manufacture for the love, but I doubt
it.  Its a matter of money. To deny that people have been subject to
violence of all kinds due to E's illegal nature, is to deny a reality that
many of us in SF are well aware.  I know people who have been threatened,
and harmed due to E.  There are people on the run due to E.  There have
been people deported to to E.  I KNOW if E was legal none of this would've
happened.   You also dismiss the factor of controls in manufacture.  How
many people have been sick due to "bad" E, or stuff being passed as E that
was really something else.  Controls, especially in the synthetic drug
realm, are quite important to its effectiveness, and realiability.  Shit
being done by people who THINK they know what they are doing (i'm talking
about making the shit), put everyone at risk when safety, and controls are
put aside.

E will not change the world. E is not a cure all.  It does not stop
bigotry, wife beating, or other severities of emotion.  Fact is you can do
as much damage on E to someone as you can do on booze.  It can amplify
emotions, both good and bad. E is illegal, which means there is major
profit to be had in its manufacture/distribution by underworld types (just
ask many SF denizens if they know anybody that has served timne for E,
they'll tell ya! And how many are on the run because of it...).  There are
no controls on its manufacture, which opens up the possibility of sloppy
work during its synthesis.  LSD and other illegal synthetics suffer from
the smae pilght.  Its a matter of status.
The same problems of manufacture/dist. of weed apply as well.  But I'll
tell you this, I'd rather smoke hella weed before I take another hit of E.
Weed is organic, besides, nature can be the overall controller.  She hardly
does wrong when it comes to what she does best, growing living green bud!

As for who'll get to heaven I quote Milton from Paradise Lost: "It is
better to rule in hell than serve in heaven."

As for you being an E head, be my guest. I've already done enough of that
shit to be one happy slappy motherf*cker for the next decade.  I don't need
something to help me empathize with people, I can do it naturally.  IMO,
the only real drug that can bring people together is weed, pre-dates E and
all that other synthetic shit.  As for beer, the egyptians had godesses of
the substance.  It is, throughout history, the great equalizer among
men/women.  Either IMO should be used in moderation.  When done in that
fashion you can't beat 'em.

Funny tho'.  I have seen one fistfight with two dudes on E.  I have been to
parties where everyone was on weed & beer.  Fact is, muthas was so busy
getting high, and enjoyin brew, the most you would want to do is either
sleep or just sit there and enjoy each others company.  Weed, when used at
hip-hop shows, gets even the meanest mutha to say hi, gives props, and say
YO!  Never seen a fight when everybody on the sinse.

"I do not sniff the coke, I only smoke the sinsemellia!" - Pato Banton <- I
despise his gangsta ass, but this song is one funny ditty,
John

 "What shall it profit a man, that he gain the whole world, yet lose his soul."
                                  Mark 5:12

help spread the tribevibe, whether you're a curious lurker, 
interested in meeting new people, video artist, musician, dj, promoter,

both may be large and pricey.  I removed the listing for the
other party on Saturday since there are no tickets left.  Don't try to
go if you don't already have a ticket.

Thanks to all who have been sending in info...


                               THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Wondering who all those SF Ravers are that you share the list with?  

Well, me too.  As a public service I'll wear my flourescent orange cap that
sayz "Wired" on the front all weekend.  It's very visible and you should
see it at F8 on friday, F&F on Sat, and the Robot Wars afterparty on Sun.
If you introduce yourself I'll be happy to point out or introduce you to
any SFRAVERs in sight (and anyone else I know).  

Ciao,

Purple Tiger - Information Kiosk On The Hoof (or paw as the case may be).

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug 18 13:59:59 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA17903; Fri, 18 Aug 1995 13:59:59 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA17898; Fri, 18 Aug 1995 13:59:50 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu
	(1.37.109.16/16.2) id AA060049479; Fri, 18 Aug 1995 13:57:59 -0700
Date: Fri, 18 Aug 1995 13:57:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: frustrations & contimplations
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9508181304.A3988-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I got back from my powerwalk a little while ago - my batteries in my 
walkman were really low, so I had to turn off Garth and in doing that I 
started thinking........

I look around me and am just fed up and disgusted in this society I live 
in.  So often I want to escape and have no part of it. People's 
rudeness, the oppression of our government, radical religious fanatics 
who wish their beliefs to be law for countless others of different 
belief systems....I could go on and on.  It seems as if "life, liberty, 
and the pursuit of happiness" is being corroded away everyday.  Dian's 
post about how permits were needed were just another example.  I could 
easily see something like the Criminal Justice Act over in England 
happening here.  The fact that something like that exists *anywhere* 
disgusts me. 

One of the main reasons I love raving so much is that it forms its very 
own society for a few hours, anyway. I always leave a party a little bit 
sad for having to face "reality" again. But, again, so often we are 
"unallowed" to be together for one reason or another: sound permits, 
trespassing, etc.  It shouldn't be that difficult to do something like 
throw a small party for godssake!  

I'm tired.  I'm tired of feeling saddened every time I have to leave my 
little rave community and integrate into a world I want no part of. I 
want to live a more simple life:  work for a community as a whole - not 
just for myself or some faceless, greedy corporation (hmmm...sounds like 
what Pacific and Gateway does for us, no?) I don't think I'm the only 
one who feels like this.  I think more and more people are becoming fed 
up and restless with their lives.  We all have a choice and as so many 
Americans preach, "if you don't like it, then leave!!"  If enough of us 
are indeed willing to sacrafice and make a huge change, then we CAN live 
in a society that we want to and we will gladly leave.  I think I 
decided to go to Burning Man this year because my subconscience told me 
I was ready and that this was a small taste of what it will be like.  

If any of you feel as I do, please, let's talk. I get so many others who 
give me reasons why it wouldn't work - I need encouragement, not 
discouragement.  So what if it sounds like I'm talking about forming a 
hippie commune - we can make it what we want someday. It *WILL* happen 
one day if our will to change directs us to do so. 

Well, I will see you all in that little slice of heaven tomarrow night 
called Friends & Family.  Ethan or Mike or anyone on the F&F crew: if 
you need any help breaking down after the party, I will be more than 
happy to help.  I know it must be the shits breaking down when you just 
want to take a shower and sleep some. More people who help out, the 
faster you can get it out of the way.  Anyone who hasn't met me yet I'll 
be wearing a sleaveless white shirt with green trim and an old pair of 
jeans with patches on the butt. (my fave pair that I couldn't throw out!)

Cya Saturday!
love,
Amy 

---------------
|   _  ,/|    |
|  '\`o O'    |
|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
|     | |     |      
---------------

On Fri, 18 Aug 1995 dbronsen@ccnet.com wrote:

> I know a while back this was talked about, but I don't remember what was 
> said. My question is how long does MDMA (E or X whatever) stay in your 
> system? If a urine drug test was given how long would it be from the time 
> of of taking the drug to the time of the test, when would it not show up?
> 
> Any info would make me happy. =)
> 
> 	-David
>     dbronsen@ccnet.com
> 

Most routine corporate drug tests do not test for MDMA, but it would show up 
as a possible amphetamine (a group that IS commonly tested for).  As for time, 
72 hours should be fine.  The more water you drink the better (this 
dilutes the sample).  I have been told by pharmacologist friend of mine 
that doing one dose of e on a saturday, could be fine for a monday drug 
test (when most companies test) as long as you drink lots of water and 
don't give the first sample of the day (i.e. urinate in the morning 
before going in for the test).  Of course the longer the better... look 
for Friday night parties.   I'm sure other people will have more info to 
add to this, but I hope it helps.

smiles,
Andrew Lawson (have to add that last name now, since I have been seeing a 
few more Andrews popping up on the list)   ; )

Amy,

I completely understand your frustrations!  Sometimes it seems so difficult to 
believe that we have such an amazing world and that we are such incredible 
people, and we are bound by regulations and restrictions not of our own 
choice, nor for our benefit, but to "protect ourselves"--from who, ourselves. 
 This makes absolutely no sense to me.  I am doing perfectly fine and so is my 
wonderful rave community, if everyone else would just adopt a similar attitute 
and allow people to truly express and be themselves.  The frustration that 
mounts in response to this can often be so dampening, and once again you (I, 
whomever) feel beat and trodden by a system that everyone dislikes and knows 
is so ineffective that the very thought of continuing it is ridiculous.

Sorry for the immense ramblings.  I always enjoy you posts and it hurts me 
inside to know that anyone else feels this way, and unfortunately I know that 
many feel this way.  That is precisely, imo, why we are doing what we are 
doing as a community.  We are creating our own society, we are are own family 
and that is such an amazing, incredible and beautiful thing, that it  not only 
keeps me going, but it gives me such immense energy and life.  Unfortunately 
we live in nothing close to a perfect world, but it has so many wonders to 
cherish, our family comes first.  I truly believe that this family cannot be 
torn apart under and circumstances because of its acceptance and promotion of 
diversity in all forms.  So long as we continue to strive for what we believe 
so deeply in, our right to gather and celebrate life, than no one can ever 
take that away.

I wish I was going to be attending F&F, but alas I have ravers illness and I 
need to stay home long enought to get well.  Have the most fabulous time!!! ;) 
 To everyone on the list, and everyone you know and so on, love and smiles, 
this is going to be a beautiful weekend, enjoy each other.

LoveAnais
bliss@rain.org

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Aug 18 20:33:05 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA07877; Fri, 18 Aug 1995 20:33:05 -0700

From: Jason Sydes <jsydes@osiris.ac.hmc.edu>

Subject: Please Read This Ravers!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 18 Aug 1995 20:32:57 -0700 (PDT)
Reply-To: Jason_Sydes@hmc.edu
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL22]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Length: 8673      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey guys,
       (Just one last post before I log off of sfraves for another two
semesters.)

           This is a great post about how to stop E Neurotoxicity!

        After reading that thread about the reorginazation of neurons,
I thought I'd put in a little bit of my knowledge and opinion. I've 
basically spent most of my free time this summer reading the current 
journal articles on MDMA, and I'm a junior chemist at Harvey Mudd College 
(which btw, has a pretty cool scene here...), so I THINK I am somewhat 
reliable of a source (though I am always learning, just like everyone else)

        If you don't like boring scientific brain stuff, just skip to the
        end for answers on how to stop E neurotoxicity. There are actually a
        lot of really effective things you can do, and I've tried to list
        all that I know of (I'm sure there are more things...).

Q: What does E do?
A: It causes the massive release of serotonin from serotonergic presynaptic
neurons. Basically the neurons terminals that contain serotonin as their
neurotransmitter are caused to fire (ie. release serotonin into the synapse)
by MDMA. 
A very simplistic view of serotonin might describe it as the "happy
neurotransmitter," since low levels of it are associated with
depression. After this massive release your body probably cannot recollect
all of your serotonin (some gets degraded, some just floats away). Hence
your serotonin levels drop.

Q: What else does E do?
A: It inhibits TPH, tryptophan hydroxylase. This enzyme is the first of two
steps which transforms tryptophan (an amino acid) to serotonin. Hence new
production of serotonin is halted (or at least slowed down signifigantly).

Q: Is this what causes depression the next day?
A: Most likely, yes. After a night in which a chemical has caused the
massive release of serotonin into the synapse, and then significantly slowed
the new production of serotonin, your serotonin levels are likely to be
markedly lowered.

Q: Is MDMA neurotoxic?
A: Yes. It selectively degeneretes (note - it does NOT kill, as far as we
know) serotonin neuron terminals. In experiments on monkeys, after stopping
MDMA use for approx a year, the neuron terminals were found to
regenerate. 

MY THEORY - It's at this point that the serotonergic neuron terminals grow 
back to the wrong place, hence causing the abnormal connections we were just
reading about in the "Rave Drug May Damage Brain...." or whatever. But this
is just my theory on things...

Q: What causes the neurotoxicity?
A: This one's a doozy.....  After the serotonin has binded to the receptor
on the other side of the synpapse (the post-synaptic neuron), there is a 
reuptake pump (on the pre-synaptic neuron) that sucks back up the serotonin 
from the synapse. Every now and then the pump will suck up a dopamine
molecule (another neurotransmitter that isn't really related to the
"feel-good" effects of E). That dopamine doesn't have any business being
inside of a serotonin neuron, so MAO-B degrades the dopamine, IN THE 
PROCESS OF WHICH HYDROGEN PEROXIDE IS FORMED!!!!! 
        
Q: So what's the big deal about Hydrogen Peroxide?
A: Nothing normally. H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide) is toxic to animals because it
splits in two to form two hydroxyl free radicals, which are very reactive
and very damaging. Normally your body can handle these varmits just fine,
just by reducing them with anti-oxidants (like Vitamin C, E, or
glutathione).

Q: H2O2 and MDMA: so what's the connection?
A: MAO-B also degrades serotonin, but not as well as it degrades dopamine,
but there is usually so much serotonin as compared to dopamine inside of a
serotonergic neuron, that it has a hard time getting around to the dopamine,
so very little H2O2 is formed. HOWEVER, during an E trip, a whole heck of a
lot of your serotonin is outside in the synapse, not in the neuron, so the
MAO-B has a much easier time getting to the dopamine, and hence forming more
H2O2. (Also I think E causes a larger production of dopamine elsewhere in
your brain, and eventually some of that dopamine will get inside of the 
serotonergic neurons). Now there is a much higher level of H2O2 INSIDE of
your serotonergic neurons than your body can effectively get rid of, and
NOW we start seeing brain damage: specifically, selective serotonergic
neuron degeneration.

MY THEORY - The neurons form abnormal connections after being damaged, maybe
because they just hook up with the closet thing nearby. If you could stop
this degeneration damage somehow, there would be no way for the neurons to
grow back abnormally since they are already fine.

                        END OF BORING SCIENTIFIC STUFF

Q: So how do I stop this shitty neurotoxicity?
A: Many Many different ways. Below is a list of the ways I am currently
familiar with, though I'm sure there are probably more...


1) Stop the reuptake of serotonin (and hence the accidental reuptake of
   dopamine also which is the real cause of the neurotoxicity) by taking an
   SSRI (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor). So take:

                                Prozac 

   Take it 3-6 hours afters taking your E dose, and this will significantly
   reduce neurotoxicity. THIS IS A WELL DOCUMETNED EFFECT! This is not one
   of my other theories. If you do this your brain will love you for it. Any
   other SSRI will also have the same effect (Xanax? Zoloft? Are those SSRIs?) 
   This might even make your trip a bit better, because it will keep the
   serotonin in the synapse longer....

2) Stop the breakdown of dopamine by MAO-B. This is the ultimate step which
   produces the toxic hydrogen peroxide. The documented case I read about
   used:

                               L-deprenyl

   which I believe is a commonly prescribed anti-depressant, though when I
   think about it, maybe it's not since.... Well does anyone have any info
   on this or where to get it? It would be greatly appreciated.... Anyways,
   take it the same time that you take your E, cause that's what worked for
   the rats.... Other MAO-B inhibitors will also work (ask your doctor about
   this....)

3) Increase relative serotonin levels. If you eats lots of tryptophan at the
   same time you eat your E, this will overcome the inhibitory effects that
   E has on TPH (tryptophan hydroxylase), which will increase relative
   serotonin levels, which will decrease the degradative actions of MAO-B on
   dopamine (since all of the extra serotonin will be getting in the way),
   which will produce less H2O2, and hence less damage. So....

        Take something like 2-3 capsules of tryptophan with 1 capsule E.

   Unfortunatley, the FDA has taken tryptophan (an amino acid!!!) off of the
   market for what I believe is essentially political reasons (they found it
   later to be a contaminent in a Japanese pharmaceuticals tryptophan
   product that was causing the sickness, not the tryptophan itself.....)
   You can still probably get it in Mexico though and you probably can even
   mail order it for European Pharmaceutical companies. It's not like it's a
   Schedule I drug like E is....
   This might also make your trip a bit better because you will now be
   continually producing serotonin. IT WILL ALMOST DEFINITELY HELP WITH
   POST-E DEPRESSION....

4) Stop the free-radical damage. This is the easiest to do, since
   anti-oxidants are extremely easy to come by. Some suggestions:

        Glutathione - This a naturally occuring tripeptide in your body. I
                      THINK it is one of the chemicals your brain uses in
                      the process that gets rid of free radicals. And it
                      itself is an anti-oxidant....

        Vitamin C
        Vitamin E
        Melatonin (fairly good report in recent Newsweek on this)
        Many others....

   It would probably be a good idea to take some with your E, and then maybe
   about 3-6 hours later....



                 Summary

Prozac & other SSRIs                    3-6 hours after taking E
L-deprenyl and other MAO-B inhibitors   When you take your E
Tryptophan ***                          When you take your E
Anti-oxidants
    Vitamin C
    Vitamin E
    glutathione ***
    melatonin

*** - highly recommend

        Well, that's it.... Hope I haven't gone too overboard. I would like 
to give one last thanks to the SF scene for giving me what I believe was the
greatest summer I've ever had. Thanks much to all you out there who have
make it so special....

                                          lots and lots and lots o luv,

                                                Jason Sydes

> One of the main reasons I love raving so much is that it forms its very 
> own society for a few hours, anyway. I always leave a party a little bit 
> sad for having to face "reality" again. But, again, so often we are 
> "unallowed" to be together for one reason or another: sound permits, 
> trespassing, etc.  It shouldn't be that difficult to do something like 
> throw a small party for godssake!  

World population is at about 6 BILLION people.  Let's decrease that by
about a factor of ten and we won't lack for good party sites, among
other things.  Wonder why everything costs so much?  Too many people wanting
to live in the same space, and we all have to outbid each other for housing.
The low bidders are homeless, the high bidders on the Hill or somewhere 
equally posh.

> I'm tired.  I'm tired of feeling saddened every time I have to leave my 
> little rave community and integrate into a world I want no part of. I 
> want to live a more simple life:  work for a community as a whole - not 
> just for myself or some faceless, greedy corporation (hmmm...sounds like 
> what Pacific and Gateway does for us, no?) I don't think I'm the only 
> one who feels like this.  I think more and more people are becoming fed 
> up and restless with their lives.  We all have a choice and as so many 
> Americans preach, "if you don't like it, then leave!!"  If enough of us 
> are indeed willing to sacrafice and make a huge change, then we CAN live 
> in a society that we want to and we will gladly leave.  I think I 
> decided to go to Burning Man this year because my subconscience told me 
> I was ready and that this was a small taste of what it will be like.  

You aren't alone.  It's hard to get together and change, though, because
everything is set up to maintain the status quo.  Of _course_ businessmen,
brokers, senators, the FBI and the rest of the people we like to think of
as "The Man" want to maintain the current rat race, because it has carried
them to where they are and they want to stay at the top.

The technical challenges of building a mostly self-sufficient community in
the city or the country have been well-researched, implemented, and 
demonstrated to anyone's satisfaction that cares to do some research into
energy-efficient construction, sustainable agriculture, wind/water/solar
power, recycling, and reuse.  The trouble is finding a critical mass of
people willing to put in the time, effort, and cash money to start something
up, and the resolve to stick with it through the growing pains.

There is a group of people called Dancing Rabbit that meet about once a month
in and around Palo Alto who are trying to get together something like this.
I believe they've been meeting for over a year, and there are a lot of neat
people involved, but not enough people have been willing to pony up to the
$80K or so it would take to get enough land and material to get started in
even Bumfuck, Nowhere, doing everything themselves.  There's a lot of energy
and a lot of good skills, but all this rat race does get us the luxury of 
being able to retreat into our OWN apartment by OURSELVES, melt into the
anonymity of the city, and just skate by at our job or on our savings until
the problem goes away.  We can always do this, and committing to a community
means taking away part of that safety net -- everyone could lose everything.

The problem is within ourselves.  We have to make a scary commitment that
our rat race doesn't leave much time to explore, and all our training
prepares us for the opposite (school, work, TV, radio, billboards, jobs, etc.)

> If any of you feel as I do, please, let's talk. I get so many others who 
> give me reasons why it wouldn't work - I need encouragement, not 
> discouragement.  So what if it sounds like I'm talking about forming a 
> hippie commune - we can make it what we want someday. It *WILL* happen 
> one day if our will to change directs us to do so. 

There is a book called the Directory of Intentional Communities that 
has listings for just about every commune/co-op/whatever in the country.

Try alt.co-ops, which should have pointers to these info-bits, and more.

Yes, I want to find, found, or otherwise live in a community which shares
my values instead of Konsumer Kulture and the Wiffle Life (tm).  I know
your pain, and feel it often myself.  Over the years I've been in places
and known people that have or can make it happen.  I am working towards
this myself, by gathering information, forming contacts, and not getting
involved in massive consumer debt (car, house) so I can cut myself loose
from whatever my current job is when the time comes.

What it really comes down to is this: can you stand to find my hair in
your soap cake when you take a shower?  On such little things does 
co-op life stand or fall.

I will see you at F&F!  Not sure what I'll be wearing.  If people don't like
nametags, how about a big sheet of paper ("I'm Here, Say Hi") which we can 
write our name, online handle, and short description?  I'll try to remember
some big sheets of white paper and a few pens...

// g

On Sat, 19 Aug 1995, Grigsbeast wrote:

> 
> The problem is within ourselves.  We have to make a scary commitment that
> our rat race doesn't leave much time to explore, and all our training
> prepares us for the opposite (school, work, TV, radio, billboards, jobs, etc.)
> 

Reminds me: I recently saw B.F.Skinner, (in)famous founder of 
behaviorism, interviewed on a public TV show. His final statement was 
something along the lines of: after having studied human behavior for 
many years, and having endlessly pondered over the ways in which 
behavior/personality could be changed, he now doubted 
whether change is at all possible. While this statement in and of itself 
may be relatively innocuous, coming from such an important figure in the 
field of psychology, it was, nontheless, quite shocking. After a bit of 
thinking, the conclusion that stayed with me was that behavioral change 
may presuppose a deep change/evolution that Skinner may not have been 
able to conceive of. I feel that the altered states of trance that we all long 
for and achieve in various ways through dance/rave/chemicals/whatever, is, 
in effect, the first step of a re-imaging of ourselves into individuals 
and communities able to initiate change.

But then again, it's 6am, I just got home from several hours of dancing, 
and I may just have my head up my ass...

On Fri, 18 Aug 1995, Robert Hughes wrote:

> Any word on Black Diamond at 76 Minna (Oddball Lounge)? I was by the same 
> Thursday that the cops were at Anarchist Disco, and when I left Black Diamond
> at 3am, there was one SFPD car at 111 Minna, but 3 at the Oddball Lounge.

Nope, It's thru.
The cops have leaned on both spots because people were dancing
all night and having some clean fun. As far as I know
the folks at 111 were really good citizens, they kept the door closed (and
thus the sound levels down) and stopped selling beer at 2). When I was
there last week a copper can in scowling looking around (I guess expecting
to see wanton drugs and sex) and found people dancing (doc was throwing down
some serious grooves) he walked around for about two minutes and left.
The excuse is "you need a permit for this kind of gathering" which is another
way of saying that you need to pay us if you want to have a party. (And
I'm not talking about the price of the permit here either)


					G

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 19 09:13:58 1995

Received: from netcom10.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA13218; Sat, 19 Aug 1995 09:13:55 -0700

>Hey guys,
>       (Just one last post before I log off of sfraves for another two
>semesters.)
>
>           This is a great post about how to stop E Neurotoxicity!

There is an even better way:  DONT TAKE E!

Fact is the effects can be stopped in its tracks by not taking the stuff.
Period.  The alternative, taking E, and taking hosts of other synthetic
chemicals to counteract the effects, is tantamount to buying more insurance
every time you get into a car wreck, due to poor driing skills.  The
soultion is to improve ones driving, not buying more insurance.  An even
better proposal in such circunstances is to cease driving until one learns
to drive.

People who tend to do E do maore than the RDA of the stuff.  And since no
real concrete studies have been done on an ongoing basis, it is difficult
for anyone, even our learned frined Jason here, to come up with real
solutions to the problem, much less recommended dosages for safe tripping.
The hypothesis Jason presents is based upon pure E no doubt.  I do wonder
how pure the shit is on the street these day s is, and if there is some
other componenet in the street E that may have other neurotoxic effects.
We just don't know.  So, IMO, unless you make the stuff yourself, and are
sure of YOUR skills as a chemist, stay away.  Otherwise you really don't
know what the hell you're getting.

This much is true, E has changed many times on the street.  When I've taken
it, it used to make me dance really hard, other times it made me piss
blood, other times, it made me feel lethargic, other times, it made me
sleepy, other times I was a happy slappy pappy.  I had been taking all of
the preventative measures outline by Eisner, and Janiger, but still some
nasty side effects.  Fact is, unless I was getting the shit from Sandoz
labs (which never happened btw), I am not really sure WHO the chemist was.
I have taken red/pink E, yellowish E, white E, etc.  And to this date, the
stuff on the street still varies in quality.  Crackin' on ain't what it
used to be, so I stay away from the E.

I am NOT one of those JUST SAY NO kinda people.  I beleive in living to the
excesses, at times.  But even, that must be done in moderation, even for
me.

I just don't like people giving the green light to stuff that is obviously
harmful to them.  You don't see me saying, "Have a beer, your life will be
all the better for it!", because I know both sides of the drug.  Nor do I
go around telling people to smoke weed.  That has its problems associated
with it as well.
I just say everything is ok, for the most part, in MODERATION.  As Markie
told me, "Even moderation in moderation!" (you tricky devil !) ).

Just beware of what you buy, and take care of yourself. Catch a groove to
make you move, and do what you do how you do in moderation. (huh?) :)

Peace out & E 'feelings' to the world,
John



>        Well, that's it.... Hope I haven't gone too overboard. I would like

sort so that he may do some SERIOUS and REAL studies of the drug.  It could
only benefit us all.  Thanks for the info Jason, I've filed it for future
reference!

Peace out bro' !

>Reminds me: I recently saw B.F.Skinner, (in)famous founder of 
>behaviorism, interviewed on a public TV show. His final statement was 
>something along the lines of: after having studied human behavior for 
>many years, and having endlessly pondered over the ways in which 
>behavior/personality could be changed, he now doubted 
>whether change is at all possible. While this statement in and of itself 
>may be relatively innocuous, coming from such an important figure in the 
>field of psychology, it was, nontheless, quite shocking. After a bit of 
>thinking, the conclusion that stayed with me was that behavioral change 
>may presuppose a deep change/evolution that Skinner may not have been 
>able to conceive of. I feel that the altered states of trance that we all long 
>for and achieve in various ways through dance/rave/chemicals/whatever, is, 
>in effect, the first step of a re-imaging of ourselves into individuals 
>and communities able to initiate change.
>
>But then again, it's 6am, I just got home from several hours of dancing, 
>and I may just have my head up my ass...
>
>

no. you don't.  ask any reborn catholic (like me (don't shoot me for that.
i've had too many "open minded people" get mad at me for being actholic))
and they will tell you that to truly form a new society (the kingdom of god,
in christian parlance), you must give up all the aspects of this society and
follow your inner music (give up all your posessions and take up your
cross).  i know it's fashionable to bash big religions, but they say the
same thing as our raver-mindset says, when it gets down to it.

peace and love,
matt
