> >I feel that the altered states of trance that we all long 
> >for and achieve in various ways through dance/rave/chemicals/whatever, is, 
> >in effect, the first step of a re-imaging of ourselves into individuals 
> >and communities able to initiate change.

I think this may be true for some ravers.  But I know for me, raving 
is energizing and relaxing, but not colossally consciousness- 
transforming.  I trance out while I'm raving, but afterwards I'm 
still me.

> and they will tell you that to truly form a new society (the kingdom of god,
> in christian parlance), you must give up all the aspects of this society and
> follow your inner music (give up all your posessions and take up your
> cross).  i know it's fashionable to bash big religions, but they say the
> same thing as our raver-mindset says, when it gets down to it.

Well, sort of.  The original prophets (Christ among them) said things 
like this.  But the organized churches took those ideas and turned 
them into the basis of some mighty large and inhuman Ponzi schemes, 
killing and repressing a whole lot of people in the process.

You're dead right though:  the kingdom of God, or enlightenment, or 
whatever you want to call that clear cosmic clue, is within us.  
Personal transformation comes first.

Some even bigger reasons to hope:  There are many poor 
societies right now where the birthrate is dropping, due to women 
taking their own family planning into their own hands.  There are 
lots of people who recognize that capitalism is a machine which 
converts insecurity into dollars.  There are even some jobs with good 
co-workers and decent wages.  And even with all the greed and fear we 
see around us, there are lots of ways in which our society is more 
free now than it was, say, a hundred or five hundred years ago.

This story ain't over yet.
Rob Jellinghaus     robj@unreal.com     http://www.best.com/~robj

Hey everyone,

With all this stuff regarding the police, I'm encouraging everyone to 
begin using a new "service" that a few of us are putting together.

We're still working out the details of what we want to accomplish, but 
generally, we want to start documenting acts of police misconduct which 
might occur at our events.

Should there be any situations where the police appear to be stepping 
outside their authority, we encourage you to report it.

Email: police_misconduct@hyperreal.com

See you all at F&F!

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>

FSOL film: missed it.     :(
Traci Lords: missed her.  :)
Keoki: nice mohawk, but didn't care too much for his tunes.  :|
Freaky Chakra vs. Single Cell Orchestra:  these guys TEAR IT UP!  And, 
they have a great time doing it.  In the year that I was away, it seems 
these two have gone from twiddling knobs in their Marin county 
bedrooms to knocking on the door of world-wide stardom.  They've got 
their act down, and they're ready to fly!  
Moby: Wow, in addition to providing a full-on techno-rave-rock'n'roll 
show, this guy even gives helpful moral advice in-between tracks- how 
could you ask for more? (example: After throwing his drum pads on the floor, 
Moby proclaims "See, it's not alive, so I can do whatever I want with it.  
Now, if it had felt anything- pain, suffering, then it would have been 
wrong, but it's just a hunk of plastic, so it doesn't matter."  Hey, who's to 
say plastic doesn't have feelings too? :)  He certainly had guts, though, 
to take a stab at SF and its entourage of big-name dj's, and to show us 
his ding-a-ling while posing as Jesus on top of his synth.  At least he 
wasn't boring...
Sven Vath:  a great set of brain-melting hard-trance from the master.  I 
hear he usually like to spin all night (12 hrs+), which could get a bit 
tedious sans large quantities of psychoactive chemicals to keep it 
interesting (one can only take so many fade-in snare drum build-ups in 
one evening and not start to feel insulted).  One hour was long 
enough to get a good feel for his style.  A good closing for an 
interesting night...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 19 12:32:18 1995

From: Seth Joshua Horvitz <acid23@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Plastikman in nature
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9508191257.B22340-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was at work yesterday evening, sitting at the parking lot behind the 
UCB Greek Theater for the Lyle Lovett concert.  I was VERY bored.

So, I started making techno music by banging on anything around me that 
would resonate.  I discovered that the metal tube which comes off the sun 
umbrella I was using, when tapped just right, with varying pressure, 
while keeping my ear very close to the opening, recreated exactly the 
clangy noise used by Plastikman in "Krakpot", without use of 
electricity.  And I wasn't even on drugs.  Really, I wasn't.  

Techno music is an existing component of nature, and always has been.

(seth's thought for the day)

Subject: ENIT

Precedence: bulk

ENIT at the Warfield: Missed Connections and a Nekkid DJ

 After not meeting anyone at Tu Lan , I did the usual queuing-up for the
Warfield , with the usual Market Street panhandlers and ticket scalpers
working the line. Finally let in at about 9:15PM. During the night , I tried
to find someone with an orange "Wired" cap on ( Purple Tiger ) or a burgundy
Alien shirt, black pants , and a goatee ( Sean "House Music All Night Long" ).
Missed those connections - anyway , I was the guy wearing the dark grey
pants and the tie dyed shirt ; I had a rainbow stripped vest on earlier in
the evening , but took it off after it got warm.

 The setup was different than the Orb show - nobody selling trinkets upstairs,
and a turntable setup at one corner. The main stage was full of musical 
equipment, with about three drum kits in view.

 ENIT was supposed to be something more "eclectic" than just house/techno 
music. In this case , the "eclectic" was provided by DJ Spooky's spacy dub 
mixes , and homocore ( I believe that's the new term for punk/thrash music
by gay/lesbian musicians ) by the first live music band of the night , 
Extra Fancy.

 Extra Fancy is a drums/bass/guitar/singer band from LA . The singer is a
good humored fellow , looks kinda like a young Bruce Willis ("Pulp Fiction"
version ) from the neck up, and Henry Rollins from the neck down ( only two
tattoos , tho' - as far as I could see...). Among other things , they did 
a version of a Peter Tosh song that they called "Sinner Man". For some 
songs , the singer would bash a 55 gallon drum with two pipes, showing much 
vigor and precision. They had folks come up on stage and dance ... I remember 
two gals in particular, who ended up in front of the drummer and behind the 
singer . They kind of reminded me of young versions of Patsy and Edina 
( "Absolutely Fabulous" reference there ...). The pair ended up generally 
goofing up behind the singer with not even a halfway decent pretense of 
being into supporting the dramatic delivery of each song.

 After Extra Fancy - DJ Traci Lords!  Strange start to the set - the 
audience staring at Lords as she ... mixed records! Wow! That got tired 
quick , and once we realized she wasn't going to do a Market Street strip 
club gynecological show-and-tell or anything even remotely like a 
performance , we got down to dancing.  DJ Traci Lords seems to have good 
taste in dance music - I had a good time. ( For those fans of Ms. Traci 
Lords' epidermis - the most we saw of it was when she removed her big red 
blouse . Black bikini top - nothing less/more than what you'd see in the 
Macy's ads in the paper ). [ By the way - one of the tunes she played had 
a vocal that went "It's all ... future" - who does that ? ]

 I wandered away to check out the 2nd floor DJ - which at 10:40PM was DJ
Spooky. A solemn black guy with neck length dreads of black and honey brown.
He was spinning some real spacy dub stuff - Depth Charge "Legend of the Golden
Snake" and other 12" with Virgin Records labels on them.

 By the time I got back to the main room , some other DJ had replaced Traci
Lords - a tall blond (?) guy . Anybody know who he was? He had good taste too.

 At 12:08 the Freaky Chakra/Single Cell Orchestra jam session got started.
They do make beautiful music together  - if they ever get a CD out , I'd buy
it. At times during the set , a gal would come out and sing vowels into the
mike in an operatic/chanting way. I think the musicians had the option of
sampling and treating her vocals if they wanted it in the mix.

1:20 AM - Moby. I've never seen him on stage , so I wasn't prepared for how 
much this guy RUNS around ! Jumps up on his keyboard rack occasionally .
Does a lot of dramatic posing too , although always in the mood of the music.
Speaking of music ; it was a mixture of styles  : fast techno/house , 
punk/thrash , Jimi Hendrix' "Purple Haze" , Lynard Skynard's "Sweet Home 
Alabama" , industrial.  ( anybody else who was there care to add to the 
list? ). Helping Moby out were Dean and Scott on two seperate percission kits , and ex-Buzzcock Allie McMarty on bass. 

 I had a quite surprising experience during one of his techno tunes - it was as 
if I was a servo-controlled puppet being twiched around by the music. That 
happened for about 30 seconds - very interesting!

 Between the songs , we got little bits of the Moby worldview - ( ... if eating 
dogs and cats is reprehensible , why is eating cattle OK? Anal sex is fun , 
actually.  A lot of DJs don't get out and dance enough . Too many music 
snobs criticizing {his} musical eclecticism, and the already mentioned
bit from Seth's post about how drum pads have no sensation of pain ).). 

 The post-encore finale tune was "Thousand" , which Moby semi-seriously claims 
to be the fastest tune ever made. It's a crunching industrial thing 
that starts at about120 bpm and speeds up - I may very well go up to 
1000 bpm!  It sounds suspiciously like a train engine sample that starts 
slowed down and then is sped up while keeping the frequency components 
unchanged. This tune required no knob twiddling by Moby , so I guess it was 
a playback or done by persons on the sidelines. At the beginning of 
"Thousand" , Moby was just in his briefs. By the end of the second 
"chorus" , he was nude , standing on his sturdy keyboard , arms outstreched 
a la Jesus-crucifed . 

 He said his final "Goodnight" , and I left the Warfield. I guess I missed
Sven Vath , but I had a good time anyway! 
 
 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Last Friday at 1559 Howard Street, then last Saturday at my house, and last 
night at 2523 Mission I went to three of the best house parties I have 
been to in years.  Remember house parties?  In peoples homes of store 
front space where the music is of all different types and so are the 
people; and there te kitchen scene, or the deck scene, or the roof scene, 
or the bedroom scene, or the dance floor scene; many options await the 
punter.  House parties and outdoor parties are whare it is at and night 
clubs be dammeD.
TRISTAN.
PS Anyone sad at not being at these last two parties which were EXELLENT 
should contact me because these parties are not put on the net, just 
flyerd.  HAVE NOT HAD SO MUCH FUN GOING OUT IN AGES!  THANK-YOU!

I laughed, I cried.. It was a techno rock concert at the Warfield. I should
have gone to Outa Sight at Big Heart City... Moby got naked and said that in
general people from SF are stuck up and don't know good music when we hear
it and something about cats and anal sex. Tracy Lords DJ??? Her first record
skipped but I guess she was allright. Maybe she should have goten naked
instead of Moby. I tried to get the video guy to show one of her early
pornos but he wouldn't go for it. Keoki was trippin on something. He had a
bandage on his nose that he said he got from walking through a plate glass
window. I didn't think he was all that great. Freaky Chakra vs. Single Cell
was really good with Daum throwing off his wig into the audience. Sven Vath
was THE SHIT! And waiting through all the previous bullshit was well worth
the wait. He told me that he was coming back to SF in the spring and that he
wants to play at a real party.
The true highlight of the evening was my roommate John spinning records
upstairs and then Spooky showed up and twisted the beat around and sideways
and played some really bizzare tip hop and punk rock or whatever you call
it. Anyways I'm really glad I didn't have to shell out and $$ for any of
this and I guess I had a good time.

 



-Sean
 "House Music All Night Long"

One mans truth is anothers lie.  I would suggest spending addtl. time in SF
and you'll get the big and real picture.  E is made by the Hells Angels, by
mafioso, by money grubbing assholes here in the US.  You should start by
LEARNING how things are run here first.  Please do not take your
experiences in England and apply them here.  They are not analagous scenes
at all.

As for the tone of your message...whatever.  It's obvious you want to start
a flame war.  I wish to avoid one, although the temptation...

In your message, you DID say you'll E your way to heaven.  Which suggest
dosages as part of your lifestyle, which suggest E headom.  Maybe it was an
incorrect assumption, and a leap of logic, but you're an E-head by MY
definition anyway.  And as cited above, in your own words, the road to
heaven for you might be a road paved in E....sad.

Proposition 187 hard to beat.

I'm outtahere,
John S.

P.S.  Tristan, you really seem like a nice kinda guy, but the way you
approach things leave alot to be desired.  Where I'm originally from, if
you were to state things like the way you do, face to face, you'd get your
ass kicked.  And all the E in the word wouldn't save you from that.  You
should try to be less vitriolic, and more considerate of people's feelings.
You remind me of my pompous ass days on the list.  No a very good memory
or time for many on the list, or myself.

I had all the ideas, and knew all the right people, and had all the answers
for these clueless newbies on SFRaves.  The one thing I didn't have was
respect for where they came from, and THEIR experiences, which were no less
valid than mine.  And now I look around and see the folx on the list being
very positive, changing things in their own way.  Networking and doing the
shit OTHERS are now just talking about.  Look at the number of people on
the list who have been going out AND doing parties now for 2 years or more.
You gotta respect that.  You also should respect the fact that people have
valid and important experiences here.  Instead of discounting their truth
for yours, maybe you might want to spend some time understanding what
things are about, before diving into how "right" you are, and how clueless
everyone else is.  Be lucky you're in SF, it's one of the last free places
on earht with the potential for change!  Cuz' I tell you this much, you
couldn't get away with half the shit you talk in NY, or Miami, FL. without
either a fist or a bullet in your face.  Just something to think about as
you step heavily on OTHER peoples ideas and feelings.  You wouldn't last a
minute in other areas of THIS country.

I'm done, now.  Bye & good luck on becoming part of a greater good.  It's a
long road, but I beleive even you can get there. I did.

Peace.

PSS:  Shouts out to my man Bryce who let me spin @ his Internet Cafe gig!
I had a great time, as did my friend Mike.  Liked hanging with you and your
buds, and had a good time spinning!  Good luck to you, F&F tonite.  Crush
some skulls!

Audi for real this time...

This "If you don't have a ticket don't show up", bullshit is starting to
sound a little redundant to me. The grateful dead have been saying this for
the last 20 years. This separatist, elitest bullshit killed that scene. I
will give the same advise to Ethan et all, that I also have given to the GD.
If you're going to have a public party obtain a space big enough for all
people willing to attend! We are all on this trip together and we shouldn't
exclude the rest of the world to save intamacy. Intamacy is closing the doors
to others.We need more open doors in this world. If a private party is what
you want, then send out invitations to friends and family. If a small public
party is what you want, then don't advertise for months ahead of time and
don't have the party on Saturday night? These are my attitudes and may be
taken with however many grains of salt you wish. I personally will not be
attending F&F, I only attend partys in which I and all others are cordially
appreciated. Have a great night, I will see ya 'round! PEACE!!!!  =  )

Just a little note for for the E crew.....
        Xanax is not an SSRI its a benzodiazapine....that is to say its 
in the same family as valium....it has no effect on seretonin 
sites...thus does not effect E's level of neurotoxicity.  Though it may 
lessen the anxiaty that accompanies the crash it does so through 
another type of neurotransmitter GABA.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Aug 20 11:27:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA00607; Sun, 20 Aug 1995 11:27:58 -0700

	id AA18606; Sun, 20 Aug 95 11:27:51 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9508201827.AA18606@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: F&F!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 20 Aug 95 11:27:50 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We got there pretty early and drove through what was really more of a friendly
checkpoint than a map point.  The party was already going off in a major way
when we arrived at around 11:30.  PLenty of room in the main warehouse dance
area.  The lighting was really nice:  a spinning oil projection covered the
entire wall behind the DJ.  Above the DJ was some kind of intellibeam thing.
And another wall hosted some really cool video projections.  Later on, the
oil and intellibeam were replaced by a nice lazer and strobes.  I really like
it when the visuals are varied over the course of a party.  Kudos again to
Michael Clay and other I'm sure.

The sound was pretty good for a warehouse setup.  Not super-crisp, but full
and bassey with no distortion, plenty of volume and no metal rattling or
weird reverberation.  We had no trouble trancing out with it.  The 2 outdoor
ambient areas also had really good sound and some nice visual projections.

The vibe was great; lot's of people dancing hard, hands-in-the-air, smiles,
shouts, hugs.  At one point I remember thinking  that this is really what the
scene is all about; people putting it together for the love of it, people 
coming and participating for the love of it. 

I couple of very minor gripes: I found the big balloon balls on the dance
floor pretty annoying.  Although they added to the fun, it was pretty
distracting to have to avoid getting hit by them or being repeatly shoved
by everyone lunging to get their whacks in.  Happily, the balls eventually
met their fate at the end of an incense stick or some sharp object.

The music was relentlessly hard and fast by SF standards.  We really got
into it and I worked up a pretty good sweat,  but 2 sets of that is usually
more than enough for me, especially indoors with the temperature rising.
Of course, we always had the option of chilling, but we really mostly like to
dance at parties.  I think if things had started off a little slower and 
worked its way up in intensity we might have stayed longer.

But we really did have a great time; it was nice seeing everyone.  Thanks
to the F&F crew and all the rest!  Also, a special thanx to whoever
made the site possible, Greg&Cindy I think?

Oh, and about that issue of elitism someone brought up concerning the need
to buy advanced tickets.  The hard reality is that whether it's F&F, Sunset,
FMR, a cool house party; a multitude of methods have been used to
exclude the hordes from overrunning what the organizers can handle.  When
you think about it, advanced tickets is less elitist than word-of-mouth,
selective flyering, or secret phone numbers.  Anyone who really wanted
to had a few days to go and get one a ticket, or could have asked a friend to
get one.  But obviously, the real solution is for more people to throw great
cheap parties.  And this seems to be happening. :-)


Lee
_______________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com

What The Grateful Dead Can Teach F&F

( I was feeling pretty good after F&F , then I logged on and read the
 following post from Begroovy@aol.com. I still think F&F was good , but
 I must exercise my crabby gland and give my reaction to Begroovy's
 post in the recent "The Rumor Mill" thread.  Also - I'm not a card-carrying
 member of Friends & Family , but I do know alot of the folks in it ,
 so I can't claim 100% objectivity. I've also been a Deadhead in my
 younger "Skull and Roses" days ... )

> Date:    95-08-19 16:30:02 EDT
> From:    Begroovy  (  Begroovy@aol.com  )
> To:      brianvan@liberty.liberty.com
>
> This "If you don't have a ticket don't show up", bullshit is starting to
> sound a little redundant to me. The grateful dead have been saying this for
> the last 20 years. This separatist, elitest bullshit killed that scene.

 Took 20 years to die , huh? In my opinion , what "killed" that scene
was the vast increase in the number of "fans" who made touring for the
Grateful Dead a nightmare as far as logistics , siting , and legal
responsibility was concerned. 

> I will give the same advise to Ethan et all, that I also have given to
> the GD.

 See his disclaimer about "taking his advice with a grain of salt" later
in this post before replying in a knee-jerk reaction to such 
egomanical condescension . Maybe I'm overreacting , but , since I don't know
anything about Begroovy , I don't know if (s)he has had any responsiblity
for or experience in the creation and performance of rock concerts or raves 
for large groups of people. I assume very little , thus my reaction.

> If you're going to have a public party obtain a space big enough for all
> people willing to attend! We are all on this trip together and we shouldn't
> exclude the rest of the world to save intamacy.

  "Saving intimacy" had nothing to do with limiting tickets - it was done to
ensure that the proper balance of site and crowd density was kept within
the range where it would be an enjoyable experience for all concerned , and 
also to avoid the attentions of the police -  an overflow crowd attacts cops.
Friends and Family has had one very bad experience with overcrowding
due to counterfeit tickets in the early part of this year. When the cops 
shut that party down , both the F&F and the ravers there lost out.

> Intamacy is closing the doors
> to others.We need more open doors in this world. If a private party is what
> you want, then send out invitations to friends and family. If a small public
> party is what you want, then don't advertise for months ahead of time and
> don't have the party on Saturday night?

 This party being discussed was not formally advertised until Aug. 7th.  Your
sense of time needs tweaking.  As far as having it on Saturday night - all the
better  , as folks who miss out on buying tickets can go to other events 
happening on the same night. Friends and Family went out of their way to get 
a stack of Tribal Funk flyers to give to folks who insisted on showing up 
without tickets. 

 According to the sfraves calender , there were three other events to go to :
Tribal Funk , Divine , and Eternia.  Plus four weekly events listed for 
Saturday evenings. Unlike the Grateful Dead , who became the "sole source" 
of yearly traveling parking lot mini-Woodstocks , Friends and Family's party 
last night was not the only happening in the area.

> These are my attitudes and may be
> taken with however many grains of salt you wish. I personally will not be
> attending F&F, I only attend partys in which I and all others are cordially
> appreciated.

 How was Tribal Funk/Divine/Eternia ? 

>  Have a great night, I will see ya 'round! PEACE!!!!  =  )

That was Begroovy - this was Larry " Getting to be like John S. Lee in my
      old age" Ching / larryc@netcom.com

> > This "If you don't have a ticket don't show up", bullshit is starting to
> > sound a little redundant to me. The grateful dead have been saying this for
> > the last 20 years. This separatist, elitest bullshit killed that scene.
> 
>  Took 20 years to die , huh? In my opinion , what "killed" that scene
> was the vast increase in the number of "fans" who made touring for the
> Grateful Dead a nightmare as far as logistics , siting , and legal
> responsibility was concerned. 
> 
> > I will give the same advise to Ethan et all, that I also have given to
> > the GD.
> 
>  See his disclaimer about "taking his advice with a grain of salt" later
> in this post before replying in a knee-jerk reaction to such 
> egomanical condescension . Maybe I'm overreacting , but , since I don't know
> anything about Begroovy , I don't know if (s)he has had any responsiblity
> for or experience in the creation and performance of rock concerts or raves 
> for large groups of people. I assume very little , thus my reaction.
> 
> > If you're going to have a public party obtain a space big enough for all
> > people willing to attend! We are all on this trip together and we shouldn't
> > exclude the rest of the world to save intamacy.
> 
>   "Saving intimacy" had nothing to do with limiting tickets - it was done to
> ensure that the proper balance of site and crowd density was kept within
> the range where it would be an enjoyable experience for all concerned , and 
> also to avoid the attentions of the police -  an overflow crowd attacts cops.
> Friends and Family has had one very bad experience with overcrowding
> due to counterfeit tickets in the early part of this year. When the cops 
> shut that party down , both the F&F and the ravers there lost out.
> 
> > Intamacy is closing the doors
> > to others.We need more open doors in this world. If a private party is what
> > you want, then send out invitations to friends and family. If a small public
> > party is what you want, then don't advertise for months ahead of time and
> > don't have the party on Saturday night?
> 
>  This party being discussed was not formally advertised until Aug. 7th.  Your
> sense of time needs tweaking.  As far as having it on Saturday night - all the
> better  , as folks who miss out on buying tickets can go to other events 
> happening on the same night. Friends and Family went out of their way to get 
> a stack of Tribal Funk flyers to give to folks who insisted on showing up 
> without tickets. 
> 
>  According to the sfraves calender , there were three other events to go to :
> Tribal Funk , Divine , and Eternia.  Plus four weekly events listed for 
> Saturday evenings. Unlike the Grateful Dead , who became the "sole source" 
> of yearly traveling parking lot mini-Woodstocks , Friends and Family's party 
> last night was not the only happening in the area.
> 
> > These are my attitudes and may be
> > taken with however many grains of salt you wish. I personally will not be
> > attending F&F, I only attend partys in which I and all others are cordially
> > appreciated.
> 
>  How was Tribal Funk/Divine/Eternia ? 
>

         O.k, I don't know how well organized my thoughts will be here
  as I sit still bathing in the warmth of the F&F sunshine:). I do have 
to say that this has to be the best party I have gone to since I ventured 
out to C.A. from the N. Virginia area @ years ago. I tend to rate a party 
on just simpily the pure energy I feel from those around me and believe 
me I was a drowning:). I arrived at the site @3/4 P.M. to start helping 
set up and it is a perrrtttyyyy thing to see all these devoted people 
working their asses off to set it all up. Now I know there were alot of 
gripes about the unavailibilty of tickets. I can only wish that any one 
could of showed up; ticket or not, but it was in the best interests of 
Ethan and crew to keep attendance at a safe and certain #. THings started 
to get a little tricky with parking as the night progressed.
      The d.j.'s had quite the energy punch to supply the night and the crowd
with loads of FAMILY love. I want to especially thank , as always , 
Ethan, Tom, and Phred who gave me just what I like in the morning some 
Funky House. As i said before the people are what can make the party for 
me. Sure, you can the most awesome D.J.'s , but you need that certain 
crowd that is just going to take off with the D.j. I 've never danced 
sooo hard! At one point I was looking down at the ground wondering what 
force was keeping my feet going. I would like give many thanks ( and If I 
get your name wrong it is only because of lack of zzzzzzzzz) to the 
gorgeous Rachel, sidekick Vanessea and Rob for letting me be me, Wayne - 
for the warm cuddles and sacred security. Micheal "e" Clay you and Patrick
gave enough visual output to drench the senses for weeks to come. Greg 
and cindy, I 'm glad to know what the real Greg and Cindy look like. 
Oh boy I feel as though I've gone way off the track here, I' ll have to 
post in a couple of days when I'm a bit more mentallyt capable of  
threading my thoughts together. In conclusion, I just have to say that I 
can appreiciate what the word FAMILY means. Thank you all who made my 
night certainly one of the most memoriable. Take care all, I love you.
:):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):)::):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):):) 
                              RAY- GUN

Subject: Of Mis-directions, a slip, and hidden ambient room..
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Seeing that everyone and thier half-brother Bob was going to ENIT.   I
decided to head off to cyber-wave trace stuff in Oakland.....

Well, I must say getting there in itself was an adventure... After riding
around east Oakland (or, shall I say, The Hood') for a 1/2hr. or so I decided
that maybe I was In the wrong side of town...  So I re-called, wrote down the
directions and managed to find the site around 12:30...

Intimate crowd, good vibe, however, I havent been to an allniter for almost a
month and it showed.. 
I slipped and fell (ouch, concrete is very unforgiving) once.   But the
people, the music was all beautiful.  Caught a few smiles and one or two
huggs.  No light show, but the weird paintings and the blacklights had great
tripabilty potental.  I danced through Myster-e perfomance.  Then nesteled
onto the floor and caught a few zzz's during Mars set (and although the music
certianly wasn't the type to lull one to sleep, it did make for some very
intense visions...).

One of the gems of this event was the "hidden" ambient room off in the corner
of the warehouse.  It was located in a hallway and the larger room totally
muffled the music.  I happend to it by chance when I saw someone walk down
the hallway.  Nice tunes tho.

Smile O meter:

Vibe:                   8Smiles
Dancin' Space:     9Smiles (concrete still the best media for steppin')
Smiles&Huggs:   9Smiles (Intamite crowds make for ideal conversation grounds)

Overall rating:  8.something or rather (you figure it out, im too tired)
In closing, don't worship people for what they do.  Love people for who they
are.....

Adam

Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id CAA05167 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 21 Aug 1995 02:45:19 -0700
Date: Mon, 21 Aug 1995 02:45:19 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199508210945.CAA05167@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: F&F goes OFF!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It was a pretty awesome event no matter how you look at it.  Well planned,
great music, excellent visuals, wonderful people, a perfectly sized and
located spot.  Nobody I talked with so far has said they had anything less
than a very good time and some did quite a bit better :)

With two outdoor ambient/tripbeat/chill areas and the main dance room, there
was plenty of music to choose from.  I don't want to play favorites or
anything, but I kinda liked the sets Jon Santos, John Carrel and Moonpup
did especially.  Moonpup showed me some moves on the Denon 2000 CD mixer
that proved again what a really good DJ can do with a, um, limited interface
than usual to get on track, but I liked the second half pretty well.  In
retrospect we should probably have wrapped up around 7, because it was
clear we exceeded the stamina limits, especially mine!  But it was really
an honor to finish this one up, and despite some disappointment in my
selections, I was more comfortable with the mechanics of spinning than ever
before, and that's very important to me as a stepping-stone to a more
responsive mix in the future . . .

What can I say about all the people who really made it happen!  Thanks
again, y'all are the best and it's always worth the trip!!

c u in the future
phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Aug 21 05:51:45 1995

Date: Mon, 21 Aug 1995 08:51:03 -0400
From: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
Message-Id: <199508211251.IAA01665@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, ff-planners@priscilla.ultima.org
Subject: F&F DJ viciousness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

_THANK_YOU_ to the F&F DJs Sat night who, with an uncustomary complete
lack of any mercy at all, ripped into pounding hard acid trance, sick
tribal techno, other unspeakable things, and kept it relentlessly
going _most_of_the_night_. I've been wanting that so badly for so
long, to get it at F&F is icing on the cake. I normally don't try to
emphasize DJs too much, but this time was really special.

And it worked; they danced like crazy, the party ended, everyone fell
down :).

The crowd size was just right. Chalk that up to advance ticket sales
and good estimation of the space capacity.

And of course thanks to everyone that worked hard to make it happen and
those who brought their smiles. :)

Sean

F&F was a good party.  It would have been a great party if they had had 
dj's playing there that were able to listen to and assees a crowd and 
play music accordingly.  Slamming techno is alright for a set but a 
whole night of it is just aural masturbation by a couple of ego infested 
people who have about as much musical sense as a choir boy.  Yet another 
sad example of how the ego can ruin what would have otherwise been a 
perfect night. BUt the vibe was really good and strong.
TRISTAN.
On Sun, 20 Aug 1995, 
Lee Fogel wrote:

> We got there pretty early and drove through what was really more of a friendly
> checkpoint than a map point.  The party was already going off in a major way
> when we arrived at around 11:30.  PLenty of room in the main warehouse dance
> area.  The lighting was really nice:  a spinning oil projection covered the
> entire wall behind the DJ.  Above the DJ was some kind of intellibeam thing.
> And another wall hosted some really cool video projections.  Later on, the
> oil and intellibeam were replaced by a nice lazer and strobes.  I really like
> it when the visuals are varied over the course of a party.  Kudos again to
> Michael Clay and other I'm sure.
> 
> The sound was pretty good for a warehouse setup.  Not super-crisp, but full
> and bassey with no distortion, plenty of volume and no metal rattling or
> weird reverberation.  We had no trouble trancing out with it.  The 2 outdoor
> ambient areas also had really good sound and some nice visual projections.
> 
> The vibe was great; lot's of people dancing hard, hands-in-the-air, smiles,
> shouts, hugs.  At one point I remember thinking  that this is really what the
> scene is all about; people putting it together for the love of it, people 
> coming and participating for the love of it. 
> 
> I couple of very minor gripes: I found the big balloon balls on the dance
> floor pretty annoying.  Although they added to the fun, it was pretty
> distracting to have to avoid getting hit by them or being repeatly shoved
> by everyone lunging to get their whacks in.  Happily, the balls eventually
> met their fate at the end of an incense stick or some sharp object.
> 
> The music was relentlessly hard and fast by SF standards.  We really got
> into it and I worked up a pretty good sweat,  but 2 sets of that is usually
> more than enough for me, especially indoors with the temperature rising.
> Of course, we always had the option of chilling, but we really mostly like to
> dance at parties.  I think if things had started off a little slower and 
> worked its way up in intensity we might have stayed longer.
> 
> But we really did have a great time; it was nice seeing everyone.  Thanks
> to the F&F crew and all the rest!  Also, a special thanx to whoever
> made the site possible, Greg&Cindy I think?
> 
> Oh, and about that issue of elitism someone brought up concerning the need
> to buy advanced tickets.  The hard reality is that whether it's F&F, Sunset,
> FMR, a cool house party; a multitude of methods have been used to
> exclude the hordes from overrunning what the organizers can handle.  When
> you think about it, advanced tickets is less elitist than word-of-mouth,
> selective flyering, or secret phone numbers.  Anyone who really wanted
> to had a few days to go and get one a ticket, or could have asked a friend to
> get one.  But obviously, the real solution is for more people to throw great
> cheap parties.  And this seems to be happening. :-)
> 
> 
> Lee
> _______________________________________________________________________________
> lxfogel@pacbell.com     (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )     lee@hyperreal.com
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>

[ To SFRaves list ]
As a comment on F&F and in reaction to Lee Fogel's post , Tristan said:
> 
> F&F was a good party.  It would have been a great party if they had had 
> dj's playing there that were able to listen to and assees a crowd and 
> play music accordingly.  

 Well , I suspect that the DJs could only hear the folks that were going
"YEAH!!!" , which probably sounded like positive feedback to the DJs.

>  Slamming techno is alright for a set but a 
> whole night of it is just aural masturbation by a couple of ego infested 
> people who have about as much musical sense as a choir boy.  

 I don't agree with the "ego infested" DJs idea , but I did find myself
wishing for some other stuff every once and awhile. Some sets were more
varied rhythmically than others ( Ethan's comes to mind ). I actully
yearned for house music for variety . I did enjoy the techno when I was
in shape for it.

 I think they were just playing what they knew best - anyway , there were
other outdoor options to "escape" to if one so desired. When I tired of
the main room  ( which was often ) , I checked out the other music spaces,
once I walked to my truck and took a nap in the back for an hour. 

 I really like the Moonpup set in the back chill/altar space - there should 
be more raves where a space is devoted to acid jazz/trip hop/dub/jungle . 
A slower dance alternative for those who still want to move but don't 
have the energy for hard techno.

> ... BUt the vibe was really good and strong.
> TRISTAN.
> 
 Yep!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

my two bits on friends and family - 

this is the first one i've gone to where i didn't stay most of the night 
- i wasn't in the party mood so missy, sho and i went with the pretense 
of staying til about 3am and then going home...

this party was fucking slamming. as usual. :) the space - perfect. the 
crowd - perfect. the music - man, if i could get techno like that on a 
weekly basis in SF i'd be a happy man...

the strict ticket limitations were the greatest idea they could have 
thought of - although that garage was *hot*, there was enough room do do 
anything dance-wise or movement-wise you wanted. 

while talking with many of the people there, the comments of 'man, this 
is a *real* rave' kept popping up again and again...memories of warehouse 
parties in DC and Ohio came back - the view from outside of the energy, 
light, and music coming from the garage brought it all back. this party 
was the jam, it's too bad i was so tired. I probably danced for an hour 
and a half straight while i was there..the music just swept me up and 
kept me going..just wicked wicked tunes. :)

the clincher as to wether the party was genuine was definitely the vibe. 
man. what a wicked wicked vibe going on at this jam...i didn't run into 
one negative person and everybody had the fever. :)

anyway - enough rambling...this party gets the two thumbs up, way up, 
*and* a bag o' chips!

:)

mikebee

::Michel.Battaglia::::San.Francisco:California:::::mike@organic.com:
::mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu::::http://organic.com/~mike::::::::::

     Hey Folks,
     
     .. and now my 2 cents :)
     
                        + Friends & Family +
     
     God, what an amazing party! I think all this has been previously 
     mentioned, but god, THIS WAS A REAL RAVE! The vibe was just intense, 
     with more smiling 'n hugging than I've seen. Was it just me, or did I 
     notice a much 'older' crowd than in previous FnFs ?
     
     The space was just *perfect* for the 500 odd people there. It never 
     got too hot, although most of the people there were dancin' their bums 
     off! Great chill area as well, although from what I heard, around 6am, 
     the word 'chill' became all too real :) 
     
     The music as well was just fantastic! I for one thought there were 
     many fast and slow moments in the techno-trancing that all the great 
     dj.'s put out. It was truly a very contiguous 'journey' from 10:30pm 
     to 7:30am!! And a very very pleasant one too :)
     
     It was great to meet more of ya SFRavers. The energy put out by you 
     all is sometimes undescribable. It makes me so proud of the scene!
     
     And finally, thanks a million to he hard work and dedication of Ethan, 
     Mike Clay, Greg, Cindy, and everyone else who put on what was 
     definitely one of the best raves I've ever been to! Kudos n Hugs to 
     you all.
     
     (: smiles, and blinky light on! :) 
     
     -Sy

Wow - it's only Monday and everybody has already said what Friends and 
Family was like.  :) It was, indeed, incredible.  I took a very good 
friend of mine who hadn't been to a rave before...I thought an F&F party 
would be a good "first time" rave.  Boy was I right!!!  I found out that 
night how much I **LOVE** that faster paced techno-trance.  I don't get 
to hear it often, and when I do, I like to get it in large doses.  All 
the djs were FANTASTIC!!!  The space was perfect for the # of people. I 
was relieved that when it got to be pretty hot and humid in there, the 
main door was raised about halfway.  Thanks!!!  It kept me cool enough to 
dance much longer. 

I got the pleasure of meeting some more sfravers for the first time: 
Elmo, SASA, Purple Tiger and Drenalin. Sorry I missed out on meeting 
others who were there, but I didn't see you.  I did look for you! :)
I think Wayne's idea of a laminated "backstage pass" type of sfraver ID 
is a great one.  I'll pay the $$.  

Well, if Sunset is in the bay area next week, I will see y'all Sunday!!

love,
Amy

p.s.  Less than 2 weeks til Burning Man!!! :):):):):):):)

Well it's great to hear how wonderful of a time everyone had at F&F.  I
almost made it.  I had some friends (Consciousness Lab) playing in the
Ambient space that had some tickets for me.  My girlfriend and I went to
Berkely to have Thai food (yum yum) then to Oakland to pick up a record I
bought from DJ MinorMinor.(thank you very much)  Several time we tried to
get ahold of our friends but they were at the location setting up.  Turns
out we were very close to the party when we were picking up the record, but
DJ Minor being faithful to the F&F crew would not divuldge the location
(understandable).  So we gave up and drove to Mills college and spent the
night on the stage of the Greek theater they have (which was great).  When
we got back to Sacramento the next day there was a message on my answering
maching from Consciousness Lab that said they didn't get the tickets but
could get us in for _free_ if we were there before 10:00 p.m.  OOOOOOhhhhhh
the pain of it all......uuuuurrrrrrggggghhhhhh..  We were like just a few
blocks from the party at well before 10:00..   ...aaahhhhhhhhrrrrrgggghhhh.
Oh well, maybe next time.  I'm really glad the party "went off", just wish
we coulda been there.

Rick and Phelps

	Sunset ruled.  Tha's all there is to say.  A fantastic follow up 
to FnF the night before, which I also had a great time at but was a bit 
too tired to enjoy to the fullest.
	Here's my Stoopid Me story for the weekend:  I was dancin real hard 
up near the DJ booth (I dun remember who it was), but I liked this one song 
so much that I started freakin' out and in the process banged the table 
with my knee and skipped the record.  I felt like such 
a fool.  Am I cursed forever?  Fah.  Gotta be more careful in the 
futcha... but it's hard to keep your balance when you're digging big, uneven 
holes in the sand as you dance.

	AFter this great weekend, what can I possibly look forward to 
that will measure up?  Another Sunset, that's fer sure.



			shub (jon)

Hi all!  Hope your week is off to a superb smiley start.  Had to jump-start
the day myself with a run and a double shot mocha, but the good vibes are
flowing strong now.

Those of you who went to ENIT and provided a self-description--I looked for
y'all, honest I did, but didn't find a one of ya!  I did however meet a
bunch of summer visitors to the Bay area from Germany, France, and some
super fun folks from Ireland!  Had a blast!  Pretty much agree with Seth
and Larry's assessment of the show, so I won't re-hash that whole thing. 
Stayed 'til the end, the last 3 or so hours were super, danced, smiled,
passed out skittles, it was great!

So I was a bit disappointed I didn't run into anyone from the list (at
ENIT) and I think Wayne's ID idea is a great one (thought the button idea a
while back was a good one too)!  I'd certainly be willing to pay for one,
and I think the benefits of meeting others on this list are well worth it.

Briefly spoke with someone while dancing to Sven Vath on the main floor,
Steven (?), asked me if I'd ever been to Sunset and I said I hadn't, if
you're out there, I'd love the new number.  Actually anyone who has the
number, it would be greatly appreciated!  I'd certainly love to take part
in the lovely atmosphere of Sunset that so many have described on the list,
it also sounds like a great atmosphere in which to introduce someone to the
wonderful world of raving, which I've been trying to do for some of my
friends.

Last, but certainly not least...
Brian, thanks for the pick-me-up of the day!...

"****<<<<<YOU'VE JUST BEEEN ZAPPED WITH 1 MILLON WATTS OF
LOVE>>>>>*********"

Sometimes that's all it takes to make an ordinary day extraordinary, and a
great day even better.  You've made my heart soar and I'll be on a cloud
for quite a while!

Peace and love to you all!

annie

I think my message got munged a bit, but the part that dropped was about
my own set so no prob.  I felt kind of out of sorts about it since I was
playing vocal-oriented house (actually quite a bit more vocal than usual
for me) after a long string of techno+trance sets, but looking back 
I realize I simply was going a bit too hard and fast given the levels of
energy expended over the course of the night!  So when I dropped it down
a bit things seemed to flow a lot better.  Just another in the infinite
lessons about how to play records in public :-)


phred

At 6:29 PM 8/20/95, schoudhu@ccmail.abbotthpd.com wrote:

>     The space was just *perfect* for the 500 odd people there.

Hey!  Who you callin' "odd" pal?!

;^)

I just want to say that helping set up this party gave me an opportunity to
see just how much heart and soul goes into a Friends & Family event.  In
case anyone was in doubt, the vibe of a good party truly begins before the
event starts.  Days before.  In the flurry of preperation mid-week I often
asked myself, "Is it worth all this work?"  And then, about half way
through the party I was in one of the porta-potties and could hear these
people yelling and cheering and generally going mad.  I smiled (and shook)
and thought, "Of course.  How could it be otherwise."

Earlier, during set-up, Ethan's son was hanging out and I had to smile at
the thought of it being like father/son day at work.  At one point Ethan
said he had to take 15 mintues to chill with his son and from a mess of
wires and amps and speakers John Carel peers out and say, "O.K., that's
cool."  I imagine you just don't get that at the Crotch-a-dero.

Anyway, these people do it with their hearts in it.  Not for an ego boost,
but to provide an opportunity to the rave community to share with them the
joy and fun in pulling off a great event.  I even had fun parking cars
because each one represented a load of friends coming to party with us.
Every car counted as one, or four, or six smiles to be added to the worlds
largest ball of smiles that is this community.

NO BUST!  (The pre-party seance worked like a charm!)

Peace all!

Tony Rotundo

(And yes, that is my real last name!  ;^)

You people ROCK!

     Yep, you heard how great it was or perhaps you were even part of it.  
     Yes, the music was good and varied (though like a couple of others, I 
     missed hearing some happy house mixed in), but overall the key thing 
     that made this party go off was the vibe and intention not only for 
     the crew that put this together but for the participants as well.  
     Imbibed or not the love was infectious, thick, and sweet.  
     
     It was a pleasure to meet more sfravers and for the many of you I 
     missed, we'll just have to try another rendez-vous (perhaps pre-rave?) 
     sometime.  
     
     As I mentioned to someone the next day, being a relatively new "kid" 
     into the scene it was a great to experience the warm, open welcome 
     into the F&F family by people I consider to be from the early SF scene 
     which makes sfraves so valueable.  Thanks Brian for creating this 
     space.
     
     It was great to go from F&F to Wake & Bake at 76 Minna (Oddball 
     Lounge) and see a few of the same faces still going off.  Some of us 
     just can't get enough...It was strange, though, to have Derrick Carter 
     and Garth spinning with just a couple of people on the dance floor. 
     According to someone working the gig, this was the second Wake & Bake 
     and they're hoping it'll catch on.  IMHO, if they keep a promising 
     line up of dj's and stay away from too many wailing divas like the 
     End-Up, perhaps there is more life on a Sunday morning--for me at 
     least.  I could easily deem dance my Sunday religion and skip going 
     out most weekend nights.
     
     After chilling for a while, I was talked into driving down to Sunset 
     (like I needed my arm twisted) to continue our weekend mission of 
     love.  Initially most of us chilled as we swapped reports of Tribal 
     Funk & F&F.  I still haven't heard from anyone who went to Eternia 
     (did they get a new space?) and Divine.  Evidentally Derrick Carter 
     and Dan?? (or is my memory failing me?) tried to top eachother at 
     Tribal Funk making the crowd go crazy.  
     
     When we finally rejuvenated, everything started coming together and 
     there we were dancing hard once again.  I didn't catch the line-up but 
     Tony's consistently incredible with his sets, and I wished I had more 
     energy and less of something else to continue dancing--but alas, even 
     this old gal has her limits.
     
     For me, this weekend was inspiring and refreshing to see shared 
     visions and love overcome the negativity we've experienced recently.  
     I'm glad to be a conscious part of it and I think Burning Man will be 
     incredibly unifying for us and our love of dance.
     
     See you on the dance floor!
     Diane

TAKE NOTE:  Tribevibe, the hip cu-seeme reflector for ravers, clubbers, 
cybercafes, and similarly-minded people has changed addresses because our 
machine recently went through some big changes.  

	Old address:  128.138.126.10
	New address:  128.138.129.243

Those of you who are Tribevibe regulars will have noticed that Tribevibe was 
down the last couple days for this reason.  It is now back up and should be 
working fine at the new address from here on out.

ANNOUNCEMENT:  If you're not doing anything this Saturday nite, 
August 26, 1995, between around 12 midnite and 7 am Mountain Time, tune 
into Tribevibe and watch as we attempt to bring global rave culture to a 
new level by linking raves around the world via live videoconferencing 
over the Internet.  The homebase for this event will be the Skylab II party 
in Denver, Colorado hosted by Come Together, The Tribe, and LowerWorld 
Productions... (featuring Rabbit in the Moon, the Hardkiss brothers, Sniper, 
MC Marvel, local artists-making-it-big NebulaNine, local kickass 
hardcore-and-junglists Vitamin D & Fury, and local party-vibers Tribal Touch 
& Larry Bishop) 

If you are a promoter or friends with a promoter who is throwing a party 
this Saturday and would like to be part of this trend-setting experience 
in rave culture, and if you have some familiarity with setting up and 
using Cu-SeeMe client software or know someone in your area who does, 
please contact Andy Hawks via email (hawks@colorado.edu) or phone 
(303.693.4361) *ASAP* so we can be assured of a link-up by Saturday.


peace and lur.

Precedence: bulk

> ... This separatist, elitest bullshit killed that scene. I
> will give the same advise to Ethan et all, that I also have given to the GD.
> If you're going to have a public party obtain a space big enough for all
> people willing to attend! ...

Yes, in the best of all possible worlds Ethan et all would have
obtained a space big enough for all willing to attend.  I'm sure
that's what they wanted.  Unfortunately, we don't live in the best of
all possible worlds.  So compromises are necessary.  And the advanced
ticket sales seems to be by far the best one.  Advertising a party by
word of mouth or secret telephone numbers IS elitist.  Selling tickets
in advance on a first-come-first-serve basis is not.  Especially since
Ethan has made it very explicit when and where tickets will go on
sale; and warned everyone that they will sell out fast.  It seems to
me that the people who really wanted to go to this party made the
effort of getting a ticket early.

> ... don't have the party on Saturday night? ...

Some people work during the week.  Saturday night is the only time
they CAN stay out all night partying.  It seems to me that a
significant portion of the crowd F&F parties attract is such.

  v
SASA

   I just haven't got the words to describe what a perfect
night it was at the truckyards.  I won't even attempt it.
Here's my geeky trainspotter report card for the early hours:

2:30 AM

Ken Ishii - Vampirella
Overlords - God's Eye
Fridge Trax - Theme Fridge
Propionic - Diphexyl Hydaxtruction
Yanu - Mental Mekano
the Aloof - Religion
Innersphere - Vernal Equinox
Astrocat - the Swarm
Vector - Phantom Cart
the Rotten Duck - the Hunt
Insider - What You're About to Hear
Psilocybin - Delicate Substance
Brain Crasher - Bump
Woody McBride - Electris
Robert Gorl - Psychoring
Mike Dearborn - Outer Limits
S. Stoll & D. Wild - Vector 6
Megalon - Spook
Dwarf - Percuss. Electronique
Dan Bell - Phreak Trak 3
Bourbonese Qualk - Digital Domain
Fred - Niteshade
Plastikman - Fuk (just a snippet)
Dj Sneak - Purple Haze
Crystal Wave
Subculture - Submission
Random Generator - Zone Paging
Universal Age - Mental Anguish

4 AM

....wheew.  the adrenaline is still percolating through
my system.  Downright stellar night of music -- nobody dropped
the ball at all, and Jon Santos, Sabin, & Jeyson were very 
pleasant suprises for me.  I'd give the prize to Jon Santos
for his dextrous turntable hijinx, and for all around workin
that motherfucker.  I've felt nothing more beautiful in this
scene than the F&F luv-juggernaut in motion, and last night
it was rollin!

   - franklin minor minor

Larry suggests:
>  How's about some folks volunteer to make SFR/SFRaves banners ; not
> the big wall hanging ones , but smaller ones that can be flown like
> flags at Sunset and other such gatherings?

One of the things I like about raves is the sense of Unity that can
sometimes pervade an entire party.  I'd have a problem with a banner that
clearly advertised a particular faction or clique within the scene -
unless it's the group that is actually putting on the party.  Last
year the MESS folks displayed an altered, but still recognizable
American flag at a few Sunsets.  Even though I am an American, I
expressed my distress to them about it.  I don't know, maybe this is
just another bug that I haven't removed from my ass yet...

Lee

Marco,

	Hey. You remember me because I had an extra ticket to the Enit
festival... Anyway, I saw your post & I thought maybe I knew what you
were feeling, so here I am writing to you, hoping to offer some comfort
or whatever.

	I just graduated from college last year, and although I never thought
it's what I'd end up doing, I did the standard thing. I got a job that pays
well but means nothing. I thought it would be ok for a couple of years
until I could find my mythical dream job that would probably pay well and
involving saving the lives and or souls of thousands of people/animals/plants
a week & then I could feel good about myself & that would be that.

	Well, after a couple weeks I could tell that the dream job was a dream
and the job job I had taken was taking over my life. I felt like a piece of
the machine and I knew I hadn't signed up for that. I felt like I was, without
my consent, slowly giving up little parts of myself (my dreams, my style, the
less societally acceptable elements of my personality) I was conforming!

	I don't know if this is what you were talking about in your post, but
I didn't know what to do with myself either, I felt like I was falling too. I 
felt utterly out of control of my own actions...

	What I did was I cried a lot until I realized that I'm always in control
of myself. I could not believe I had forgotten my own free will. I didn't
quit my job and embark on a journey of the earth, but I regained my assurance
that I control my thoughts and actions. I'm at my job because I want the money.
It's as simple as that. While I'm there they don't control my feelings about
anything, and while I'm not there I can participate in anything I like. It
might sound like a very little thing - but it's something that was being
obscured from my view and I'm so glad I can see it again. 

	I have plans. I'm not going to get stuck in a situation I can't feel
free in because I'm determined not to & I'm determined not to forget that
I'm determined not to. I'm tempted to get specific, but the specifics don't
really matter at all...

	I guess the point is I would never have gotten here if I hadn't
realized I was falling... I'm proud of you for realizing it about your
life - and for posting. We all need a reminder now and again...

						With much love & respect,

								Kat.

Received: from localhost (doom@localhost) by kzsu.Stanford.EDU (8.6.10/8.6.9) with ESMTP id KAA07086 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 22 Aug 1995 10:27:23 -0700

Subject: Ambient Improv Performance 
Date: Tue, 22 Aug 1995 10:27:22 -0700
From: Joe Brenner <doom@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Tonight (Tuesday, August 22nd) there's going to be a
performance by Mandible Chatter at the Hotel Utah (4th and
Bryant in SF)... they're a group with roots in industrial
ambient that's slowly been losing interest in harsh and
noisy sounds and I would say is now definitely in territory
of interest to ambient techno fans...  The last time I saw
them play at this venue they had a woman doing Tai Chi-like
moves throughout the performance, and recently I've heard
about them performing with a troupe of Butoh dancers, which
may give you an idea of what to expect tonight... or maybe
they'll do something else entirely.  

The opening act is some jazz-oriented improv
people... Ellery Eskelin, a tenor sax player visiting from
New York will be joining the Ben Goldberg Trio (Ben Goldberg
is an excellent local Clariniet dude), and in my opinion
this is an inspired line-up.  A lot of the tracks on Ellery
Eskelin's last CD, "Jazz Trash" have a definite ambient feel
to them: lots of long, slow notes.

I don't know what the time is exactly for this, probably
around 8:30 PM.  Cost is just $3.  

This is part of the "Dark Circle Lounge" series organized
by Gino Robair, if that means anything to you...

Tonight (Tuesday, August 22nd) there's going to be a 
performance by Mandible Chatter at the Hotel Utah (4th and 
Bryant in SF)... they're a group with roots in industrial 
ambient that's slowly been losing interest in harsh and 
noisy sounds and I would say is now definitely in territory 
of interest to ambient techno fans...  The last time I saw 
them play at this venue they had a woman doing Tai Chi-like 
moves throughout the performance, and recently I've heard 
about them performing with a troupe of Butoh dancers, which 
may give you an idea of what to expect tonight... or maybe 
they'll do something else entirely.  
     
The opening act is some jazz-oriented improv
people... Ellery Eskelin, a tenor sax player visiting from 
New York will be joining the Ben Goldberg Trio (Ben Goldberg 
is an excellent local Clariniet dude), and in my opinion 
this is an inspired line-up.  A lot of the tracks on Ellery 
Eskelin's last CD, "Jazz Trash" have a definite ambient feel 
to them: lots of long, slow notes.
     
I don't know what the time is exactly for this, probably 
around 8:30 PM.  Cost is just $3.  
     
This is part of the "Dark Circle Lounge" series organized 
by Gino Robair, if that means anything to you...

I didn't realize what a burden I'd been under at some recent parties trying
my hardest to put out positive energy and keep things going up.  F&F was pure
joy for numerous reasons but a big one was that I didn't have to even think
about trying to increase the vibe -- it was flowing into me faster than I
could put it back out!  I too kept thinking, "Oh yeah, this is what its all
about. How did I forget? "  Thanks and big hugz to everyone, especially Ethan
and crew, for a wonderful night and kickin my faith back into high orbit. 

Maybe its just me, post-F&F energy, end-of-summer increased mammalian
activity, post-Jerry deadhead invasion, or that special new friend of mine
but I feel so much positive energy and activity from this list the past
couple of days.  
Badges, lunches -- what we're missing is bowling I'm tellin ya ;-)

love y'all,
phuture

Subject: Yet another rave report (F&F/Sunset)
Cc: ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friends and Family/Sunset review
================================

Well,  it's certainly been a while since I posted any reports,   so this
is my first one,  now that I finished my programming work,  which was
writing a new language.   I always wanted to know what it would be like
to design a complete programming language from scratch,  designing a
syntax,  and implementing it.   Now that all I have to do is bug fixing,
I can start writing killer reports again,  and work on my WEB page.

Speaking of WEB pages,  I'm looking for any SFRaver/AusRaver who is
willing to send me pictures of themselves so I can include a picture and
link to those that have WEB sites.

Anyways,  back to the report...   Sorry I couldn't make the indoors
Freq-8 party,   but lack of wheels prevented me from attending.   Nor
was I able to attend the Aquatic park Sat afternoon thingie,  because I
was unable to talk Robert into taking me there.

That evening,  Craig lost his ticket to F&F,   but with some sleuthing
around,  reading my SFRave mail,  learned that someone had an extra
ticket and called him 15 minutes after he posted it.   WOW!  What luck.
But when I tried to tell Craig,  he had already made up his mind not to
go.   Besides,  he needed an extra day for his knee to heal.

Thanks go to Robert for getting me to F&F,   and on the way there,  due
to heavy traffic caused by I-80 road work,  we had to detour through
Berkeley,  and on the way,   we saw some rave-like event on the bottom
part of Gilmon St.   Wonder what it was?

We finally make it to High St (Appropriately named - of course),  and to
the Map point.

The venue was a medium size warehouse in a large shipping yard with huge
shipping containers,  and one was put to use as a cozy chill zone area.

As I arrived,   checking things out,   I knew that this was going to be
ONE FAT party,   and it certainly lived up to my expectations.

One thing that really pit a big phat smile on my face was the higher
BPM's of the music.   Omygawd..  It even got faster than 140 BPM's,
quite rare for these parts.

It didn't take me long to get absorbed into all this good energy
floating around,   as I started dancing my ass off.   WOW!! The energy
was INSANE!!   Especially Ethan's set....  I was literally in a trance,
where my brain was somewhere out in the next galaxy...   The video was
superb and provided me with some great "Eye candy".   Great work!
Speaking of Eye candy,  has anyone seen the HeadTravel computer CD yet?
It contains a lot of clips from the SF rave scene/ Sunsets,  etc.
Check it out,  if you have a Mac or PC with CD player.    The video
section is really spacey and provides some excellent EYE candy...

All throughout the wonderfully warm evening,  the energy level stayed
completely off the scale...   As usual,  the temperature was hotter then
I liked,   but thanks to the fans,  and the wonderful warehouse owner
who opened the large door,   the temperature stayed below my tolerable
level.   Providing me with more dance time...

It wasn't until Fred came on,  that things started to slow down into a
more traditional house pace.    But most people welcomed that,
especially after so much hard trance all night.

Things stayed hopping all the way until WELL AFTER 8:30 AM,  and hats
off to the wonderful warehouse owner who was literally getting into the
groove,  dancing just as much as everyone else.

I left shortly after that,  as Robert wanted to get back and get some
rest before Sunset.   As usual,  I TRIED to get some sleep,   but I was
way too energized to even consider sleep.

That afternoon,  we headed down to Santa Cruz but really phucked up and
took the WRONG ROUTE,  and got stuck in traffic.   We eventually made it
in over 3 hours.   As usual,   sunset was PHAT!   and the vibe was
really great.    As usual,  it didn't take me long before I was out
there, dancing like a maniac....   Again,   thanx to the wonderful vibe,
I went into a really great happy trancey space....  Everywhere around
me,  all I saw was a really good vibe,   lots of people (at least 400 or
so),
having a GREAT time.

The organizers of Sunset really have it down,  and never fail to put on
a GREAT party...  taking care to not let things get TOO BIG!!

Sunset went WAY INTO the evening,  with Tony spinning a total INSANE set
of some of the finest trancey house I've heard.   WOW!! This dude just
gets better and better.   Not to be outdone,  Galen finished up the
evening with his usual brilliant set,  always doing different things
with his music each time he goes on.

Towards the end,   the rangers came "en masse" but as Gelen realized
that the beach ws closing,  faded down the music,  and thanked everyone
or coming,  and reminded people to pick up their litter.

The rangers were really nice about it,   and shined the flashlights
around to help us locate our litter,  as I'm sure all they wanted was
for us to leave the beach as soon as possible.

We get word of an After-party on Pacific Ave.  in Santa Cruz,  so head
on out there to check it out.    We arrive and learned that the cover
was only $1 and danced until 2 am before crashing at a friends place in
Santa Cruz.    While I was at Blue Lagoon (Name of the bar),   This
older hippie type dude came up to me,  and said "WOW!!  I like your
energy?"

We talked a while,   but I wanted to get more dancing in before 2 am,
when the Blue Lagoon closed.   Sometimes,  it's hard to balance my dance
time with Schmooze time...

Afterwards,  we left,  and I still have a big phat smile on my face as a
result of over-exposure to all that good vibe that took place over the
weekend.

Crunchman

        Kat and Marco and others :)

        i know this feeling all to well. Right now i'm not able to follow
my dreams because i DON'T have a good solid income.  It's always a trade
off. What has always helped me break out of that feeling of helplessness,
that feeling of heaviness, intertia. Is to step outside of everything for a
bit, either through meditation or dancing or other things that pull you out
of your way of thinking. We all don't realize what ruts we create for
ourselves in approaching problems, and these 'ruts' can start off as being
a 'groove' too.  Routines can go from good to bad easily. So, every now and
then, break the routine: go for a walk somewhere where you've never been,
do something that you've never done before, cut your hair, drugs may help
some people but it can be a crutch for some as well.  Go perpendicular on
your path through life instead of the straight and narrow. ;) Drop
everything, become one with the universe _then_ go back to balancing your
checkbook, you'll find you can deal with it better. Well, it has worked for
me :)
        hope this helps,
                brad

see Sunset flyers.

It's a tough call trying to decide how public to make the number.

Transist 24 Hour Line, additional techno friendly, responsible, clean,

a place. Thanks, & call me if interested, case we may sign a lease at

> >in what I would not really consider a "mainstream" magazine.
>

> and having the number in the Guardian, which I'm sure has a circulation in
> excess of 50,000. And I have to admit, I did prefer the smaller size of the
> first Sunset after the number change. There's a reason why you hardly ever
> see Sunset flyers.

Yes, very true. "You can't make all of the people happy all of the time" 
comes to mind. On the other hand, as one who happened upon the scene by 
themselves, and not through friends, I feel for those that are not as 
"connected." That's all. It saddens me to think how many wonderful people 
are out there missing out, and get discouraged after going to shitty 
parties that aren't worth the cost of the phone call to find out where 
they are, because that is all they can find. It is a bit of a balancing 
act, isn't it?

                                              Black Adder

Recovering too.  I was in SF over the weekend, Saturday afternoon I did
a two-hour slot at Ameba on Haight St., then we had Friends & Family in
a classic "virgin Oakland warehouse" (now deflowered, heh) and I spun the
cleanup spot (literally, they were pushing brooms across the dance floor
when I finished up near 9 :)

Just came back from a meeting of the local club and rave people with
Officer Langston from the Portland PD Central Precinct.  This was to
talk about club-related problems and to move toward more productive
relations with the police.  Reps from Up Front and Montana (Ali and
Jeff), the Quest, D-J from Queer Night, Brad, Yasu and me were all
there.  It was a pretty good meeting, Langston handed out some preliminary
summaries of the police incident reports from the last couple of years
and it really doesn't look very bad at all, certainly not enough to
support the kind of "teenage nightclub ordinance" a few of the police
command types want.  There's a more formal meeting with the city at
1
1 pm on Thursday to look at the latest draft of the ordinance, which
is almost identical to the last one.  I think we're doing pretty well
in responding to this whole thing.  In Portland, at least, there is a
chance to work with the police in a productive way, which currently seems
to be difficult (Seattle) or impossible (SF) elsewhere.

see you in the future!
phred

brian -
hello!  one nitpickey question about milgram.  i thought that he actually
hypothesized that people wouldn't be obiedent.  from my reading of him, he
thought people would not do what they did.  am i wrong?

peace and love -
matt

>
>>Dear All;
>>
>>	Stanley Migram for those too stoned in college to remember, or who
>>never took Intro Into Psych, taught my Mr. Staff, god he teaches
>>everywhere.  Stanley Milgram conducted the Psychological study called
>>Obedience To Authority, which shocked the psychological community of his
>>time, and left important information for those of us still able to read
>>such uncensored texts. 
>>
>>	The study was performed on average people like you and me, well
>>maybe not like you and me, but earth people. The study theorized /
>>hypothesis, that we(earth people) are a very obedient race of beings. That
>>any type of authority fiqure(someone dressed in a uniform, or a lab
>>coat(actual experiment dress)), could tell us to perform tasks, or give us
>>orders, that we would carry out to the letter, even if we were directly
>>aware that these orders were directly hurting/harming/maming individuals
>>we weren't acquainted with, and had no prior knowledge or history of, not
>>even a 1st name. 
>>
>>	The study was conducted with 3 people, the authority fiqure, a
>>test subject/actor, and the earth people.  The earth people were told that
>>this subject/actor was the person the study was being conducted on, when
>>it was really the earth people the study was being performed on. They
>>didn't know, until the study was over, that it was all fake, and that the
>>person they thought was the subject, was really an actor. 
>>
>>	The earth people were led into a room in which they could not see
>>the subject/actor, and then placed in front of a console with a bunch of
>>switches. The switches were labeled from left to right with increasing
>>voltages marked on each of them. The authority fiqure told the earth
>>person, that he would ask the subject/actor a question, and if the
>>subject/actor got the question wrong, that the earth person should throw
>>the 1st switch, and that it would shock the subject/actor with the voltage
>>label on that particlur switch. The more ?'s the subject/actor got wrong
>>the higher the voltage went, the more severe the shock would be ...etc. 
>>
>>	What was actually happening, as the earth person threw a switch to
>>a wrong question, it would play back a prerecorded fake response, Like oh
>>that feels funny; at the low voltages, to fits of pain, screams of "STOP
>>please STOP", to finally dead silence at the higher voltages. So actually
>>no one was being shocked, but the earth people throwing the switches
>>didn't know that, and when the authority fiqure would sense hesitation in
>>an earth person, they would say things like please continue, or they're ok,
>>and encourage the earth people to continue.(Pretty Fuckin Scary Huh)
>>
>>	The results, something like 85% and higher of the earth people
>>tested, took the voltage levels to the point where there was dead silence,
>>appling voltages to another human being that were clearly deadly, under 
>>protest, and completing that particular case.
>>
>>	All the earth people who were tested who, were shown the fake
>>board & equipment, and met the actor afterword for tea, just so there
>>would be any feelings of guilt.
