------- Forwarded Message

>  THE PEOPLE WITH HOLES IN THEIR HEADS
> 
>  Amanda Fielding lives in a charming flat looking over London's
>  river with her companion, Joey Mellen, and their infant son,
>  Rock.  She is a successful painter, and she and Joey have an art
>  gallery in a fashionable street of the King's Road.  Another of
>  her talents is for politics.  At the last two General Elections
>  she stood for Parliament in Chelsea, more than doubling her vote
>  on the second occasion from 49 to 139.  It does not sound much,
>  but the cause for which she stands is unfamiliar and lacks obvious
>  appeal. Fielding and her voters demand that trepanning operations
>  be made freely available on the National Health.  Trepanation
>  means cutting a hole in your skull.
> 
>  The founder of the trepanation movement is a Dutch savant, Dr.
>  Bart Hughes. In 1962 he made a discovery which his followers
>  proclaim as the most significant in modern times.  One's state
>  and degree of consciousness, he realized, are related to the
>  volume of blood in the brain.  According to his theory of evolution,
> the adoption of an upright stance brought certain benefits to the
>  human race, but it caused the flow of blood through the head to be
>  limited by gravity, thus reducing the range of human consciousness.
>  Certain parts of the brain ceased or reduced their functions while
>  others, particularly those parts relating to speech and reasoning,
>  became emphasized in compensation.  One can redress the balance by
>  a number of methods, such as standing on one's head, jumping from
>  a hot bath into a cold one, or the use of drugs; but the wider
>  consciousness thus obtained is only temporary.  Bart Hughes shared
>  the common goal of mystics and poets in all ages: he wanted to
>  achieve permanently the higher level of vision, which he associated
>  with an increased volume of blood in the capillaries of the brain.
> 
>  The higher state of mind he sought was that of childhood.  Babies
>  are born with skulls unsealed, and it is not until one is an adult
>  that the bony carapace is formed which completely encloses the
>  membranes surrounding the brain and inhibits their pulsations in
>  response to heartbeats.  In consequence, the adult loses touch with
>  the dreams, imagination and intense perceptions of the child.  His
>  mental balance becomes upset by egoism and neuroses.  To cure these
>  problems, first in himself and then for the whole world, Dr. Hughes
>  returned his cranium to something like the condition of infancy by
>  cutting out a small disc of bone with an electric drill.
>  Experiencing immediate beneficial effects from this operation, he
>  began preaching to anyone who would listen to the doctrine of
>  trepanation.  By liberating his brain from its total imprisonment
>  in his skull, he claimed to have restored its pulsations, increased
>  the volume of blood in it and acquired a more complete, satisfying
>  state of consciousness than grown-up people normally enjoy.  The
>  medical and legal authorities reacted to Hughes's discovery with
>  horror and rewarded him with a spell in a Dutch lunatic asylum.
> 
>    Joseph Mellen met Bart Hughes in 1965 in Ibiza and quickly became
>  his leading, or rather one and only, disciple.  Years later he wrote
>  a book called _Bore Hole_, the contents of which are summarized in
>  its opening sentence: 'This is the story of how I came to drill a
>  hole in my skull to get permanently high.'  . . . (a few paragraphs
>  detail Joseph Mellen's early experiments with LSD, and how he finds
>  out about Bart Hughes.) The time came when Joey felt he had preached
>  enough and that he now had to act.  He did not agree with
>  Holingshead that the third eye was merely a figure of speech,
>  believing in its physical attainment through self-trepanation.
>  Support for this can be found in archaeology.  Skulls of ancient
>  people all over the world give evidence that their owners were skill
>  fully trepanned during their lifetimes, and many of these appear to
>  have been of noble or priestly castes.  The medical practice of
>  trepanation was continued up to the present century in treatment of
>  madness, the hole in the skull being seen as a way of relieving
>  pressure on the brain or letting out the devils that possessed it.
>  By his scientific explanation of the reasons for the operation, Bart
>  Hughes had removed it from the area of superstition, and Joey Mellen
>  proposed to be the second person to perform it on himself in the
>  interest of enlightenment.
> 
>    Bart had become a close friend of Amanda Fielding, and they went
>  off to Amsterdam together while Joey took care of Amanda's flat.
>  This was the opportunity he had been waiting for to bore a hole in
>  his head.
> 
>    The most gripping passages in _Bore Hole_ describe his various
>  attempts to complete the operation.  They are also extremely gruesome,
>  and those who lack medical curiosity would do well to read no further.
>  Yet to those who might contemplate trepanation for and by themselves,
>  Joey's experiences are a salutary warning.  It should be emphasized
>  that neither he, Bart nor Amanda has ever recommended people to
>  follow their example by performing their own operations.  For years
>  they have been looking for doctors who would understand their theories
>  and would agree to trepan volunteer patients as a form of therapy.
>  Strangely enough, not one member of the medical profession has been
>  converted.
> 
>    In a surgical store Joey found a trepan instrument, a kind of auger
>  or cork-screw designed to be worked by hand.  It was much cheaper and,
>  Joey felt, more sensitive than an electric drill.  Its main feature was
>  a metal spike, surrounded by a ring of saw-teeth.  The spike was meant
>  to be driven into the skull, holding the trepan steady until the
>  revolving saw made a groove, after which it could be retracted.  If all
>  went well, the saw-band should remove a disc of bone and expose the
>  brain.
> 
>    Joey's first attempt at self-trepanation was a fiasco.  He had no prev-
>  ious medical experience, and the needles he had bought for administering
>  a local anesthetic to the crown of his head proved to be too thin and
>  crumpled up or broke.  Next day he obtained some stouter needles, took
>  a tab of LSD to steady his nerves and set to in earnest.  First he made
>  an incision to the bone, and then applied the trepan to his bared skull.
>  But the first part of the operation, driving the spike into the bone,
>  was impossible to accomplish.
> 
>    Joey described it as like trying to uncork a bottle from the inside.
>  He realized he needed help and telephoned Bart in Amsterdam, who
>  promised he would come over and assist at the next operation.  This
>  plan was frustrated by the Home Office, which listed Dr. Hughes as an
>  undesirable visitor to Britain and barred his entry.
> 
>    Amanda agreed to take his place.  Soon after her return to London she
>  helped Joey reopen the wound in his head and, by pressing the trepan
>  with all her might against his skull, managed to get the spike to take
>  hold and the saw-teeth to bite.  Joey then took over at cranking the
>  saw. Once again he had swallowed some LSD.  After a long period of
>  sawing, just as he was about to break through, he suddenly fainted.
>  Amanda called an ambulance and he was taken to hospital, where horrified
>  doctors told him that he was lucky to be alive and that if he had
>  drilled a fraction of an inch further he would have killed himself.
> 
>    The psychiatrists took a particular interest in his case, and a group
>  of them arranged to examine him.  Before this could be done, he had to
>  appear in court on a charge of possessing a small amount of cannabis.
>  The magistrate demanded another psychiatrist's report and demanded him
>  for a week in prison.
> 
>    There followed a period of embarrassment as the rumor went round
>  London that Joey Mellen had trepanned himself, whereas in fact he had
>  failed to do so. As soon as possible, therefore, he prepared for a third
>  attempt.
> 
>     Proceeding as before, but now with the benefit of experience, he soon
>  found the groove from the previous operation and began to saw through
>  the sliver of bone separating him from enlightenment or, as the doctors
>  had predicted, instant death.  What followed is best quoted from _Bore
>  Hole_.
> 
>    'After some time there was an ominous sounding schlurp and the sound
>  of bubbling.  I drew the trepan out and the gurgling continued.  It
>  sounded like air bubbles running under the skull as they were pressed
>  out.  I looked at the trepan and there was a bit of bone in it.  At
>  last!  On closer inspection I saw that the disc of bone was much deeper
>  on one side than on the other. Obviously the trepan had not been
>  straight and had gone through at one point only, then the piece of bone
>  had snapped off and come out.  I was reluctant to start drilling again
>  for fear of damaging the brain membranes with the deeper part while I
>  was cutting through the rest or of breaking off a splinter.  If only I
>  had an electric drill it would have been so much simpler.  Amanda was
>  sure I was through.  There seemed no other explanation for the
>  schlurping noises I decided to call it a day.  At the time I thought
>  that any hole would do, no matter what size.  I bandaged up my head and
>  cleared away the mess.'  There was still doubt in his mind as to whether
>  he had really broken through and, if so, whether the hole was big enough
>  to restore pulsation to his brain. The operation had left him with a
>  feeling of wellbeing, but he realized that it could simply be from
>  relief at having ended it.  To put the matter beyond doubt, he decided
>  to bore another hole at a new spot just above the hairline, this time
>  using an electric drill.  In the spring of 1970, Amanda was in America
>  and Joey did the operation alone.  He applied the drill to his forehead,
>  but after half and hour's work the electric cable burnt out.  Once again
>  he was frustrated.  An engineer in the flat below him was able to repair
>  the instrument and next day he set out to finish the job. 'This time I
>  was not in any doubt. The drill head went at least an inch deep through
>  the hole.  A great gush of blood followed my withdrawal of the drill. In
>  the mirror I could see the blood in the hole rising and falling with the
>  pulsation of the brain.'
> 
>    The result was all he had hoped for.  During the next four hours he
>  felt his spirits rising higher until he reached a state of freedom and
>  serenity which he claims, has been with him ever since.  For some time
>  now he had been sharing a flat with Amanda, and when she came back from
>  America she immediately noticed the change in him.  This encouraged her
>  to join him on the mental plane by doing her own trepanation. The
>  operation was carefully recorded.  She had obtained a cine-camera, and
>  Joey stood by, filming, as she attacked her head with an electric drill.
>  The film shows her carefully at work, dressed in a blood-spattered white
>  robe.  She shaves her head, makes an incision in her head with a scalpel
>  and calmly starts drilling.  Blood spurts as she penetrates the skull.
>  She lays aside the drill and with a triumphant smile advances towards
>  Joey and the camera.
> 
>     Ever since, Joey and Amanda have lived and worked together in
>  harmony. From the business of buying old prints to color and resell,
>  they have progressed to ownership of the Pigeonhole Gallery and seem
>  reasonably prosperous.  They have also started a family.  There is
>  nothing apparently abnormal about them, and many of their old friends
>  agree in finding them even more pleasant and contented since their
>  operations.  There is plenty of leisure in their lives, mingled with the
>  kind of activities they most enjoy.  These of course include talking and
>  writing about trepanation.  They have lectured widely in Europe and
>  America to groups of doctors and other interested people, showing the
>  film of Amanda's self-operation, entitled _Heartbeat in the Brain_.  It
>  is generally received with awe, the sight of blood often causing people
>  to faint.  At one showing in London a film critic described the audience
>  'dropping off their seats one by one like ripe plums'.  Yet it was not
>  designed to be gruesome. The soundtrack is of soothing music, and the
>  surgical scenes alternate with some delightful motion studies of
>  Amanda's pet pigeon, Birdie, as a symbol of peace and wisdom."
> 
> 
 




- --Boundary-153880-0-1--
- --Boundary-153880-0-0--

------- End of Forwarded Message

     Over a year ago Brian Behlendorf, sfraves list founder and moderator, 
     bought a machine to host sfraves, the techno-rave archives, the drug 
     archives, and various othe rave and non-rave-related lists and 
     projects on. 
     
     At that time he submitted a domain name registration to the INTERNIC 
     for sfraves.org.  So, to answer your question, he filled out a form to 
     get the name for the machine.  That's it.  It's just a name, no big 
     governing body or anything.  sfraves.org sounded a lot better than 
     sfraves.com :-)
     
     Laura

No Fuckin Way.....  In a book I read by T. Lobsang Rampa called "The Third
Eye" (best seller at one time I believe).  A young Tibeten monk (the author
of the book) has his third eye opened by a senior lama.  A hole was drilled
in the third eye area and a wood chip soaked in some kind of herbs and oil
was incerted.  Eventually the skin grew back over the area, but after the
procedure the monks perception was greatly enhanced.  Great book.

Rick

On Wed, 23 Aug 1995, Matthew D. P. K. Lanier wrote:
> question - when did sfraves become an .org?  how does one get that status?

When I wanted to make sure no one tried to grab that domain name for less 
than honorable reasons.  Should have done the same for vrml.org, ah 
well.  Don't worry, there's nothing more official than just that name, no 
"organization" headed up by any secret world government under the nation 
of Schwa with Dick Assman as its leader - noo, certainly nothing like 
that.  :)

	Brian

was working. And the next day I got a raise. Call me crazy- But they don't

Dear All;

	I totally agree with all that's been said, E is Not cut with 
Herion. First of all having tried China White, Mexican Black Tar, & 
French Synthetic Herion, the high is nothing like anything I've ever 
experienced on any E. Herion is any of its forms both pharm, & black 
market would kill a lot of people who weren't used to it, due to respitory 
depression., not to mention the cost increase of the drug itself. 

	For me however, having done the two together (prescribtion narcotics 
& E) the high is something to experience, & I find it very enjoyable. 
However I would not recommend that anyone try this unless they are very 
familar with the effects of both of those drugs separately, and then 
being very conservative, and slowly increaseing the dose of each(together) 
over time, and incidence.

	But hears the ?, if herion & speed is called a speed ball, & E &
acid is called candy flipping or trolling, then what would E & narcotics
be called? Suggestions welcome

     A brief lesson about email and the net, for those of you who are new 
     to this.  Forgive me if I bore the techies.
     
     The net's connectivity and reliablity is by no means perfect.  It's 
     not anywhere near as reliable as the phone network, for example (you 
     would not believe the redundancy built into that thing).
     
     For instance, my mail leaves the PC on my desk --> 
     goes out on our local Novell network --> 
     gets pushed through a gateway --> 
     gets put out on a link to UUNET (our company's internet service 
     provider) --> 
     gets passed through multiple machines on the way to UUNET--> 
     once it gets to UUNET, it then gets passed out of UUNET (probably 
     along SPRINTNET) toward hyperreal, again passing through several 
     different machines --> 
     Finally, the mail arrives at hyperreal.
     
     Let's say, for the sake of argument, that my letter passed through 10 
     machines just to get to hyperreal, and that there are 10 machines 
     between you and hyperreal.  Therefore, there are 20 machines and 21 
     individual net-links that my  message must travel over.  At any time 
     one of these machines or links could go down, causing a delay (or 
     sometimes a message to be bounced).  Each of these 20 machines gets 
     its DNS (domain name service) from another machine...if the machine my 
     mail message is on can't contact the machine it gets its name service 
     from, then the first machine can't pas the mail on through the net.
     
     To make things worse, some machines "speak" different mail protocols 
     than others.  There's been lots of work to make these protocols 
     compatible, but every so often a bug surfaces and something doesn't 
     work right ... so mail can be delayed, lost in the great bit bucket in 
     the sky, or be reincarnated in multiple copies arriving in your 
     mailbox.
     
     A lot of the time it's not hyperreal's fault, and there's nothing 
     Brian can do about it.  Believe me, he, Andrew Bennett, and the other 
     hyperreal administrators do stay on top of how majordomo (the sfraves 
     list server) operates and on how mail in general is doing as it passes 
     through hyperreal. 
     
     In a way, it's a marvel that mail works at all, what with all the 
     things that must happen for a message to get from one place to the 
     next.  For example, as Brian pointed out today, something is wrong on 
     one of the links between where hyperreal is and where AOL picks things 
     off the net, so no one from AOL is getting mail (this may be all 
     better by now).  These things happen....
     
     Basically, the Internet is now a collection of networks that talk to 
     each other.  There's really no central routing scheme like the US Post 
     office uses...for example, you'd THINK that if I sent email from my 
     account at Berkeley to my account on hyperreal, it would stay in the 
     Bay Area.  Not true -- last time I checked, it got routed out through 
     WASHINGTON DC to eventually get to Sprintnet's gateway, wherein it 
     then got passed back to hyperreal.  It's vaguely like a freeway -- 
     sometimes you need to go past your destination to get to an exit that 
     will let you on the road you really need.  Actually, it's more like 
     flying internationally -- to get to Swansea (Wales), you might fly to 
     London (closest major international gateway) and then depend on 
     services in London to get you to Swansea.  Along the way there can be 
     bad weather (bursty internet traffic, downed routers, brain-dead DNS), 
     equipment problems (machines down), and dealing with customs 
     (different mail protocols talking to each other).
     
     Yours for better Internet understanding,
     
     Laura

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA04511; Wed, 23 Aug 1995 19:18:27 -0700

Message-Id: <v02130505ac6182ccb9b1@[131.146.2.200]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, laural@inmark.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@collab.com>
Subject: Re: My Mailbox From Hell!!!!!;
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi there,

What was said was more true when hosts were primarily connected to the
Internet via UUCP. It was truly a co-opeartive effort, and back when my
friends and I first got our AT&T Unix PC's connecting to each other (circa
1985) and sending mail around it used to amuse us to see the wacky and
mysterious routes our mail took.

Now, most computers (or mail hosts, that is) are directly connected to the
Internet via TCP/IP and use SMTP to send the mail along its way.

In my case, I use Eudora on my Mac. When I press the "send" button it
connects directly using SMTPto my collab.com (my mail host) which is a
machine that's always running at my loft. Our loft network is directly
connected to the internet via a dedicated digital line. Because of this, in
our case, no UUCP is involved. As a result of the direct TCP/IP Internet
connectivity of both 'collab.com' and 'hyperreal.com', the hosts directly
connect and transport mail to each other using the SMTP protocol running on
top of TCP/IP. From 'hyperreal.com', it is delivered as directly as
possible to the hosts that each of you have your accounts on. If you
connect to an internet service provider (Netcom, Best, PSI, etc.) there's a
very, very high chance that Hyperreal.com was able to directly connect to
and deliver your mail to your mail host directly. If you are on a LAN not
directly connected to the Internet, then there's some host that has to dial
up and check for mail that's waiting for you on some directly connected
host that is configured to me your (or your company's) mail host.

This stuff's a bit boring to some (I am sure), but becomes more interesting
when things aren't working and you're wondering why... This is by no means
a complete description of Internet mail transport, (hey, it's a rave list,
right? not comp.protocols.tcp-ip!) but I just wanted to interject a bit
more info).

It's F&F review time, part 87!

Last week's F&F was the best event I've ever been to. If there were an
ideal "warehouse rave" I would have ever pictured in my mind, this was it.
The outdoor ambient areas were very cool, especially the carpeted one where
the Jerry Garcia shrine was. It was like a little Ewok village with all the
people piled around on those bean bags later in the night. I spent a bit of
time there myself!

In order, my favorite events I've been here are: last week's F&F, Wicked
(in June) at 174 King St., and that small renegade outdoor F&F at the
Albany landfill a few months ago.)

Fred Heutte wrote:

> There is an excellent organization in San Francisco called HEAR which
> puts out info on ear protection for musicians and listeners.  Contact
> flash@well.sf.ca.us for more info.


At Hyperreal <http://hyperreal.com/raves/health/tinnitus.FAQ>
is a FAQ about Tinnitus, which is characterized as "ringing ears" 
due to external loud noises. It's quite interesting. 

I would post it, but it's really long!

-Cindy
aka Sea Of Sin

a few comments...

> 
> > ... This separatist, elitest bullshit killed that scene. I
> > will give the same advise to Ethan et all, that I also have given to the GD.
> > If you're going to have a public party obtain a space big enough for all
> > people willing to attend! ...

friends and family is NOT a public party ...it's based on word of mouth 
invitations/tickets and is limited to FRIENDS (and friends of friends) 
and FAMILY.  

> > Yes, in the best of all possible worlds Ethan et all would 
have > obtained a space big enough for all willing to attend.  I'm sure
> that's what they wanted.  

i have to disagree slightly here... while i do not speak for the whole 
collective, i must say that i do prefer smaller parties - not over 700... 
once you get over that it can still be great, but it's defintiley a 
ddifferent atmosphere...  especially indoors...however, i would like to 
se not "all those WILLING to attend" attend, but all those willing to 
make it a priority (i.e. getting a ticket in advacne or whatever it 
requires..)  unfortunatley, i think this time there were many willing to 
take the extra steps and just not enuf tickets...however, i am glad we 
kept numbers limited to ensure enuf space and safety for all...

 Unfortunately, we don't 
live in the best of
> all possible worlds.  So compromises are necessary.  And the advanced
> ticket sales seems to be by far the best one.  Advertising a party by
> word of mouth or secret telephone numbers IS elitist.  Selling tickets
> in advance on a first-come-first-serve basis is not.  Especially since
> Ethan has made it very explicit when and where tickets will go on
> sale; and warned everyone that they will sell out fast.  

well, i've got to disagreehere, too...advance tickets may be LESS 
elitist, but let's face it, who is the announcement made to: 
SfRaves...people at Sunset...friends and family and friends...i mean, 
we're not standing on the corner of 16th and Mission screaming it out...

monicat

Ok here is all the info.  First it is SUPPOSEDLY going to run from 6pm 
saturday to Noon on Sunday (although from peoples previous experience, 
I would seriosly doubt it if it runs much past 6amish).  It will be in SD 
county and it will be within 1 hour of all major SD beaches.  Also it 
will be outdoors.  The site/directions should be announced either today 
or very shortly.  Rumor has it that it will be in the Ramona area (very 
strong rumor) which about 1 hour from SD proper.  Hope you all have fun.  
The following is from Socal-raves calendar (kept up by Joachim):


Saturday, August 26

I live in a big house (2000+ sq. ft.) on 1.3 acres in Los
Altos Hills (lucky me).  One housemate wants to move back
to SF in the next couple of months, and one is considering
going back to apartment living (they get on each other's
nerves a bit).  So, space is opening up.

Cool things:
-Techno/house OK, nearest neighbors 50-100 yards away
-Great quiet location on an actual Los Altos Hill
-Big house with musical-type guy

Bad things:
-Neat freaks will not get along with me.  Sorry.
-Hardcore earlybirds probably won't either.

Rent is $750-900/mo., depending on which room and whether
you want to park your car in the garage.

Oh- it's a 3 BR house.  Master has its own bathroom, two
others share one.  Kitchen has dishwasher.  Other rooms
include dining room, big lounge area, and HUGE rec room,
plus the Ominous Corridor (tm) and garage.  It's an older
house with wood floors and lots of built-in cabinetry but
a kind of strange floor plan (I kind of like it).  Definitely
not your standard econo-suburbo-injection-molded box.

Yard is wild land with trees and such, not lawn, so no 
gardening fees, and trash and water are paid.  It's at the
end of a dead-end: very pastoral.

Enough rambling -- mail grigsby@shell.portal.com if you're
interested.

// g

I do not know the exact geography of this years sight because the 
organizers swear it's in a different part of the dessrt then it was last 
year but as it's on an area of dried up lake bed that is totally barren.  
it should not be to hard to spot.  Last year we were set up about 1/4 of a 
mile West of the main camp (it 
will be easy to spot).  As far as cxamping in the rave area goes we can't 
stop you but I guess we would kind of prefere it if the ravers set-up their 
own little living area slightly away from the rave scene so that  it 
looks like the actual dance floor is open for all.  Remember, there is 
lots and lots and lots of space out their so lewts use as much of it as 
is practical.  I am bringing my bike so that I can ride around all the 
different camps easily and I highly recomend other people to do the same 
(bike/roof racks are very cheap to hire).  BUt it would be exxellent if 
we all camped at the same place just outside of the rave camp so that we 
can all feel like part of the family.  I'll be setting up a camp in an 
area such as this and I sincerlly hope to see as many of you lot there as 
possible.  Anybody wanting more info on the camp or other burning man 
info should call me on 415-487-9804 or, preferably, e-mail me.I am so 
happy about the prospect of what burning man could represent that I feel 
like a little kid waking-up on Christmas morning.
SEE YER ALL AT THE PARTY OF THE YEAR.
TRISTAN.

     Hey all!
     
     As many of you are going to the "most creative time ever", I thought 
     I'd share with you a list that I made off the top of my head for 'our' 
     crew. As this may help you as well, I thought that the rest of the SFR 
     group may want it as well... By no means is this a 'definitive list'!
     
     Later :) Sy
                                      
#####\             _             /#####  
#( )# |          _( )__         | #( )#  
##### |         /_    /         | #####  
#" "# |     ___m/I_ //_____     | #" "#      
# O # |____#-x.\ /++m\ /.x-#____| # O #      
#m.m# |   /" \ ///###\\\ / "\   | #m.m#     
#####/    ######/ Bio \######    \#####    
     
     ====================================================================   
          THE HYMNS AND ANTHEMS BURNING MAN LIST OF WHAT TO BRING 
     ==================================================================== 
     
     WHAT YOUR GROUP SHOULD BUY/BRING
     
     -Automobile, Motorcycle, or Van
     -Food .. remember, 4-6 meals! 
     -Water  1 gal/person/day: Lots.. in those big box containers 
     -Ice
     -Christmas lights? Maybe?
     -Fire wood
     -Garbage bags
     -Big Compass
     -Beer
     -Sodas
     -Paper Towels 
     -Money to give The Group Leader for the car and supply fund. 
     -One Mountain Bike : Helps scouting for anything we may need. 
     -Box O Tools
     -First Aid Kit
     
     
     WHAT AN INDIVIDUAL SHOULD BRING
     
     -Personal Compass
     -Flashlights per person.. NEW BATTERIES!!! 
     -Pack light.. cars fill up quick!
     -Tents
     -Bricks to hold down tents 
     -Second set of shoes
     -Sweatshirt! Perfect for nighttime
     -Gloves.. YES Gloves!
     -A cap or hat
     -Shorts
     -Tshirts
     -Bathing Suit/ or no suit for Hot Springs 
     -Toiletries and makeup
     -Money for Gas, Food on the way
     -Cameras - highly recommended!
     -Blinky lights and toys ( blink blink :)
     -Lawn Chairs
     -Beer coolers
     -Sleeping bags     
     -Towels

--PART.BOUNDARY.0.15148.mail04.mail.aol.com.809290985

UNIQUE IDENTIFIER
95255607

AUTHOR(S)
Reiter RJ

TITLE
Oxidative processes and antioxidative defense mechanisms in the aging bra=
in.

SOURCE
FASEB J  1995 Apr;9(7):526-33

ABSTRACT
The debilitating consequences of age-related brain deterioration are
widespread =

and extremely costly in terms of quality of life and longevity. One of th=
e =

potential major causes of age-related destruction of neuronal tissue is t=
oxic

free radicals that are a natural result of aerobic metabolism. The brain =
is =

particularly susceptible to free radical attack because it generates more=
 of =

these toxicants per gram of tissue than does any other organ. The major
defense =

mechanisms the brain uses to combat reducing equivalents is via their
enzymatic =

metabolism. The vitamin antioxidants, vitamin E (alpha-tocopherol in =

particular) and vitamin C (ascorbate), also aid in protecting the brain f=
rom =

oxidative stress by directly scavenging toxic radicals. A newly discovere=
d, =

potentially highly important antioxidant in the brain is the indole
melatonin. =

The pineal hormone melatonin is rapidly taken up by the brain. In vitro =

melatonin is more effective than glutathione in scavenging the highly tox=
ic =

hydroxyl radical and also more efficient than vitamin E in neutralizing t=
he =

peroxyl radical. Furthermore, it stimulates the main antioxidant enzyme o=
f
the =

brain, glutathione peroxidase. In vivo melatonin is a potent antioxidant =
and
it =

lacks prooxidant actions.

=0C
UNIQUE IDENTIFIER
95230554

AUTHOR(S)
Eison AS ; Freeman RP ; Guss VB ; Mullins UL ; Wright RN

TITLE
Melatonin agonists modulate 5-HT2A receptor-mediated neurotransmission: =

behavioral and biochemical studies in the rat.

SOURCE
J Pharmacol Exp Ther  1995 Apr;273(1):304-8

ABSTRACT
Interactions between melatonin and serotonin type 2A (5-HT2A) receptors i=
n
the =

regulation of the sleep-wakefulness cycle in the rat have been reported. =
We =

studied the acute effects of melatonin and related agonists on 5-HT2A =

neurotransmission as reflected in behavioral (head shake) and biochemical=
 =

[phosphoinositide (PI) hydrolysis] responses to 5-HT2A receptor stimulati=
on. =

Like 5-HT1A agonists and antidepressants, acute administration of melaton=
in
and =

related agonists inhibited the 5-HT2A-mediated (+/-)-1-(2,5-dimethoxy-4-
iodophenyl)-2-aminopropane-induced head shake in a dose-dependent manner.=
 =

Consistent with these behavioral findings, in vitro incubation of cortica=
l =

slices with melatonin agonists robustly inhibited 5-HT2A receptor-mediate=
d PI

hydrolysis in a noncompetitive manner. 2-Iodomelatonin-induced reductions=
 in
5-
HT2A-stimulated PI hydrolysis were blocked by preincubation with the
melatonin =

antagonist N-acetyltryptamine. Further, pretreatment of rats in vivo with=
 =

melatonin and related agonists reduced the cortical PI hydrolysis respons=
e to

the 5-HT2A agonist alpha methyl-5-HT but did not alter cortical 5-HT2A
receptor =

density. The present data support an interaction between melatonin and 5-=
HT2A

receptors in the central nervous system.

=0C
UNIQUE IDENTIFIER
95222524

AUTHOR(S)
Garratt PJ ; Jones R ; Tocher DA ; Sugden D

TITLE
Mapping the melatonin receptor. 3. Design and synthesis of melatonin agon=
ists

and antagonists derived from 2-phenyltryptamines.

SOURCE
J Med Chem  1995 Mar 31;38(7):1132-9

ABSTRACT
Three series of 2-phenyltryptamides were prepared as melatonin analogues =
to =

investigate the nature of the binding site of the melatonin receptor in
chicken =

brain and in Xenopus laevis melanophore cells. The 5-methoxy-2-
phenyltryptamides (6a-j) have high binding affinities for the chicken bra=
in =

receptor, in some cases (6a-d) greater than that for melatonin, confirmin=
g
and =

extending the work of Spadoni et al., and act as agonists in the Xenopus =

melanophore assay. Analogues lacking the 5-methoxyl group (2a-n) had a =

considerably lower affinity for the chicken brain receptor. In the Xenopu=
s =

melanophore assay the compounds acylated on nitrogen by an alkyl group (2=
a-d)

were agonists whereas the compounds acylated on nitrogen by an alicyclic
group =

(2f-i) were antagonists. Introducing a methyl group at N1 (7) led to an =

increase in binding affinity in the chicken brain assay, whereas introduc=
ing
an =

ethyl group (13) led to a decrease in binding affinity. A methyl substitu=
ent
at =

the beta-position of the 3-amidoethane side chain (8, 11) also led to an =

increase in the binding affinity. The only analogue acylated on nitrogen =
with

an alkyl group (acetyl) which showed antagonist activity was 9, which has=
 a =

beta-methoxymethyl side chain. In the absence of the 5-methoxyl group the=
 =

methoxymethyl function may cause the molecule to bind in a different =

configuration so that it is no longer able to activate the receptor. All =
of =

these observations are in agreement with a model of melatonin at the rece=
ptor

site in which the 3-amidoethane side chain is in a conformation close to =
the
5-
methoxyl group.

=0C
UNIQUE IDENTIFIER
95203378

AUTHOR(S)
Giusti P ; Gusella M ; Lipartiti M ; Milani D ; Zhu W ; Vicini S ; Manev =
H

TITLE
Melatonin protects primary cultures of cerebellar granule neurons from
kainate =

but not from N-methyl-D-aspartate excitotoxicity.

SOURCE
Exp Neurol  1995 Jan;131(1):39-46

ABSTRACT
the antiexcitotoxic efficacy of melatonin, a putative endogenous hydroxyl=
 =

radical scavenger, was studied in primary cultures of rat cerebellar gran=
ule =

neurons. Excitotoxicity was induced in 7- to 9-day-old cultures by an
exposure =

to glutamate (15 min in the absence of magnesium) or to glutamate recepto=
r =

agonists, kainate (30 min), and N-methyl-D-aspartate (60 min in the absen=
ce
of =

magnesium). Thereafter, cultures were returned to the culture-conditioned=
 =

medium for 18 h at the end of which time viability was assessed by
quantitative =

staining with 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromi=
de. =

Cotreatment with melatonin (500 microM) protected the neurons completely =
from

the toxicity of kainate (up to 1 mM) and shifted the ED50 for glutamate f=
rom
55 =

+/- 2.6 to 97 +/- 3.6 microM. Melatonin cotreatment was ineffective in =

protecting the neurons from N-methyl-D-aspartate toxicity. When melatonin=
 was

added to the cultures only before or after kainate treatment, there was n=
o =

resultant protection from kainate toxicity. The neuroprotective effect of=
 =

melatonin does not appear to be related to the direct action of melatonin=
 on =

ionotropic glutamate receptors. That is, the kainate-stimulated inward
currents =

measured by a patch-clamp technique in voltage clamped neurons and the
kainate-
stimulated increase in free cytosolic calcium measured at the single-cell=

level =

using digital imaging fluorescent microscopy with fura-2 were not affecte=
d by

melatonin. Moreover, the binding of [3H]glutamate to rat cerebellar membr=
anes

was not competed off by melatonin. Further studies are needed to evaluate=
 the

pharmacologic relevance of the neuroprotective action of melatonin.

=0C
UNIQUE IDENTIFIER
95131961

AUTHOR(S)
Vijayalaxmi ; Reiter RJ ; Meltz ML

TITLE
Melatonin protects human blood lymphocytes from radiation-induced chromos=
ome =

damage.

SOURCE
Mutat Res  1995 Jan;346(1):23-31

ABSTRACT
Cells in human peripheral blood were treated in vitro with increasing =

concentrations of melatonin (0.5 or 1.0 or 2.0 mM) for 20 min at 37 +/- 1=
 =

degrees C and then exposed to 150 cGy gamma-radiation from a 137Cs source=
=2E
The =

lymphocytes which were pre-treated with melatonin exhibited a significant=
 and

concentration-dependent decrease in the frequency of radiation-induced =

chromosome damage as compared with the irradiated cells which did not rec=
eive

the pre-treatment. The extent of the reduction in radiation-induced
chromosome =

damage observed with 2.0 mM melatonin was similar to that found in
lymphocytes =

pre-treated with 1.0 M dimethyl sulfoxide, a known free radical scavenger=
=2E =

Melatonin at 2.0 mM (a 500 x lower concentration) was as effective in =

decreasing the radiation-induced chromosome damage as dimethyl sulfoxide =
at
1.0 =

M. These observations may have implications for human protection against
damage =

due to endogenously produced free radicals and also due to exposure to fr=
ee =

radical producing physical and chemical mutagens and carcinogens.

=0C

The new moon collective will be helping out with a party this weekend up 
in the Sierras, ~3.5 hours from SF.  If you're interested, call the new 
moon voice mail (415)267-3076 _soon_ -- we may not be able to accomadate 
everyone...

							gregg

   I cleaned out a few of the weeklies this week. Thanks to everyone
   who's been sending updates. No clear winner this weekend - try the
   Ambient Jungle cruise for ambient, Friction for Trance, and the others
   for House. Or stay home and pack up for Burning Man next weekend...
   

                              THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
    
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, August 25th - Ambient Jungle Midnight Cruise
   top deck: Ismael & Co., reggae ambient dub. mid deck - Ernie Munson &
   Markie. lower deck: Jason Walker, Moonpup, Nick Philip, Sean Murray.
   departs Pier 40 at midnight, goes till 5am. All Ages. advance tix $18
   at Housewares and BPM. $25 at boat. 415.241.1560
   
   Friday, August 25th - Green
   Pumping Hypnotic Sound: Garth, Shon, Josh & Jeff Miller. Lasers &
   Visuals by Acropolis. 10pm-6am. 408.551.2813 510.464.5974 415.267.6998
   
   
   Saturday, August 26th - Friction (The Trance Zone)
   DJs Trance, Barry Weaver, Tony, Ghost, Dutch & Minor Minor, Ivo &
   Carol. $5 off at door w/canned food donation. 415.286.7570
   510.553.7910 408.397.7780

   Garth, Simon, Dutch, Spinner, Markie. Live performance by Darwin
   Chamber and Fidelity Bytes. 510.202.0125 415.270.7602

   Lucero

Radio/TV Shows 

     * Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.
     * Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU
       90.1 Stanford
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.

Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   

    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Greetings everyone,

Just thought I'd let you know I've got a new radio show at KALX 90.7fm 
Berkeley, taking up the slack for MinorMinor on thursday nights 
(tonight!) at 9pm until midnight.  I play anything from 
ambient/experimental to acid trance techno to industrial to trip-hop, 
with a heavy emphasis on mixing.  Gotta run now- more info later...

Seth on KALX 90.7fm Berkeley
Thursdays 9pm-midnight

ps- due to the recent change of KSJS to 90.5fm, KALX can now be received 
all over the bay area!!!   :)

FREE LIVE AMBIENT MUSIC OUTDOORS

The show is titled: 7.83

7.83 is the Schumann Resonance, the resonant frequency of the Earth.

It will be held this Saturday August 26, 1995 from 12:30 p.m. to 2:30 p.m.
at the Center for the Arts at Yerba Buena Gardens in front of the SF Museum
of Modern Art.

Purpose:  Evolution through Sound. Consciousness expanding environmental
soundscapes by Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research and featured guests.

FREE

>doesn't disclose the admission fee over the phone... isn't that a crappy
>thing to do?)

Heh ... that's why they do it ... so that by the time you've actually
GOTTEN there, you're at the point of "Oh well, now I'm here, I may as well
pay for it".

I try never to go to anything which has no price listed on the flyers or
the infoline, and buy my tix in advance whenever possible, it saves money,
at least here in the Great Wet North ...

Last $20 party I went to was worth maybe $10 (if that), and the last $10
gig I saw (Sven Vath) was worth about $200!!!

k

[ To SFRaves mailist - I thought I had sent this out last night , but
  it hasn't shown up , so here it is again , with some more info. ]

 Thanks to all the folks that answered my inquiry about Internet service
providers. Here's a summary of the replies:

ba.internet: Folks recommended I check out this newsgroup. It is supposed 
   to have a weekly listing of S.F. Bay area Internet access providers ,
   and also has posts from folks who are customers of local access 
   providers.

Other sources of information about local access: "Cyberspace Today" , a
SF monthly newsprint tabloid. A magazine called "The Net" had a list of
415 area code providers. "Computer Currents" monthly newsprint tabloid
is supposed to have a Web page that has information about access 
providers.

Work-around - TIA : The SLIP emulator TIA was recommended by some other
 folks on my present provider ( NETCOM ). 

Recommended Internet Access Providers:
[ In 408 area code or with 408 dial-up numbers , or nearby 415 area code ]
best.com - recommended by some , but panned by a lot of folks too.
crl.com 
aimnet.com
the WELL


 Thanks again for the information!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I've seen a couple of post about this here and I feel maybe I may be of
assistance.

I recently (past 4 months of my life) have felt a complete increase in
self awareness and self worth. Stagnancy in not in my vocabulary. I'm
comepletely happy with myself and the choices I'm making.

Here are some simple things all of you can do on a daily basis to feel
better:


1) Doing the minimum is never good enough. Do at least one thing a day
that improves your life.

2) Challenge yourself! Find something you would like to do but can't,
   AND DO IT!!!!!!!!!

3) Give yourselfg a mental hug everyday. If you can't love yourself then
   how do you expe t to love others.

4) last but def. not least. Pet your cat on a daily basis!!


Love you all,

Andrew

Soundgod@iccse.com is happy to be a humane individual.

>    how do you expe t to love others.

From: mturyn@world.std.com (Michael L Turyn)
Date: Thu, 24 Aug 1995 18:01:24 -0400
Subject: [SubG] Re:  Subgenius Digest V6 #172

The holes-in-head group is covered well in "Eccentric Lives and
Peculiar Notions," as well as in Donna Kossy[sp?]'s "Kooks," both
of which may be considered as a field guide to unimaginative
SubGenius thought patterns.

"Never `presume,' because when you do, you make a `prez' out of
`u' and `me'."
	---"The Anarchist Chocolate Dessert Cookbook"
		(Unknown, Kropotkinist-Spoonerist-Wonkaist Thought Press, 1991)

From: stevek@oeonline.com (Steve Kennelly)
Date: Thu, 24 Aug 95 19:31 EDT
Subject: [SubG] Re: Subgenius Digest V6 #172

>>>
>>    Joey's first attempt at self-trepanation was a fiasco.  He had no prev-
>>  ious medical experience, and the needles he had bought for administering
>>  a local anesthetic to the crown of his head proved to be too thin and
>>  crumpled up or broke.  Next day he obtained some stouter needles, took
>>  a tab of LSD to steady his nerves and set to in earnest.  First he made
>>  an incision to the bone, and then applied the trepan to his bared skull.
>>  But the first part of the operation, driving the spike into the bone,
>>  was impossible to accomplish.
>>

Ah yes, reminds me of the first time I trepanned myself.  The trick is use
the proper equipment.  I tried  hand-cranked tools, electric drills, power
sanders, concentrated sulphuric acid, and half-starved rodents.  I finally
lit on the idea of using a dab of construction adhesive to hold an M-80 in
place while the fuse burns down.  The hole is not as neat as can be
obtained by other means, and it is a bit messy, but the time saved is well
worth it.  I've helped a number of friends and pets reach enlightenment
using this method, although for first-timers, I'd still recomend the
pilgrimage to Dobbstown for an official third-nostril "opening".

Steve Kennelly   stevek@oeonline.com



- ------------------------------

From: William J Jacobs <bjacobs@mintaka.sdsu.edu>
Date: Thu, 24 Aug 1995 18:06:54 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [SubG] Re: trepanation

I'm the guy who a couple of years ago originally typed in that essay about 
trepanation, so I feel kind of guilty when it shows up without the right 
attribution.  To make me feel a little better could everyone please note that
that essay is a slightly edited version of a chapter from _Eccentric Lives and
Peculiar Notions_ by John Michell.  Rush out and buy it, it's full of neat-o
stuff like that (although that chapter is, by far, the most gory).

Bill jacobs

William Jacobs                    | Tragedy is when I cut my finger, comedy 
Astronomy Dept., San Diego State  | is when you fall in an open sewer and
bjacobs@mintaka.sdsu.edu          | die.  -- Mel Brooks

From: Dave Voorhis <dave@onramp.armchair.mb.ca>
Date: Thu, 24 Aug 1995 21:50:27 -0500
Subject: [SubG] YABWP

"Yet Another Bloody Web Page," in case you didn't guess it right off.

In the fine tradition established by somebody else, I'm going announce one
of my own Web pages here.  Why?  Because I FEEL LIKE IT, and because y'all
are a captive audience WHOM I CAN BLUDGEON WITH SENSLESS RANTS ANY TIME I
FEEL LIKE IT!

Actually, given that it's brand-spankin'-new, I figgered I'd let you folks
at it (Oooh!  Priveledge!) before I involve the rest of the Internet, which,
as we all know, is really a guy living in a trailer somewhere just south of
Milwaukee.  (Didn't somebody post something 'bout that a while back?)

So, try http://www.armchair.mb.ca/~dave/wall, and bludgeon ME with senseless
rants...

well, since
 I go to school there I can tell you that there is no scene!
If your into the bar scene there is a few cool places but I haven't 
really checked it out cuz I'm only nineteen. There is one club called the 
"Graduate" that is supposed to be 18 and older.  you might try it out. I 
think thet ocaisionally have alternative music nights.  I know some acid 
house dj's that are trying to put some parties together down there but 
have only had minimul success at atrracting the ravy type crowd.  Mostly 
hip-hopers suport the dance scene there.  The parties are far and few in slo.
But i happen to meet a few ravers down there last year and we know more 
of us are out there its just hard to find em and bring em all together!
Too bad you couldn't make it down for one of our private parties during 
the school year. They rock! Its really funny walking around SLO and being in 
an environment were people have on clue  or don't care that there are other 
ways to celebrate life than keg parties!
take care,
hugs n stuff
dan

This was how I woke today (at 2pm so at least it wasn't all bad).

ME: Hello? (very shaky morning/just woke up voice)
Friend: Hey man, I have some bad news...
ME: What?
Friend: They "postponed" Narnia.
ME: No way!
Friend: Yeah they had site problems and said they are gonna try to
	reshcedule it for three weeks from now!
ME: That can't be true.  Who did you hear it from? (realize that I just
       woke up and I am not an morning...err...afternoon person)
Friend: Well I just got off the phone with Man from Mars and that's what 
	said. 

(BTW, when I say list in the following part I mean socal-raves, I need to 
clarify that since this message is also being sent out to all my friends 
up at SF...hi!).

Well I said my goodbye's and then hung up.  This happened BEFORE I read 
anything on the list (and I my friend I don't think is on the list 
anymore).  I then logged on and saw all you guys talking...it must be 
true....ahhhhhh!!!!  This REALLY sucks.  I mean REALLY REALLY REALLY 
sucks!!!  NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!  

Like I said, my friend said it will be in three weeks.   He also had an 
idea that this may be a ploy on their part to get some of the 
non-raver types out of it.  Afterall the raver types will call the info 
lines but the non raver types may not.  I wouldn't put it past GUN at 
this point.  I'll try to keep you all informed.

	-Christian

What food do you like to eat when you take ecstacy?   We're building a super chill space at Narnia tomorrow night and we're going to be giving out lots of free food.  I know from my own experience that you aren't really too hungry when you take e but since the event will be going on for 31 hours we want there to be nourishment for people that need it.  We're going to buy food in the morning so any suggestions anyone has would be greatly appreciated!!

I've been asking around and here are the suggestions so far:
Watermelon
Super ripe and juicy peaches
Oranges
Bubble Gum
Strawberries
Whipped Cream (!)
Charm's Blow Pops
Barebecued white corn "slathered with butter" (?)

If anyone else from the sfraves crew are going please come by and say hello!  We've got a 32' geodesic dome, and 45 sq foot carpeted area where you can lay on your back and look at the stars (you have to check your shoes first) - all music will be ambient acoustic - live african drummers, sitar and digideroo players plus food, water and tons of other stuff.
And if you're not going to Narnia, see you at Burning Man ...

"People need people. Not only for the practical benefits which derive 
from group life, but for our very health and survival. Somehow 
interaction with the larger social world of others draws our attention 
out of ourselves, enlarges our focus, enhances our ability to cope, and 
seems to make the brain's reactions more stable and the person less 
vulnerable to disease"

"The Healing Brain"

	Howdy!  I'm checking back in after being out of town for a week and
it looks like quite a bit of discussion has happened about the article in 
the Chron.  From a quick literature search, it looks like this guy Ricaurte
has done quite a bit of research on MDMA's effects on various aspects of
human behavior (sleep, memory) in addition to its neurotoxicity in humans.
I'll be running to the library at some point tomorrow to pull a few of his
papers, and I'll post a quick summary of the details.  The lack of dosage
info in the article bothers me too...  From the titles of his papers, it
looks like he's been at this for a while and has a grip on the problem, 
unlike a lot of papers I've seen on the stuff which feature abnormally high
doses in animals.

take care,

steve

= 		    Steve Boyer (sboyer@violet.berkeley.edu)		     =

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Aug 26 14:24:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA28694; Sat, 26 Aug 1995 14:24:15 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA28687; Sat, 26 Aug 1995 14:24:11 -0700
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.10/1.33(web)-OV4)
	id OAA29844; Sat, 26 Aug 1995 14:24:08 -0700
From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199508262124.OAA29844@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: new moon, light family movement party
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 26 Aug 1995 14:24:08 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 7128      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hi all!

last night gregg, p. and I jetted up to a little town in the high sierras 
for a rave.

it was a party put on by the light family movement, also known as gateway 
systems, plus some other folks, as well.  including the new moon!

we left the east bay around 11 and arrived in the little ghost town-also 
known as forest city- around 2:30 in the morning.  when we arrived, we 
were instructed at the entrance of the town to steer clear of a house 
with a big green alligator cross on it because some white supremecists 
lived there.  "they have more guns than we do, probably," we were told.  
"just don't bother them and they won't bother us."  well, okay.

with great excitement we walked up the road to the new moon ambient 
saloon.  the saloon was kind of a historic site as it once was the most 
important building in the town in its glory days.

inside we found some new moon folks putting together what would later 
become perhaps the most beautiful new moon altar to date.  some ambient 
tunes were playing and various folks were dancing and talking.  a few 
people were already sacked out in sleeping bags on the floor.  the party 
had been going on for quite some time and already people were getting a 
little worn out.  but it made for a very mellow, very warm ambient 
experience.

then we walked up the road some more...past the aforementioned white 
supremacist house...(which was quiet)...to a meadow that the organizers 
had spent all day clearing and setting up the system.  cyril was 
spinning as we arrived.  there was a firepit and lots of tents, plus some 
people dancing in front of the dj.  after plugging in the trusty DAT 
recorder, we mingled and chatted and danced some.

then we went back to the ambient saloon.  along the way someone told us 
that some white supremacist guys had been bugging some people over by the 
firepit and pissed off some kids, who left.  this was bumming people 
out as we felt we should have tried harder to convince the kids that left 
to stay instead.  i felt especially bad for the organizers who had worked 
so hard on this party and now had to deal with this awful blotch on their 
otherwise perfect evening.  and i also felt sorry for the kids who left, 
after having driven all the way there and then having to put up with 
insults and bad energy.  such are the risks you run when you have a party 
in a new location, in a place where anyone at all can show up.

i made the best of the situation and tried to enjoy myself anyway, 
despite feeling bummed.  the music all night long was very enjoyable.  i 
especially liked a set that Phil Smart (from Australia) did.  it got me 
up and dancing.  later i on, i got to hear dj stonie and his just-right
deep house set.  

as i was listening to phil smart's set, i saw a guy with very short hair 
walking  circles around the dance-area.  he looked like he was 
possessed by some restless spirit as he circled the dancers several times.
this was a ghost town, after all, and you never know what might happen.  
then i realized  he was one of the white supremacist guys.  then i saw 
him talking to a friend of mine, a young woman, and i went up to them and 
suggested we walk back to the ambient saloon.  i asked him if he was the 
white supremacist guy.  this question surprised him a little, but he said 
yes.  his name was greg and he'd come up there a little early for 
a meeting his group was having the next day in this little town.  the 
weirdness of such a thing happening after a rave!

when we got back to the ambient saloon, i suggested we and another 
friend, who is chinese-american, sit at a table and talk about our 
respective "movements," the white supremacist movement and the house 
movement.  we sat and talked for about an hour.  greg had some trouble 
collecting his thoughts as he was very tired and had been drinking, but 
we managed to have a passable conversation.  even though his movement 
preaches separation of the races and other things i don't really 
understand or approve of, greg himself was actually very nice to us both, 
even though we were "mixing the races" by hanging out together.  he told 
us he had been a punker down in L.A. and had done a lot of drugs there.  
he basically seemed like he was completely cut off from mainstream 
culture.  it seemed to me we had similar complaints about the media 
distorting our respective groups.  he thought that was because of the 
media being controlled by the jews. my raver friend and i had no theory 
we believed in so strongly to explain the media's habitual distortions 
concerning the rave community.  his own group is despised by most 
people.  our group tries hard to keep out of the public consciousness, 
but when stories do get told about us in the media, they seem always to 
focus on the negative-such as lurid drug tales and kids staying out all 
night and getting into trouble.  so i guess to a lot of people, we are 
both classified as low-lifes.

then we all walked back to the meadow where phil smart's set was going 
strong.  greg started to enjoy himself a little more.  the restless 
spirit that had taken him over earlier appeared to have departed.

i asked him if out of all the drugs he'd done, if he'd ever tried E.  he 
said no and that he wasn't interested in trying it.  i told him i thought 
he should because it would give a fresh perspective on things. strange
as it may seem, underneath all the rhetoric, he seemed like the kind of 
person who would benefit from such an experience, since in my 
conversation with him he was good at responding to nonverbal cues.  this 
to me  means someone is receptive to other people, and it is this 
receptiveness that gets enhanced when you take E.

well, it just goes to show you that you can meet all kinds of people at a 
rave. i hope no-one will think badly of me for talking to this guy.  
mostly, i was curious to see what kind of a person might have such 
beliefs.  i really don't know more now than i did before i talked to 
him.  but maybe some of the things we said made an impression.  at the 
very least, i think he started to enjoy himself a little more after we 
talked.  the first step for becoming a raver is to have fun at a rave, i 
figured.  the fact that he was there at all, and stayed all night, means 
there's hope.  part of being a raver for me is learning to see the beauty 
in all people.  so maybe if he learned to do that, he would let go of 
whatever it is that makes him want to cut himself off from people that 
aren't white.  the rhetoric of anti-race-mixing and all that other stuff 
i realized was the very same restless, angry and disquieted spirit that i 
saw him grappling with during phil smart's set.  i don't underestimate 
the power of this destructive spirit to hurt its host and others.  
perhaps we of the house community should work a little harder to diminish 
this spirit's power.  love is the only way, i think.

all in all this was a very good party.  the people that put it on 
worked very hard so that all of us could have a good time.  Thank you!  
And good luck with all your future projects!

love,

ann

Narnia is a perfect example of a scam that has been going on in Uk and 
Europe for years.  It is this: say your going to be having a massive 
party at a secret location  and say that one must have there ticket in 
advance to go.  Because you have not dealt with a ticket agency but 
dierectly with thhe promotoors themselves (which is, incidently, illegal) 
you buy the ticket with no garuntee from them that you will go to the 
show or 
get a refund.  Thus if one sells a thousand tickets at $20 a pop thats 
$20,000.  A nice little earner for the few promotoirs, if you know what I 
mean.  "It's food for thought, mobsters."

I have some information on the prevention of MDMA neurotoxicity using 
fenfluramine, and also some possibly partial bullshit (it was in the 
newspaper and is therefore suspect information) about the nature and 
manifestation of said damage on nerve cell axons. Also some background 
info on MDMA if you're interested... it was NOT invented by illicit 
chemists in the 1980's who were looking for a "stronger, technically 
legal form of methamphetamine"... which is what the news article claims...

I don't wish to dump a lot of unwanted info on sfr heads, so contact me 
via email while I put some articles together for ya'.

Maui

Dis Post Contains 2 Countem Two Posts, For The Bandwdith Of One

/The Weekend of the Private Parties

Dear All;


	It seems that this weekend was one of those weekends that it was 
who ya know, rather than who you are. I have a lot of problems with this 
rave philosopy, but private parties are still my P favorite.
 
	Unfortuately there needs to be a way to limit parties due to the
number of ravers in San Francisco. I will proabbly annoy Bgroovey will
this post, not my intention, but I feel that Rave Kultur at least in the
early days was elitest, in a lot of ways. In always seemed like it was who
ya knew, rather than who you are, especially in most allof  the major club 
scenes eg New York, London.

	But there were penty o killer events out there, last night to make
up for killer private parties, and my only advice to people who feel that
they were left out is, and I'm gonna quote AA/NA of all sources, cause I'm
the AA/NA Satan, "keep comin back", of god don't ya just love it!!!!!.
Cause hon's, sooner or later, someone will see just how much you shine, and
invite you to one of those closed events, cause we ALL FUCKIN SHINE!!!!!!,
something however, you will never hear in AA/NA. 

/Rave Suicide

	Sometime this weekend one of the members of a band, who are 
considered by many; including myself, to be one of the founding fathers of 
the electronic groove, attemted to commit suicide, by slashing his wrist, 
the band is Depeche Mode, the members name I uncertain of, please add 
details to this story, thanks. I quess it just goes to show you, flame & 
forture won't buy you love, peace or happiness.

		 Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET

Dear All;

	Bloody sick as hell of all dis new age; hmmmmm how should I put it,
crap!!! 

	If your stuck in a rut, maybe it's cause you're taking advice from
others rather than listening to your own heart & your own dream. That
little voice inside you that keeps telling what to do & where to go. Don't
read about how other people did things, you just recycleing stuff that's
not your own. Think for youself, be yourself, love yourself, don't sit at
home reading how some other clueless fucker made their life work. There 
is no manual on life; at least I didn't get one, were all just as 
clueless as the next, or just as insightful.

	The extent of my literialy knowledge you could fit on the head of
a pin. I'm a self made modern day, 100% pure ME, filled with nothing but
my own thoughts, ideas, feelings, belief systems, perceptions, &
perspectives, not someone elses. 

	Educate yourself and use that knowledge to defend youself from the
people in the world the will tell you how to be, who to be, who to love,
who to hang around with, what to do, what to think, what to believe
....ETC. Lead by example and people will if not follow, at least support you.

	Find yourself, whether it be in a drug, in a book, on the top of a
mountain from some beggar, or just by looking inside yourself and
listening to that voice inside yourself. Love yourself, and people will
love you, they will see that light, that light that they see inside
themselves, and love. Cause when it comes to YOU, you are the only person
who knows whats best for you, and I dare anyone to challenge that concept.

i think that's great you talked to the supremist dude - the worst thing
to do is not to exchange ideas and opinions with people whose views differ
from yours.  after all, how are they to ever going to change their opinion
if no one challenges their ideas ?  plus, it's bad practise to assume
what you believe is beyond refute and infallible.

On Sat, 26 Aug 1995, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:

> hi all!
> 
> last night gregg, p. and I jetted up to a little town in the high sierras 
> for a rave.
> 
> it was a party put on by the light family movement, also known as gateway 
> systems, plus some other folks, as well.  including the new moon!
> 
> we left the east bay around 11 and arrived in the little ghost town-also 
> known as forest city- around 2:30 in the morning.  when we arrived, we 
> were instructed at the entrance of the town to steer clear of a house 
> with a big green alligator cross on it because some white supremecists 
> lived there.  "they have more guns than we do, probably," we were told.  
> "just don't bother them and they won't bother us."  well, okay.
> 
> with great excitement we walked up the road to the new moon ambient 
> saloon.  the saloon was kind of a historic site as it once was the most 
> important building in the town in its glory days.
> 
> inside we found some new moon folks putting together what would later 
> become perhaps the most beautiful new moon altar to date.  some ambient 
> tunes were playing and various folks were dancing and talking.  a few 
> people were already sacked out in sleeping bags on the floor.  the party 
> had been going on for quite some time and already people were getting a 
> little worn out.  but it made for a very mellow, very warm ambient 
> experience.
> 
> then we walked up the road some more...past the aforementioned white 
> supremacist house...(which was quiet)...to a meadow that the organizers 
> had spent all day clearing and setting up the system.  cyril was 
> spinning as we arrived.  there was a firepit and lots of tents, plus some 
> people dancing in front of the dj.  after plugging in the trusty DAT 
> recorder, we mingled and chatted and danced some.
> 
> then we went back to the ambient saloon.  along the way someone told us 
> that some white supremacist guys had been bugging some people over by the 
> firepit and pissed off some kids, who left.  this was bumming people 
> out as we felt we should have tried harder to convince the kids that left 
> to stay instead.  i felt especially bad for the organizers who had worked 
> so hard on this party and now had to deal with this awful blotch on their 
> otherwise perfect evening.  and i also felt sorry for the kids who left, 
> after having driven all the way there and then having to put up with 
> insults and bad energy.  such are the risks you run when you have a party 
> in a new location, in a place where anyone at all can show up.
> 
> i made the best of the situation and tried to enjoy myself anyway, 
> despite feeling bummed.  the music all night long was very enjoyable.  i 
> especially liked a set that Phil Smart (from Australia) did.  it got me 
> up and dancing.  later i on, i got to hear dj stonie and his just-right
> deep house set.  
> 
> as i was listening to phil smart's set, i saw a guy with very short hair 
> walking  circles around the dance-area.  he looked like he was 
> possessed by some restless spirit as he circled the dancers several times.
> this was a ghost town, after all, and you never know what might happen.  
> then i realized  he was one of the white supremacist guys.  then i saw 
> him talking to a friend of mine, a young woman, and i went up to them and 
> suggested we walk back to the ambient saloon.  i asked him if he was the 
> white supremacist guy.  this question surprised him a little, but he said 
> yes.  his name was greg and he'd come up there a little early for 
> a meeting his group was having the next day in this little town.  the 
> weirdness of such a thing happening after a rave!
> 
> when we got back to the ambient saloon, i suggested we and another 
> friend, who is chinese-american, sit at a table and talk about our 
> respective "movements," the white supremacist movement and the house 
> movement.  we sat and talked for about an hour.  greg had some trouble 
> collecting his thoughts as he was very tired and had been drinking, but 
> we managed to have a passable conversation.  even though his movement 
> preaches separation of the races and other things i don't really 
> understand or approve of, greg himself was actually very nice to us both, 
> even though we were "mixing the races" by hanging out together.  he told 
> us he had been a punker down in L.A. and had done a lot of drugs there.  
> he basically seemed like he was completely cut off from mainstream 
> culture.  it seemed to me we had similar complaints about the media 
> distorting our respective groups.  he thought that was because of the 
> media being controlled by the jews. my raver friend and i had no theory 
> we believed in so strongly to explain the media's habitual distortions 
> concerning the rave community.  his own group is despised by most 
> people.  our group tries hard to keep out of the public consciousness, 
> but when stories do get told about us in the media, they seem always to 
> focus on the negative-such as lurid drug tales and kids staying out all 
> night and getting into trouble.  so i guess to a lot of people, we are 
> both classified as low-lifes.
> 
> then we all walked back to the meadow where phil smart's set was going 
> strong.  greg started to enjoy himself a little more.  the restless 
> spirit that had taken him over earlier appeared to have departed.
> 
> i asked him if out of all the drugs he'd done, if he'd ever tried E.  he 
> said no and that he wasn't interested in trying it.  i told him i thought 
> he should because it would give a fresh perspective on things. strange
> as it may seem, underneath all the rhetoric, he seemed like the kind of 
> person who would benefit from such an experience, since in my 
> conversation with him he was good at responding to nonverbal cues.  this 
> to me  means someone is receptive to other people, and it is this 
> receptiveness that gets enhanced when you take E.
> 
> well, it just goes to show you that you can meet all kinds of people at a 
> rave. i hope no-one will think badly of me for talking to this guy.  
> mostly, i was curious to see what kind of a person might have such 
> beliefs.  i really don't know more now than i did before i talked to 
> him.  but maybe some of the things we said made an impression.  at the 
> very least, i think he started to enjoy himself a little more after we 
> talked.  the first step for becoming a raver is to have fun at a rave, i 
> figured.  the fact that he was there at all, and stayed all night, means 
> there's hope.  part of being a raver for me is learning to see the beauty 
> in all people.  so maybe if he learned to do that, he would let go of 
> whatever it is that makes him want to cut himself off from people that 
> aren't white.  the rhetoric of anti-race-mixing and all that other stuff 
> i realized was the very same restless, angry and disquieted spirit that i 
> saw him grappling with during phil smart's set.  i don't underestimate 
> the power of this destructive spirit to hurt its host and others.  
> perhaps we of the house community should work a little harder to diminish 
> this spirit's power.  love is the only way, i think.
> 
> all in all this was a very good party.  the people that put it on 
> worked very hard so that all of us could have a good time.  Thank you!  
> And good luck with all your future projects!
> 
> love,
> 
> ann
>

well, not sure if this is important or not, but i found out why sunset 
didnt happen, for those that didnt know. if this has already been posted, 
then sorry, and please ignore.


I went to the state fair today in sacto. and i went to the Technologica 
exhibit and ther were people from some college up there running a booth 
for Netcom. i was talking to one of the guys, and we got into a 
discussion about raves for some strange reason. he asked me if i heard of 
Sunset. "yup."  he said that he knows one of the people that produce it, 
and the guy had to drive his sister to some state above us...so, he wasnt 
in town...probably will be back in town next weekend? so.....if that 
helps any...dunnooo
take care

X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Progress review
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well I had a great time at Progress on Saturday night.  It was at a
warehouse on Mission...not huge, but big enough for an good intimate party.
I spent all but about 5 minutes in the chill room, which was great because
it was on the first floor and was really good sized, and the dance floor for
the main room was on the third floor so there was no bleed through of BOOM
BOOM BOOM during any of the ambient music.  My frinds Dave, Kevin, and Brad
from Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research had invited me to SF to
perform live with them at free show in the park on Saturday afternoon (which
went really well), then they invited me to play live and spin some records
in the ambient room at Progress as well.  This was my first SF party. :)
The vibe in the chill space was so great all night.  So many wonderful
people came up and complemented us on the music (live as well as vinyl and
cd)  I was especially moved by Kevins set which consisted of mostly FAX
stuff that he played on his cd mixer.  Incredible music! It was soooooo fun
playing live there.  Most of it was improv. and turned out really really
well.  I played my digeridoo and hand drum - with heavy delay and other
effects, and some patterns from my drum machine, along with C-Lab's plethera
of music making devises.

My brief journey to the third floor was really cool as well.  As I was
coming up the stairs the music had broken down and was building with a nice
snare drum role.  I got up to the floor and it was still building...everyone
was kinda swaying back and forth and feeling the build.  Then as it peaked
and some wicked beat came in the whole crowd just flailed and bounced and
bugged out all over the place.  It was reall cool, and I wished I had got
there five minutes earlier so I could have been a part of it.  It was also
really great to see a large group of my friends bugging out together at this
time too.  Then it was a quick hug and kiss from Phelps (my girlfriend), and
back to the ambient room for my second dj set (which ended up turning into
this live improv with this flute player that showed up....fun fun fun all
night). 

The only problems I noted were that the main bathroom was broken for about
half the night, but was somehow fixed later.  There was also a fight way at
the end which really disturbed me, and I'm sorry for sharing it, but I
really hate violence and like I said it bothered me.

So there you go...My first Progress Party, my first show in SF...and
although reports on Progress parties haven't been all that great, I had a
very good first impression and a wonderful time.

Rick

OK,  I aquired a station wagon for Burning man.    I have room for 3 or
4 people to ride with me and share the gas expenses.   I want at least
two people with valid drivers licenses to share the driving.   The ride
takes 8 hours (including the usual stops for gas, toilet,  food,  whatever).

Ideally,  I want to leave late Wed evening to drive through the night and
arrive early AM in Gerlach,  then out to the Playa.

I've seen numerious postings in SFRaves from many people who want to go,
and need rides.   Please RSVP via Email or phone (415) 381-5847 in the
evening.

Don't forget!!   Bring at least 5 gals of water per person (for 5 days)
a tent (or share one),  and a tarp would also come in handy to lay down
on the desert to prevent getting everything dusty.    I should have plenty
of room for baggage and water.

Crunchman
