I went to San Diego despite the fact that Narnia was cancelled. Apparently
the cancellation of the event was on the news and it was on the
front page of the San Diego paper. According to the newspaper, the 
promoters did have all the permits, rented the equiptment, etc. While 
they were setting up, they were told to get off the property by the owner,
who lives up in Washington state. The owner of the land did not know 
anything about the party was surprised to find out that this was going on 
without his knowledge. And told the police to arrest anyone who 
trespassed on his property. The promoters thought they were dealing with a
"part-owner" of the property and gave the supposed property owner $3000 
up front and the other have after the event. They were dealing with a 
con-artist. The FBI is now is looking for the guy now. 

Another party happended that night an hour east of San Diego in the
desert. It reminded me of a Full Moon rave, minus the moon. They were 
about 500-600 people there under the stars. I must admit looking at the 
stars was a big bonus. I must have saw a dozen shooting stars. 
Unfortuately there wasn't an ambient area, since the truck ran out of gas 
getting there *doh*. 


Even though we didn't set up the Geodesic Dome, I had a really great time 
thanks to my travelling partners: Bart, Jonathan, Miho, David, Paula and 
Anna(SD). 

Cindy

ps. Is there another outdoor party that anyone can use a 32" Geodesic Dome?
;-)

BUt we are tottally seperate from the main festival and the rave camp IS 
free and as it is in a flat barren 200 square mile area there's lot a 
lot they can do about it is their?  But people should pay, not because 
they have to but because they want to because it is expensive and all 
and your money will be going to a good cause.

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yeah, that's another angle of the scam that does not really come into 
play in Europe because of the squatting laws over their but I can see 
how, especially with the US laws on tresspassing, how this side of the 
scam could work as well.  But to not talk to all the owners of the land 
was rather silly and nieve.  Better luck next time is what I say.  One 
livces and learns or dies and burns.  We used to have festivvals like 
this in England but what we would do is hit people up for money as they 
were leaving at the end of the party rather then weeks in advance.  This 
way poeple could not complain about paying because they had already been 
to a great party and couold not vomplain.  This also makes the 
promotors/dj's work harder because they know that success depends on them 
and not on the punters.  But something like that is more difficult to 
pull off here then in Europe.  See you all Burning Man!

On Mon, 28 Aug 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> The Burning Man festival is not free, that is true, it does cost $35.  
> BUt we are tottally seperate from the main festival and the rave camp IS 
> free and as it is in a flat barren 200 square mile area there's lot a 
> lot they can do about it is their?  But people should pay, not because 
> they have to but because they want to because it is expensive and all 
> and your money will be going to a good cause.
>


Yes but In order to get to the rave camp you need to go to the mappoint 
run by the burning man folks, it is really silly to try and circumnavigate
this, not to mention anti social.  The fees for burning man ONLY cover
the cost and if their luck provide seed money for next year's event.
Before you complain about the cost, stop and think how much it must
cost to for the insurance and for the medivac helicopter that is on stand-by
24 hours a day for the 5 days, I don't know about you but I feel a little
more relieved that htese guys are responsible and have RESOURCES
(which in this capitalist world of ours) requires money.

FYI.  I'd plan on forking over the $35.  I went last year, and after you
leave the main hwy you follow small black flags for a couple of mile to the
base camp (which consisted of a small trailer and radio transmitter). You
pay or give them your tickets there.  Then the person working the base camp
says "OK, go that way (points in some direction) for 10 miles, turn right
and go 5 miles and you sould see it."  There are no roads out there and no
signs.  If you don't know exactly where it is, you probably won't find it.
Good luck if you try.

Rick

I agree with Rick.  This party was great.  I stayed on the third floor most of
the
night and the music was really cool.  A totally un-orchestrated evening
unfolded.
Where a large group of friends and acquaintances showed up and it was
surprise hugs and kisses all evening.  The crowd tended to be a bit young and
a little on the tense side, but for the most part very smiley and fun.

BTW, the bathroom was fixed midway through the evening by yours truly, of
course it was a bit difficult with my eyes jittering and me constantly telling
the toilet that I loved it :-)'

Ron.

 For those who don't know , the South Bay Lunch is basically
me with a CD/Cassette/radio boom-box , ready for a nice day in
the sunshine! Attendence has varied from me/myself & I on up to
nine SFRavers , depending on people's schedules. At special times,
we've met at a restaurant ( no boom-box , tho' .... ).

 It's every Tuesday, depending on my own work schedule , the
weather , and park usage . I hope to see you folks there!

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

------------------------------------------------------------------

What: The SFRaves South Bay Lunch ...

When: Tuesday  
Time: 11:55AM to 1:10PM or so ... 
Where: Greer Park, Palo Alto

Directions:

* From 101 (South or North) take the Oregon Expressway Exit
  Northbound: Past San Antonio Road 
  Southbound: Past University Avenue 

* Left at the first signal - W. Bayshore
  (it's a frontage road that takes you south again)

* Follow this road approx. 1/4 mile (pass apartment complexes on right)
  
* You will see the park on your right hand side. Turn into the first 
  driveway on your right.

* We'll meet on the grassy knoll , behind the round baseball fence.
  Next to the restrooms and ball courts.

Bring lunch, toys, yourselves!

Date: Mon, 28 Aug 1995 15:53:52 PDT
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9507288096.AA809647814@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: Burning Man Fees
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     I'm not sure where people get their information about Burning Man and 
     the rave camp but my understanding from what was mailed to me from 
     Burning Man is that the Rave Camp is part of the event/attraction(s).  
     Yes, it will be separate from the main camp but it is still part of 
     the festival.  Thus paying the $35 helps support the festival, 
     contributes towards the chemical pit toilets, the first aid, the 
     responsibility of contracting with the Bureau of Land Management for 
     use/abuse of the desert, etc., as well as it gets you a map to the 
     festival.
     
     If we were confident enough in our own abilities to host a free rave 
     festival that would be a different story, but right now we are sharing 
     resources in the spirit of the Burning Man as well as relying on 
     their/our resources to create this interactive event.
     
     "Burning Man is entirely supported by paticipant contributions.  Bear 
     this in mind:  there is no "they".  They have never funded us, nor 
     will they pick up garbage off the desert floor...construct our camp, 
     provide electricity, or help publish and mail the newsletter...Only 
     when they become "us" does anyone contribute."  (Taken from the 
     Burning Man Newsletter)
     
     I realize that $35 is steep for some people but when you think about 
     what you spend on admission to some raves, as well as the "flavors" we 
     purchase at/for raves and compare this to $35/5 days, $7 per day 
     doesn't seem like that much for what we'll be getting in return.
     
     I hope those of you who haven't registered and plan to attend take 
     this into consideration.  And in the future, if you plan ahead early 
     enough you can pay $25 for the event.
     
     See you at the rave camp!
     
     Diane

Subject: Re: Burning Man Fees

FYI.  I'd plan on forking over the $35.  I went last year, and after you 
leave the main hwy you follow small black flags for a couple of mile to the 
base camp (which consisted of a small trailer and radio transmitter). You 
pay or give them your tickets there.  Then the person working the base camp 
says "OK, go that way (points in some direction) for 10 miles, turn right 
and go 5 miles and you sould see it."  There are no roads out there and no 
signs.  If you don't know exactly where it is, you probably won't find it. 
Good luck if you try.
     
Rick

At 15:01 08/28/95, Karen wrote:
>I'm just curious - but is Burning Man going to be in California or Nevada?
>
>k

It's in the Nevada Black Rock Desert. This is about 100 miles north of
Reno, Nevada.

<< check out http://www.aeropac.org/aeropac/blackrock.html >> for more...


>From Reno: Take Interstate 80 East from Reno, about 30 miles from Reno take
the "Wadsworth"/"Pryamid Lake" exit, the last cheap gas is available at the
I80 truckstop
at this exit. Take highway 447 north (it's about 75 miles from the freeway
to Gerlach), as you approach the town of Nixon don't take the Pyramid lake
exit, instead drive
through Nixon and continue north to Gerlach, about 5 miles before you get
to Gerlach you will pass through the company town of Empire - the store by
the road here is
the only thing locally that can be considered a supermarket - stop on your
way through to buy ice (and lettuce if you forgot your wadding). Gerlach
itself has a number
of bars and a gas station, most of which also sell ice. Be carefull about
your speed going through all these little towns

>From California: Take I80 East from the Bay Area through Sacramento to
Reno, follow the directions above. Some people from the north (or Oregon)
take CA 299 from
Alturas to NV 447 to Gerlach - I haven't done it so I can't recommend it myself

>From Utah and states east: Take I80 West through Winnemucca and then take
the Wadsworth exit, take 447 north (see above).

>From the Reno Airport: Take 395 north to Reno then I80 East.

-w

900 Tennessee St., #20   ~  wayne@collab.com  ~  TEL: 415.826.6000
San Francisco, CA 94107  ~      www.club.net  ~  FAX: 415.826.6100

changed the way I look at music I'll say that much.

Hello Ravers
My good friends Keith and Stephanie will be doing fire performance at 
Burning Man, and they're looking for gigs in the SF and LA area 
afterwards. Their performance is wicked--erotic, fun, and 
awe-inspiring--but they're totally broke and could use some gigs to get 
by on the west coast. 
Keith works with Hakim Bey and the autonomedia collective (publisher of 
T.A.Z.) 
You can email me at sferg@echonyc.com or Keith and Steph can be reached 
by their New York voicemail. (212)726-1935.

Hope this isn't considered a "commercialization" of the site. By way of 
intro's, I'm Sarah from NYC, a senior editor at High Times and freelance 
writer. I met Crunchman and the SPAZ crew last summer when I was out west 
covering those screwy Zippies. I mostly lurk around the site cause I'm 
not in SF. But I'm hoping to make it to Burning Man.

thanx!

On Tue, 29 Aug 1995, Rick Riffle wrote:
> Simply amazing...He spun unreleased FAX stuff that was totally incredible.
> He played about a two hour set with about 3 records, 1 microphone, and about
> 7 cd's.  One of the highlights was Vexelspang II (sp).  This track just blew
> me away.  Wicked intellegent dance with an extremely complex structure.  It
> was like I wanted to get up and dance, but it was all I could do to sit
> there and listen as carefully as I could to atempt to understand.  It
> changed the way I look at music I'll say that much.

It was pretty incredible...everything he played just rocked.  I liked the 
faster stuff he played more, as it was this weird fusion of many styles 
of music (dub/jungle/ambient/whatever).  Check him out if you ever get 
the chance.

-John

        B u r n i n g M a n F e s t i v a l

                 Thursday, August 31 through Monday, September 4, 1995


To aid you in your relentless quest for the latest news, not yet expired
from its media-driven
ever-shortening half-life, I offer you this synopsis of the latest changes
to this site, of the latest
news on the festival front, the latest plans, dreams, hopes and aspirations.

       Latest Changes to This Site:


              Directions to Gerlach are now available.
              What's the weather in the desert now?
              What will I find in Central Camp?
              What the heck is a dry lake anyway, and what can I expect
driving there?



       New Announcements:


       Ride Share to Burning Man!
              The Burning Man Project is proud to announce the Burning Man
Festival
              RideShare Info line. Call (415)985-7152 to help yourself or
someone you don't
              yet know get to the festival. Leave your name, number, where
you are leaving
              from, when you are leaving, and of course, whether your
offering or looking and
              our crack team of transportation professionals will pair you
up with the ride/rider
              of your dreams.

       Take the Stage Coach from Reno to Gerlach
              Once a day, the Gerlach Stage Coach leaves Reno for the
gateway to the Black
              Rock Desert. Shane, your driver, is available to ferry both
you and your
              equipment to downtown Gerlach for a benevolent price. Call to
arrange pickup
              times. (707)331-5181.

       Didn't get your Registration Materials Yet?
              The Burning Man Project doesn't want you to waste away,
sweating and fretting
              over the arrival of your registration materials. If you are
at all worried about the
              arrival of your tickets, you can now call the Burning Man
Ticket Troubleshooting
              Line at (415) 985-7142. Please have the following information
handy: When you
              sent you materials, how you sent the materials, your check
number, and be sure to
              leave your Name address and phone number sop we can get back
to you with the
              details.

       A Live Link in the Happening Stages
              The Burning Man Project is sparing no effort in connecting
you live to the desert
              through the Internet. We will be putting a low bandwidth link
live to central camp
              (barring acts of nature) to the net. At this point we are
envisaging doing something
              on IRC chat (It must be good for something!), possibly a MOO
or MUSE
              environment, and if we can get ahold of a Studio Transmitter
Link (STL) we will
              be able to do much much more. The webified version of the
Black Rock Gazette
              will be uploaded nightly to this archive section of the site.
If you have any
              expertise in radio packet networking, have video capture
equipment, digital still
              cameras, or psychic abilities we would love to hear from you!



                                  What's New

                           Multi-Media version of this Site

*Seth D. Carmichael(scarmike@tmn.com)*
*Global Business Network*
*PO Box 8395 Emeryville, CA 94662*
*510.547.6822 **510.547.8510 FAX*

Subject: Getting into burning man for free
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yes, it is quite possible to get into burning man for free? As Geoff stated
it could also be quite costly and/or dangerous. The only people you will be
scamming to get in for free are the others attending the party. BM is not
produced by BGP or some other huge corporation. Most of the money goes to put
this thing together. I went last year and was not hesitant to pay $35 again
this year to attend, even knowing I could easily get in for free. I am paying
the money because I have seen where it goes. These people put on an awesome
experience and we should be lucky to only have to pay $35. If you are totally
anti-capitalism and money, I'm sure you could get in touch with the BM people
and work out some sort of deal. As, I, said this is not a huge corporation.
These are real people with many progressive ideas. They would more than
likely appreciate your anti- capitalistic ideals. The phone # is
(415)985-7471. Have a great night/day, PEACE!!!!  CID

>I'd like to buy my burning man tickets, today, but i have no idea where to
>purchase them - please advise ?
>Thanks - Mr Last Minute Man (aka jim cyr)

You can call the hot line (415)985-7471 and get directions to the gate,
then pay there ($40.00) then go on and have a good time with out having to
worry about bullets from the gatekeeper or the Black Rock Rangers disabeling
your vehical.  

Burning Man spends alot to put this thing on. (always ends up several thousand
in the red) They actually have to rent the land from BLM, supply porta-pottys
(please don't trash the playa), pay insurance, and haul everything out there
plus clean up after the people who don't.  The people who work the event only
get five dollars off the price.

The Newt King

Subject: ID a la Playa
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey, all! I've finally got some info regarding how to ID 
our site at the Playa. We'll have about 4 or 5 tents (two 
large grey/blue, one red, one sky blue), placed in 
a more or less half-moon at the center of which will be 
a yellow shade tent (roof without walls). Hung somewhere 
nearby will be a sheet/banner, which reportedly has an 
infinity symbol on a background of stars. There are (so far) 
two vehicles associated with our site- though I don't know 
how close they'll be to our camp- one's a Dodge caravan 
of which color I won't know 'til I pick it up from the rent-a-car 
place; the other is a black, Infiniti G20. We'll have firewood,
water and other fun stuff- so come on by!
me? I'm petite; have longish brown hair & brown eyes. i 
haven't got any costumes planned, but I just got a new pair of glasses 
which will likely be hanging around my neck from a 
"i-can't-keep-track-of-these" black chain. i'll be easy to spot if 
i'm wearing my swim suit, too- it's shiny, almost metallic 
aquamarine blue 2-piece that exactly matches my veins (except for the 
shiny part).

also, we plan to reserve at least one of the smaller tents 
as a quiet, private, sort of safety tent- if you need 
such an interlude to maintain that yin/yang balance, please feel free! 

Hasta la playa!

jocelyn

p.s. other people who are reportedly sharing the site:
Gretchen, Kevin, Jeff, Alyssa, Christina, Renee, Brady,
& later on Manny, Daniel, Jim & possibly more ? you?

Heck, we could even do a Carlos-for-Carlos trade.  When I left New York a year 
and a half ago, Brooklyn's Carlos Tera (sometimes listed on flyers as "Tera", 
"Terra", or "Terror") was really hot but unknown outside of the Cybertek / Back 
to Basics / Mental Unity parties.  He was playing trancey acid that ranged from 
dreamy to brain-splattering, depending on mood and move.  Very nice, 
professional guy who never messed a mix.

Heather is great too!  Any DJ who can go from old Chicago-style acid house to 
*HARD* German acid (like PCP - Planet Core Productions) in one set *and have it 
all work* is worth it.

Laura

	id AA06193; Wed, 30 Aug 95 23:32:25 PDT
Message-Id: <n1402297469.42612@digipix.com>
Date: 30 Aug 1995 23:22:26 U
From: "Bart Cheever" <bcheever@digipix.com>
Subject: Geodesic Dome For Sale! (Na
To: "sfraves* " <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: "Cindy Kawakami" <cindy@organic.com>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-QM 3.0.2
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

By now everyone's heard about what happened at Narnia, the promoters had planned to use an 800 acre horse ranch in Ramona, which is in the hills about an hour north of San Diego.  They negotiated with someone who claimed to be rightful owner of the land, but later turned out to be a con artist.  Before anyone calls Global Underworld naive, keep in mind that they had applied for and been granted all the necessary permits from the city - the city is supposed to stringently check ownership before granting permits and even they didn't catch it.
Apparently, the main stage had already been set up and part of the land had been bulldozed in preparation for the event when the real owner of the property found out what was going on and stopped the event.

We had already purchased our plane tickets so we decided to go to SD for the weekend anyway.  On Saturday there was a really cool party that was on a mountain overlooking the desert.  You had to drive down this tiny dusty dirt road for about a half hour through cactuses and riverbeds before all the cars abruptly stopped in the middle of nowhere - you couldn't hear music or see anything, there was just a line of cars stretching upward as far as you could see.  We piled out and walked uphill past the line of parked cars for another 20 minutes before reaching the site - there were about 500 - 600 people in a clearing, dancing to Steve Pagan, DJ Knobby from Fat Cat, (a really great record store in London) and some new guy named Steve (?) from San Diego who was really good. Also one of my favorite dj's anywhere, Mark E. Quark, took the sunrise shift.  Pretty solid sound system too, it looked like they had 5 or 6 Jr. Earthquakes. After dancing awhile I walked down a ways from the site and chilled out with two good
 friends next to this giant rock outcropping - looking at the most incredible stars I've seen in years, millions and millions and millions of them. After a while the sun came up and you could see the Salton Sea and desert everywhere.
It started to get hot so we drove back to the ocean and went swimming. 
This event, because it was spontaneous and free and illegal, was a lot of things Narnia could not have been - props to Bill and Brian from Tribal Funk record store and everyone else who was involved in hooking it up.

The official word is that Narnia's been rescheduled for September 23rd.  We'll be there.  I'll pass on any more info as I get it.

From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9507318099.AA809906802@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, wshartle@eos.ncsu.edu
Subject: Simply Done Nutshell Review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Though I wasn't there the whole night/morning, I did want to check out 
     Jeno playing at DV8 since I was up in SF for a Burning Man meeting.  
     This is the second time I've been to Simply Done at this location and 
     for me, it leaves alot to be desired.
     
     Perhaps I'm just really picky, but I experienced the following.  (Note 
     that it's just _my_ perspective and perhaps it's just where I'm coming 
     from these days.)
     
     -  The high ceilings and the supporting posts seem to divide up the 
     view of the space as well as divide up the contributed "party" energy. 
      It's a good place for lurking, but for me, sometimes to get a party 
     going off, it helps to have everyone more aware of eachother.  This 
     space is not conducive to this.
     
     -  Per a 1015 promoter, the mgmt installed some new boosted bass 
     system or something of the sort.  (I'm real technical here!)  Before I 
     knew this, I thought the dj's were just plain old distorting the sound 
     by pumping the levels 'cause the sound was very muddy.  The highs and 
     lows were not distinct at all making it unexciting for me to dance to 
     (as I like to coordinate my moves w/an instrument, sound, or a 
     vocalist).  
     
     There were some nice things about it:  the visuals, lasers, and 
     lighting are not too bright so you don't feel so inhibited being a 
     voyer or dancer.  Jeno started putting out a nice mix and got people 
     moving harder; and John Howard wasn't bad if the sound was better.  
     And best of all, there's friends who always give good hugs.
     
     So that's my nutshell review.  Can't wait until I get to the desert 
     w/our sfrave rv contingent.  I think we're just one of at least seven 
     rv's that I know of. 
     
     Have a great Labor Day Weekend whatever you do!
     
     Diane

Right on!
TRISTAN.On Tue, 29 Aug 1995 Begroovy@aol.com wrote:

> Yes, it is quite possible to get into burning man for free? As Geoff stated
> it could also be quite costly and/or dangerous. The only people you will be
> scamming to get in for free are the others attending the party. BM is not
> produced by BGP or some other huge corporation. Most of the money goes to put
> this thing together. I went last year and was not hesitant to pay $35 again
> this year to attend, even knowing I could easily get in for free. I am paying
> the money because I have seen where it goes. These people put on an awesome
> experience and we should be lucky to only have to pay $35. If you are totally
> anti-capitalism and money, I'm sure you could get in touch with the BM people
> and work out some sort of deal. As, I, said this is not a huge corporation.
> These are real people with many progressive ideas. They would more than
> likely appreciate your anti- capitalistic ideals. The phone # is
> (415)985-7471. Have a great night/day, PEACE!!!!  CID
>

   The Burning Man Festival is the big story this weekend. It's a few
   hours north of Reno in Nevada's Black Rock Desert. The rave camp is
   supposed to be going full time this year. If you're staying here,
   you've got Kundalini, Basics, Spundae and Lumina...
   
                              THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

       Progressive house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415)
       281-3377.

       90.1 Stanford

       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Tuesday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9pm-midnight - Seth w/ambient-experimental,
       acid-trance-techno, industrial and trip-hop on KALX 90.7
       (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)

       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)

       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes 

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

I'm 5'6" with long brown hair (which will most likely be in a braid or

um, you know, not to sound mean or anything, but why do we need those 
east coast DJs here? i've been to maryland a few times, and the "ravers" 
there should be called lamers. to them, its not about the rave "scene" 
and getting along with one another...etc...but its about what fashon 
trend you are in, and if you dont dress like everyone else, or dance like 
everyone else, you get laughed at, and shuned. im sorry, but if the 
general poplulation at ravers there feel that way, then im sure the DJs 
are on the same tip, and my personal opinion is why have them here? let 
them stay there in their own concided(sp) world and think they are ravers.

of course, i could be totally off the wall about this idea, but its the 
way i felt things were out there.
